author: {'steamid': '76561198041110489', 'num_games_owned': 892, 'num_reviews': 298, 'playtime_forever': 3907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 254, 'playtime_at_review': 3816, 'last_played': 1710820296}
review:
63+ hours (100s more on DRM version) and roughly 13 YEARS LATER!  

And I FINALLY BEAT DREDMOR!!! 
Ill be honest I kind of cheese the win. Dredmor was behind bars and I pretty much unleashed all my fire spells on him and some laser wand attacks. Bit underwhelming but consider how the first moment I see him THE MOFO ONE SHOTS ME! Im level 24 and I get ONE SHOTTED!!!! HOW?!?!?!?

Anyways. I got this game from a body of mine back in college in 2011 and originally I didnt like it because I thought it was stupid and turn based RPG  with parody of everything was stupid also I was playing Skyrim at the time and didnt think anything else could compare. Little did I know over time I grew to love this game and now I want to try all sorts of builds. 

Also I had the non DRM version of this game on an old laptop that I lost the save file to and that one had more hours compared to my steam account.

This game. Oh my God this game. People have their First Rogue-like game. This one was mine and I am proud to say so. Ill come back to this game time and time again just to see how far I can get. I kind of wish there was a DoD 2 but honestly maybe not. I cant express how much I love the music that I even have it on my phone to play from time to time. Thats how good this is.

10/10 BEST ROGUE LIKE GAME EVER!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998784855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 11981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11981, 'last_played': 1708688622}
review:
[h1] [i]Dungeons of Dredmor[/i] belongs in a museum. [/h1]

As far as dungeon crawlers go, the game is fairly standard:  it's a little clunky, but reasonably balanced with 3 difficulty levels, a permadeath setting and a less-grindy setting to suit your interests.  You pick your skills to guess at a playstyle, you head off into the dungeon, you fight stuff and level up and get gear, and then (most likely) you die.  All you get out of that run is becoming more familiar with the game; there's no persistent/metagame progress.

Where DoD shines, and the reason why I say it belongs in a museum, is how it delivers just so many references through tasteful writing.  More specifically, it's delivering references from the 2000's and early 2010's.  [i]It's a time capsule,[/i] a snapshot of Internet culture and a glimpse into what everybody liked at the time.  From now-dead memes to now-forgotten movie quotes to now-unused cultural phrases like "Oh snap," DoD has it all.

Being a piece of cultural history, [i]Dungeons of Dredmor[/i] is worth picking up to witness.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971508249', 'num_games_owned': 633, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2072, 'last_played': 1708650845}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a game I love very, very much, but that unfortunately, I also hate very, very, very much as well. You'll notice there's a slight imbalance in the "very"s up there.

DoD is an unusual example of a true roguelike, with no cumulative research or buffs, no unlocks, no filter and absolutely no mercy. To start with you will choose from an oodle of "skills" to tack onto your character, from weapon specialization to more out there ones like "paranormal investigator" or "emomancy". Once your character is done, you will be unceremoniously dumped into the first floor of a dungeon, and your job will be to simply go around the place, get EXP and items, and try to make it to the end.

The dungeon floors are truly massive, and as you increase your level, you will be able to improve the skills you chose at the beginning, with a number of tiered upgrades that will unlock truly wild and bizarre spells and skills on those skills. I'm not sure it would be fair to say that they are all equal in power, but to my estimation, you could probably beat the game by specializing on any one of them. Since you cannot see the possible paths when choosing the profession itself, a lot of the intended game route goes by the player trying wild combinations of perks and seeing what professions work better with which ones, not only in a mechanical sense, but also because some of these professions will allow you to craft a gazillion items and gear that will work better or worse with the rest of them. You will also learn new recipes as you keep on adventuring, and once you hit your stride, this game will give you all the dungeon you can handle to keep improving and experimenting on your builds, for hours, and hours, and hours. Seriously, I literally spent like 6 straight hours into a run, and I only made it past floor 3, so neither content nor playtime is being called into question here. It is incredibly fun and satisfying to get a build going, and once you do, you will want nothing else than to experiment and explore for better loot, more skills, and what surprises await you deeper into the dungeon.

This  being said, however, and while having an absolute DREAM of a groundwork and basic game loop, I cannot honestly recommend the game due to the constant annoyances, dragged out pace, and general frustrations that at this point and 12 years after its release, I can only attribute to either the developers not caring, or thinking it'd be hilarious to be a dick to their players.

See, you'll pick up a ton of stuff in DoD. At [i]ton[/i]. And not just gear, but also resources that you should be able to use for crafting, if you pick one of those professions. The selection is absolutely insane, and you can not only build, but also "enchant" your gear using those professions to craft and experiment with. But for that, you will need to find the right ingredients, keep track of them, and use them at the right time. For one, inventory management is an absolute fucking nightmare that I cannot in good conscience wish on anyone. Your inventory space is pretty generous, and you'll even get a "pocket dimension" acting like some kind of vault you can put stuff in, but good luck managing all that in a timely manner without going crazy. Your pocket dimension will in no time start looking like a hoarder's basement, full of piles of items that you can't use 'cause you don't have the right profession, and "item management" comes down to, essentially, either spend ungodly amounts of time meticulously picking up and dropping down and going back and forth, or succumb to the siren call of "fuck it" and be expeditious but inefficient, point at which you'll eventually reach because you'll soon learn that nothing means anything and you'll end up dying anyway. You will always be missing that one reagent because you can't control or predict drops, and by the time you inevitably die, your pocket dimension will always look like a collection of unfinished dreams and time wasted.

Combat is... okay. It's not particularly pretty, but spells usually will hit their mark, and enemies are dumb as a doornail so they are relatively easy to kite and eventually take down once you settle into a groove. There's an insane amount of versatility in what you can do and how you can use what you have and what you find to your advantage, and the game will use a random name generator for named mobs and items, giving it a very fun, dwarf fortress-y flavor to the world. But as you forge on through the levels, what started like a fun succession of rooms and enemy groups will turn into Somme-levels of attritional, repetitive combat that will grind down your enthusiasm and creativity. By level 3, you will whittle down a room full of enemies, coming down to a sliver of your health, with your reward being a handful of reagents that you can't use 'cause you don't have the profession and another door to another room chock full of monsters that you will have to whittle down to a sliver of your health, with your reward being a handful of... you get the drift. Granted, this takes a few hours to settle in, but every room of every floor will become this ever increasing ramping up of pressure of more powerful and dangerous enemies, tight situations, asshole traps everywhere and the possibility of a new enemy or boss [i]juuust[/i] out of sight about to introduce you to its room clearing, absurd damage spell until again, you end up dying.

And in death comes oblivion.

Listen, I'm not against roguelikes. In fact, I consider the genre to contain some of the most intricate, clever and interesting designs in all of videogames. But I would lie if I said that spending 8 hours in a row playing a game, minutely organizing my inventory, planning out my builds and crafts despite the incredibly obtuse and barebones item management and trudging through combat that ends up feeling equal parts routine and horseshit only to die and have my character wiped and deleted from existence with absolutely nothing to show for it feels anything close to good. Moreso when the game crashes on death and doesn't even record your run in your high scores, but that's really beside the point: your time and effort means NOTHING. You don't get any unlocks, or an extra level for your next character, you don't get to pass down money, or items, you don't get second chances, or even a fucking chest for your pocket dimension.

This kick in the balls is what truly makes me not want to recommend this game to anyone. Not only you can die to a sometimes temperamental click detection, but even if you and the game work perfectly as intended an elite mob or a "monster zoo" that you will just stumble in with no prior knowledge can and will get you in an instant, and then it's fuck you, thank you for wasting 10 hours of your time. The game has this design dissonance between looking like it was designed for multiple, quick runs, but at the same time being absurdly long, arduous and frustrating to deal with without a reward mechanism that makes dumping a work week into it satisfying or worth your while. And there's a million little things that make it *juuust* that extra frustrating, such as dealing with the traps littered everywhere that you *will* step on while backtracking and exploring, forcing you to be slow and methodical, or having to drop your lockpicks if you want to save them for chests instead of doors because there isn't a quick way to choose what to use, or doors being a pain in the ass to close if you want to try and block a horde of monsters bearing down on you, or the item management in general, or not knowing what telepad connects with which, all of which will just grind its goodwill with you a little more, and a little more, until eventually you come out of playing this game feeling frustrated and robbed of your time, and look, I'm not a videogame PhD, but I will go ahead and say that this is not what a game should make you feel like.

5/10.

I am extremely unhappy, and I can't get more than a few hours in.

9.5/10, highly recommended for masochists.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039943190', 'num_games_owned': 366, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 56525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55823, 'last_played': 1708538436}
review: Ive played this game a lot. From when it first came out through all the expacs to now and I must say it is a good game, its a fun game, but its a frustrating game that somewhere  along the line decided to just become impossible on the highest difficulty. It doesnt matter how good you are, how much you have played, Going Rogue, the highest difficulty has been adjusted to impossible standards. Its been far too long since I played last but I dont remember the game actively scaling even level 1 content on going rogue to the levels of, you need X skills to survive even one monster. Going  rogue severely limits any and all possible combinations down to a handful. Its sad to see such an awesome game become just a frustrating mess. its still a great game,  and its super fun on Dwarvish Moderation but trying to do Going Rogue is just an exercise is futility and just not fun,

author: {'steamid': '76561197974465543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 2951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2348, 'last_played': 1705631837}
review:
Very likely the greatest *traditional* roguelike ever made. This is a definite buy for fans of the genre, but modern-roguelike newcomers may be put off by the amount of depth and nuance.

I've played this game for 40+ hours and each time I open it, I still feel like its the first time I've ever played. It does lean on the dense side (even though it might not look it) so be prepared for a very thinky- and somewhat of a slow burn- experience. However, Dungeons of Dredmor makes up for that with non-stop, incredibly well written humorous dialog and quirky interactions. Even in the midst of that quirkiness, this is such a solidly well-built rogue experience, it never feels unfair or cheap.

It's a shame the devs are no longer working on games like this as it desperately needs a sequel, even though it's hardly necessary as there is so much content here (especially with the DLC) you could play this for a good long time and still see new things.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960783864', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1705207006}
review:
So before I begin let me warn everyone to play in windowed mode. Using full screen mode causes mouse acceleration or jumping, not sure which, but neither is good.

[list]
[*]Movement is very slow and disjointed. If you click on a door from a distance you'll walk up to it instead of opening it. That takes another click once you arrive. The same goes for combat.
[*]Vision is constantly obscured, the camera is just a bit too close.
[*]The belt bar and action bar are very small and hard to make out. The same goes for text in general on any given window.
[*]When in combat you must wait for the enemy turn. This can have you waiting several seconds depending on how many enemies are on screen.
[*]I'm not sure the cartooney art style matches the theme. Character and enemy art seems inconsistent with the scenery and items.
[*]Extreme abundance of seemingly random items, filling your inventory with random garbage. [*]You must place this random garbage in your inventory manually, even if what you have could stack on something else.
[/list]

I think perhaps the developer didn't really refine or streamline anything. A victim of constant addition and no subtraction when appropriate. I wandered around several floors of dungeon picking up everything in sight, aimless. I didn't come across anything interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967437326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1705339515}
review:
A delightful, turn-based dungeon crawl with peak 2010's humor. Not too cringe, either! Kind of like Munchkin in that way.

The build variety is a hoot and you will die a lot, but it has a great gameplay loop and plenty of charm. Was gifted the base game and after an hour I went to by all the DLC without hesitation. 

I do wish there was some progression between runs, but that said it's close adherence to the roguelike nature adds a special something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025744135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1675470836}
review:
I really can't understand how this one got a review score so high. If you've never played a roguelike it may be a good intro, otherwise a lot of things will frustrate you. Movement speed is horribly slow which makes backtracking (necessary in this kind of game) a real pain in the ass. Not a fan of the art style and the art direction is inconsistent. Crafting is also really frustrating, it's a good idea but poorly implemented : most recipes are useless and you will rarely find an interesting one for the right character.
All in all, I would advise to find other roguelikes : Tales of Maj'Eyal, Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup, Jupiter Hell, Caves of Qud ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198014925488', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8003, 'last_played': 1703226991}
review: Played this game since 2011, and *finally* got a win on normal mode 12-13 years later. This game got me into Roguelikes and I still appreciate its humor. This is the kind of game I think is rather hard to do well at without wikiwalking, and I for one appreciate that many forum posts from 2014 are still relevant for its strategy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198235848300', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9071, 'last_played': 1707799484}
review:
Do you Like Tongue-in-cheek Humor? Do you like Crawling around dungeons? do you like experimenting with tons of different builds? then HOOOO BOY do i got a game to sell ya! This Dungeon has them all and even some great modded content to try! ever wanted to be a dual sword wielding burglar assassin called Stabatha? wanna be a shielded dagger wielding astrologist named gingy? you'd be surprised how little damage you'll take like that.

Need something you can just pick up and faff about for a few hours? this will do that my friend. great for if you're out and just want something to play on your laptop

review: Over ten years on, this is still a solid true roguelike that really exemplifies jumping in with a random build and 'just one more run'. Hilarious writing and silly characters will make you smile even after being exploded again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961324577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1562, 'last_played': 1703352428}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029194710', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2606, 'last_played': 1605936130}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor (as an RPG:) 

Has an exclusivity as both a gaming experience & latch-elements that some could supply as being 'off-beat'. However, as this is the first and only legacy title of it's type---- 
the 'hit and miss' style, including humour of it's own originality is owned by it's self. This style, takes a breathe of the 'creation process' and decision making branch that really holds the subject together.  But also fails to deliver upon the connectionary themes to which a first time player would be or feel suitable in trying to attempt to ignore. review: Holy cow what an annoying inventory management system! I'm not wholly sure why, but for some reason this one didn't grab me. I'm going to keep playing every so often with the hope this changes... For now, I guess I give it a thumbs up because it's not bad per se, but I don't feel there's anything here to really charm enthusiasts for roguelikes more vast and rich like CDDA or ToME nor more simplistic and elegant like Rogue Fable. Recommended for people new to the genre only as a lightweight entry point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005062450', 'num_games_owned': 966, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1698521812}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980243623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1266, 'last_played': 1698440829}
review:
Fun Roguelike, but I cannot recommend it until they fix the crashing that's been in the game since 2013 that also corrupts your saves.

The game is playable, but at literally any time, your game could try and save, only to crash and corrupt/deletes your save-file, losing you hours upon hours of progress.

--Edit--
While my save wasn't recovered, I still really appreciate the dev for at least trying.
They said they were working on it, so hopefully we'll see a fix soon?

As I said originally, it's a good game, definitely a lot of fun to be had, but it's hard to recommend when you could lose hours of progress so easily.
developer_response:
Hey there!

If you could zip up your entire savefile directory and send it to contact@gaslampgames.com we'd be interested in potentially fixing that for you.

(There's a chance we can't. But also there's a chance we can!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032901764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5430, 'last_played': 1698880139}
review: D of D is such a fun and wacky little game, and addictive: Beat your own high score, die, begin angain. Not a very deep game but the Monty Pythonesque humour makes op for it. It can get pretty grindy, I mean, you basically f*** about in a procedurally generated dungeon, kill monsters and loot stuff, and as you delve deeper, it gets harder - and that's it. But the game features a neat skill-system, where in the beginning, when you create your character (well, create... you chose some skills, name your character and assign a gender), you can pick, or randomly get, seven different skills which you can mix & match as you please. This makes dying fun, because it is fun to try different combos. You can go permadeath or not and there are three difficulty levels. As I mentioned, it can get grindy. When you get the hang of it, you can get far in the dungeon pretty easy. But if you are like me, eventually you'll make a stupid mistake and die - and you'll have had enough of dungeons and Diggles for a while. Then, some grey and rainy autumn Tuesday, you remember that weird and funny game, and once again you don the traffic cone and rusty sword and go on a killing spree to fight evil. Dungeons of Dredmor is a game for you if you occationally enjoy a light-weight game that is not too serious and gets your character killed a lot. It is not for you if you are looking for an RPG with a deep story or Souls-like game with a crazy complicated battle system to master.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004486906', 'num_games_owned': 496, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4796, 'last_played': 1697503893}
review: Dredmor is an excellent roguelike. Some stats, behaviors and items are unclear but become understood over the course of play, much like the original rogue or nethack. The humor here is really good and the various skills you have are excellent, each with its own flavor and suprising uniqueness. The nature of the skill system, random generation etc. have also made dredmor a robustly modded game with many, many skill mods, dialgoue mods etc. I heavily recommend Dredmor to anyone who likes roguelikes or top down rpgs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075421471', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 2959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2959, 'last_played': 1635734496}
review:
This game holds a special place for me as my first proper Rogue Like (RL). After playing the Binding of Isaac, I checked out this game and was absolutely blown away by all of the RL trappings; procedural generation, extreme build diversity and freedom, unforgiving difficulty, permadeath, and an insane amount of content stuffed into a single-run format.

I can recommend it as a good entry point to RLs simply because it has graphics, mouse support, and some seriously goofy and consistent humor. A great dungeon crawler with super fun build variety.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083093749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 11338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10263, 'last_played': 1703050743}
review:
Kickstarted my rogue-like addiction and is still the best introduction to the traditional rogue genre, there's a easy mode, you can turn off permadeath, and even shrink floors if you have a life, unlike me! 

the game is not all sunshine and rainbows, if you are playing a hard mode run with permadeath the game can crash and break  after a long run, and that is a major problem.

overall this game's gameplay and mechanics work great, the flavor text is funny, the enemys are creative and bring things to the table that the game needs, the items are creative and can even do things that the game does not even tell you (wish they fixed this) and the music is great. 

highly recommend.

review: Dungeons of Dredmor is in my eyes one of the best dungeon crawls out there. From satisfying visuals, near-endless skill combinations, replayablility, complex yet random dungeons, the crisp soundtrack and witty humor to so much more, this game is truly perfect to me. You can really tell that Gaslamp Games poured their heart and soul into this creation, and that it's a genuine labor of love. It holds up with flying colors, even with being from 2011 and with so many other similar games on the market now. 10/10.

review: this is one of the first games i ever bought on steam, i got it for something like 3 dollars because i had enough left after buying terraria and portal with a steam wallet card. i havent played insane hours, but every time i dip my toes back in i thoroughly enjoy my time. its a rogue-like in the purest sense: turn based tile grid combat and movement, randomized level based dungeon crawling, permadeath, and zero meta progression. the stats are seemingly overcomplicated and jokingly unconventional on purpose as a joke and the systems take a while to wrap your head around, but damn is it just a goofy and relaxing game to play

review: Наиграв 25 часов на одном сейве, с вероятностью в ~0,7%, Пр***ал 4 зачарования подряд, решил засейвскамить, вышел без сохранения, игра удалила сейв [spoiler] (предупредив об этом 2 раза, а я не поверил) [/spoiler], за***сь. Рекомендую!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122306721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1686840495}
review:
誰もが一度は見たことがあると思う、2011年リリースの名作ローグライク。迷ってるなら買え。

スタート時にスキルを選ぶ方式で、そこである程度ビルドが決まります。どういうキャラを作るにせよトラップを感知できるスキルがあるとゲームが快適。あとは好みの武器、魔法、クラフトをひとつずつもっておくといいのでは。

ダイアゴナルムーヴ（斜め移動）なしの簡単操作で、斜め方向には近接攻撃も届かないので1 対 1の状況を作りやすいです。スキル制のゲームとはいえ、ToME4ほどバフの貼り直しで忙しくなく、黙々とモンスターを叩いて経験値を貯める作業ができます。サイドクエスト、クラフト、モンスターハウス、店など、ローグライクで考えられる要素は一通り出てくるので、とにかくやることがたくさん。

ゲームスピードをキーボードの-=で調整できます。これが１段階速くするだけでもめちゃくちゃ速い。10年前のゲームとは思えないほど快適で、後発のローグライクはなぜこれを真似しないのかと思う。

UIを拡大してもまだ文字が小さいのだけ残念。

author: {'steamid': '76561198020403264', 'num_games_owned': 4365, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 26983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26839, 'last_played': 1684750903}
review:
A wonderful very classic Roguelike, with a humorous overtone.

The pixel graphics and unique artstyle create a great atmosphere of pure adventure throughout the dungeon, each with a unique tileset and monsters, for the most part at least. It has a status showing character portrait. Loads of beautiful item sprites.
The music, instead of being per floor, which would get on the nerves very fast, especially the early levels, choose instead to just cycle thru all its normal level music. An elegant solution that more games could adopt. Of course, some events or special rooms get their own music. And the music is all download-to-listen-all-the-time worthy. Even if some compositions remind me bit too much of some specific tracks from Chrono Trigger and Final Fantasy. 
The sound effects are competent, but the "narration" get misunderstood sometimes.

Story is minimal, but the atmosphere the game creates with every little thing it does is unparalleled. EVERY equipment, enemy, skill, consumable and even a lot of stage elements have it's own description. Almost always overflowing with humor. It's the crux of the game, and what glues all of it together. It has a lot of different styles, from references of it's time, like monsters quoting portal 2, and older music, movies etc, to environmental and just jokes and gags. You'll most probably find your preferred humor here.

Now, for the gameplay. It's a classic roguelike, which means grid based, you-move-everyone-moves type of games, with a different dungeon each run. You have a lot of information to contend to. Stats are influenced be your skills and equipment, each stat does something important, and you'll want to specialize in one or two different builds, which are basically Martial, Wizard or Rogue like (heh). For equipment you have a lot of weapons to choose from, daggers, swords, staves, etc. 
You have a lot of character slots: Hat, Body, Pants, Shoes, necklace, 2 rings and a crossbow. Each item can be enchanted for more damage of a certain type, resistance of said damage type (there are more than a dozen of damage types), or other stats.  
You have other consumable items like food for HP regeneration (over time usually, not instant recovery), alcoholic drinks for mana regeneration (if you drink too much you'll get drunk debuffs), mushrooms that have crazy effects, Potions and wands that do all sorts of things. You can, of course, craft them and a lot more, like weapons, armor and bolts for your crossbow. 
You also have traps to avoid, or disarm and even use them against your opponents.
For skills you choose 7 at character creation. They determine starting stats and equipment, you can mix and match as you like. Each time you level up you simply choose the next level of one of your chosen skills, no independent stat allocation.
It's an immensely complex game that will take a lot of your time, and may require a wiki to play. I haven't even scratch the surface here. Play and you'll understand.
The game has DLC, that adds more of everything, even dungeon floors and new mechanics, very much worth it. Like the main game is. Also, it has a good amount of mods in and out of the workshop. Won't go hungry playing this game (except for all the cheese you see here all the time that will leave you wanting some gouda or something...).

Difficulty, as expected, is pretty high, but surprisingly customizable. You can set permadeath on or off, and choose 3 difficulty levels. Don't expect easy to be a cakewalk, though, especially on your learning phase.

In a normal playthrough you'll start, die a monster. Restart, die to a trap. Restart, die to a monsterhouse. Restart, etc etc. Fun that don't end. For the completion, you'll earn a number of your achievements as you play normally, but some are also good as learning tools, as there are some for completing a skill paths, leading you to try out new builds. The finish-the-game-in-a-difficulty ones are very much doable, even the permadeth ones. There are a couple of achievements that are actually, literally impossible to obtain normally, one for a removed skill, one for having to meet the devs in person, but you can mod them in from the workshop. (Or used to be, I can't find them on the list anymore, they might have just removed them.)

In conclusion, this gem of a game is a must play for any classic roguelike fan. This game deserves much more praise and recognition for the amount of passion and work the devs poured into it. 
Buy the complete package and dive in for hundreds of hours like I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007343154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 448, 'playtime_forever': 3482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3482, 'last_played': 1373699495}
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994108981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 12747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12746, 'last_played': 1681080153}
review:
This is a polished and fun rougelike straight dungeon crawler that is very well done. The most unique element of this one is probably the character building system - you pick a variety of pieces - a weapon class, magic school, crafting type, or something weird and wacky - and combine 7 of them into your starting character, and then level up one of your abilities each time you level up. This results in a crazy high amount of replayability, because not only will you see new things in the dungeon, but you can try out all sorts of new strategies with your character builds. (Hundreds of) hours of fun.

Highly recommend if you enjoy games like Faster than Light, Rogue Legacy, or really any of the roguelike genre, or if you enjoy games with a focus on character building, like Pathfinder, D&D, Pillars of Eternity, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045657317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 8692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4923, 'last_played': 1705495424}
review:
It's hard to write a review for a game that was mostly thrown into backyard of gaming and developer is defunct and it's community mostly fall off. But i will try. 
DoD aside from some technical unsolved flaws and no longer-supported program life-line is still good game. If you a novice for "rouge-like" genre - Dungeons of Dredmor is good way to start. If you find Caves of Qud , ADOM  and canonical original Rouge too rough or not-so-graphicall-pretty - DoD can give you some taste. It's a good solid game with nice mechanics suitable for all Rougelikes big and small. Quite nice graphics and a load of builds can give you some nice time in dungeon crawling as long as you can witstand smell of quite dank and moldy jokes, some classic culture references and load of dank and bit moldy puns. It's quite humororus in it's own way but aside from humor-esque names and events it's pretty nice experience. In pros - a good starter game for rouge-likers (haha Pun intended) , pretty load of rpg stuff and loot, decent level of difficulty, in cons - obsolete game-code that can and will crash time to time, some mods are defucnt and no longer working and some achievments are unreachable, yet i really recommend it for some nice hours. It may make you to love rougelikes or abandon em forever because of loads of humor and puns all around. (Jk) . So total Yes to this bit abandoned game that feel like thing brought on some garage sale - some holes, some rust yet it still can be loved and played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035252335', 'num_games_owned': 1756, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5522, 'last_played': 1672109708}
review:
The gameplay in Dungeons of Dredmor is top-notch, with deep character customization and a wide range of skills and abilities to master. The randomly generated levels ensure that no two playthroughs are ever the same, keeping the experience fresh and exciting. The turn-based combat system is easy to learn but difficult to master, and the game's punishing difficulty will keep even the most seasoned roguelike veterans on their toes.

In terms of market expectations, Dungeons of Dredmor doesn't have the name recognition of some of the bigger players in the genre, but it has a dedicated following of fans who appreciate its unique blend of humor and challenge.

There's no multiplayer in Dungeons of Dredmor, but the single-player experience is more than enough to keep players engaged. The game's narrative is largely delivered through item descriptions and flavor text, but the world is so richly detailed that it's easy to get lost in the lore.

The graphics in Dungeons of Dredmor are simple but effective, with colorful pixel art that perfectly captures the game's whimsical tone. The audio design is similarly charming, with a catchy soundtrack and hilarious sound effects.

In terms of technical performance, Dungeons of Dredmor runs smoothly and is relatively bug-free, although there are occasional issues with crashing or freezing.

In terms of value, Dungeons of Dredmor is an absolute steal. It's a feature-rich game with a ton of replayability, and it's priced to move.

Overall, Dungeons of Dredmor is a fantastic example of what a roguelike dungeon-crawler should be. With its deep gameplay mechanics, quirky sense of humor, and punishing difficulty, it's a game that will keep players coming back for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028558172', 'num_games_owned': 1044, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 3846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3846, 'last_played': 1679176131}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor, one of the early indie games released on steam. Took me more than 10 years and several runs to finally defeat the last boss and give a full review.

So let's start out with positives. This is a turn based, roguelike RPG game that has optional permadeath mode on. I'll talk about permadeath later but what you should know is the game has randomly generated dungeons. For some of you this might be negative but for me, I like randomly generated dungeons because they bring replay value, meaning every run you do in this game is different. The starting skills are the only skills available to you, so pick them wisely although there is a downside to them and I'll explain later, for now you should know that the positives are infinite replay value and tons of choices in building your character. The weapons and armor are also randomly generated which as I said means every run will be different run.

The game is quite long, took me around 15 hours to beat my last run so you will be playing this game for quite a long time. In addition there are also bonus dungeons which you can go through and acquire more loot if needed.

Crafting in this game is excellent, the materials are abundant and you can always find new recipes in the bookshelves

Oh and the music is excellent. It is limited though, for a game this long you would need a lot more soundtracks but they are really good.

One also thing to note, this game has a lot of humor based either from the 80s or 90s gaming, although it has a fair share of memes that used to be popular back in 2011, so some jokes you might find cringe. 

The combat is simple and it's quite satisfying when you get new equipment or spells and see how enemies get destroyed on your path.

Now for the negatives. This game likes to recycle enemies and dungeon designs a lot, but that's only a minor complaint. Even bigger negative is that as one user noted, there is a bug where auto saves cause the game to crash and sometimes even corrupt the saves. Developer Gaslamp Games went defunct in 2017 so don't expect them to fix this game, just keep that in mind. I did come up to this bug 2 times but I managed to recover my saves (somehow).

The second biggest negative is the permadeath. Normally permadeath isn't a problem in roguelike games like Binding of Isaac or Slay the Spire, but here is the thing: Those games have short sessions of gameplay, they are designed to have permadeath because each session of the game lasts for a short time. Dungeons of Dreadmor is not the type of game where permadeath fits, because as I said this game is long, really long. How would you like if you went halfway through the game, opened a door, find a monster zoo event (that's the room where every single square is filled with a monster) and right at the start there are 2 elites who 2 shot you, and your run is gone. If this game had maybe like 3 floors permadeath run, that would be fine but 10/15 floors with permadeath on? Unless you have a patience of a buddhist monk, it's not fun, at all.

The probably biggest complain is the last boss. Now when you pick skills at the start, you think to yourself you are gonna pick a melee class and bash the boss in the head right? Well no because not only the boss has ranged but he also has a very nasty melee damage that can 3 shot you even with the best armor and the armor skill maxed. So you think that you are gonna be a wizard and cast spells at him? Well no, because he is extremely resistant to spells and it will take hours of casting before you kill him. The only way to kill him is with ranged. That kind of sucks, and the last boss is the only thing that doesn't change in your entire run. He is always gonna be mage with stupidly high damage.

So is dungeons of dredmor worth your time. For 3.99$ if you keep in mind of the autosave crash, yes, although do note, it is an old game with some outdated mechanics and if you want a better roguelike games, then you should probably pick Binding of Isaac. With all the negatives, it comes out as an okay roguelike game, I'll put thumbs up just because of the extremely low price, but don't get your hopes that this is something unforgettable. In fact, only 4% of players beat the last boss.

review:
If you're like me, you'll be put off my the art style of this game. I hate to come off mean but it definitely has an amateur look and that almost held me back from trying it. But, thankfully that doesn't really matter too much once you get going. It turns out to be an interesting dungeon crawler once you get used to the different classes and skills and stuff.
I don't know what else to say except that if you like this type of game, you will like this game. If you find the art style off-putting, screw it just buy it and you'll get used to it eventually. It's a really great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015326061', 'num_games_owned': 1962, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 11447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11437, 'last_played': 1676829674}
review:
[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] A great beginner-friendly traditional roguelike, with a quirky aesthetic/humor and rich character customization. It has its fair share of issues--it doesn't explain finer mechanics well, crashes are not uncommon, and random loss of save data can rarely happen--but if you can look past the scuff (and remember to back up your saves), you might find it becoming one of your favorite games like I did.

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Dungeons of Dredmor[/i] harkens back to the early days of the roguelike genre: exploring a dreary dungeon, turn-based gameplay, grid-based movement, procedural map generation, and permanent death. It isn't all derivitive, however, as it sets itself apart thanks to a unique aesthetic, quirky humor, and a really neat approach to character customziation. I will say right up front: this is arguably one of my favorite games ever, but my recommendation comes with a few asterisks--it's a fun game, but it has some glaring flaws that you should be made aware of before buying it.

Before I get into that, though, I want to talk about the positives, starting with how [b]the game offers a lot of possibilities for character customization[/b]. For one, there are a ton of different stats: you have 6 "primary stats" that translate to your classic STR/INT/DEX/CON/CHA/LUK; as well as 19 "secondary stats" influenced by your primary stats and/or equipment, which includes everything from attack power, crit/counter/dodge chances, defenses, crafting ranks, and more. It's a little hard to wrap your head around at first, but you can eventually use it to create some very unconventional characters, like someone built entirely around counter chance who has to survive by never getting hit. My favorite part of the customization process, though, is the class system--or rather the lack of one. Rather than picking a traditional class like warrior or mage, your abilities are determined by selecting from a list of Skills--a grand total of 51 between the base game and all DLC, of which you get to pick 7 for each run. These range from the mundane like Swords, Archery, or Alchemy, to the badass or utterly bizarre like Viking Wizardry, Battle Geology, Archaeology, and even Communist. These Skills can radically change the way you play, and discovering which ones compliment each other is the key to reaching the end of the game.

[b]Traditional roguelikes are known for being difficult, but [i]Dredmor[/i] is surprisingly beginner-friendly[/b] with simple controls, different difficulty settings, and the ability to disable permadeath. It's easy to pick up, but the difficulty still stems from trying to beat it. Even on the lowest difficulty, your first runs will have you die fast and often in ways that might feel unfair--and in some cases, they kinda will be. Your character at low levels is fragile regardless of your build, the tutorial doesn't cover everything you'll encounter, and there are a handful of beginner traps to watch out for ([spoiler]red portal good, blue portal bad[/spoiler]). Rest assured that the feeling of unfairness will largely go away once you learn how things work. Having spent almost 200 hours playing as of writing this, rarely does a death happen now that I feel was the result of poor RNG. Most of my deaths tend to happen because I get impatient or careless, rushing into rooms without looking for traps or getting into fights without checking my health bar first. [b]My advice is to play without permadeath in your first playthrough(s) so you're not punished as harshly for experimenting, then turn it on once you get more comfortable with the mechanics[/b]. After a while, you can get decently far with many different character builds; but actually beating the game is another story. It does something that made me give up on games like [i]FTL[/i], where [b]the final boss introduces a sudden difficulty spike[/b] that will immediately end your run if you don't know what you're getting into. Unlike [i]FTL[/i], however, I don't think it's quite as reliant on RNG to win as there are multiple Skills that can guarantee a more level playing field (e.g. [spoiler]Magical Law's "Gag Order" ability[/spoiler]); though it still won't be a cakewalk.

Each of the dungeon's 10 floors (15 with DLC) has its own enemies, randomly-generated rooms, and even cosmetic tileset to try and give you a real sense of progression during your run. That being said, there's not as much variation as you might like: "enemy variety" often means palette swaps of older enemies, and the actual number of different rooms on a given floor is low enough that you'll exhaust the total amount to be found there after just a couple visits. All of this is to say that [b]the lack of overall dungeon variety between runs can make the game feel repetitive after a while--but that's where the modding scene comes in[/b]. The Steam Workshop has an assortment of mods offering new Skills, items, rooms, and more in case you're bored of the base game; and the amount of content that can be found in some of these can even rival that of the official DLC (you can find some of my favorites [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2915043168]here[/url]). Fair warning: some mods (even on Steam) are old and no longer work, and any modding carries the risk of corrupting/deleting save files; so follow any listed installation instructions carefully and make manual backups of your save files (C:\Users\<YourUserName>\Documents\Gaslamp Games\Dungeons of Dredmor\).

On a related note, it's time to get into those issues I mentioned at the start, because [b]this game is heavily flawed--if not outright broken--in multiple ways[/b]. The first is that [b]it often fails to properly teach the player[/b]: the tutorial glosses over a lot of the finer mechanics (the most egregious example being crafting), the in-game descriptions for abilities are usually unhelpful and require a wiki to figure out what exactly they do, and there's even a character stat (magic reflection) that doesn't appear on your character sheet for no good reason. All of this can be resolved through continued play or community support, but what can't be resolved this way is [b]the litany of technical problems that plague an otherwise good game[/b]: some abilities have incorrect descriptions and warrant editing XML files to fix (e.g. Magic Training's "Extra-planar Concentration", whose -5 stat debuff was actually -50 in practice), you'll experience sudden freezing and lag spikes on even the most high-end machine, certain actions (e.g. completing a quest) can randomly crash the program (which happened 3 times while replaying for this review), and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/boobina/recommended/98800/]the built-in autosave feature can crash the game or even corrupt your save file in rare cases[/url]. Gaslamp Games dissolved some time around 2017, and the developers have all gone their separate ways in the years since; so unless someone buys up the rights to the game in the future, problems like these will never be fixed. I don't mention all of this to deter you from buying the game, but I want to make sure you know what to expect before picking it up.

It's not perfect by any stretch of the imagination, but something about it has kept me coming back time and time again since I first played it over eight years ago. It's addicting in a way that few games manage to be for me, and even losing hours of progress to some stupid mistake does little to deter me from getting back up and trying again. [b][u]Despite some serious flaws, and despite occupying a genre I rarely have the patience for these days, [i]Dungeons of Dredmor's[/i] quirkiness, rich customization, and replayability have cemented it as one of my favorite games of all time.[/u][/b]

[quote]For more game reviews, check out my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42524563/]Curator page[/url]![/quote]

review: I probably wouldn’t play this on my PC; it’s been in my library for ages and I haven’t played it much. However, I decided to try it on my Steam Deck and man, am I glad I did. It plays like a dream on the Deck and is currently one of my fave Deck dungeon crawlers. With a large variety of enemies and items, a lot of humour, and a reasonably complex crafting system, I recommend anyone with a Deck get this immediately!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993866756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3089, 'last_played': 1692669144}
review:
At 6 dollars, or 3 as of this writing due to a sale, this game is a friggn' steal.

Dungeons of Dredmor has an attitude, and it's silly, but not in a "scream in your face" kind of way. Even though the game is extremely tongue in cheek, it's a very well designed and accommodating rogue game. Fans of hack and slash should really enjoy this one. Even though it's a turn-based game, it's very fluid, and the game speed can be adjusted on the fly.

The experience is somewhat typical of a rogue-like: lots of items, enemy types, objects, traps, character classes, crafting, and secrets. What's not so typical? You fight creatures like bee people named Bee Arthur, turn your items into lutefisk using a lutefisk cube to be given to a lutefisk god statue to receive a buff, have the ability to choose a communist + capitalist class combination, and drink mother-effing PILSNER to restore your MP. I wouldn't exactly call the humor subtle in this game, but it also isn't rubbed in your face too much either, so if you don't like it, it doesn't affect the gameplay too much.

As a small note, this game does not use Steam DRM, so you can back up the game and run it without Steam if you'd like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137511598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 102049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101976, 'last_played': 1678376766}
review: This is a Role-playing Dungeon-Crawler, with fifteen levels of dungeons. The character-selection is unusual, having options to play as a Communist, A Kemetic Wizard, a Vampire, a Diggle and many, many more. This last is a creature peculiar to Dredmor's Dungeon. There is also the capability of fabricating artefacts, potions and wands from items found in the dungeon. Although the game-play is simple and rather slow, it makes up for this by the humour displayed in every aspect of the game. It's not for everybody, but i love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039844830', 'num_games_owned': 845, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1669844890}
review:
I honestly love this game, I’ve clocked only about 12 hrs casually in this game but it was well worth it and memorable.

I did the casual mode where you can save and load and it’s almost more fun than most ARPGs on the market. 

The skills are wacky but intuitive, surprising but viable.

You wouldn’t expect “tourist” to be a skill tree, or a ghost hunter.

For hardcore rogueLIKE fans, it’s fun, it won’t replace TOmE or CDDA.

The elephant in the room is it’s old and most forums are dead, I’m sure you could find a community somewhere but it’s non existent. Folks do talk about the game though.

Buy it, play it, love it.
No rule 34 tho :/

review:
A pretty interesting roguelike with a diverse class/skill system that can be combined freely, offering unlimited replay value.

On my last run I created the most powerful emo, vegan, communist, egyptian warlock (yes, these are actual skill trees) then I died by kicking a door and hurting my feet.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198040728689', 'num_games_owned': 706, 'num_reviews': 288, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1668618761}
review:
Brilliant Roguelike dungeon crawler. 

You are presented with many different options for builds. You become a wizard, warrior, and even brew your own potions and craft items. 

The humor is great. The music is definitely background music and hardly noticeable. The graphics are pretty decent considering this is a 2d game.

I'm two and a half hours in and have barely scratched the surface of the second level.

You will be able to easily put in 80+ hours.

8.3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198018246949', 'num_games_owned': 1965, 'num_reviews': 1200, 'playtime_forever': 3379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3379, 'last_played': 1344150000}
review: Simply brilliant game, unfortunately plagued by an auto-save issue that can corrupt your save file. If you implement the workaround to turn that off, it's more than worth your time. If like me, you didn't know about that until it was too late...

author: {'steamid': '76561198111593510', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 1800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1755, 'last_played': 1699257670}
review:
Это игра не без проблем, да. Даже один рейд сложно пройти, да. У неё очень много но, верно. Но, всё-таки игр с ещё более крутым билдостроением и разнообразием ещё поискать надо.

Графика и дизайн (7/10)
Графика в рогаликах не главное - это уже давно доказано сотней других примеров. Собственно, и DoD здесь нельзя назвать выдающимся. Спрайтов тут великое множество, есть свой некий уникальный стиль, пусть он зайдёт не всем (особенно хорошо выглядят арты), да и главный герой легко запоминается за счёт своих шикарных бровей. Кроме того, прекрасно (но не всегда) работают визуальные ожидания - если ты видишь легендарный меч в камне - наверняка у него будет максимальная редкость. А если ты видишь невнятную редиску - то с лёгкостью его убьёшь.
Но есть и проблемы. Так, игра очень злоупотребляет банальным перекрашиванием мобов. Мне кажется, что как минимум каждый из них встречается в 4-5 цветах, но технически - это разные монстры. Аналогичная ситуация с уровнями - их здесь 15 штук, но отличаются они в первую очередь полом и стенами, а типы помещений остаются теми же самыми. Кроме того, интерфейс у игры не самый дружелюбный - много мелкого текста и маленьких окошек.
В целом, графика пусть и поднадоедает, но зато она приятная, понятная и даже битвы тут выглядят вполне красиво за счёт множества разных спецэффектов.

Звук и музыка (7/10)
В общем и целом - звуковое сопровождение приятное. Мелодии не напряжные. Открывающая тема по-настоящему героическая. А при открытии карнавала монстров начинается вполне подходящая музыка. То же самое касается и озвучки. Пусть сам герой не говорит, но некий загадочный голос постоянно уведомляет о малом хп и мане, что очень полезно. Да и многие монстры и абилки имеют уникальные звуки. Вот только всё это рано или поздно приедается.

Геймплей (7/10)
Во многих играх геймплей - это главное. И для рогаликов - тем более. Вот только у Dungeon of Dredmor есть с этим некоторые проблемы. И главная из них - продолжительность игры. Всего игра состоит из 10/15 этажей. Казалось бы, это мелочь, есть рогалики, где они ещё длиннее. Вот только прохождение одного этажа полностью занимает минимум час времени, а то и больше. Из-за этого многое в игре очень сильно приедается, даже несмотря на разнообразие. И, более того, это сильно усложняет прохождение игры. А ведь исследовать этажи надо - без опыта не прокачаешь все ветки.
Но, с этим вы столкнётесь позже. А вот начало игры сразу же показывает то, насколько она разнообразна. При создании игрок волен выбрать 7 деревьев навыков из более чем 70 различных деревьев. И какие же это навыки! Помимо банальщины, вроде владения мечами или пиромантии, тут есть и Матемагия, Археология, Стимпанковство (!?), и даже Коммунизм! Я так играл за Амбидекстера-мечника-латника, владеющего псионикой, ковкой плоти, пиромантией и магией крови. А ведь в каждом дереве минимум шесть умений. Представьте, какие открываются перспективы для билдостроения. А ведь тут ещё есть крафт, алхимия и другие механики.
Различных параметров у персонажа так же более чем достаточно. Куча видов элементарного урона, много различных переменных, которые меняются при прокачке и от снаряжения (причём, не всегда в хорошую сторону). Правда следить за всем этим не обязательно - главное помнить правило "Чем больше - тем лучше".
Различной снаряги и вещей тут так же огромное количество и практически все они имеют шуточки в описании. Будь то легендарный меч в камне, шляпа Алукарда, или книга "Король в Желтом". И даже бесполезная броня для лошади.
Сама по-себе игра довольно обычная. Ходим, убиваем монстров, ищем снарягу. По началу игра довольно лёгкая (если не играть на харде). Враги убиваются быстро, наносят мало урона и проблем могут доставить только карнавалы (большие комнаты с 50-300 монстрами за раз). Но чем дальше вы идёте, тем...неожиданнее может показать себя ваш билд! Ибо баланс - не про эту игру. И это весело - сложно предсказать, насколько играбельным у вас выйдет класс. Мой последний персонаж забил босса Дредмора как нефиг делать, но его могла вынести тройка рыбо-паладинов из-за уязвимости к свету. Как и любой другой рогалик, игра не будет брать вас за ручку и разъяснять, что и как делать. Всё придётся тестировать весёлым опытным путём. И, честно говоря, это делать веселее, чем пытаться полностью пройти игру.

Сюжет и Лор (7/10)
Сюжета здесь почти нет. Есть злой некромант Лорд Дредмор. Вы должны его убить. По-факту, это всё. Почему же тогда 7 из 10? За отсылки и описательные тексты. Благодаря им мы можем очень много узнать о мире игры, а так же насладиться бесконечным количеством отсылок. Они везде. В достижениях, в описаниях, в речах, в визуале, в обучении. Давно я не встречал игры, которую можно описать одним предложением, но при этом с настолько цельным миром.

DLC, Дополнения, Бонусы (9/10)
Тут есть почти всё, что нужно. Два дополнения с навыками, дополнительными этажами, лутом и плюшками? Есть. Возможность полистать арты? Есть. Есть энциклопедия со всем найденным лутом и монстрами. Жаль только, что у монстров нельзя прочесть описания и нет счётчика того, сколько процентов открыто.

Баги, Фичи, Оптимизация (9/10)
Пару раз случались неприятные вылеты, что сильно плохо из-за того, что тут нет ручного сохранения. Оптимизация не требуется, ибо игра пойдёт на чём угодно. Из фич - вас могут забросить в место, из которого не получится выбраться или можно убить себя по неосторожности.

Итог
Dungeons of Dredmor - это та игра, в которую весело играть, но не весело проходить. Строить билды, изучать деревья навыков, однако 15 (и даже 10) этажей по 1-2 часа каждый - перебор. В иделае, здесь бы хорошо смотрелась вторая часть - с доработанными подземельями и возможностью менять навыки. Однако, любителям рогаликов и билдостроения я эту игру всё-таки советую. Даже без прохождения она может принести удовольствие.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053089197', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1610, 'last_played': 1667912080}

author: {'steamid': '76561198078887697', 'num_games_owned': 1796, 'num_reviews': 645, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1466030427}
review:
Ultimately I found this a little obtuse to play more than a few hours. This is probably exactly what traditional roguelike players want, but that crowd is also smaller than ever in 2022.

Once I was finished playing, I watched a speedrun of the game to see how it's played at the highest level. There are strategies employed that would have taken dozens of hours to come up with on my own, but this isn't the caliber of game I'm interested in sinking dozens of hours into.

10+ years later, the roguelike genre is so more thoroughly developed I think Dungeons of Dredmor is too niche of a product to recommend to anyone... except the kind of players who aren't getting their recommendations from the steam reviews section.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146918903', 'num_games_owned': 532, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1854, 'last_played': 1706766945}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011369934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 10822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10822, 'last_played': 1658723721}
review:
I've had this one for a while and thorough enjoyed it.  

I love the flexibility of the character design system which makes replaying with a new character so interesting.  Graphics weren't great, but I can live with that.  There is virtually no story to speak of, which is also okay.  This is a game to play if you want to experiment with character builds while pushing deeper and deeper into the dungeon.

I loved it..so here's to hoping for Dungeons of Dredmor 2.

review: Despite this game's age relative to other rogue-likes and dungeon crawlers that have come out in recent years, Dungeons of Dredmor still holds up as a light-hearted and enjoyable games that is easy to pick up in the evening after a long day. This game rarely ever gets frustrating, but you can make it as easy or as hard as you would like it to be. It is endlessly replayable, especially if you are someone who loves to experiment with unconventional builds.

review: The game was interesting for the first hour, then it became repetitive and nothing to offer. There is around 15 monsters, and they are recolored, professions are really sad and hard to use for some reason. Spells don't give any description on what they do when you start the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068118575', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2370, 'last_played': 1670406313}
review:
This is a really cool, modern variant of Rogue/Nethack/Angband etc. It's sad the company went out of business after the main dev and owner decided to work for Nvidia instead. Because this is a very well polished and well made game which will, sadly, never get a sequel.

Dungeons of Dredmor is not only for those of us who liked playing the old games I listed above, it's a great introduction to the REAL Rogue style games for everyone. To those who don't know, Rogue-style games used to be a real style of games, and not just a label/tag they slap onto every game which has any sort of randomized variables/levels/characters each playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993762417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1584, 'last_played': 1661119824}
review: Awesome roguelike with good graphics, fun pop references, lots of humors and huge HUGE amount of content, especially like the huge number of specializations (you can chose up to 7 skills) and items. Nothing ground breaking on the gameplay, hard but not too punishing if you don't enable permadeath, it is a standard roguelike (old school) with modernized bits but it works. Only meh things are those very random monsters spawning such as evil clones which are... way overpowered... there is also balance issues i guess, i started with a ranged (crossbow) / dagger combination but this is harder than regular warriors (maybe the initial specializations were the issues ?), there is still issues with ammo if you are not lucky (and it will require wandering for a good amount of time if you didn't mark the ammo vendors) so i don't recommend starting with a ranged class, it is not really fun. Lack of inventory space may be an issue but the pocket dimension is easily accessible so it is okay, for ranged however... it is tedious to manage because you may have to hold your ammos. I didn't like having to remember the portal spells (from wall tags) also for one the extension. There is minor UI / accessibility issues (elements too close to each other) and few bugs such as ennemies spawning in inaccessible areas, nothing game breaking though but still meh. It is still a very fun and featured game that i enjoyed pretty much, it does not require huge amount of times due to the "less grind" mode which shrink the dungeons and make it fast to progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972188950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 9458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2427, 'last_played': 1706814684}
review: This light-hearted roaguelike holds up well today, years after Dungeons of Dreadmor was released. It's a lot of fun, and there are a variety of different builds and play styles available. It's pretty standard dungeon crawling fare for the most part, but it has a nice crafting system. My main complaint is that there isn't a lot of variety in the way that enemies feel, even as the game progresses. But, in general, this game is really solid and a lot of fun for a quick laugh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042882896', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1659833404}
review: LUTFISK FOR THE LUTFISK GOD, SMOKED FISH FOR THE LOX THRONE!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027708057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 6747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6747, 'last_played': 1654054203}
review:
I like Rogue Likes.   I also Like NOT taking them very seriously.
But then keep in mind, this is somebody who gleefully explored the "Tourist" skill path.   
If you like the idea of a character wearing flashy clothes, taking pictures of everything (Subsequently blinding them with the flash) and then proceeding to beat the monsters to death with a large bone obviously stolen from a museum display somewhere, even the slightest bit amusing... You have a good idea how silly this game can become.
Never beaten it, because it's hard.  But it's the kind of hard that makes you laugh your ass off when you're annihilated by a random acid spewing trap for the fiftieth time.   
If you are in the mood for chaos at its most FUN, play this.   You will get to know patterns, but every once in a while, it'll still surprise you with something right out of left field.    (Usually a softball to the head.   Which are present in the game.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993265691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 22337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 499, 'playtime_at_review': 18688, 'last_played': 1710559459}

review: DoD is, to me, an all-timer. The combat is simple, but addicting. And nothing is quite as satisfying as your stats slowly climbing ever higher. One of the best old school rogue-like dungeon crawls ever. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198061859631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 6671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6039, 'last_played': 1695883517}
review: There's so much I could say about this game, but I'll keep it simple. I've played tons and tons of roguelikes and lites over the years. Way too many to count, it's probably the genre I've played the most. This game has some jank, it has some bugs, instability, and some rough edges... and is probably one of my favorite games of all time. There may be a few rogues I revisit over the years, but none so often as Dungeons of Dredmor. It's weird, the style is unique, and it doesn't take itself seriously in any way. Under that is an insanely customizable, fun game mechanically. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072429429', 'num_games_owned': 758, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 9377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8975, 'last_played': 1708063063}
review:
One of the few dungeon crawlin' roguelikes that I actually enjoy.  It's got a load of wacky humor, is easy to get into, has a lot of class-variety, and a horrible crafting system. 

The UI's more than a bit dated, but if you can look past that then this is a great roguelike to pick up.  The developers have long since gone bankrupt so future updates or a sequel are a no-go unless someone else tracks down and obtains the rights to it - which I really hope happens someday.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051261898', 'num_games_owned': 870, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 3031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1467, 'last_played': 1693021276}
review:
>Finally having my first good run
>Make it to floor 10
>"Who's this funny looking fellow? Is he part of a sidequest?"
>It's Lord Dredmor
>Wait, THE Lord Dredmor?
>Okay but how hard can he be
>Oh he's really strong, let's make a tactical retreat
>He smites me with lightning and kills me in 2 hits
9/10 Would wear a traffic cone as a helmet again
In all seriousness, there's obviously a lot of love (and memes) put into this game . It's engrossing, addictive, and funny. It has good enemy design, a variety of great skill trees, fun combat, heroic vandalism...I'll edit this review when I finally beat THE Lord Dredmor. You funny looking fellow, you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019284331', 'num_games_owned': 1377, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 9685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5736, 'last_played': 1674888957}
review:
Já vou deixar logo de cara o motivo pelo qual você vai amar ou odiar Dungeons of Dredmor: esse é um verdadeiro [i]roguelike[/i], onde quando você morre não leva absolutamente nada para sua próxima [i]run[/i] a não ser o conhecimento que vai adquirindo conforme for jogando mais vezes.
Como eu gosto do estilo, adorei esse jogo. Além do mais, tem uma variedade imensa de itens e habilidades. Não sei se alguma vez eu vi uma árvore de habilidades tão grande quanto essa aqui, com possiblidades de ser um Vegano ou um Comunista, entre muitas outra opções. 
E aí entra outro ponto que faz Dredmor tão charmoso e viciante: é muito bem escrito! Todos os itens/habilidades/inimigos e a ambientação do jogo tem descrições muito legais e bem humoradas. O detalhe é que só tem em inglês, o que pode ser um ponto decisivo.
Outra complicação inerente ao gênero é que o jogo é muito difícil. Tem a possibilidade de jogar sem [i]permadeath[/i], o que dá uma aliviada, mas fora isso é ir jogando e aprendendo quais habilidades e itens são melhores na base da tentativa e erro.
A dificuldade é bem cruel quando você chega no último inimigo, o Lord Dredmor. Ele funciona de um jeito diferente do que o resto do jogo todo e tem atributos muito altos, ou seja, é provável que você morra algumas vezes antes de conseguir fazer uma [i]build[/i] capaz de derrotá-lo.
A parte artística do jogo é maravilhosa! Além do texto que eu já elogiei acima, o design dos personagens, inimigos e todas as artes de forma geral são muito bonitas e estilosas. A música é outro ponto muito alto, bem variada e de muito boa qualidade.
Mas no fim das contas, voltamos ao ponto inicial: é um [i]roguelike[/i]. Se você não gosta do estilo, não vai gostar desse jogo, não tem muito o que fazer. Mas pra quem curte o estilo, não tem muito erro, Dungeons of Dredmor é um dos melhores que já joguei!

review:
Just how many games have cheese for healing items (among others of course, but still mostly cheese) and booze for mana recovery? This is one of the few games I giggle about when describing it for friends gathered to have a drink - assuming they're even slightly interested of the genre.

110 some hours in, I frequently return to this game to have few runs, because to me its one of the best in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038658887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 16804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3580, 'last_played': 1707522946}
review: Great game if you like traditional roguelikes. I have beaten DCSS several times, TOME on hardest difficulty, Caves of Qud, but I haven't beat this one.. yet. It's forsure a traditional roguelike(no diagonal movement), but more accessible kinda. It doesnt make you use the keybindings that some truer roguelikes do but it's still the same at the heart of it and very addictive once you get past the learning curve. It's still as brutal as the rogues that I have mentioned, just with a bit less of learning curve.. imo. Just jump in and try everything, you'll get it eventually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068234161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1703312021}

author: {'steamid': '76561198150905041', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 4919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1386, 'last_played': 1693885140}
review:
It's very possible Dungeons of Dredmor is the most traditional rogue-like I've ever seen and I mean this in the best way possible. This game is very accessible with multiple difficulties and even an optional perma-death mode.

I have yet to beat DoD because I play on the hardest difficulty with perma-death. This makes the game tough as hell, but also tenfold more rewarding and addictive. I rarely die due to something I had no control over, be it my carelessness around traps or simply going too far too quickly.

Selecting skill trees at the character select ensures every run will be as diverse as you want.
Did I mention this game has mod support? Because there are some fantastic mods out there that add EVEN MORE content. Seriously if the screenshots look even remotely appealing to you, do yourself a favor and BUY IT.

I would happily pay $20 for this game and the fact that it's only $5 means you have no excuse.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967459353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 1562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1535, 'last_played': 1696980732}
review:
This is a pretty dang good roguelike. For one thing, it's super crunchy. There are 47 skills to choose from, of which you chose a loadout of 7. Each rank of each skill does something different, from raising stats to giving you abilities, both passive and active. Also, there are 24, count em, 24 stats that all do different things.

What really puts it over the edge, however, is the humor. The game is downright hilarious. Every item and enemy has a humorous description, and the items themselves are amusing. For example, there are skills like Viking Wizardry and Communism, and your early games items are stuff like using a traffic cone for a hat or cutoff jeans. 

The game is dirt cheap, even when not on sale. Grab it, you won't be disppointed.
