author: {'steamid': '76561197995731610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8971, 'last_played': 1649797556}
review:
If I had to describe this game in a word, that word would be "Tedious".

Dungeons of Dredmor technically does everything correct. It has all the basic parts that make up a classic roguelike dungeon crawler: Permadeath, a huge HUGE dungeon, a variety of enemies, neat weapons and armor, and a ton of flavorful consumables. On top of that, it's got a lot of cheeky cute humor, and probably the most notable feature of all: The "classless" character builder. You choose a loadout of 7 skills to define your character, rather than simply picking "Wizard" or "Fighter" at the character select screen.

These are all really cool things, and when the game first came out I loved it. But I'm replaying now, and just realizing that all the little complaints add up until this game is just difficult to deal with.

What's so tedious about it? Here's a few things:
*Your inventory is essentially unlimited thanks to the 'storage dimension' they give you, but your actual in-game backpack is TINY, so you'll spend more time sorting items out in your storage dimension than actually playing the game. If you take any of the crafting skills, it gets worse... I mean there are 14 types of ingots alone, without getting into the potion items, and random junk like wires and springs. 11 types of CHEESE. Your inventory fills up in seconds.
*There's no way to split item stacks, except to alt-click one item out of a stack at a time. If you need to pick up 500 of a resource so you can drop it on an altar, be prepared to spend about 4 minutes clicking.
*Enemies and items can spawn inside of statues, walls, and inaccessible areas. This can make some treasures impossible to collect and some quests impossible to complete. No quests are mandatory, but it is still annoying. On top of that, items and abilities that do 'knockback' on enemies will frequently knock them through walls or doors, into places you can't see.
*There are SO many elemental types in the game that combat just gets flooded and messy. It's hard to keep track of what resistances you should worry about when every attack looks like this: "You hit the diggle for 27 slashing, 4 crushing, 7 piercing, 6 freezing, 3 burning, 4 lightning, 3 aetherial, 6 corrosive, 4 temporal, 1 suffocation, 2 putrification, 5 necromantic, 3 righteous, and 14 blasting damage." It's an absolute mess and just serves to make the combat log too flooded to read.
*The amount of backtracking you'll do to re-visit old shops and stuff is insane, and travel is slow, since you have many frames of animation with every step you take. There's no fast/auto-travel option like most roguelikes to save you from the mediocrity of spending 10 minutes holding down the walk button to visit a previous level shop that has an item you need.

Despite having released multiple expansion packs, problems that have existed since day 1 of release are still present and will clearly never be fixed since there's no real development on the game anymore. And there are so many problems, most a lot less obnoxious than the ones I've listed, but it just kind of goes to show that there was a lack of either developer skill or time spent on polish.

Anyway, Dungeons of Dredmor is a great example of how "more" doesn't mean "better". There's so many skills and items and elemental damage types to choose from but it just ends up making everything feel messy instead of interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965551723', 'num_games_owned': 2014, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1474, 'last_played': 1600193385}

author: {'steamid': '76561198127149725', 'num_games_owned': 28, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1684269481}
review:
I have around 300 hours playing this game on an old account. That being said, I bought it again.

This game is witty as heck and I want to die kicking a door for blissful eternity.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969587017', 'num_games_owned': 1378, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1648698508}
review:
A fun graphical rogue-like in the pure and classic sense. Full point and click mouse controls make this a breeze to pick up and play. It contains ridiculous skills for class building that often seem designed more for humor than practicality, but if you're playing this game you're definitely here for the jokes in the writing. Elevated language and pokes at the genre are ever present. I like the art style as I think it fits the tone very well, though your mileage may vary.

At this time, it doesn't play nice with the Steam Deck. The music is butchered, and playing it on mute loses some charm. I was using a mouse in Gaming Mode hooked up to a monitor and the cursor occasionally skipped around the screen, making unpredictable jumps. That's absolutely a deal breaker in a point and click based interface.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081656935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 12742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12021, 'last_played': 1696329103}

review:

如果有想要汉化补丁的玩家，这个其乐社区的帖子里有。

author: {'steamid': '76561198084053324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1968, 'last_played': 1653906582}
review:
I'd recommend this as a one of the (contemporary) classic roguelike for someone to get into the subgenre. Saying this even after almost ten years and despite it being largely stagnant in terms of development (no sequel, developer news). Adding that now we're at a time when there's sooo many bigger roguelike games to choose from and roguelikes are no longer niche.

I'm reviewing it now because I surprised myself by ending picking this up and playing it again recently. Pushing several hours once more into it. I had so many other roguelikes to choose from that haven't been even tried or some that are my usual go-tos.

And of course, its quirky humour.

The bugs it has here and there that I found are bearable. 

Edit: typo, add line(s)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028484650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 4420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3391, 'last_played': 1644462123}
review:
A "roguelike" in the truest sense of the word, this game is basically a remake of Rogue, or Nethack. It is mechanically deep and very funny, and very replayable. It's also pretty hard if you're not cautious! 

I think it's telling that the only negative reviews for it are for compatibility problems. Give it a shot, and if it doesn't work on your machine, just refund it. You've got nothing to lose! Highly recommend, great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006288889', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1888, 'last_played': 1642132074}
review:
It's a roguelike that tempers the frustration with an insane sense of humor.  In the 9 Years i've had this game, i come back to it for a few days at a time and get a LOT of runs in in that time (i'm not very good at it, but i do enjoy it).

Lots of skill combinations to keep things fresh.  Side quests, crafting, enchantment and curses, zoos, so many things to keep the game fresh and different with each run.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016046767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1614, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1641834136}
review: It's more like a parody of the rogue like genre but absolutely nails it. From the humor to the game's mechanics everything about it seems solid. Tons of ways to customize your character and some ridiculous outcomes. Great variety of enemies to slay and loot to collect. If you enjoy this kind of gaming you will definitely love this one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045500061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 3570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3570, 'last_played': 1640823875}
review:
The game has a lot of great things going for it. Good humor and references, nice gather and craft system and countless builds to play around with. I really enjoyed messing around and seeing how far I could get. 

That was until I wanted to beat it. 

I played on easy and had a rather straight forward run. I was a melee build and tanked up as much as I could. I has the occasional difficult situation(all from monster Zoos) But for the most part it was easy. Then I found dredmor. With two spells he killed me. I had nearly full max star equipment, I was level 24 I had several potion buffs on. 
It felt like I had missed something, like several floors or something. 
Nope.
That's just how it is. 
My mistake I was playing on Iron man mode. I figured since its easy That will add some spice, bad move.
I choose that the dungeons be shorter which still took way too much inventory management, dozens of trips in and out of the dimensional space, constant crafting and about six hours of work just to get to him.  

It happened so quickly I am sure that even if I wasn't playing on Iron man, there was no way I could have beaten him. I checked steam discussion and there are ways to beat him, but its recommended not to play melee, to known he is weak to piercing and holy or have some way to escape and heal.

Now the holy I get but honestly I never like to look up wiki's on game, at what point am I really gonna look at the last boss of the game and not use my melee skill which up until this point has carried me, and instead go get a crossbow? 

I read that several people have beaten him with dozens of different builds, and hats off to those people, good job, but that's not for me.

I enjoyed the game until I saw just how much of a gap there is between the final boss and the rest of the game. If you don't have a broken build, or read the wiki, its probably not going to happen. I am not even mad, I am just done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045036485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 459, 'playtime_forever': 2126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2126, 'last_played': 1513406928}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976933541', 'num_games_owned': 165, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1648915915}
review: A seemingly basic RPG but don't let this fool you. This is a very nice roguelike in -- what feels like -- the true indie spirit. Skills and items offer many variations. The game is easy to learn, but offers plenty of freshness through procedural generation and the amount of combinations that are possible. This game was probably ahead of its time and I suspect that it deserves more attention, even nowadays.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983869611', 'num_games_owned': 1643, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 1411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1640672799}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor es, con toda seguridad, uno de los primeros juegos que recomendaría a cualquier persona que quisiera dar sus primeros pasos dentro de un género tan hermético como el de los 'roguelike'. El motivo es que, pese a ser un juego profundo y lleno de matices, también es muy accesible. No hace falta memorizar una veintena de atajos de teclado ni tener una mano en el teclado numérico y la otra en la fila de efes, sino que se puede jugar únicamente con el ratón. Y aunque como es habitual el género, la dificultad es elevada, sí es cierto que es algo más permisivo que la mayoría de sus hermanos en lo que a penalizar los errores con la muerte se refiere. El resultado es un 'roguelike' para todos los públicos, al que ocasionalmente me gusta volver a jugar. Buena prueba de ello es que, según acabo de comprobar, tengo logros sacados en 2011, 2013 y 2017.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047988603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 5348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3874, 'last_played': 1663039300}
review:
It's a classic that still holds up for any Roguelike lover.  The quirky references will make you smile, the customization and crafting will you keep you thinking (a fairly large list of skills and classes), and the combat will surprise you when you inevitably question what finally killed you and how.  

That said, it's lacking a lot of features if you actually care about what's happening on your screen.  I really really wished the character's appearance changed with the armor and abilities he/she gains.  The enemies, plot, and powers either teeter on completely generic or jokey-reference.  There's no in between.  And while I know no one plays a rogue game for the plot, ... I like plot and there's none here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044511522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1637360082}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998598944', 'num_games_owned': 2056, 'num_reviews': 1144, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1636496592}
review:
So this is an "OG" Steam Roguelike and came well before the hundreds of Roguelikes on  Steam.  Still playing this in 2021 I  have two gripes.

My first gripe is in an attempt to be funny, this game has a lot of silly humor text instead of actually telling me what an ability does.  Things like "you are an archaeologist!" instead of "you find traps easier."  This is funny, but frustrating when you are trying to create a character.

My second gripe is you don't get better with every run.  When you die you simply start over again.  In other Roguelikes you build on your progress (more health, more damage, whatever) and it really makes every run feel impactful.  In this game I'm as weak as I was when I played this game in 2011.  That's a real shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970054631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 31952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26902, 'last_played': 1657429516}
review:
Oldie (in 2021) but Goodie.   Still come back to DoD occassionally.  A Turn-based Tile-based hack-slashin' lock-pickin' dungeon crawlin' with a challenging final enemy & near infinate replayability & humor.   Tons of items, character statistics, and skill builds.   Whats more to like!

Never had a technical problem such as a crash to desktop.

Some may find the graphics primitive and inventory management excessive.
Allows some cheesy tactics like zoning to recover & AoE through doors to burn down enemies.

review: My playtime hours is probably the time it took to develop this game . But honestly, I can't express how lucky I am that out of all the years mankind has lived, I live in the era of 21st century where I can play this game. I honestly believe every dead person out there who never played Dungeons of Dredmor must come back to life for some time and play this game. They can die again if they want. But every single human being should definitely try this. I genuinely think that the person behind the development of this game absolutely should be the richest person of the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067288891', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 13033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10936, 'last_played': 1700696669}
review: This game has a lot of good memories for me. It was my first ever game on steam. And it was also a gift from a dear friend who introduced me to Steam. They gave it to me as a birthday present back in 2012. Almost 10 years ago now. Sure, it has it's quirks, but I love it. It's charming and so much fun. I've recently gotten back into playing, and I've added some mods to make it more interesting. I would recommend you to back up save files, as sometimes they can become corrupted. While I find that challenging, it also gives me the chance to start over and figure out a new plan of action. I had about 100 hours invested when I lost my save. Devastating for sure, but it's been a few years now, and I just can't help but come back to my first game. You never forget your first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044571814', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 4169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4169, 'last_played': 1629193085}
review:
Obscure, dated, and full of quite a lot of anger. Absolutely fantastic turn-based dungeon crawler, with a hyper-focus on witty humour (if puns are witty to you), very dated references for a decade-old game, and insane amounts of semi-cryptic wording for skills, item descriptions, and tooltips.

Cryptic is a valid criticism and description of this game, because it expects you to play the game with a lot of trial-and-error, and if you aren't familiar with these kinds of roguelikes or RPG's, the game can be overwhelming. 

I'm not entirely certain how to recommend the game because it's a genre I am so inexperienced with, but it's so much fun to play around with on occasion. It took 69 hours (nice) to finally beat the game on the normal difficulty, with the final successful run taking around 13 hours to complete while going at trickle pace. 

100% worth it for the price if you want a classic dungeon crawler that doesn't take anything seriously. If english is not your primary language, the verbatim and metaphors used in this game can be difficult to understand. Play with a guide, or go in blind, the single digit price is generous even on the tightest of budgets, and is worth getting the complete edition with the DLC for an extra 2$. This game can run on the lowest end pc's available on the market.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991021948', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2045, 'last_played': 1629433953}

review: Hru jsem si kdysi pořídil jen z důvodu, že mi zrovna klekla grafická karta a na tohle stačí integrovaná, hodně Steam achievementů to je fajn, ale to je tak všechno..

author: {'steamid': '76561198001027647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8400, 'last_played': 1629240218}
review:
I finished this game after 140 hours of play.  It was enjoyable, but I have a few recommendations.

1] Don't buy the expansions.  The game is long enough as it is.  Getting the expansions drags out an otherwise long period of play.

2] If you get the expansions, DO NOT pray to any of the Diggle Gods.  The one I worshiped really hit me with some severe bad side effects.

3] I played on the moderate (Dwarf) condition which does not have perma-death.  If you don't play permadeath then a portion of your game is collecting enough stuff to defeat Lord Dredmor in the final battle on level 10 (without expansions) or level 15 (with expansions).  The key to defeating Dredmor is to horde all of the invisibility potions/items you can.  Then horde the best throwing devices/arrows possible.  Clobber Dredmor.  When you get low on health, go invisible.  Heal up.  Clobber Dredmor.  Rinse/repeat.

4] Before the last level collect up all armor and items that you can that reflect spells.  That limits Dredmor's damage.

5] I played as a straight warrior and maxed out Archery.  Weirdly, throwing items were more deadly than arrows.  If I played again I would take
Potions - to make invisibility/regeneration/healing items.
Throwing - it must work better than archery for a warrior type
Smithing - to make great stuff
One weapon type - probably swords or maces not sure which is better
Armor
Shield
Either Magical Law or Tinker for the last pick.

Anyway, the final battle was not that hard but I had so much invisibility/healing stuff that Dredmor never came that close to killing me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052391171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 25889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17832, 'last_played': 1692218996}
review: Look, there is nothing else to say. This is the best Rogue-alike (in the purest set of the word) game available under Steam for the PC and whatever else consoles it has been released for. The core game was already an almost perfect balance of skills and enemy abilities that really required you to think before rushing moves, the 2-D tile graphics are a joy to look at, and while the monster selection might be lacking, in skills everything is perfect in what a character needs as they grow from novice farmboy to worldly avatar of a God.  You simply cannot miss this game if you are playing with your brain engaged, and if you want to play on total autopilot and just watch your avatar absolutely wreck some ass, you can easily do that too. Enjoy!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005555352', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2289, 'last_played': 1628902616}
review:
Charmy, smarmy, and crashy as all hell, you'll enjoy it for hours up until your save file corrupts and/or you get ejected back to the desktop before ever seeing the depths of the game. The mods for the game work neither in tandem with each other nor alone, which is all well and fine because neither the base game nor the mods tell you how any of them work.

There's a very good reason that very nearly half of the playerbase has the achievement granted for crashing the game.

Avoid.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983448037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9750, 'last_played': 1706051875}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a classic roguelike in the same vein as the original Rogue from 1980, with modern sensibilities, a point and click interface and a dash of humour thrown in for good measure.

Seasoned veterans of the genre will appreciate the high quality of presentation and myriad of references to older titles, and newbies to this type of Roguelike will find that Dredmor is a much more manageable and user friendly challenge than many others in the trad-roguelike catalogue.

Dredmor differs from the norm in that there is no diagonal attacking in it, and as a whole the challenge tends to randomly spike much less than in games like Tales of Maj'Eyal or Dungeon Crawl. I would strongly recommend it as a title for people who bounced off stuff like ADOM or Nethack and want a way to get acquainted with the genre.

So how does it play? Your task is to descend the 10 (or 15 with the DLC) floors of the titular dungeon and dispatch the eponymous Dredmor who lies in wait on the lowest floor. You begin by selecting 7 out of a possible 52 skill trees that will define the way your character progresses, and you are unceremoniously dumped at the entrance of the dungeon after a short text box summarising your quest.

From there you explore each floor of the dungeon, leveling up, avoiding traps, and gaining new loot to equip your character. One of the strongest features Dredmor has is the skill system in the game, featuring jobs ranging from Big Game Hunter to Vampire, from Astrologist to Demonologist. There are professions in here you won't find in any other RPG, such as Paranormal Investigators who can transform Potions into different potions and discover crafting recipes by autopsying the bodies of monsters, or Magical Law, which lets you use the power of litigation to reset your cooldowns and silence monsters. If you're someone who just enjoys coming up with fun builds you will love the skill trees on offer here.

Once you get used to the fact that none of the stats are called what they should be called (Strength is Burliness, Spell Crit is Haywire Chance, Dexterity is Nimbleness) and once you get to grips with the 16(!) different damage types in the game which range from the usual Fire and Frost to Existential Damage (Existential damage: does it exist or not? We don't know, but your weapon may inflict it on somebody... if they exist.), the stat system in Dredmor is actually pretty fun and exploitable.

In most RPGs, stats like Armour and Dodge Rating suffer from diminishing returns as you stack them up to prevent players from becoming unkillable gods. Not so in Dungeons of Dredmor. For a lot of stats what you see on your character see translates one-to-one with your actual statstics, so if you see 100 Block on there, you block every hit. It's possible to get characters dual wielding mirror shields for 100% spell reflect, stacking encrusts (the enchant system in the game) to be immune to certain types of damage, or abusing cooldowns to parry every melee strike. It's a lot of fun.

The game isn't perfect by any means though, and there are a few problems with it. First of all the game has a crashing issue for some people that won't be fixed by the devs and isn't moddable. Secondly, the inventory management in the game quickly becomes a big part of it after you hit about Floor 4-5. There are vast array of random pickups in Dredmor, most of which you won't initially know what to use, which all supplements a complicated crafting system. There are far too many items in the game which only have one specific use for one specific profession, and it takes a lot of game play to recognise what's important to keep and what you can sell. In addition to this some of the aspects of the game feel a little half baked, for example the Dredmor fight. When you encounter him there is no change of music, no special throne room he inhabits, he is just randomly pathing around the dungeon doing nothing in particular. He's just chillin'.


You would like this game if:
a.) You like thinking up different character builds and trying them out
b.) You want a way in to the traditional roguelike genre that's user friendly
c.) You appreciate a sense of humour in your games
d.) You like really exploitable games
You won't like it if:
a.) You hate inventory management and crafting
b.) You are a roguelike purist who baulks at the thought of no diagonal attacking

I'd give Dungeons of Dredmor an 8/10, I've got a ton of fun out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967223692', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 223, 'playtime_forever': 9678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9678, 'last_played': 1524617099}
review: Probably one of my favorite rogue-like games ever. It has a fantastic atmosphere, is always super funny, and every time I come back to play it I get even more of the jokes. There are so many different skill sets, items, crafting recipes, and more, that I have never been bored with a play-through. It is just the right amount of 'tough-but-fair', and 'if-you-are-stupid-you-will-die'. Some things can get a bit repetitive, like some of the enemy types and the music, but over all I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes rogue-like/light games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064850410', 'num_games_owned': 770, 'num_reviews': 373, 'playtime_forever': 4747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2406, 'last_played': 1665106650}
review:
[h3]Rogue-ish endeavors abound![/h3]
[b]Dungeons of Dredmor[/b] is a satirical dungeon crawling “traditional” roguelike. For the uninitiated, “[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1443430/Rogue/]Rogue[/url]” is an actual game from 1980 and the term roguelike was coined to describe games that were... like it. However, in more recent times it's come to surface that not all games described as such were actually that similar to Rogue. Hence the phrase “Traditional Roguelike” becoming more prominent. Of course, there are other variants now in the 'roguelite' sub-category that involve some sort of meta-progression to the runs.

That said, [b]Traditional Roguelike[/b] refers to the game being run-based, procedurally generated, grid/turn-based while featuring permadeath. The overall goal of Dungeons of Dredmor is to reach the final floor and kill Lord Dredmor themselves.

However, the one aspect where I would venture to say that Dungeons of Dredmor was different is that Dredmor only allows movement and combat to take place within the four cardinal directions. Whereas Rogue (or other more modern “traditional roguelikes” like Caves of Qud or Tales of Maj'Eyal) allow it to be done diagonally as well. [I believe older Civ games operated using the numberpad for unit movement as well, for instances where you'd want to move diagonally in 1 turn), Dredmor does allow limited interaction diagonally, but not movement or combat. You'll use WASD in conjunction with the mouse. You are able to pick up items and perform actions like disarming traps from adjacent and diagonal tiles, however.

The style of humor it uses is having off-theme sorts of gags, there's even a Mass Effect reference in one of the achievements. Other "gags" involve things like wearing traffic cones as armor or using baseballs as weapons. Not your standard medieval-castle sort of affair.

[h3]Gameplay — discretion is the better part of valor.[/h3]
A lot of mechanics are not obvious. However, the game is not aggressively obtuse either. I found that there's [i]just[/i] enough mystery in discovering new items, mechanics and enemies on the next level to keep you interested while remaining strait forward enough such that you don't really need to think all that much. So it fills the proverbial “podcast” game role quite well whilst retaining a considerable amount of depth.

[b]To give an idea as to what to expect:[/b]
[i](I would consider some of these [u]mechanical spoilers[/u], so don't read this section if discovery is your gambit.)[/i][list]
[*] There are more subtle things you learn as you go. For instance, while you cannot always tell what traps are arrow slit traps, (unless you take the tinkering perk) the arrow always comes form the top of the screen so you could trigger it and do damage to an enemy above you.

[*] Food and drink takes a number of turns to digest and replenish HP/Mana. Potions are instant. Eating food gives you a “well fed” status effect that slowly heals you over time depending on the food. Clicking the “digest” button allows you to fast forward those turns.

[*] Unfortunately, armor does not change character appearance. Weapons do, however.

[*] Portable (or stationary) crafting stations allow you to, for instance grind old meat or cheese into ingredients that can be further crafted into [i]better[/i] food for more sustenance, refilling more health. There is a general rule of thumb I noticed in that food restores health and drinks restore magic. Some things are written clearly within the [i]flavor[/i] text. However, many are not.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2528582239

[*] Kicking locked doors repeatedly has potential to hurt you. Finding lockpicks and successfully using them rewards XP. Additionally, bashing open locked containers can break what's inside. So using lockpicks is also helpful in this regard.

[*] Weapons like wands are not considered a primary weapon, they'll need to be placed into the active slot and used like magic or throwable items. Similar to how different types of arrows are used.

[*] Inventory space can be limited, but you can find a 'pocket dimension' that can be accessed anywhere that's restricted by cooldown. It acts as a tertiary inventory to your hotbar and bag.

[*] The UI can be pretty small and hard to read, however each element has a tiny square on it that you can click to increase its size.

[*] Sidequests can be obtained and completed mid-dungeon for extra XP.[/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2528582214

[h3]Technical problems:[/h3]
You'll need to add “-opengl” (without the quotes) in the launch options if you want to enable the Steam overlay. And you'll most likely experience a few crashes.[u]I found disabling the Steam Cloud solved the issue. I've not experienced a single crash after doing this.[/u] There is actually an achievement the first time the game crashes — [b]Suddenly The Dungeon Collapses[/b]: “This achievement is our way of saying 'thank you for participating in our voluntary quality assurance program'.” All said, the small amount of issues apparent are relatively trivial to fix. Considering the asking price, I would be hard-pressed to list it as a negative. Though, it's certainly not a positive.

[h3]Anecdotes:[/h3]
The vagueness of some of the “flavor” text for the items feels a lot like 'Toejam and Earl' when you test mystery presents, some end up being really useful buffs or attacks while others end up spawning rocket boots, sending you flying off the map. Of course, in Dredmor it's more likely you're going to drink some acid or consume some horrid fungus that ultimately kills you.

[h3]Miscellaneous:[/h3] 
The perks you take at the beginning will alter your starting items in addition to your stats. They will also be the skill trees you're able to level into, provided you're able stay alive that long.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2528587280

The game features a considerable amount [u]Steam Workshop[/u] support as well. Especially given the age of the game and its relative esoteric and niche audience.

[h3]The Gist:[/h3]
Dungeons of Dredmor is a game that offers a lot for very little. Both in entry price as well as what's needed to run it — which is essentially negligible.

[quote]If you've read this far, consider following my curation  — [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198035820942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 9397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9059, 'last_played': 1708603069}
review:
This is one of the first and best roguelikes I've ever played. I racked up hundreds of hours on my laptop when I first played it and I'm yet to come across a contender that even comes close.
There's a million different items, styles, skill trees, spells, scrolls, wands, and ways that you can play the game so it never gets stale.
It manages to pull all this off and still be simple!
It's majority point and click so no real need to remember awkward keybinds like a lot of roguelikes. It also has a subtle underlying comedy throughout the whole game without being in your face or cringy. 
Every year or so I'll come back and have a new playthrough just because it crosses my mind. Dungeons of Dredmor is one of my favourite games and you'd be doing yourself a disservice not to give it a go if you're a fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961702409', 'num_games_owned': 754, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1623177386}
review:
Technical problems exist with the game but that's not why I am not recommending this game.

Game is a bit lacking in skill variety and weapons. Compared to your average 2D game there is like 4-5 animations for attacking and barely any character difference if you equip different equipment. It's just the same guy. Your character can have spells and other things like that if you choose your skills for it but as a melee player, It got really boring in 5 hours. Didn't even finish the dungeons once.

When it comes to technical side, If I don't play it in windowed mode in any resolution, my mouse cursor bounces around to the corners of the screen. It's really distracting and makes the game borderline unplayable. I tried a couple of solutions from forums but nothing worked. You  might have it or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049883320', 'num_games_owned': 1032, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2273, 'last_played': 1705688492}
review:
This game has a good mix of humor and interesting gameplay mechanics. The way you can mix and match skills freely gives room for virtually infinite ways to build your character. There are also many fun items from simple but effective to wild and chaotic ones, making so that no matter what, something interesting will happen at a high frequency.
The biggest negative I can give is that the interface could be improved to make it easier to navigate, but it's not so bad that you can't get used to it.
TL;DR It's a fun rouge-like that will give you hours of fun for a very low price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027990153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 13277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12581, 'last_played': 1623891883}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002468148', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2831, 'last_played': 1373553689}
review:
10 years on, still one of the best roguelikes. It has charm, tactics and boots to the face.

Get the complete version, the DLCs add a lot and really flesh it out so that every game feels very different to the next. If you've never tried it and you like roguelikes it absolutely has a lot to offer.

A shame the developers no longer exist, but their single game legacy is a pretty envious one I'm sure many studios would die for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051755093', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1332, 'last_played': 1617293852}
review: I've had this game pretty much since it was released. I usually play until I get far as fuck and die. Then I drop it swearing it off for the rest of eternity. This is the only roguelike that's this punishing that manages to drag my ass back like a woman drags back her wandering lover. I hated it at first but it grew on me every game until I get dungeon starved and start comparing whatever I'm playing to it. It may be a few months or even years between delves, but I have definitely gotten my money's worth out of it. It's one of those games that a long time after you play it you only remember the good times, and none of the traumatic wtfs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022854959', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 383, 'playtime_forever': 9633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9633, 'last_played': 1607408336}
review:
One of the best roguelike dungeon-crawlers I have ever played. 

It has a great art style, enjoyable humor and is quite challenging.

There are so many different skills that it feels really overwhelming sometimes.
 
I wish the inventory was a little bit bigger.... there is just so much loot in this game; it’s insane!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968470997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 2889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2889, 'last_played': 1419629555}
review:
this was - could have been one of the best games ever made. what did the devs do? screw everything up.

it seems they hated their own creation. so many issues were no fixed, e.g. a hard-coded inventory space (seriously, WTF?) that they deemed too hard to expand, so they gave players a kind of space where they could store items -- which quickly became a nightmare if you tend to hoard -- and some classes/ combinations simply have to.

what they should have done is release a DoD 2.0 with more depth, better inventory management and more monsters and I'd have paid 100€ for that.

nope. they decided to launch an idiotic doomed from the start ultra-niche game that nobody cared about even from day 0. then they made that game crap to boot.

now they're out of business afaik. 

don't buy. it hurts too much to enjoy something that is really good, but runs against more and more issues the farther you go, knowing that it's a dead game and there's nothing else coming.

better play the equally as fun "Tales of Maj'Eyal". a different take, way more complex also turn based and still has incredible updates and expansions. your time is not wasted there

author: {'steamid': '76561198980331369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1705845523}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018201450', 'num_games_owned': 936, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1666720459}
review:
An easy recommendation .  A surprisingly deep rougelike that has a veneer of whimsy which takes some getting used to, but with the right sense of humor you will learn to embrace the silliness and fall in love with it.  Certainly will be on my rotation of games I will keep playing for years to come.

A few minor things I would change about the game:
1) I wish in addition to the flavor text for all the items and monsters, that there was a more descriptive description of what the item/monster does.  Instead of me guessing or going to an external wiki.
2) It would be much better if the items I wear actually appear on my character.  It just all looks so samey after awhile with the look of your character.  Even simplier graphical tiles of DCSS or CDDA have items show on your avatar.  This can be jarring on a modern audience really.
3) I wished the UI scales better to large displays, I have an 3840x1600 monitor and the mini map and the character screen are still way too small.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042022498', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 27811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25202, 'last_played': 1616907705}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040020629', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 2513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2031, 'last_played': 1673348907}
review:
An excellent rougelike greatly extended by its modding capabilities. Stands the test of time. Add around one hundred hours to my playtime, for the record.

Largest con with the game is it has several gameplay systems that don't track knowledge gained between playthroughs. This mostly doesn't matter, but in the case of the secret realms you can visit, having to write down the codewords detracts from the experience. Still, there's very few, if any, rougelikes on the market more fun than this, and Monster Zoos are a delight every time they murder me!

author: {'steamid': '76561198223212980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2105, 'last_played': 1612228882}
review:
If you want to make fun builds and they aren't melee, this is fun.
If you want actual balance or challenge, pass.
If you want to play melee, maybe pass.

This is a game where 90% of the enemies are melee exactly as fast as you. So the instant you get the ability to A: Turn invisible or B: teleport, you can casually walk away from any fight at all that's any threat. Up some stairs/around the corner. Press + a few times so the game is faster. And walk backwards and forwards for max hp/mp. 
Because of this, only 1 non-optional enemy in the game is any threat at all: The final one. 

With the DLC you can just take magic lawyer and silence him though, and then he's also a melee only enemy that can never actually hit you. 

Balance wise, melee v others, is so insanely bad that if you do this on an otherwise entirely melee character, he will absolutely mawl you. Nearly instant death. While taking no damage. Melee is insanely weak compared to range/magic in terms of the damage it does, riskier and requires far more investment to 'make work'.

A melee character to be decently functional needs a dozen skills at decently high levels, good gear and even then is mediocre at the absolute best. 

A magic character literally just takes the fire magic and then however much mana regen you want. You can take 0 and just walk backwards and forwards, but I'd suggest taking some to make the game faster. 

A ranged character? A maxed out melee character is better served using a ranged weapon with absolutely no skill in it v the stronger enemies. Its that insanely strong. 

Its the kind of game that's just objectively incredibly poorly designed, but its so fun messing around with I'd still rec it

author: {'steamid': '76561198072253387', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 19095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11037, 'last_played': 1680204606}

review:
My wife gifted me this because it was a game she enjoyed years ago. I thought i wouldn't like it as i pretty much never liked a single roguelike game in my life, i thought the genre was not for me.

But i gave it a go as in to please her and boy i was in for a blast. This thing screams old school. Kinda made me feel i was back in my old days of crusty-old rpg games.

What surprised me more is the ammount of skilltrees you can have, holy crap. I died 3 times already but still having fun with my Blacksmith Engineer Rogue

author: {'steamid': '76561198048986589', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 5047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5047, 'last_played': 1444992946}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025455325', 'num_games_owned': 696, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1610894673}
review:
This game is... Ok. Ish. I am a fan of roguelikes and RPGs. I appreciate the witty tropes and comedy it brings to the genre. I like the art style. It has a vast amount of customization through skills and character creation. Absolutely tons of loot. A decent crafting system as well as inventory management.

I could NOT get over the controls for the game... It forces you to click on moving targets, often times causing a mis click. And in a game like this, a single missed click can cause death. Not only that, but there always seems to be pauses as combat was calculated.

If this is your only experience into the genre... Then I would say that's disappointing. There are so many better options then this available. But I guess if it is cheap enough, then it doesn't matter, maybe on sale for under $1.00. I wouldn't recommend it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198321740054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 252, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1610854927}
review:
A traditional roguelike where you move with WASD (numpad keys not supported!) and click with the mouse to attack enemies ("moving" into them not supported!) - literally throwing away decades of roguelike common-sense and the previously learned lessons of the genre. I can't see myself playing this over any number of free games that are much less awkward to control.

You're trying to hit the enemy with the mouse but it's so clunky that you end up hitting a pixel off and your character walks 5 squares, wasting turns and suffering damage as the enemies attack. Who could possibly think that this control scheme was a good idea over the roguelike controls figured out literally decades ago?! It's like the author never played one before!

Diagonal movement not supported! On a turn-based, grid-based tactical  game! I joke you not!

Have fun developing Repetitive Strain Injury by clicking the mouse X times to kill ONE enemy!

Do yourself a favor and go play Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup completely for free - even the music is better (and I say that fully knowing that DCSS has no soundtrack whatsoever).

author: {'steamid': '76561197991755794', 'num_games_owned': 1035, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 2329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2159, 'last_played': 1607553052}
review:
Too grindy, feels repetitive after third level, monster houses are tedious.  Even with smallest level size and fast animation.

Crafting is almost unusable and very confusing, you never get the ingredients. You never want to pick any of the crafting classes.

Nothing about the secondary systems and encounters in the dungeon is explained. Blue portals and password are always an instant death.

Regarding items and inventory, you never feel that you find good gear, most of the time it is about collecting food and bewerages for health and mana, with many different names so makes it really hard to manage inventory and find things. After second level your inventory is full, you have to drop things in a dimension for storage.

Stats are there but you do not feel they reflect in your performance against different escenarios. Too few enemies, almost all feel the same. Would be great to be able to inspect enemies stats somehow, know what we are fighting and why my build is not holding the encounter. Anyways, the system is very limited regarding customisation of items / adapting to enemy types, so little can the player do: praise the RNG lord.

Character classes are cool. Playing bankster or communist feels appealing and hilarious. However, most of the time selecting random classes becomes into a non-win combination. When you find a working combination game becomes repetitive until you find a situation in which you sudddenly die. So class combination has its limits and you need luck with gear in the run.

Humour and tone in general is ok and original, ie jokes in the crafting recipes are cool. 
However, if you are looking for a classic ambientation it may be a drawback.

Animations of enemies are really good.

Too grindy and shallow to my taste. Thumbs up because played many hours and enjoyed figuring out combinations of perks that work.

Good ideas, bad execution. Grab it on sale for a ridiculous price, the developer deserves it, but keep in mind that there exist better options nowadays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067920006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1675532982}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024724501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 5304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5255, 'last_played': 1605114187}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor got me into roguelikes almost ten years ago. Just picked it up again for a little blast of the past. In retrospect, it's really not that good.

Its main flaws are:

1) Lack of transparency 
2) Repetitiveness & Tedium
3) Crafting & Inventory Management

Going into detail:

1) Lack of transparency:
The game doesn't explain its mechanics and there's no way to read them up online. I'd like to know how chance to hit, dodge, block, counterattack and so on works and how the mechanics interact with each other, but the only thing the game tells you is (literally) "bigger numbers good". Cool.
The skills also don't tell you clearly what they do, they just have reddit tier meme descriptions. 
When I play roguelikes I want to make decisions what to level up and what to equip based on my understanding of the mechanics, just wearing stuff with big fucking numbers and picking cool sounding skills just doesn't cut it for me.
Oh yeah, the game also doesn't really have an exhaustive combat log, so good luck figuring out what the fuck is even going on while you're playing.

2) Repetitiveness & Tedium:
There's not a whole lot to do and see in DoD. Even with quadruple speed animations and the smaller floors option enabled, the game quickly becomes a chore starting at around floor 3. You kinda explore the floor, dodge or disarm traps, clap the occasional monster and stumble upon a monster zoo that just contains around 50 or so monsters. Very fun for the first time, alright the second time, makes you want to Alt+F4 the third time.
There's not a whole lot of enemy variety, they mostly just look different while moving next to you to hit you. Bosses are just stronger regular mobs.
Oh, and there's also no rest button, so you have to continously eat food and press "digest" to fast forward while regening 1hp per turn. Even if you have natural hp regen the game doesn't offer you a way to rest, it forces you to spam space or eat food. Why? Does this really add so much challenge?

3) Crafting & Inventory Management:
There are a lot of crafting tools and skills in DoD and they're extremely confusing. There's no good way to stash your crafting reagents and the crafting interface is so bad (I mean it, probably the worst I've ever seen) that I wonder how anyone could even bother with crafting. If you pick up everything (as you do as a new player), you'll very soon find your inventory to be clogged. I could go in great detail here but I don't want to bother, just know that inventory management is atrocious and will take way too much time.


In summary, if you're new to roguelikes maybe check this out, not like it's expensive and it's certainly fun for a few hours. Or just play ToME right away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047176008', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2874, 'last_played': 1605995937}

author: {'steamid': '76561198036373796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 15438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15379, 'last_played': 1604871482}
review: Every game is different, and when every game is not different enough any more, mods, lots of them. Zany humour and bullshit deaths so be warned if you don't like that. But nothing feels too serious with this game. And if you really don't want to have those bullshit deaths be permanent, you can disable permadeath but honestly I love rolling up new characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058424368', 'num_games_owned': 1103, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1692361656}
review:
As I grow older I find myself playing games and genres that I wouldn't touch in the past.
I was never into DnD and the complex system of RPGs

When I first decided to give this a try and saw the different skills you get to choose in the beginning, all I wanted to do was ALT+F4.
But then I saw the little magic "Random" button and decided to give it a go with permadeath ON so i can learn from my mistakes.
2 minutes later and Im back at the "choose your skills" menu! So I hit the "get the last skills you used" button and decided to actually read what skills I had on my last run. After swapping around some stuff I gave this another go and to my surprise I almost cleared the first floor.
With every run I learned something new and by the looks of it the game is simpler than I initially thought.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075069389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4196, 'last_played': 1709410323}
review: O jogo é muito bom, cheio de variações no que diz respeito às salas, itens, monstros, principalmente àqueles monstros e itens que possuem um nome adicional, o que dá a eles, bônus em cima dos stats originais. O gameplay é bom para esse estilo de roguelike clássico em turnos, com certeza um dos melhores jogos roguelike que já joguei. Com relação aos pontos negativos do jogo, um dos mais marcantes é a falta de mais itens no end-game. Quando se está abaixo do 12º ou 13º piso, é perceptível a repetição de itens encontrados e disponíveis na loja, o que causa um desânimo no jogador por uma atmosfera monótona que se forma. Mas, em geral, o jogo é muito bom, com certeza vale a pena ser comprado com todas as DLCs lançadas. Agora vou começar a experimentar alguns mods dentro do jogo. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198087420815', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1131, 'last_played': 1661625448}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor é um jogo incrível. Apesar dos seus gráficos simples e jogabilidade um tanto quanto datada, as opções de customização nas builds através das skills são enormes tornando a estratégia do game muito complexa. Também conta com um toque de humor descontraindo a jogatina em certos momentos, o próprio jogo não se leva a sério, como por exemplo: existir a skill tree do vegano assassino. Apesar disso não se engane é uma experiência difícil já que nem todas as informações são dadas na sua cara, é necessária muita tentativa e erro para dominar as mecânicas do jogo. Nota final : 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198000323870', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2605, 'last_played': 1603256425}
review: Fun game to come back to every once in a while and see how far you can get. You don't need to win, just have fun trying something different or trying to beat a previous record. The only bad thing I'd say about this game is that it doesn't explain its mechanics very well, especially all those tiny little colored icons. Also, nearly every text description of anything in the entire game is a goofy joke reference to some other media, which isn't what everyone wants. But, you can consult the various wikis to understand it better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025510154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1602308545}
review:
Mid-rez isometric RPG.  You are a hero entering a dungeon to stop the rising of the lich Dredmor.  Explore.  Kill monsters.  Make new things.  Defeat Dredmor.

This game is more roguelike than many other games called "roguelike".  It is a dungeon crawl, with turn-based movement for you and monsters, with procedurally generated levels.  There's loot to find, things to craft from available supplies, skills to master, side quests to complete and an overarching objective.  There isn't quite a "return to town" functionality, but there's a private room you can gain access to where you can store your excess stuff, do crafting and the like.

When you generate your character, you have a large number of skills to choose from: weapon-oriented skills that let you specialize your combat, crafting skills that give you access to better recipes, more esoteric skills such as golem creation and mushroom finding, and even more esoteric skills such as Paranormal Investigator, Pirate and Tourist.  Each skill has a track you can spend skill points to advance along, which gives you new abilities.

It's simple, somewhat violent fun.  Be all you can be, so that when you finally get to the bottom of the dungeon you're prepared to kick lich butt.  I got it through HB, but the current store price of $4.99 is more than reasonable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988760457', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2089, 'last_played': 1688151114}
review: Good fun but difficult to master. So many options to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964735295', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 1905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1376278549}
review: The graphics are terrible and some of the content is goofy (I have no idea what the developers' fascination with lutefisk is), but this is a solid game. It's a rogue-like game, which means tons of treasure, random dungeon, and monsters to battle - and it's all well-balanced and enjoyable. The price is right, too. If you are building your library, I wouldn't start with this one, but it's a worthy addition if you've already hit up the greats.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021049970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 2192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2129, 'last_played': 1657338474}
review:
A ridiculous rogue-like game in the earliest sense of the genre (really I could just repeat the word ridiculous 100 times and it still wouldn't be enough).

Recommended for anyone who likes turn-based games with a lot of DnD-like mechanics, very little explanations, crippling difficulty, brokenly ridiculous powers, and cheesy sound effects that will sit in the back of your memories for years to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972392547', 'num_games_owned': 669, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 31023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31023, 'last_played': 1557664908}
review:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for one of my favorite games of all time.

Dungeons of Dredmor is an incredible roguelike.  It's a liiiiittle buggy, but sometimes that bugginess is part of the charm.  Other times you get stuck in geometry by accident and crash to desktop.  It's a SOMEWHAT stable game, but it does sometimes hardlock, so make sure you save frequently(I recommend right before and after heading down a floor).

the classes are varied and creative, with literally over four dozen different skill trees to choose from, you pick seven and head off to your likely rapid doom.  Most skill trees have viability, there's very few out and out stinkers, and even then those can be propped up by better skills or even buoy good skills into amazing skills when combo'd together.  

the humor is top notch, it's slapstick and absurd, with some biting wit and extremely sarcastic and beaten-down enemies who spout one-liners at you upon aggroing.  One of my favorites is, say, busting down a door and revealing a Diggle who says "only two more days until I can retire" as it charges at you, or "Strength in numbers, boys, strength in numbers" or "what, you again?".  The equipment is often referential and ridiculous, with flavor text often alluding to silly things like the Dwarven Plasticsmiths.  I really love the earnest humor of the game, and the often ridiculous enemies like crabs who wear knight armor, eldritch potatos, and diggles who have spent way too much time at the gym are a regular occurence.

again, I love this game's humor: https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/391049170413542381/65D62805CEC02C489C3A3EF772F2C55163DB9B8B/

the combat is turn-based, you take a step or perform an action, so does everything else.  This lets you think out your next moves and plan around movement patterns of enemies, but like chess can also quickly put you into checkmate if you're too hasty.  And you WILL die.  A lot.  Much like every classic roguelike in the vein of Rogue or Nethack, the game is out to get you, and make sure you know it.  Drink from a magical fountain and you might find a shiny ring in the bowl, or you might be drinking acid and melt to death in two turns.  Think you can take that boss-class enemy from a prior level?  surprise, it's corrupted your equipment and now you're suddenly slower than everything and it two-shots you.  Playing cleverly and safely is often the way to go, but fast and loose can get you through a run much quicker at a much greater risk.  Attacking a shopkeep might let you loot the shops of all the possibly-insane loot they have, but it also incurs the wrath of a boss-class monster who summons infinite, extremely strong minions that can easily overwhelm you with numbers.

Death in Dungeons of Dredmor is often frustrating, but tends to teach you something each time.  Don't kick a door when you're at one health or you might stub your toe and die.  Don't open a door without an escape route or a Monster Zoo behind that door with 100+ monsters crammed in it might overflow into where you are and completely engulf you.  Don't assume that you'll always waltz unscathed over that Acid Arrow Trap trigger with your heightened trap sense ability and never set it off.  Again, hubris is one's greatest enemy in this game.

Beating the game is fairly uneventful, you fight an insanely tough boss and then get an end screen.  It's a small game made by a small group of people(who have long since vanished since the studio blew up ages ago), so the cracks do show occasionally.  But I love the rough, silly artstyle and the jank.  I've beaten it countless times and had a blast almost every time, once you get the hang of things try hitting Random at the generation screen and see how far you can make it with a random build, it can get pretty ridiculous.

The DLC is generally good and tends to add a lot of variety.  Realm of the Diggle Gods adds 5 more floors which are a little bit samey but I still like them.  Conquest of the Wizardlands adds further shenanigans in the forum of alternate dimensions, which can be fairly mundane and crappy, but can also have lots of ridiculous items and hidden alcoves, it also adds a storage dimension where you can toss all your crap.  The bundle package for DoD is 7 bucks, and is an incredible bargain for this amazing roguelike.

My screenshot page for DoD with a variety of mostly-nonsensical screenshots is: https://steamcommunity.com/id/spessmarine/screenshots/?appid=98800

review: For such a cheap game that I got in a humble bundle this game was amazing and a lot of fun and I have still nowhere near exhausted all there is to play. It's quite difficult and at times it can be very frustrating but in a good way when you've been playing one playthrough for hours and are several levels down and then die in some stupid way such as a trap or your own spell because you were going too fast and weren't paying enough attention. it's a great game though partly because it's difficult. I also really like the humour in the game which is a big part of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031050279', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1435, 'last_played': 1555449061}
review: This game is great, character skills are incredible. This is a roguelike that has effectively been dumbed down for people like me. There definitely still is complexity and the crafting, potion, tinkering, yada yada are all very complex and great if you dive into it. It's a 100% grind but if you have time and a microwave computer this is awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149949607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9277, 'last_played': 1661469066}
review:
Classic rogue-like game with more modern graphics. Prepare to die. A lot. Like, I died less playing Dark Souls for longer. Difference is, there are a wider variety of builds to try in this, and permadeath gives you an excuse to try more of them. 

Best run so far was Crossbows, Tinkering, Dodge, Armor, Shields, Perception, and Burglary. I didn't die to anything other than Dreadmore's magic (and only because I forgot to swap my dual shields for Dark Mirror Shields).

author: {'steamid': '76561198042304767', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 44050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29179, 'last_played': 1705631068}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969556854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 26307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 22, 'playtime_at_review': 20401, 'last_played': 1710508441}
review:
Dredmor in 2020 is still a great game with incredible replay value. There are so many different ways to play the game and it's super simple to pick up and play. If you've ever played an 8 bit RPG or Rogue-like you will be fine and even if not, you'll pick it up in no time.
You can really tell the devs enjoyed making this game. It's light-hearted and doesn't take things too seriously whilst still providing a significant challenge regardless of your playstyle or choices. 

Highly recommend it. Classic masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998787120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 11371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10508, 'last_played': 1703488345}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062843733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2404, 'last_played': 1683367166}
review: I began playing Dungeons of Dredmor a number of years ago... It was right around then that I was starting to really enjoy roguelikes, so the fact that a roguelike RPG with tons of different skill trees, monsters, items, etc. exists makes me extremely happy. In fact, I've been a fan of Dredmor since the game was released and I still find myself picking up and playing the game 5+ years later. Massive maps, lots of loot, and even a little bit of comedy for good measure!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004785234', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1621814007}
review: For what it's worth, I normally don't like traditional roguelikes.  I generally don't like the kind of game design that treats randomness like added difficulty.  "You drink the water.  It's poison.  You're dead..."  I've seen this in other games.  Thankfully, Dredmor is better than that.  You can choose your level of unfairness in a lot of different ways.  Also, there are a lot of enemy types that will let you chug through them without being a spellcaster.  My general mode is axes and barbarian rage.  The game caters well to that.  Just play it.  It's a great game.

review:
Основная фишка игры куча классов. Вы выбираете 8 из них и с каждым левелом прокачиваете одну из 8 выбранных веток.
Скилов море. А с дополнениями их 2,5. Пройти бывает сложновато.
Плюсы
+Инновационная система скилов.
+Неплохая графика.
+Куча предметов.
В остальном неплохая данжен рпг.
Из минусов.
-Достаточно однообразна, на долго может не хватить. Но скорее вы вернётесь, т.к. не все скилы ещё опробованы.

7.5\10

author: {'steamid': '76561198072843459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1594171835}
review:
I wanted to like this more. The sense of humor, interesting and unique skills, and reasonable number of floors got my attention.
The thing is, the game doesn't tell you what the skills do, making character building impossible without consulting the wiki. Leveling up a skill is vital to increasing your main stats, and it doesn't tell you what they will level. Stats are labeled only with miniscule icons. Difficulty spikes and cheap shots abound (in a game with permadeath, where it took me almost 10 hours to reach the 15th and final floor! Fortunately, you can turn it off and the worst that will happen is the game will crash when you try to load your save). Any door could be a monster zoo containing hundreds of enemies (no joke, triple digits). It crashes a lot, costing you progress. Regenerating health takes forever unless you have a great regeneration stat, not to mention the carpal tunnel potential that ensues when you have to mash the spacebar to pass even a single turn (unless you use food and click the digest button, which heals maybe a sliver of health).

Also, the communism skill tree (amazing first skill aside) is a liability that probably should never be used. You'd think the power of memes would be worthwhile, but no. Whenever you're in a fight, a freezing cloud could show up- and it affects YOU. Said cloud is impossible to escape unscathed without some kind of movement/teleportation skill, and this happens too frequently for my lifesaving leap skill to even come off cooldown.

Anyway, I'm savescumming the final boss now because I'm not sure how much more of this I can handle. I'm only bothering to finish it because there's just enough good in here that I'd feel empty for the evening if I gave up.

EDIT: There we go. It is technically possible, but not really worthwhile. Might be worth watching a playthrough, because the soundtrack, humor, and style are all right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044012546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1597357686}

author: {'steamid': '76561198091153684', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 2573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2532, 'last_played': 1642651837}
review: I can’t recommend this game, though it’s not, in essence, ‘bad’. The issue comes down more to the fact that the game crashed more times than it didn’t. In fact, I rarely had to use the quit button, the game crashed so often. The achievement for having the game crash, (and yes, they really did put in an achievement for that), is the 8th most achieved achievement in the game, out of 122 achievements. This issue is made all the worse due to the fact that the crashing will sometimes cause your save files to corrupt/disappear, unless you manually edit the games config file to disable steam cloud saving. The game is 9 years old now, and from what I understand, the engine it was made in is now 11 years old, as of writing this review. As a result, there’s a very tangible aged quality of the game, and that’s not just in reference to the outdated humor and pop-culture references. When the game does work, its a fine and fun roguelike, especially if you delve into some of the mods from the workshop. However, whether it’s a result of the games age, or if those issues were there to begin with, the technical difficulties are too prominent for me to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022186788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1546, 'last_played': 1591809286}
review:
I can't think of a better classic RPG rogue Dungeon crawler than this one. Keep in mind, the focus is on turn per turn action, dungeon exploration and character building, some loot and crafting. It isn't on pure action or graphics, look at a few seconds of gameplay and you'll be able to tell.

Humor is pretty out there but mostly funny. You must be ok with the fourth wall being broken though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027372201', 'num_games_owned': 1128, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1591474413}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a rather old game so this rating is not entirely fair i guess.

The problem is that after a while the game just doesn't feel like it has a real drive, that is a sort of tension.
You meander around, collect stuff and try to go deeper. But it does not really feel like you are discovering great sights and tools.

Often its not that difficult, you just sometimes die rather suddenly.

I do have a kind of nostalgic fondness for it, it is like coming back to the house of your childhood, but really nothing has changed, so you sit in the simple kitchen that your young parents had back then, the room smells from soup on the stove and you remember the sound of your mother cooking while you do the homework.

So i can only recommend it if you have played it from somewhere else before this and want to relive old times again, when you have a sort of history with it.

But for others the simple truth is that after so many years after the release of DoD we have been spoiled by plenty of excellent roguelikes and similar games that simply do it better, with more depth, more visually and exploratory pleasing and better driving gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027956461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3021, 'last_played': 1708298708}
review:
One of the most user friendly rougelikes I ever played, I really appreciate the pun based humor.

The interactions between skill trees and the crafting system takes a while to figure out and the final boss is really freaking tough, but other then that it's one of my favourite games.

Shame the company colapsed, I wish we could get a remake or a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006434250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 7653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7300, 'last_played': 1589741751}
review:
A classic that certainly was the introduction to proper roguelikes (not roguelites) for many people due to its presentable tiles, approachable game mechanics and quirky humor.

Nowadays (05/2020) the game definitelly shows its age in terms of user interface and controls because the game engine is old and was sorta of janky to begin with even at the time of release.

That said, the gameplay still holds up decently well (recomended to use the "No Time To Grind" option) and for its very cheap price I think it remains a strong contender as a game to ease yourself into the roguelike world if you're unfamiliar with it and wishes to start delving into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012395761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1587771797}
review:
PROS: 
Very moderately priced (so much so that there's really no harm in trying if this game suits one's taste). Cutesy graphics. A lot of variations for character creation. Mod support.

CONS: 
Very clumsy UI (so bad it can get you killed with accidentally wasted turns). It is not possible to play solely with keyboard or mouse, some actions require one and some the other. Dungeons are repetitive and get boring quickly (layout of the floor maps vary from game to game, but the dungeon level specific themes, monster types and general content seem to be always the same). Traps are marked with the same golden sparkle as treasures (!), resulting in unhappy accidents. 

There is a mini map (yay), but it cannot be used for setting waypoints, which would make moving to off-screen areas much easier and faster. Dungeons are also chock-full of teleportation devices, some areas can only be reached via them, and they often don't return you to your original location, resulting in an arduous and annoying mapping process. 

Pieces of equipment typically affect various stats in a myriad of ways, making it hard to figure out which ones are most beneficial. There's WAY too much junk (gazillion different items for healing, mana replenishment, buffs, trading, to be used in crafting etc., while carrying capacity is limited -- even with the inventive "pocket dimension", inventory management soon becomes an unbearable nuisance). 

Music is irritating and repetitive (but can thankfully be turned off). I found the game's all-encompassing. rather asinine humour more alienating than amusing, your mileage may vary.

SUMMARY: 
Playing this game was more of an ordeal than a pleasure. To me there are numerous much better rogue-likes, from the 30+ years old ASCII Nethack to Angband to Darkest Dungeon.
