author: {'steamid': '76561197972529071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2758, 'last_played': 1602269001}
review:
Despite always being curious about the genre this was the first "roguelike" I could actually get into. I think what made the difference is that you can actually *see* everything that's happening at a glance instead of having to try interpret what hundreds of different ascii and colour combinations mean. Then top it off with some decent humour, a MASSIVE list of abilities to chose from and tonnes of personality and you've got a great little starter roguelike.

Can't reccomned this game enough, even to people who don't enjoy "roguelikes". This game converted me, maybe it'll do the same for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046528878', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 8019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7896, 'last_played': 1679020195}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a game with a lot of personality that stays fun for a long time.

Essentialy, this is a roguelike that relies heavily on referential humor and old-school charm,, while giving you great music and nice graphics.  At it's core, it's a fairly deep game with lots of interesting mechanics, none of which you absolutely HAVE to use, and character loadouts with enough variety to make almost any playstyle viable with enough skill.  There's also sliding scales of difficulty and complexity (You can make the floors of the dungeon smaller, while XP gains for a faster, more streamlined experience), and DLC expansion that actually add quite a lot.

The only negatives really are glitches (there's an achievement for crashing the game) and the ones that are inherant to roguelikes, such as it being absolutely unforgiving.  Despite each new game starting from scratch (you can never unlock things to make your character stronger from the get-go), you may have quite an easy time as you slice, crush and kick your way through the first few levels, or you may die a few steps from the starting point because an above-average strength monster appeared there.  The game's layout for inventory and menus can be a bit unweildly, though you can move things around where you want them to be and resize most windows.

Also, good luck on getting all the acheivements, some of them are quite hard to get simplly because so many of them involve your character dying in weird ways (for example, if you don't have a lockpick, you can kick down a locked door, but there's a chance instead of kicking it down, you'll hurt your foot, takiing minor damage, like 1 or 2hp.  There's an acheivement for dying to this, which is pretty impossible to get, since you regenerate health naturally as you move, so you have to position yourself in front of a door while being at low enough health that hurting your foot will kill you, and then kick it, hoping the door doesn't just open.  Then, if you fail you have to get to another locked door while regenerating health, meaning you'll have to hurt yourself, but it'll be hard to not die doing that.)  There's also achievements that have been impossible to get due to changes in the game, such as filling out a skill tree that has been removed from the game.  So, if those sorts of things bother you, buy with caution.  Otherwise, great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042460330', 'num_games_owned': 2705, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1525487351}
review:
I like the concept of this roguelike, but try as I might I just can't get into it. 

I can't say it's especially bad - the concept of selecting your own traits for your hero every time you die is really neat.  Many of said traits are actually pretty fresh and unique.  Many of the secrets and whatnot are really cool. What really kills Dungeons of Dredmor for me is the mechanics and controls - I find combat to be repetitive and the controls to be highly unwieldy.

There's just better-made roguelikes on the market.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036424953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4307, 'last_played': 1605774368}

review: My go to roguelike.  Also the whole game is cheaper than DLC for some games.  Be a hammer and sickle wielding, pan-galactic gargleblaster chugging pyrocommunist.  Yeah.  You can do that.  Nuff' said.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996087647', 'num_games_owned': 935, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 11511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 3096, 'last_played': 1709692953}
review:
Still the best Rogue-like you can play. Even if you don't care about the cheesy humor, the game itself is very true to the "Rogue" itself with proper turn based gameplay bolstered with tons of skill combination and items to have, challenging but fair levels which you choose if you want to just blaze through or grind through. It's a game like back when games used to be games rather than "Rogue-likes" or "Soulsborne" or "Metroidvania" stuff. You may associate this game with those that are clones of better things. But this game earns itself the right to not be called a clone. Because if Rogue had graphics and a bit more technology behind it, it would be this game.

Not a mere imitator, but a perfector.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028322145', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1475351152}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor é um rogue-like simples na execução, mas que pode ser bastante profundo e com rejogabilidade infinita caso queira jogar com todas as combinações de classes e habilidades possíveis.

O mapa é gerado aleatoriamente, os inimigos são dispostos aleatoriamente, itens também.

A variedade de classes é enorme, você pode montar qualquer combinação inusitada que desejar. Um mago que também é ferreiro e usa ataques marciais. Classes estranhas como Comunistas, Geomancer, Turista, Vampiro, Por que não? Este jogo te possibilita as combinações mais diversas e fora do comum.

Mesmo tendo jogado mais de 20 horas, ainda não consegui terminar esse jogo. Mas recomendo a todos que querem um jogo com extremo humor, dificuldade constante e desafios em toda sala que você entrar. Há como jogar salvando o progresso ou no modo mais hardcore com permadeath.

Recomendo fortemente. Quando joguei segui alguns guias na internet para o sistema de craft e para saber o que poderia combinar ou não nas poções... Tomar algumas poções sem nome podem gerar morte instantânea. E, com o permadeath ativado, morrer por causa de um uso errado de uma poção ou comendo o cogumelo errado... acontece...

author: {'steamid': '76561198003609321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1708649243}
review: The Pan-Galactic Gargle Blaster was worth every Zorkmid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021087888', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 12447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12447, 'last_played': 1518744043}
review:
This is one of the most charming things in gaming, and also one of the rare examples of truly great british humor. If you've got to play one roguelike in your life, I certainly recommend this one. It's witty, it's charming, it's both classy and polished, while not being cheezy and overly glossy. What shortcomings it has come with the genre, and what strengths it has nothing else in the genre has, as far as I'm concerned.

Minor word of caution for the achievement grinders - getting all the chievo's will take serious grinding, and there are a few which are unobtainable without messing with the files. Intentionally, I assume. So while I'd recommend it to anyone looking to experience a roguelike, the achievement grinding demographic is really looking at a tall order.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003664291', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1542173852}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023277635', 'num_games_owned': 638, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7415, 'last_played': 1597621860}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor makes me happy.  Everyone has their own pet concepts and enjoys certain bits and pieces that the game provides.  Small details make the game great.  Most of my joy is in the crafting section.  I have yet to make it to the bottom of the dungeon, but that doesn't bother me so much.  The journey of many years has been excellent.

This game comes very highly recommended, and is among some of the genre defining and defying games that make the crown jewels of my gaming library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042239887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1404233472}

author: {'steamid': '76561198046491083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 8648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6056, 'last_played': 1667136572}
review:
If I could play this game then I would recommend it.
Unfortunately there's two problems with it at the moment;
- When in Fullscreen mode the mouse jumps all over the place.
- When not in Fullscreen mode the window is too large for the screen and cannot be resized.

These two problems aren't specific to me, many people get them, and still get them in 2018.

I used to be able to play the game and I did enjoy it, but after reinstalling Windows 10 I get the above problems. So I know the game would be enjoyable...if I could play it.

Finally, I'm not sure that the problems will be fixed. I googled the games release history and it says that the last time it was updated was in 2012.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105716988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 21623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4311, 'last_played': 1708422773}
review:
I'm still not technically GOOD at this game, but that doesn't matter so far--I'm having fun just exploring the dungeon!  First of all it has the traits of a rougeLITE that I like, such as the dungeon being randomly generated + permadeath (which you can turn off)...but the potions, wands, etc. consistently do the same thing every time.  (As compared to, say Nethack, where the "fizzy potion" could be healing one time and acid the next!)  You will, however, die a lot, so get out your favourite fantasy name-generator!  And it's turn-based, which means you can stop to think about your next move and take as long as you like.

For me, the real star of Dungeons of Dredmor is just how customizable it is.  You can pick 7 skill trees at the beginning, allows you to make almost any fantasy(ish) archtype you want!  Want a Viking barbarian?  Okay--axes, berzerking, Viking Magic, for starters.  How 'bout a straight-up D&D style thief?  Burglary (duh), Artful Dodger, Perception... Ninja?  Sure--throwing objects and martial arts.  A Jedi?  Keep the martial arts and throw in some psionics, maybe a sword or quarterstaff skill.  Wizard?  What kind ya want--dark creepy necromancer, studious crafty type, or set sh#t on fire battlemage?  We got it all.   Wanna be just a crafter?  We got that too.

OR...you can just give into the game's silliness, which at times reminds me of Kingdom of Loathing's sense of humour.  How 'bout a vegan pirate?  Vampire lawyer?  Club-wielding Communist mushroom-farmer. WHATEVER.   And each "build", no matter how silly, gives a distinctly different experience, making no two games the same.  

Overall, I'd say that if you want a nice quiet rainy-day dungeon crawler with a sense of humour and a surprising amount of gameplay depth...I'd reccomend this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989529268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2827, 'last_played': 1520963312}
review: Finally killed Lord Dreadmo but not with melee, luckily I had clockwork Sawblades.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142343106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1489737786}
review: Gameplay is decently fun but this game is a time sink. Be prepared to lose yourself in hours of grinding, and come out of it only mildly satisfied.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108235797', 'num_games_owned': 4056, 'num_reviews': 550, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1581896343}
review:
Not a bad game but not really worth it honestly, I'm giving it 5/10 but I'm giving it a negative so people get curious about this review and read it.

What's the problem? Well, in a few words, Tales of Maj'Eyal does everything better.
I don't really see the point of playing this since Tales of Maj'Eyal is way better.
Dungeons of Dredmor isn't a bad game but Tales of Maj'Eyal is better and you could think that it would be best to play both but Tales of Maj'Eyal has infinite replayability so there is no point in playing this game.

Visually, the character equipment/clothing is always the same which shows how lazy/bad is the developer.
The game has lot of glitches/bugs.
The mouse cursor will randomly move at times, it is extremely annoying.
The game is slow in two manners, one, it feels like it plays at 20 - 25 fps and the paced is way too slow.

Music is good but honestly, you should just play Tales of Maj'Eyal instead, worth way more than this game.

5/10 - but keep in mind that i'm comparing it a lot with Tales of Maj'Eyal which is a better game but I can't get myself to not compare it and since Tales of Maj'Eyal is a better game, better spend your time on Tales of Maj'Eyal instead.

Go and get Tales of Maj'Eyal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052390102', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 23532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15590, 'last_played': 1621548484}
review: Solid game all the way around, so many builds to choose from. Found a lot of the content funny myself. Countless hours of fun to be had, even more once you include the optional dungeons.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968708097', 'num_games_owned': 1089, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1171, 'last_played': 1519419103}
review: Great traditional roguelike, especially for first timers. Quirky, silly, great art and sound, easy to understand mechanics and configurable difficulty (including optional permadeath). Veterans and pureists will probably dislike it because it is simpler and more forgiving, but there are pleanty of other games out there for them. Well worth the price of admission.

review: After some time playing this I was enjoying this advature with its qurkyness of insults from enemys, HOWEVER, i do not excuse how the so call "healing" healing poitons are worthless, your better off eather make a attack healing tank build ( tryed to kill the vamp diggle with my lover but all tactics fails) witch questions me how this game trully works, the only way i can get back into this is healing potion TRUELLY HEAL or remove the potions all togeather because last I check, healing potions should do more then "20" and I know someone is gonna pull a fast one "get good" then try playing Xenogears with no upgrades, final fantasy tactics with no items phonix downs and paper mario TYD no badge run & Luigi only.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060612816', 'num_games_owned': 574, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 8422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7362, 'last_played': 1572726073}
review: I've played this game since it came back in like 2012. Honestly, it's 100% worth the $7 for the complete edition (and trust me, it's worth it), and it's a steal on any sale so you owe it to yourself to buy it. This game is one of the most simple, yet amazing dungeon crawlers out there. Leveling up feels great, the loot is varied and gives you tonnes of play styles, enemies are not extremely dangerous but you can find yourself in trouble really fast sometimes. The game has some age on it but really it works fine for the most part and even without any mods, the game plays perfectly. This is one of the best "turn based" Dungeon Crawlers you can get, for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004418141', 'num_games_owned': 1336, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 11719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11067, 'last_played': 1666244645}
review:
A really fun roguelike in the classic sense.  Crawl through a dungeon to get to the big bad and put him down.  Comes with a marvelous sense of humor and support for a lot of modding.  The class system is really interesting, and allows you to make fun and powerful characters that really suit your personal style.  Add in a bunch of mod classes, and it multiplies the number of possibilities.

Ended up stopping playing it after a while due to instability once you start getting into the few dozen mods range, though.. so go a little light on that front.

review:
God i wish I could give this game a good review and a nod, however, playing on a Windows 10 4K system and investing over an hour trying to get it working = not gonna happen. 

If the devs could do a few simple things, instant time sink and hundreds of hours lost to this game!! 

Find how to make the hud scale with 4k, or when selecting 1080p (1920x1080) have the game scale up to the resolution of the screen instead of being 1/4 of it in the middle (windowed or fullscreen doesn't matter). 

Also, and more of a PITA, the mouse jumps/hitches all over the place when playing, click on an item infront of me it jumps to the upper right, left, side, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967078573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3264, 'last_played': 1600000497}
review:
One of the best roguelikes ever. There are plenty of builds and they all feel different. The lore is a bit silly, but it's a welcome change from the usual fantasy tropes.

It's easier than most games of this genre but it still can kick your ass if you're not paying attention.

It's still worth playing nowadays as nothing compares to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050993432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5220, 'last_played': 1638419588}
review: This is probably the best RPG I have played. Its fun, easy to mod, and hard, just the way I like it.  It has a lot of replayability within the main game, and even more with the DLCs and Steam Workshop.  There can be some confusion at first with what everything does because it is not explained very well, but once you play a little bit, it's not that bad. Overall a great game, I'd rate 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019766208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1516285480}
review:
This game is awesome!

Rouglike Turn based RPG like no other. There is alot of combinations for your hero skill which could lead to terrible and very OP charactes. I suggest you search the webz for some if you are begginer since it would help alot.

Gameplay is obvious you will explore dungeons. Kill monsters and get alot of loot. Well sometimes monsters will kill you (sometimes more often). And of course you will level up and get more awesome skills. Thats all plain and simple.

Best thing about this game is how funny and meta it is. If you are scifi/fantasy and movies/books fan you will have a blast even from small things like what monsters say etc.

For the price is no brainer. Buy, kill monsters die, laugh and repeat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032206548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1644468870}
review:
While not perfect, this game is a pretty good take on the roguelike genre. The loot pool consists of a much larger amount of items than you would need in any one play through, to the point where you eventually start looting things based on what you expect to need for your skill set (which... can be frustrating, as the only way to learn how to not spend most of your run sorting inventory involves already knowing what will be useful and what wont).


The main sort of gimmick behind DoD is that you get to pick all of your basic class skills at the start of the run (or hit random because it leads to some really interesting, unorthodox combinations). You know and can plan in advance for exactly what spells you will unlock, and what level to unlock them at. Some of the skills are balanced rather poorly, but due to the sheer amount of them (especially with the DLC), and the wide variety of gameplay offered by all of the strange synergies within the skill system is something that probably can't be properly balanced (so many skills effect others in unpredictable ways, so you get stuff like double-shield fist fighters, necromancers with high dodge and counter attack with heavy maces, or hammer + sickle dual wield communists).


This game wanted to do call back to classics like NetHack, Rogue, and Angband while still doing its own very modern thing, which it managed to do while also focusing on very self aware humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021619738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1031, 'last_played': 1687702924}
review:
Отличная игра, огромное количество лута прекрасно подходит для любителей подбора статов.
Советую играть с подключённым интернетом, иначе можно потерять сейв.
Огромное количество навыков и возможностей.
Большое спасибо разработчикам за «бездонный»карман, который здорово помогает сохранить любой предмет до конца игры.
Для первого старта подойдёт стандартный воин,а потом уже можно пройтись и по рандомному подбору классов.
Совершенно не жалею о покупке данной игры, советую всем любителям рандома и веселья.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999921146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 423, 'playtime_forever': 1915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1915, 'last_played': 1511024277}
review:
Un ROGUE-Like plaisant avec des graphismes certes pas exeptionnels mais corrects et une difficulté bien présente. L'interface n'est pas toujours très ergonomique (pour les crafts notamment et la taille des caractères) et j'ai eu un peu de mal à bien cerner toutes les informations.

Pour les amateurs du genre, il me semble qu'il a de quoi les contenter. Personnellement, malgré plusieurs tentatives, je n'ai pas réussi à vaincre Lord Dredmor.

Le prix, DLC compris, est très abordable. Si en plus il y a une promotion n'hésitez pas à essayer ce ROGUE-Like. Le jeu est en Anglais, mais finallement celà ne gène pas trop.

review: An extremely quirky roguelike that I already love to bits. Full of a nice mix of humor and goading that get you to press on, no matter how tough it may get. The writing and mechanics are both fantastic, I particularly enjoy how the potions are always the same, but the effects are never told to you, you have to try them and then remember what they do in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040856223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2018, 'last_played': 1605643274}
review:
Heeey, endlich ein Spiel das seinem Genre gerecht wird, allein dafür gibts ne' Medaille.

Aber mal ernsthaft, von den zehntausend Spielen, die als Rogue-like gekennzeichnet sind, gibt es lediglich eine Hand voll, auf die diese Bezeichnung zutrifft und Dungeons of Dredmor ist eines davon.

Zum Gameplay lässt sich nicht viel sagen, entweder man mag es oder nicht. Ich hab es auf jeden Fall gemocht und Replayvalue ist wegen der vielen Charaktere, Skilloptionen und DLC auch vorhanden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089110753', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 6471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6248, 'last_played': 1514223429}
review:
i think this appeals to a certain type of rogue+like person.  at first, i played this game and i loved.  i loved that there was an indiana jones-based skill tree, the freedom and creativity.  i sped through my first character to the final boss, and got slaughtered.  i started grinding for more xp, leveld up several times, went back down, got slaughtered again.  beat the boss by kiting him and using none of my skills, but rather my arrows and other things. overall, not very fun.

then i started another character, thinking i learned from my mistakes.  nope, got slaughtered again.  now i don't have the willpower to try this all over again, since the game is essentially 9.5 levels of grinding, plus one crazy insane boss.  i can only imagine what its like on the permadeath mode.

even if someone told me the way to kill the final boss without being slaughtered, im not sure i would since the gameplay is so slow and derivative after one playthrough.  it is by no means a terrible game, and i probably would suggest it for a cheap price or for those who think they are interested, but i just did not have that much fun, to be honest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000833782', 'num_games_owned': 498, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1543325873}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. I like roguelikes, and this is a modern, nice-looking one that seems to have the right level of complexity. I've tried to play it a number of times over the years and I always bounce off immediately. The interface is bad. It doesn't know what the game wants to be. It lets you move your character from tile to tile with the arrows like any other roguelike, but most things you do in the game require you to use the mouse.

There's an option to perform certain tasks, like attack enemies and open doors, with the arrow keys, but (a) it's insane that attacking enemies by walking into them isn't the default, this is a ROGUELIKE, and (b) activating items by walking into them doesn't feel natural. I accidentally activate items I don't want to. Just give me a use key.


The game description says "Classic Roguelike gameplay with the sweet, refreshing taste of point-and-click interfaces. No longer must you press CTRL-ALT-SHIFT-x to drink a potion." But this isn't any better. It's the interface of an action RPG without the action. Just give me intuitive, well-designed menus that I can access with the keyboard, or god forbid, a controller! Being able to do most (but not all) things you need to do with the keyboard but then having to click the mouse to pick up an item, dismiss a dialog box, or access your inventory is incredibly frustrating.

I'd recommend Fatal Labyrinth over this. It's $2 cheaper, and despite coming out 2 decades earlier, it feels a lot better to play than this game. Arrow keys or D-Pad plus three buttons. Your inventory is nicely arranged by item type. It's a little basic, but it doesn't feel like the mutant offspring of a roguelike and an ARPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060938708', 'num_games_owned': 56, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 8392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1946, 'last_played': 1602629226}

author: {'steamid': '76561198079992988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1577, 'last_played': 1511820004}
review:
== Medium Length Review ==
Hi folks! 
This is my review to "Dungeons of Dredmor" ("DOD") . So what's this game about? 
In short, it is a classic, turn-based hack 'n' slay RPG / dungeon crawler with retro-style, pixelated graphics.

The main story is as simplistic as it is uninspired: You are the hero ( or heroine) who has to slay the evil king who is in charge of the (also evil) dungeons and you shall bring an end to its (ever-so evil) reign of evil.

In order to do that, you first decide which kind of class or class-combination you want to play. After choosing the corresponding skills, you are ready to go and you start at the first of (up to) 15 dungeon levels.

The dungeon levels of the game are arranged in a semi-random order, meaning that they are generated differently each time you play the game, though certain elements stay the same which you will recognize pretty fast.

In order to fight of your evil opponents, you can resort to melee attacks, ranged attacks with throwing or shooting weapons or you can finally resort to magic attacks of different kinds. Since - of course - the enemies get tougher with every level, you will need to look out for all kinds of loot after slaying the enemies, use the built-in crafting system or buy new stuff in the "shops" where you can also sell your outdated gear.

That pretty much covers the basic gameplay. Suffice it to say that the dungeon is not only covered with enemies, but also with deadly traps and some (very tiny) puzzles. You can optionally also take on side-quests which will reward you with some extra loot like a special unique weapon.
Depending on the initial difficulty setting you have chosen, you will be able to save the game and reload your save game after dying or your character will be permanently erased,  once killed. Also, you can choose whether you will be able to return to earlier levels by "going back up" (which helps a lot) or you will be forced to play the game "rogue-like" (which is much tougher).

So now let's have a closer look at the good and bad aspects of the game. Let's start with the good ones:

1) There are many classes to choose from and each class has different skills you can choose. 

2) The general mood of the game is funny. You will find a *lot* of references to other titles,  
movies, etc. etc. in the game and if you like this kind of "nerdy humor" (which I do), you will probably find that this is one of the best aspects of the game.

3) The crafting system is quite okay (though needlessly cumbersome to use).

4) There are a lot of mods for the game which you can use to blow some fresh wind through the dusty dungeon if you get tired of the original game.

So, why did I not recommend this game, you might ask?
So let's look at the things I did not like about this game:

1) The game is extremely repetitive. I know - that is to be expected for a turn-based game and I do not mind that, but combined with the fact that most of the time the full extent of "strategy" you have to use to overcome your enemies is just to click on them for a melee attack, that gets boring way too fast.

2) If you want to play the game on a higher difficulty level, be warned: Once permanent death is turned on, it can get very frustrating. Although the general difficulty seems to be okay, you sometimes end up being killed "out of the blue" after playing straight for hours without ever losing more than a quarter of your health points before. The problem is that once you get to realize you are in trouble this time, it is almost too late. If you chose a sub-optimal combination of classes and skills, you will not be able to run away from the fight and will simply be battered to death by your enemies. Yes, you could argue that this is only a problem if you play on higher difficulty settings, but it is also worth to consider this when looking at the next point:

3) A single "run" thought the dungeon (at 15 levels) takes way too long - especially when playing this game rogue-like. If you are playing carefully (mind pain point 2) and you collect a lot of loot, then you are in for a lot of tedious inventory management and walking back and forth. A complete run at lower difficulties may cost you up to 20 hours, not to mention higher difficulty settings. So now imagine your frustration of carefully grinding for 20 or even more hours just to fall victim to a stupid trap + enemy combination...

4) A lot of the in-game mechanics are not explained very well or are not explained at all (also not in the tutorial). This can lead to very frustrating moments in the game when you have just activated a new skill (with just an ominous explanation text to it which gives no real clue on what it truly does) and then finally realize that you do not know how to use it. The game gives you no kind of explanation or hints whatsoever.  I played one run with rogue-class, buying a skill which seemingly "revealed all hidden items" which never had any kind of effect during may play-through at all, although it was activated. This pain point might sound trivial, but if you choose the wrong classes / skills, your "hero" will be pathetic up to the bitter end.

5) There is no real skill tree. Skills of one category can only be activated linearly, meaning you cannot activate the last skill in the "tree" without having activated all others first. The problem is that many skills sound much better than they actually are, and - which is even more unnerving - you sometimes have to activate three or even four useless skills just to get a decent one.

6) The final boss / bosses of the game can be very challenging if you do not prepare for the final fight from the very start. I will not spoil this for you, but suffice it to say that some classes will have a *very* hard time beating the boss, even if they have been maxed out. Also suffice it to say that the final boss can deal out a lot of more damage with single hits than any other enemy can, so be warned!

7) This point weighs most heavily for me: The combat system is too simplistic. If you play with a fighter or rogue-class, then all you ever do is hack and slay. There is almost no kind of strategy whatsoever required to progress through the game as long as you collect the strongest gear and do not let yourself get surrounded by too many enemies at a time. Since all enemies behave somewhat identical with only little exceptions (some enemies can indeed use ranged attacks against you - imagine that!), that makes the game too boring way too fast.

8) (Auto-)Saving and Loading takes surprisingly long. 

9) During my 20-hour play-through, the game crashed multiple times for no apparent reason.

10) The soundtrack of the game gets boring very quickly. There are too few songs and the music is way to repetitive.

So what is the verdict?
DOD is - all in all - a mediocre game. It is not "bad" but it certainly isn't good or great either. It makes me wish that steam would offer a third, "neutral" recommendation. 
But since it doesn't, I am forced to not recommend this game. The retro-style artwork and humor of the game is good, but it cannot make up for the boring and tedious game play. In any case you should not be required to look up how skills work in a wiki to get a basic understanding of them. 

If you are heavily interested in mods, this game might be for you, after all, but I cannot really consider this fact in this review of the basic game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985207656', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1555994214}
review:
-Started game with intention of stealing loot from Diggle gods.
-Picked random skills with absolutely no logical sense of interaction.
-Random skills worked surprisingly well together in illogical combinations.
-Fought Diggles and so much more.
-Nearly died to aforementioned Diggles and so much more.
-Healed up and reminded self to tread carefully and safely.
-Immediately found a teleportation pad.
-Without hesitation, leapt upon teleportation pad.
-Appeared in room full of Diggles.
-Backed away very slowly, realizing Diggle Doom is at hand.
-Diggles surge forward, intent upon stealing my loot for the Diggle gods.
-Sacrificed to the Diggle gods via horde of looting Diggles.

10/10 - Would have my loot stolen for the Diggle gods again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089494976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 7011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7011, 'last_played': 1511577276}
review:
I give this game my highest thumbs up, but I must admit that would not have been the case had I reviewed it when I first tried it more than a year ago. At that time I found the game to be not too hard but too repetitive. All the floors, I thought, had a sameness to them, despite being randomly generated. So I quit and put the game aside.

Recently, bored of what I was playing, I decided to give DofD another try. My new first impression was that the text was way too small, so I fiddled with the resolution until it was more readable. That may have been part of the problem in my previous run- I could not see all the detail, thus did not understand much of the content.

So I restarted were I left off and made it to the final level, but Lord Dredmore just kicked my butt. That's when I really started studying up, reading  the forums and guides, learning the stats, memorizing the effects of shrooms, etc. There should be a University PhD of Dredmor for all the stuff you need to learn to be good at this game. I am still a Redshirt Freshman but enjoying the ride.

I started a new character with a build designed exclusively to beat Lord Dredmor. If I can handle him then I can deal with anything else that comes along the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093230223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 6096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2114, 'last_played': 1586120504}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986624324', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1355731200}
review:
Explorar os calabouços é muito divertido, eles estão cheios de monstros, armadilhas e itens para serem coletados. Os gráficos estão bem legais, o personagem principal se move, ataca, recebe danos e é atingidos pelas armadilhas. Já os monstros é um ponto negativo do jogo, não pela dificuldade ou variedade e sim pela caracterização, enfrentar monstrinhos coloridos, sem um tema definido é muito ruim e acredito que foi a unica mancada da Gaslamp (produtora do game.)
Eles são uma mescla de passarinhos coloridos, gosmas, tamagochi,  lulas, e até monstros mascarados.
Acredito que a decisão de usar monstros neste estilo, foi a premissa de humor que eles decidiram por no game, eu sou contra, acredito que o humor utilizado nos textos, falas dos monstros e até nas mensagens como por exemplo quando o personagem morre, e na tela aparece "Congratulations! You have Died" é um tipo de humor muito mais interessante do que trocar os tradicionais monstros dos jogos com temática fantasia medieval por monstrinhos coloridos que mais parecem exportados do desenho animado pokemon.
Já os itens, equipamentos e armas estão bem produzidos, bem variados também, assim como um jogo do gênero roguelike pede. Usando-os percebemos um UP no personagem e isso incentiva o jogador a explorar cada aposento das masmorras atrás de mais  e mais itens.
Os efeitos sonoros são muito bons, as musicas enjoam um pouco, mas não compromete, afinal tem o botão de volume, assim podemos abaixar a música do game e explorar o jogo ouvindo mp3 (assim como a maioria dos players que jogam roguelike faz).
Dungeons of Dreadmor foi uma grata surpresa, apesar dos poucos pontos negativos é divertido ao extremo e vale cada centavo. Eu não esperava um game tão puramente roguelike quando vi os screenshots.

http://nerdone.blogspot.com.br/2011/10/dungeons-of-dredmor-analise-review.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198060942356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1205, 'last_played': 1370202717}
review:
One of my favorite rouge-likes ever. Classes, humour, varied items, and all the other rouge-like charms give enough variation that you'll want to come back again and again. 
Like other rouge-likes you'll have that deep run that ends in death then start over the next day just to die on the first level and QUIT FOREVER.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073092169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 619, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1682021163}
review: ok

author: {'steamid': '76561198047292749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4319, 'last_played': 1510290502}
review:
Very fun but it is unplayable on Mac because of a few bugs that break stats on later levels.  I looked to see if the developers were addressing the bugs but it seems like the last major discussion about these bug issues were on 2014 so it seems like developer support for the game (at least on Mac) is doesn't exist.  

I do not recommend this game if you are a Mac user.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043219500', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1512194090}
review:
I found this game completely underwhelming. After an hour, nothing made me want to continue. The game tries way too hard to make everything funny. Calling the currency "zorkmid" is not funny - it's annoying. But besides that, the gameplay is simply not deep. Sure, there are like 40 different stats and a million different items and crafting and whatever, but there are not clear strategic decisions that you need to make, and the tactics are quite bland.

Compare this to Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup (DCSS), where the graphics are quite primitive but it is extremely well balanced and it feels like a real challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994971635', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1943, 'last_played': 1509594720}
review: Very well done roguelike.  Creative and witty descriptions of everything build a universe that feels "used" in the best way possible.  A must play for the adventurer of the century.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273254344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1509500014}
review:
Weird and quirky, yet fun and satisfying.  I'm having a difficult time comparing this to another game because it's rather unique... but maybe if you took an action RPG and made an indie version of it that's rogue-like and technically turn-based, you'd had Dungeons of Dredmor.

Only negatives I can see is inventory management and too many items.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035371396', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1912, 'last_played': 1682774235}
review:
Я напишу ревью сейчас, пока у моих друзей есть возможность взять эту игру с отличной скидкой. :)

[h1]Что это такое?[/h1]
Игра DoD предлагает вам рандомно генерируемое приключение в подземельях. Каждый раз, начиная игру заново, вы будете оказываться в новых интересных условиях. Знаете, какого слова обычно недостаёт в других подобных играх? [i]"Интересных"[/i]. Мне эта игра внешне сразу не зашла. Много текста, странная графика, шутки повсюду. Но стоило попробовать, как сразу стало понятно, что за этим стоит великолепная, очень обдуманная система — а шутки не такие уж снобские. Эта игра не сложная, но настолько глубокая, насколько можно представить, услышав слова "случайно создаваемые приключения".

[h1]Пять причин поиграть в DoD:[/h1]
• Огромная вариативность. Просто "случайности" нам неинтересны — интересно именно ощущение новизны, исследования, комбинаций разных вещей. Обычно подобные игры выдают тебе в случайном порядке три-пять однородных, скучных действий. Здесь случайные уровни создаются так, что ими даже можно любоваться. Это не скучные коридоры, въющиеся с разной длинной — это десятки комнат на одном этаже, каждая из которых действительно умудряется иметь своё лицо.
• Игра может быть очень лёгкой и очень сложной. Этот выбор вам подконтролен. Не хотите грызть гранит, но хотите приключений — пожалуйста. Хотите, чтобы комичность ситуаций доходила до абсурда, а смерть приходила минут через 10 — тоже есть.
• Действительно большой выбор механик. Да, крафтинг и рандомные комнаты только что в тетрис ещё не добавили, но от этого не начинает казаться, что у тебя интересное и разнообразное приключение. Здесь же... хотите выращивать грибы? Телепортироваться в другое, тайное измерение? Колдовать, драться без оружия? Это только то, что мне выпало при рандомном создании персонажа. Вы можете собрать всё сами или набросать себе что-то другое. И скиллы, которые я пробовал, не ощущаются как наскоро пришитая и ненужная скучная вещь. Для всего нашли своё место.
• Игра недорогая. Особенно на распродажах.
• Если есть сила воли, можно легко поиграть 15 минут, не заскучать и закрыть до следующего раза. Если депрессия или идёт игровой стрим, то играйте два часа — и, наверное, не надоест.

[h1]Минусы.[/h1]
• Без понимания английского здесь делать нечего. Игра шутит, крутит, придуряется и обучает; интуитивно разобраться было бы сложно. Есть любительский перевод части игры, я его не пробовал. Гуглил по "Dungeons of Dreadmore перевод на русский".
• Графика и анимация всё-таки немного утомляют. Они и недостаточно плавные, и при этом броские. Глаза немного устают на 23'' мониторе.

====

Я сильно сомневался, брать или нет — собирался возвращать. На видео мне игра сразу не понравилась. Но в итоге я выключил музыку, хорошо поиграл пару часов и понял, почему ревью на неё — Overwhelmingly Positive. Это просто настолько хорошо сделано как игра, система так хорошо работает, что трудно ей не увлечься и не любоваться.

Что-то такое я представляю себе, когда думаю о "каждый раз разное приключение".
По впечатлениям от первых часов: палец очень сильно вверх.

P.S.
1) моё видео, перевод оригинального туториала на русский: https://youtu.be/yt0_XHjEkag
2) я запускаю игру и прохожу небольшой кусок, поясняя, что к чему:
https://youtu.be/9DwxJ49-_ls

author: {'steamid': '76561198053062834', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2531, 'last_played': 1553129745}
review:
I am usually not a fan of rogue like games, but this one definitely is one of the few exceptions for me. The game has a great sense of humor to it, lit's of classes that actually make replaying kind if refreshing and fun, which was very nice to me since dying frequentry in games and having to start over is usually very frustrating for me. 

Sometimes the game does crash, but it doesn't happen frequently enough for me to stop playing. It was also pause for a few seconds to autosave, which can be a bit annoying, but again not enough for me to stop playing. 

I highly do recommend this game, can be good to pass 30 minutes to several hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131130492', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1506754409}
review:
I really wanted to like this game... I REALLY DID... 
It looked like it would remind me of Chocobo's Dungeon 2.
It is kinda like that, but it's waaay too much going on at once.
The dungeons are randomized, okay that's not bad. 
The graphics aren't buggy and I found no issues with the game running.
There's no controller support, which I thought about setting up one on xpadder but it would've been worse playing that way with the layout of the controls.
Your character is a mess of a million different stats that don't make sense. You want a wizard to wield a great axe? By all means, go ahead, this game isn't gonna stop you... But if you want to use mushrooms you gotta have the skill. So inconsistant! 
Then, you constantly run into the same two monsters which drop a plethora of items so your inventory is full before you finish half the map on the first floor. Where's the pleasure in getting everything you need EVER before getting into the game?
You pray for side quests, which they make no effort to tell you anything about them, and when you finish it(if you even figure out wtf they meant), it doesn't feel very gratifying. 
There's random "graffiti" on the walls in which they tell you to write down somewhere because they didn't program your character to have the capacity of learned knowledge, so I wrote the ones I found down, then never found anything for which I needed them.
What is the goal, anyway? Oh, yeah, the beginning cutscene explains it in a massive paragraph that I didn't differenciate between a loading screen and plot so I missed it. I think you're going after some evil or getting treasure or something dull, I'm guessing because the game never shows any indication of explaination for anything.
There's an option for permadeath... Why would you do that to yourself? Roguelike games are made so when you have to start over, there's perks from playing before. Is the perk slowly figuring out wtf you're supposed to be doing besides killing a bunch of blobs, ducks, and bats? 
There's random stuff that constantly happens, like an anvil that when you put an item on it, it either is pleased with you and makes it better, or not and I dunno what happens because the 5 times I found the anvils, they were always pleased.
There's statues that you can break that give you a lot more exp than an actual fight... for apparently no reason "heroic vandalism".
There's been one monster that I ran into that was actually hurting me (and I mean like it changed my facial portrait once). I'm assuming it was a boss monster, and it gave me ten times the amount of exp than a regular monster, but nothing happened. Was it supposed to be a bigger fight for no reason?
I gained 7 levels before exiting the first floor, and in those levels, I figured out that the skill tiers felt more and more meaningless as time went on... I picked the banker atribute thinking "Okay, money skill, must be important..." NOPE!
There's a shop that tells you that you can pick up stuff without paying for it, then you can't even fight the shopkeeper when he "stops" you from leaving(He blocks the only entrance/exit to the room and you can't move past him). You also can't travel to another demension in the shop. I got stuck in the shop because I sold an item and filled his tables, but I picked up an item I didn't pay for and I dropped it on the ground but he still wouldn't move and I couldn't afford anything else to put it back on a table because I JUST STARTED and the item I sold only gave me like 10 coins. I had to restart. I later learned you could quick sell and not take up tablespace in the shop... WOULD'VE BEEN NICE TO KNOW!
I tried using my get a loan skill that was in the corner of my screen, nothing happened. Still never figured out how to make that work.
I'm not going to do a pros and cons because my rant is far too long for that to even matter.
It would be great with some tutorials and a better movement system that would make you interact with something by walking into it instead of just walking into it 
i.e. if you use the arrow keys to move, you'll step on traps, but if you click on it, you can attempt to disarm the traps... WHICH ARE EVERYWHERE so if you use the arrow keys, you'll likely die from traps, leading to a TON of clicking to move, which is incredibly arduous. (PLEASE PLEASE play Chocobo's Dungeon 2 for psx, that controller layout was fantastic and it's such a better game)
OR If you find a treasure chest, or a door, you can't open them by walking itno them... The treasure chest you just walk through, and you just don't move with the door. 
Okay, this was waaaay longer than I anticipated. This game deserves a 2/10. I could see where you were going, but this feels very unfinished. If this were early access, I could understand and wouldn't have been so harsh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084577486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1505145925}
review:
If this game had controller support I would be all about it.  I am not a fan of the keyboard/mouse combo of controls in this game.  It doesn't feel good to me but I am not a fan of keyboard/mouse for these types of games anyway.  It was my mistake buying it knowing this wasn't a feature.

I also am not a fan at the insane amount of trait choices when creating a character.  I would rather a more direct and rigid approach rather than such an open set of choices.  The game really feels like it could be amazing I just can't get past these issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012672954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6822, 'last_played': 1545590622}
review: I was curious to see what would happen if I attempted to put a Horadric Lutefisk cube inside itself, so I gave it a go. It burst into flames and killed me. 10/10 would create a paradox and set fire to myself again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999018200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 17632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12066, 'last_played': 1516049716}
review:
[h1] TL:DR Imagine if your favourite comedian was also a nuclear physicist. [/h1]

It's taken me a while to write this review - because I CAN'T STOP PLAYING.

[i] Thou art a pimple on the dungeon floor! [/i]

I used to play a dungeon based game called Larn when I should have been studying. In those days PCs only had two colours and in that game walls were portrayed using the '#' and 'U' was reserved for a creature called Umber Hulk. The little 'g' was a creature called Gelatinous Cube. I hated that guy. The whole world was built using key board characters which allowed your imagination to flourish. Cue deep romantic sigh.

30 years later we define games like Larn as part of the Roguelike genre and happily for all of us Steam has a pretty good collection.

Dungeons of Dredmor has quite a few roguelike elements. 

[i] Thine eyebrows cannot protect you this time! [/i]

Random dungeons, loot, knocking down doors, permanent death and save game wipe, cash to buy things from shops, turn based combat, funky music, a heavy eye browed hero, pointy hats, wands, an archaeologist...hmm.

Let's just say there is a lot here and some things can be turned off, like the perma-death or reduced, like game difficulty.

Another thing to note is that the game is simple to play but diabolically difficult to beat. In 200 hours I managed to beat the evil Lord Dredmor...once.

I liked the following elements:

Character creation: Choose your skills or have them randomly assigned. Concentrate on the standard Fighter, Mage, Rogue areas or just go crazy. 

[i] You do know I am at least five levels above you! [/i]

The Archaeology class includes the ability to send an artefact to the giant, secret scary government room full of boxes, and gain experience equal to its value.

The Blood Magic class includes the ability to pour your blood and soul into a secret hidden thing when you can tap when the need is greatest - or whenever you fancy a nip of forbidden sanguine juices.

It's nuts and I love it. Part of the problem in this game is figuring out what anything does. My current guy is concentrating on Polearms as his melee option and has completed the Very Long Stick Damage Enhance Training. How funny words translate to real dungeon mechanics can be a nightmare to figure out.

Graphics and Sound: It's very bright and loud. Simple stuff. Almost annoying. Deceptive because you often walk around the dungeon having a fun time then wallop! - you have one health point left.

Crafting: Look simple but pure crazy. Tinkering, Smithing, Alcheming, Pressing, Making Potioning and Wands. You can cultivate mushrooms and other fungus on dead bodies. It's almost like its own minigame. 

Monster zoo: It's a room filled with monsters. Filled to the brim. Each level from the second onwards has a zoo and behind every door that opens, might be a zoo. 

[i] We have ways of making you talk! [/i]

Panic? Yes
Ran away like a coward? Yes.
Came back and died? Yes and yes.
Tried to avoid? Yes.

The character screen itself is hideously complex. There are loads of stats defining your character and many more little symbols defining the various resistances. 

Let's just say I don't always know what things do. It's the biggest problem in the game. Behind all the fun and simple gameplay we have this nuclear physicist busting a gut working through all sorts of complex formula and statistics. The game is almost bursting through its seams.

[i] You walk like an undead turkey! [/i]

And I love it.

I also recommend Don't Starve and Dungeon of the Endless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003908255', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1937, 'last_played': 1459719058}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198064563168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1623, 'last_played': 1549934532}
review:
Overall 9/10

This game is definitely a wonderful surprise. The Character Customization, Randomly Generated levels, Choice of which skills to level and plethora of loot make this game something worth giving a try. it is a Square-like movement that has enemies move once after you move once, but is nearly instantaneous after your movement. This board like movement is important for placement for your type of character you made.

Pros:
- Tons of Replay Value
- Simple Yet Difficult
- Options for Higher Difficulty
- Hundreds of Skill combinations in Character Development
- Can See a list of your past Explorers to remember the best of your best
- Expansions

Cons:
- Needs Recommended Builds for beginners
- Takes Time and Testing to figure out what Skills do as they can be unexplained to their actual purpose

Overall this fun game at this Price Point is well worth your time. Customization and Strategy make this a fun game to remember.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109439672', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1592404734}
review:
[h1] ASPECTOS DO JOGO [/h1]

O jogo em si é muito bom. Um magnífico exemplo de jogos Roguelike e RPG. Muito fiel à esses gêneros.

Inimigos bem diversificados, alguns exclusivos de cada nível (ou andar, como você quiser chamar). Você só tem que tomar cuidado com [b]OS MONSTERS ZOO[/b] e alguns inimigos fortes demais para você, [spoiler]Como os que você pode encontrar usando os Endereços Arcanos.[/spoiler]

A customização de personagens é algo muito interessante no jogo, já que há várias possibilidades de combinações. Algo que é quase obrigatório em um jogo de RPG.

Algo muito bom que Dungeons of Dredmor traz é a possibilidade de uso de mods. Ele tem integração à Steam Workshop, o que torna o jogo mais diversificado do que já é. Os mods podem trazer tanto skills novas quanto monstros. Isso depende muito de qual mod você usar.

[h1] PREÇO [/h1]

O preço é algo magnífico para este jogo, está muito barato pelo o que ele oferece. Na minha concepção, o preço poderia até subir um pouco, até mais ou menos R$15,00...

[i]OBS: Na data na qual eu publiquei está análise, Dungeons of Dredmor custava R$8,49[/i]

[h1] VALE A PENA? [/h1]

Sim, vale [b]SUPER[/b] a pena. Pelo preço e pelo o que ele oferece... Eu recomendo para qualquer um que goste de jogos RPG e Roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970934254', 'num_games_owned': 460, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1505628584}
review:
I know, I know, many gamers feel every game should be recommended and liked. However, if every game only got accolades, then the review process would be somewhat worthless.

While this game may be for great for most, for me it wasn't and here's why.

Pros:
- Many different skills and play styles
- Three difficulties
- Can turn perma-death off
- Saving
- Extremely difficult final boss--even on the easiest difficulty

Cons:
- Some of the skills are weak, and if you don't pick some of the good skills you are severely handicapped.
- Speed is either to slow or fast
- If your player noticed a trap, they should auto try to disarm when moving, stop movement, or prompt you to proceed
- Resolution makes it hard to tell icons and read text--this may be solve if playing on a 32" monitor, however, a 15" laptop screen is challenging
- The use of chokes makes it way easier, however, a bit boring
- The controls just feel weird
- Crafting is a pain--you can only craft 1 highlighted item, not select anything on the screen
- What seems random isn't, the rooms can be memorized (trap locations, items, etc)
- Inventory is small, and there are a lot of items
- I missed the humor part, didn't seem funny

author: {'steamid': '76561197960440131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1504684038}
review:
Kinda fun game, but suffers from a clusterf*** interface.  

So here's how the game works.  You start out on a somewhat massive floor that's been randomly generated and filled with monsters.  Every time you click or move a square, you'll use a turn.  The gameplay somewhat resembles Diablo 2, but the developer went nuts and made the whole interface a mess.  You custom generate a character with something like 6 skills you choose.  Every time you advance a level, you can improve one of these skills.  

Here's where things turn into a mess.  The character sheet has something like 30-50 stats that you can increase.  You have no idea what 90% of them do, but every item or skill will improve or lower several of them.  The major difference between this and Diablo 2 is that Diablo 2 stopped at 4 resistances and 5-6 stats.  Dungeons of Dredmore has 50 and it bundles them altogether in one cramped section that gives you a headache just looking at it.  

Because of what I mentioned above, the skill system is completely meaningless. I have no idea what would be a good thing to level up. Unless I spend an hour deciphering the stat screen, which I don't plan to do.  

Same problem with items.  I just find the most expensive item and equip it...  I have no idea what is "good" in this game.  

Another problem is the flavorless monotony that is the gameplay.  You are dropped into the middle of a floor full of monsters and have to clear it.  Then you go onto the next floor and do the same thing.  Then the next and the next.  In Diablo 2 they had some storyline to break up the monster killing.  Stories about this horrible monster and that horrible monster.  However, Dungeons of Dredmor has NONE of that.  Just one floor of monsters after the next.  

On a technical note, when you start the game for the first time, the game will let you set whatever resolution you like including ones WAY OVER your monitor's capibility.  If you do this, the buttons at the top of the screen won't be visible and you'll be stuck at the main menu until you fix the resolution.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296532886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 16007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4018, 'last_played': 1686311951}
review:
强烈推荐的硬派沙盒DOD游戏。可以搭配的内容太丰富了！
笔者游戏时间远估计在100小时左右，steam上是补正后的时间~这个游戏时间可能是笔者这种20年游戏年龄中很少达到的，毕竟玩过的游戏太多，所以大部分游戏的吸引力不足。由此可见这款游戏的魅力！
鉴于如此好游戏的推广度太低，决定写点东西。相关百度贴吧已经无人打理了。
入门这些东西就不赘述了。多死两次就晓得~（笑）

刚刚用一个魔武build（BUFF物理近战）人物通关。
核心在于双持dual配合维京viking+埃及Egpyptian的BUFF技能，其实就是Viking的1，5技能以及Egpyptian的5,6技能配合以及增强双持的高伤害。尤其埃及的6技能，虽然没太搞清楚机制，但是明显使得近战攻击具有大范围伤害。再次就是发现维京的4技能，BUG一样的存在。
这次通关笔者感觉加点顺序有问题，（由于考虑到耗蓝问题，所以埃及的最后一个技能出的太晚），导致前期就是个近战，没有群攻技能。所以打算这次调整搭配，再来一次，看看前期出埃及的最后一个技能的效果如何。
P.S.维京的4技能简直就是BUG的存在，不清楚其作用机制是不是与力量属性挂钩。反正笔者用它几乎没有怪物能抵抗其恐惧效果的（眩晕效果不明显），尤其大家关心的BOSS，最多吼两声，BOSS就开始跑，跟着其到墙角，就任您蹂躏了，当然，记得插几下就再吼两声接着插~（笑）。

author: {'steamid': '76561198237369574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 7121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1697381626}
review: 发现忘记评测了~很久之前就已经玩盗版玩得不亦乐乎，补票之后即使没中文也很好玩（当然希望有）

author: {'steamid': '76561197991157647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 7920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7820, 'last_played': 1702884531}
review:
Oookay so it's fun and I've spent a lot of time on the game. The humor is amusing for awhile and trying out all the ability choices is fun and trying to see how far you can get is also fun.

It's fun enough to justify buying the game in fact. Buuut I do have some criticisms.

So the gameplay itself seems to take a long time. You can increase the speed of the game but it makes you very vulnerabile to stepping on traps. This means if you are playing non-tanky classes or non-thief classes you will need to constantly throttle the speed so you can progress faster and still stay safe from traps.

There is a shorter dungeons option but it's not as good as it seems. They seem to add a lot more monster zoos to compensate for the lack of dungeon space to space out the monster spawns and give you enough experience points. But after doing your 10th monster zoo this way it starts to feel repetitive.

Lastly, there's the skill descriptions. They are funny and all but when you replace actually telling us what something does with just 'humorous descriptions' that don't tell us anything it becomes frustrating. I need to open up the wiki to get the actual information on what some of these skills do.

But it's all about your playstyle and this game accounts for MANY playstyles. I could play a tanky melee warrior and have the game speed on near full throttle while laughing at traps. I could play a wizard who slowly but steadily grows in power and progresses through the dungeons to become a force to be reckoned with, or a thief who uses cunning to widdle away his or her enemies. Or I can mix and match or pick some seemingly incompatible build just to see how far I can get lol.

There are multiple crafting systems in this game if that's your thing too. But if it's not your thing, you can ignore it like it doesn't exist except minus some of the food crafting (which is easy enough). You can even set the auto loot rules to not pick things up that you don't care about (though you can vendor everything)

Aside from the flaws, it really is a fun game and after spending 130+ hours playing it I will go back for more every now and then.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007614870', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1425692826}
review: This game has its moments, both of interesting tactical combat and funny jokes (or is it the overabundance of jokes that’s funny?). However it plays too slow compared to classic roguelikes, and their dungeon generation is pretty bad compared to those. Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup in particular has an interesting variety of rooms; Dredmor’s levels feel jumbled together. I think having detailed graphics for everything unfortunately reinforces the perception of a big mess. Also their stat system is ridiculous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029413779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2441, 'last_played': 1521329405}
review:
When I bought this on a whim after waking up early on a day off I expected to play one life and go back to bed. Instead a drill monster called me an n'wah and after a couple of deaths I became an explosive-crafting necromancer who sends corpses in to finish what my explosive crossbow bolts start. This game is amazing, It's the kind of game where I'll spend half an hour in every shop I encounter, a brief check for better stats and 29 minutes of reading all the fluff text. Not only that, But it's a rouge-like game with a modern, easily accessible GUI plus a tutorial showing you how to use it. I love rougelikes, I love Cataclysm: DDA and Dwarf Fortress, ADOM and TOME. But even I'll admit that they have their moments where they feel more like projects at a data entry job than a video game. Not this one, Though. WASD, hotkeys, mouse, and you're good.

Even better, The base game with it's two expansions was bundled for $7. There's a third expansion, too. IT'S FREE. Then there's mods! It's beautiful, It's funny, It plays great, It's a great deal. Buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034463216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 18659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18364, 'last_played': 1691860077}
review:
I've had an incredible amount of fun with this game, chucking would be adventurers into the wood-chipper that is my incompetene. The game definitely has style, beyond a doubt. The music and visuals have a lot of charm to them. The skill tree takes a whole bunch of getting used to, and the relative difficulty to get equipment suitable to your character unless you luck upon finding it or get one of the crafting skills is a pretty steep curve. That said, I've sunk an incredible amount of time into this game and I have enjoyed every moment. 

I remember the first time I set foot into a Monster Party, and I just sat there, mouth agape wondering what I could do. So of course, I waded into battle and got completely crushed. Crossbows and ranged weapons are your friends, people. So are chokepoints.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006756028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1996, 'last_played': 1553371331}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a rouge-like that plays much like a DnD campaign mostly because of the length a run can take but also because of the depth of the lore.  Combining a furistic-twist on the basic magic, swords, and bows. The sheer amount 0f unique class traits, unique items, and unique spells will keep you interested for hours to come. 

Yes..Yes i understand the game is abandoned and devs will not be working to fix bugs or new content... That being said the  game was well made and I have not come across any 'bugs' as I see some people complaining out... 
 
bought the game on a whim during summer sale. Went back to get all the dlc probably the best $8 I've spent in a long time. 
A must buy for fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042771865', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1500079309}
review: Great old school style dungeon crawler. That is incredibly hard. But once you get the hang of it it is really fun

author: {'steamid': '76561198034372199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11895, 'last_played': 1658587225}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a game that tells the story of a scandinavian man (or woman!) whose life-destroying addiction to lutefisk causes him to hallucinate and causes his trip to the cellar to get some slivovitz to go horribly awry.

The hero in question, Døømgåi, is a talented swordsman, who has never let fear best him in a fight. He gets a selection of skills at the start of the game which let him delay his undoing for at least an hour or so, if you get lucky with traps.

The game features an insane amount of whacky items that are either highly humorous, or referential to games and pop culture, or both. Pair these items with your chosen skill trees and you will soon become an unstoppable force for good, until you die.

Gaslamp games is a great developer and is very in touch with the community which leads to this game having some great mods, most of them as crazy as the actual game already is.

If you like roguelikes, enjoy spending like 4 hours on a run only to lose it all, and if you're looking for a good time. Dungeons of Dredmor is a game you should check out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058736695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 11388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1642773608}
review: I have to say, this is one of the best, if not *the* best roguelike game I have ever played. It features tons of class customization, huge dungeon floors, and plenty of humor. I haven't beaten the game yet, though I have a feeling I'm gonna love it.

review: This game is lots of fun. It is one of the best rogue-likes I have played in recent memory. There are tons of combinations possible as well as many different ways to play the game. However, I have two main complaints. 1) The game just crashes sometimes. 2) If I play for more than an hour or so the game starts to lag, bad. That being said, I do enjoy playing the game. So if you enjoy rogue-likes and don't mind some sloppy coding this game is definitely for you.

review: I dislike turn based combat. A lot. It's usually a really long draining grind for anything noteworthy to happen; that includes pseudo turn based like Xenoblade and WoW, so when I say this game is good as hell, that means a lot. For $7 you get literally dozens of hours of content, jokes, and wacky weird monsters very akin to Douglas Adams's style of writing. You won't regret playing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064066770', 'num_games_owned': 607, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1684846585}
review:
[h1][b]Abandonware[/b][/h1]

This game is fun and I really like lot of concepts, it involves. Its, probably, one of most modern roguelikes, I've played so far. [b]BUT ITS SO BUGGY[/b]. EVER WITHOUT COMMUNITY DLC.

[b]Items spawn under wending machines[/b]. So - you wont be able to pick them up.
[b]Enemies appear in small rooms behind walls[/b]. Wanted to do Zoo for exp and reward? Lolnope, one enemy left behind wall. Git gud.
[b]Equipment stats dont display properly[/b]. You think, that you found fancy armor with 16 points of absorbtion? Recheck your stats - most likely, it will give you nothing!
[b]Some skills are broken as hell[/b]. If you was unlucky, when using some of buffs, you will lose your stats permanently, when they will run out. Enjoy playing with 50hp cap, ever if you had 100 one floor ago!
[b]SEGFAULTS EVERYWERE[/b]. If you was lucky before game crashed and got autosave - good for you. Otherway - enjoy grinding everything since last manual save.

Its all may be not that bad for game, that receive updates from time to time. But not this time - [b]developers of this game went bankrupt, so - there wont be any updates anymore[/b]. The game is broken and it bury down all pros, it has.
[b]Abandonware. Dont buy at any cost.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041586855', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2417, 'last_played': 1577325809}
review:
Very hard game with a steep learning curve, but extremely rewarding once you learn the system. Great for my crummy old laptop when I'm away from my desktop. Extremely replayable. 

10/10
