author: {'steamid': '76561198046052571', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1498375538}
review:
Short version: Out of the 150+ (mostly-indie) games in my Steam library. I feel that this one is the most harmed by a poor visual presentation. I generally don't mind progammer-art, but this hurts my eyes. 

Longer version:
It is what it looks like. If you dig the video and screenshots, you'll dig the game.  If not, then not.   

The linux port ...  well, it's old.  It has problems with multi-monitor setups.  You'll need to disable secondary displays before launching if you don't want it to span across all displays (you can turn them back on once the game is running). There are no settings.  There is no "fullscreen mode". It launches in an un-resizable window, maximized across all displays. It's been about five years since this game showed up on Steam for linux with no fix.  I've never attempted to launch the game on any other OS, so YMMV.

I drop in for a few minutes every year-or-so, but nothing encourages me to keep playing beyond five minutes.  I think the art style is the biggest turnoff for me.  Knowing that I'll have to keep staring at this for hours if I really want to explore the depths of this game.  I don't have anything against pixel-art (FTL and Papers Please are among my faves), but the when the low-res east-meets-west syle of the sprites, combines with the noisy background tiles, it just becomes an eyesore to me.  I hate to say this, but just looking at the game makes me feel a little queasy. Again, YMMV.

At the same time, I am certain that a lot of thought went into this game. 

I'd like to like this game more, but I'd also like to like nethack more.  I've had it for five years and I've only racked-up 30 mins. Would your money be better spent on Nethack/Vulture?  I dunno. (Note: that's a trick question.  Nethack is free, and so are old versions of Vulture). IMHO, the game's presentation is an impediment to enjoying the game's mechanics.  I was just never able to fully engage with it.

When I really get down to it, I agonized over this review more than is apparent. I found reviewing this game to be more fun, challenging, and rewarding than playing the game itself.  In the end, I spent more time writing this than I did playing it over the course of five years.  I really Don't want to leave a scathingly negative review, because this game hasn't earned one. At the same time, I don't feel it's earned a remarkably positive one. 

"Maybe it's you.  Maybe it's me.  But i think we can agree we're not meant for each other"
-- Unattributed

The game does have workshop support, so If someone can recommend a cleaned-up tileset mod, I might be able to flip to a positive review.

Also, it could use some optimization or a frame-limiter or something.  A game this simple shouldn't 100% a whole core. Nothing about this game suggests it would need more than a 50 MHZ CPU, but it will happily chew up 3 GHZ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103264863', 'num_games_owned': 1228, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 17672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3778, 'last_played': 1679344136}
review:
[h1]I Diggle It![/h1]

This review runs very long, so here's my summary: A turn-based roguelike role-playing game that is as deep as it is comical, and totally worth playing. Score 8/10.

My very long review begins here.

The first time I ever tried this game I remember going straight to the tutorial, being bored, and uninstalling it. Yes, I was being impatient. Yes, having a big library of games on Steam and elsewhere has spoiled me. Yes, I wanted fun and I wanted it now!

And a few months later when I gave this game another chance, fun was all I kept having.

Dungeons of Dredmor is an unexpected gem of turn-based, rogue-like, role-playing game goodness that is deep and deeply humorous. There is a lot to see, do, and learn, but the game is extremely gentle about easing players into its breadth. The tutorial is excellent, and really, I was hasty when I judged it.

The premise is a simple one. You must traverse the depths of a deep dungeon, build your skills, defeat a lot of monsters, build your arsenal, and explore. The dungeons are generated anew with each play, so no two plays will be the same. This includes item and enemy placement, side quests, formulas, and so on. It feels sometimes nonsensical, but it just works. Every game is its own experience; every floor a journey.

The game play is turn based and on tiles. Every step, every cast, every attack, almost every click with certain exceptions is a turn. Turns are rotated at once, so everything feels closer to real time but things only move when you do. This give a lot of room for planning your next move, or in many of my cases, getting overrun with Diggles and stranger things. Action and inventory bars at the bottom of the screen make choosing what you want to do a snap, but you can also open your backpack as well and use items on hand.

The game felt a little too big at first with so many things to collect, enemies to defeat, and places to explore, all of which are up to the player. [b]As I played I felt less overwhelmed and more curious.[/b] What would this mushroom do if I ate it? This is a flask of what? Let's drink it and see what happens!

The customization is off the charts, an absolute wealth of possibilities await when you can combine seven different skills from the [b]more than fifty skills available.[/b] None of the skills are worthless. They all have something useful to offer, and their usefulness depends entirely on how you choose to play. Ever wanted to be a clockwork armored alchemist with psychic powers, skilled thievery, and exceptional eyesight? No? Okay, cool. Be an archeologist vampire mushroom farming wand crafter with a diverse stock portfolio and no morals! Seriously! Tourism, Smithing, Mathemagic, Viking Wizardy, Fleshsmithing, and a ton of other totally weird and totally awesome skills await. You decide how to approach, and the possibilities here are vast.

Crafting in this game is fun, Alchemy, Smithing, and Tinkering seem to have especially deep possibilities. You have a preset amount of skills, items, tools, and gear based on your chosen skills, but as you play you will unlock or discover many others.

My first big gripe is that there could have been more storage options for items. Space is sparse, even with the 'pocket dimension'. A couple of tabs for things, like a gem sack or a potion bag, would have been very welcome. I have never gotten further than four floors, and usually by floor two I've horded myself a huge collection of stuff, even if I sell things that none of my skills would allow me to use.

I also wish the potions, mushrooms, wands, and other such items offered details about what they do. You can always use a wiki, and you probably will, but truthfully some raw data on these would have been immensely welcome. There are just so many things to collect or use that details on the fly would have made the game feel smoother.

That said, the author's descriptions were, as with the rest of this game, entertaining and pretty clever. In some cases the description of the item, and the subsequent description of the buff (or power up) the item provided were cleverly done, and really funny. The same goes for the achievements; some of their descriptions are just so witty.

Mods are fun, and there are a lot out there made by fans that work pretty well with the game. [b]I strongly recommend reading comments on them before installing a mod[/b], just to be sure they won't cause your game to go haywire. I've tested and confirmed that [b]using mods does not affect achievements,[/b]in case you're wondering.

The music is good, kind of generic in some cases, but serviceable. The graphics are definitely of an old-school feel, but they really work here. In some cases they were actually perfect for what the game seemed intent on doing, like making a comical reference to something else, which is to say that the art style was excellent!

The story is fairly nonexistent, but the writing here is terrific. I loved the gags, the references, the oddball item descriptions. Sometimes it's Monty Python, sometimes it's Mel Brooks. A lot of pop culture references, many that will show their age in just a few more years. This game is dripping with wit and personality, and I found myself laughing out loud a couple of times when I got the joke. Don't let me build it up too much for you, just know that I really respect the writer's work here.

Dying happened a lot in this game, but it never felt unfair. The first floor of the dungeon isn't so hard. You get some levels, skills, items, and equipment to help out. Danger is everywhere, but being turn based there is a lot of room to think. Every defeat felt like a learning experience, and after a while I began to understand how I messed up. A key ingredient to a great roguelike, or really in most video games, is being able to lose and feeling like the loss was fair. It is a rare game that I feel this amicable about when I’ve blown my hours of progress on some careless mistake. Never angry, never cheated, and usually ready to dust off and try again.

If the thought of dying repeatedly doesn't appeal to you the game has a 'No Permadeath' option, allowing you to save and reload if you lose. The game doesn't appear to fault you for this, so it is purely up to you if you want the roguelike experience or are looking for more of a role-playing game.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Deeply customizable experience
    [*]High replay value
    [*]Different dungeon layout each time
    [*]Engrossing game play
    [*]Secrets everywhere
    [*]Witty writing
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Could have offered more storage possibilities
    [*]Early areas can feel repetitive
    [*]Item descriptions too ambiguous
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 8/10[/b]

I've lost hours in this game, but none of them ever felt wasted, even when I died. Wholeheartedly recommended!

Edit: Nominated for 2019 Labor of Love award. This game, despite it's shortcomings, was clearly that and then some.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968301967', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4309, 'last_played': 1605987921}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmore is a unique and funny turn based RPG with roguelite elements like permadeath, procedurally generated levels and loot, and a tile based movement system. 

Instead of choosing a class to play as, you choose 7 skills out of the over 50 available (much more in the workshop) and each time you gain a level, you can level up one of the skills you chose.  Each level you get to decide if it would be better for you to gain passive or active ability from, for example: Swords, Vampirism, Alchemy, Magical Law, Battle Geology, Perception, or Demonologist.  All of the skills themselves have a real identity, and combining 7 skills gives each character a real uniqueness.  This uniqueness coming from character creation is both why I like randomizing skill selection and why I like to play with permadeath, learning new characters can be as fun as maxing out a long lived one.

Calling the gameplay turn based is accurate but might give the impression that it is slower than it is.  For example you can click any tile on the screen to take as many turns as you need to move there, and fighting monsters using attacks and skills on hotkeys feels natural.  On your turn you can move to a new tile or use a spell or attack, then any visible enemies will take their action before its back to you.

The humor is on point, the core gameplay loop is satisfying, and the customizability is deep.  This is a game you can find yourself getting immersed in and coming back to again and again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970883414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 6532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6062, 'last_played': 1600151002}
review:
edit REMINDER: YOU HAVE TO NAME THE EXPANSION PACK.

This is easily one of the two greatest roguelikes ever made - the other being Tales of Maj'Eyal - and it will hold a special place in my heart for all time. As you progress through Dredmor's lair, you will be consistently driven to bemusement, bafflement, and BRUTAL PLAYER DEATH in equal measure. And since the player death is so brutal, this game is therefore exceedingly funny and weird. It is one of the funniest games of all time in any genre. Oh, sure, the game's mechanics are perfectly functional and easy to learn, but the presentation - the sheer experience, the horror that creeps into your mind crying, "that did what?! who would think of this? why would they think of this?" - will likely cause a few existential deaths onscreen and off. Existential damage is actually a damage type that some abilities and monsters can inflict.

Seriously, though, pay close attention: most of the sprite animations have few frames... except, for some reason, monster deaths. Sure, you may be a little weirded out by what the monster is, but then you take a moment to really watch it die.

These developers were completely out of their gourds. I once got an achievement for somehow crashing the game, and another for getting killed during the tutorial, and of course one of my very first achievements was for dying on the first level with an identical build twice in a row. Your basic diggle is a small, yellow floppy bird with a rubbery drill instead of a beak, and you can collect achievements for getting killed by each of almost every species of diggle in the game. I will not speak of Thrusty. When you try to quit the game, the Unreal Tournament-esque (?!?!?!) announcer (...?)  will occasionally plead with you in his gravelly voice, saying, "Please don't go. The diggles need you. They look up to you." The same voice that, minutes prior, was yelling "YOU NEED MORE MANA! DRINK MORE BOOZE!" Also, you have to name the expansion pack.

The Steam Workshop content is full of great stuff, too! However, I strongly recommend spending a lot of time with the vanilla+DLC version before installing any mods. Some mods certainly approximate the devs' particular brand of insanity, but even now sometimes I have more fun without using any mods. And, yes, I bought the game when it came out and I still play now and again - and, when I do, it's "one more turn" all night.

And, no, I have never killed Dredmor, that son of a bitch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972966915', 'num_games_owned': 604, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1539794883}
review:
I'm changing my review to recommended due to good points made by commenters, but only to people who are not bothered by some technical issues with the game, which i'm not happy about either.
The game still has work to be done to fix bugs and performance issues. The game runs fast enough but uses plenty of CPU for a turn-based 2D game. I've also had this version crash.

Now with that out of the way, the game is good. It evokes that "one more turn feeling" quite well and is accessible for a roguelike. And there aren't terribly many accessible roguelikes around, that also have good amount of depth to them. It provides what it promises.

And if this game still sells and an actual developer is on the receiving end, i urge them to keep working on the game some more still.

wonderfully deep and complex (but not too complex) little rouge-like rpg. i suck at these types of games, but i still enjoy them quite a bit; ever since i was young and discovered nethack, i've been fascinated by how insanely detailed such a simple looking game could be.

my only wish is that you could zoom the UI elements a bit more. i discovered a zoom button for the inventory, but not the other windows. 

this game is well worth the price of admission; do yourself a favor and take a trip to the...

author: {'steamid': '76561198014821911', 'num_games_owned': 954, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1661, 'last_played': 1496551539}
review: I love this game's irreverent sense of humour, the accessibility it brought to roguelikes. Dungeons of Dredmor is well worth the sale price, at best its an amusing adventure and a wonderfully frustrating roguelike to sink time into, at worst its going to be good for enough laughs to be worth the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198264335255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1507672348}
review:
Achievement: Normandy - Die on floor 1.  Create a new character with the same skills and....die on floor 1.

10/10 would laugh uproariously at my own severe lack of skill again.

Game cracked me up so often, my son ended up buying it on his own Steam account after about the 10th time he had to come in my room to see what had me giggle-snorting.  Buy it on sale or at full price, it's worth it either way.  If you can laugh at yourself and game for the sheer fun of it without getting your ego bruised for every piddly little thing that you don't like or understand, then get this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013884709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4442, 'last_played': 1679269880}
review:
I really want to love this game, trust me. It is catchy, has silly graphics, a terrific sense of humor along with tons of easter eggs and a fully fledged combat system where you can create your very own perk system.

So the question arises, why is this a negative review?
Well one reason only, the crashes. I saw many players complaining about it and I understood the risk, but I wanted to try it. I've played this game for a few hours as you can see and it has crashed when I tried to save it 5 times when I was on the last or second to last floor. Flat out crashed, corrupted the save files and couldn't retrieve them. Literal hours of trying on runs wasted away in seconds.

This is a lovely game, but you need to be ready for many instances like what I stated above and have patience. Unfortunately, mine is worn thin.


EDIT: As you can see this was originally a negative review, but I had to come back and shape it around today's state for me.

So, after my anger has been calmed I got back to this game. It really magnetizes me and always makes me want to come back, thus doing so even after the aftermentioned crashes. Some time ago, I would recommend this game without second thought. The way it combines humor with some serious gameplay with tons of options to make your own build is really well made and seen through. It kept me for some hours and I know it will do so for more. But you should be wary of it Not responding and losing your precious saves.

All in all, I love this game. Even after what I've been through, I recommend it with joy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025069268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1494083485}
review:
This game is trash. Do not buy it.

Download Nethack for free and enjoy a game that is infinitely better.

Horible music, horrible art, horrible UI, horrible controls, horrible 'map structure' (sometimes you can't see south of your character more than a few squares), horrible scaling (the boss is ridiculously overpowered compared to whatever you had to face before it), horribly boring (same old thing over, and over, and over, and over), and provides almost no challenge (aside from ridiculously OP boss). 

This game does a lot, but it does nothing well.

I am deleting this garbage as soon as I post this review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212605888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1796, 'last_played': 1536512424}
review:
Rollicking good fun, with lots of classes and a good reason other races are not playable, for once. I hate it when you can only play a human in a game and they don't tell you why, so I'm glad that not the case here. You can combine all sorts of remarkablely odd skills just to see what happens, though unless you have permadeath off that is often you dying on the third level. Ah well, that just means you can try a different combo. Any attempt at seriousness is undermined, making this game low stress despite the whole 'being a roguelike thing'. 

Unforutnately, it needs content-adding mods to feel complete, suggesting that it doesn't contain enough randomness on its own. 

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198161289655', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1658250426}
review:
Ben normalde rouge-like oyunları sevmem, hatta tiksinirim. Çabuk sinirlenen biriyimdir ve oyunun kişiyi strese sokması değil rahatlatması gerektiğini düşünürüm ve rouge-like oyunlar için tam olarak zor diyemesekde insanı en çok strese sokan türlerdendir çünkü saatlerce oynayıp oyunun sonuna geldikten sonra ölüp en başa atılmak çekilmez bir şeydir. 

Ancak bu oyun çok farklı. Öncelikle ben çok DnD oynamış/oynayan birisiyimdir. Bu oyun dungeon hissini çok iyi veriyor. Oyun sıra tabanlı ancak pek de sıra tabanlı gibi hissettirmiyor oynayınca anlarsınız. Oyunun skilleri, silahları, zırhları oldukça çeşitli. Ayrıca henüz oyunu bitirmedim (kısa zamanda bitereceğimi de sanmıyorum) ama duyduğum kadarıyla oyun yalnızca 10 level miş (ben daha 3 e gelemedim) bu durumda öyle 100 lerce saat oynayarak 10 levele gelindiğini sanmıyorum yani oyun sonunda ölsenizde muhtemelen en fazla 10 saatlik uğraşınız gider. 

Rouge-likelarla ilgili diğer bir problemim ise sürekli aynı levellerden onlarca belki yüzlerce hatta binlerce kez geçtiğimiz için sıkmasıdır ancak bu oyun çeşitliliği kullanarak sıkıcı olmaktan kurtuluyor. Öldükten sonra farklı skillerle farklı spelllerle ve farklı silahlarla tekrar deniyorsunuz. 

Ayrıca oyunda isterseniz bu ölünce başa atma muhabbetini kapatabilirsnizi ama tavsiye etmem bir kapının önünde durupta acaba kapının arkasından 10 tane zombi çıkıp etrafımı sararak saatlerce süren ilerlememi yok mu edecek yoksa çok güzel bir silah mı bulucam muhabbetini tamamen yok etmiş olursunuz yani kısaca STEAMDEKİ EN İYİ ROGUE-LİKE OYUN diyebilirim rahatlıkla.

+ lar:
1- Sıkmıyor
2- Çıldırtacak kadar zor değil
3- Dungeon hissini iyi veriyor
4- Çeşitlilik çok iyi
5- Ucuz

- ler:

1- İçindeki metin sayısı oldukça az olmasına rağmen yalnızca ingilizce var oysa ki kolaylıkla diğer dillere çevrilebilir.
2- Bazen oyun çökerbiliyor ancak bununla ilgili bir başarımı var ve eğer oyun çökerse size bir başarım verip gönlünüzü alıyor bende oyunun çökmesine sinirlendikten sonra ''Zindan bazen çöker'' adlı başarımı görünce güldüm :D hemen başarım vitrinine ekledim bunu hoş olmuş aslında bunu + bile sayabilirim o derece.
3- Ufaktan karakter yaratabilseymişiz iyi olurdu (yalnıza 2 karakter arasından [kız ve erkek] seçim yapıyoruz)
4- Senaryo sadece girişteki 2 paragraflık yazıdan ibaret sanırım. bundan emin değilim ama eğer öyleyse biraz sade kalmış gerçe bu sadelik de bi yönden iyi aslında, bilmiyorum.

puan:

oynanış: 10/10
grafik: 8,5/10 (Tabiki grafikler patates ama çizim tarzı çok hoş.)
senaryo: 7,5/10

GENEL: 9

NOT: Söylemeden edemicem şu UEBS denen şeye 25 tl vermiştim iade edip bunu aldım üstüne bide 5 tlye arma 2 aldım cüzdanda mis gibi para kaldı sonraki indirimler için şöyle gereksiz şeylere 20-30 tl vermeyin, böyle cevherleri bulun, bunları alın.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068292927', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1483, 'last_played': 1699465456}
review:
Soooo... Dungeons of Dredmor. This game is a rogue-like (one of my favorite genres) so it's different from games like The Binding of Isaac, FTL (Rogue-lite) and it has most of his gameplay features present in the 1980 game Rogue like turn-based combat, randomized levels on a level structure and permadeath (you can disable it). But the game adds many more features like the possibility to personalize the character with different skill trees instead of a classic class system.
The graphics are good but after a while it may bore the eyes but it's still better than ASCII graphics.
The music is meh, some tracks are good like the tutorial one but the others sounds like the cat of the composer got on the keyboard and started jamming the keys.
Overall the game is one of the best rogue-like that i've played even with all the little defects and i love it and the workshop adds that cherry on the top of the cake
Final Vote 8/10
P.S. Someone complains that the game crashes often with the autosave feature, it never happened to me but remember to save often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285735689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1501876299}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor makes for a funny and enjoyable roguelike that has a great in-depth rpg system with loads of downright wacky items to use and modify your character’s stats with. The story description of the game is quick and gets you straight into the meat of the game, which is the old classic of kill, loot, and try to live as long as you can. Despite going for a simple approach the game handles these core aspects very well and, with the procedural generation of the levels, can most definitely make for a surprisingly addictive yet enjoyable experience. The game itself plays as a strange form of turn based combat where everything only moves or acts when you do as you progress across a grid styled surface in the guise of various dungeon tiles. Its combat is nothing too terribly fancy but shines in replayability due to the fact that you can mix and match various skills each with their own level up effects and different ability combinations that make the possibilities quite literally endless. Overall the game is a pretty solid roguelike with a lot of very well done rpg stat customization going for it. As for my final thoughts, the game gets a thumbs up from me for being able to smash statues to get some serious free xp lol. Nothing quite beats the sounds of heroic vandalism.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073221991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 16994, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16241, 'last_played': 1490096130}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991304212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1546, 'last_played': 1695924697}
review:
Интересный рогалик. Уютный такой, по-домашнему теплый. Добротная рисовка. Довольно однообразный, но весьма вариативный игровой процесс. Куча всяких интересностей внутри есть - телепорты, различные измерения, множество приятных мелочей, хорошая система крафта. Кстати, система крафта напомнила мне "Арканум", практически один в один. Героя можно собрать с абсолютно любой комбинацией скилов. Есть чем насладиться. Птички щебечут, женщины-пчёлки летают. А ты ходишь и качаешь героя потихонечку.
Ну а теперь обратная сторона медали: по смертности героя, Дарк Соулс сосёт с проглотом у этой игры. Никогда не знаешь где тебя настигнет кончина - можешь помереть от любоого случайного события, особенно если герой ещё не прокачан толком. Ну, а если прокачан, то шансы конечно есть, но.. в общем, соболезную.
К счастью, наинать игру заново легко и просто - просто зашел и создал героя по новой. Правда, меня уже задолбало проходить снова и снова первый этаж, но от этого никуда не деться. ПРИДЕТСЯ ЭТО ТЕРПЕТЬ.
Любителям рогаликов и мазохизма игра понравится. Кстати, в мастерской для неё лежит много всего интересного.
8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198048692462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3881, 'last_played': 1483494431}
review:
Humor. Dungeons of Dredmor has plenty of it. Item descriptions are absurd, enemies are bizarre, damage types are ridiculous, and the monsters frequently spout flavor text that will elicit a chuckle. The game takes nothing about itself seriously, and I LOVE that.

Dredmor also has an amazing class selection system, being one of the most varied ones I have encountered in a game. You are given a plethora of skills to choose when you make a new character. Mixing potions, dagger adeptness, vampirism, communism, emo magic—the list goes on. Each of these corresponds with primary stats (burliness, nimbleness, and sagacity to name some) and secondary traits (dodge chance, block chance, and enemy dodge reduction to name some). With the vast amount of skills that you can choose, there is a near infinite amount of variation in primary stat and secondary stat intensities as well as attacks that you can use.

However, these two things cannot save this game from the abyss.

The humor is fun when you first play, but it gets old after you’ve seen and heard everything.

The combat is grindy as fuck, feeling like a hack-and-slash game even though this is turn based. There is no strategy. Fighting is heavily dependent on RNG and the game does not force you to diversify how you approach each encounter. All you have to do is use your three favorite attacks, run, wait for them to cooldown, and then repeat. Nothing is stopping you from fighting this way, so I cannot help but fight this way.

The developers claim that there are “hordes of monsters never-before-seen in a video game” to be found here. Don’t be fooled. Only two enemy types exist: melee and ranged. The difference between each enemy in these categories is what types of damage they deal and what types of resistances they have. To top it all off, the creatures you fight are only reskins of things you already have seen with their stats changed slightly.

Inventory management is horrible. To make this even worse, there are so many different variations of ONE item (bleu cheese, grated cheese, cheese log, etc.) that your inventory will quickly become cluttered with crap.

Crafting is complex, but perhaps too complex. As with consumables and wands and ammo types, there are just too many different components that you can acquire and they are randomly generated. This will frequently make it difficult to craft anything meaningful.

Only the first twenty to thirty hours of this game is fun. While that might sound like a lot, trust me, it is not. I should easily be able to squeeze at least a hundred hours out of this before I get bored, because the developers clearly say 
“Infinite replay value: choose from a selection of mind-boggling skills to create your character. A new gameplay experience waits every time!” The only reason I have played this for sixty eight hours is because I like to pursue challenges. But all while I played I could not sit still. I was bored—I knew I was forcing myself to keep going.

If you still want to get this game heed my warning: complete it only once and leave with a good taste in your mouth.

Verdict: 65%

author: {'steamid': '76561198048101201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 3454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3454, 'last_played': 1484880447}
review:
When my friends told me I needed to go kill a dark lord, I thought it was the shrooms talking. Turns out it wasn't. I woke up in a dungeon, the way out was locked, and there are drill-faced hell penguins everywhere. And mushrooms, all over the place.

Mushrooms? I got this.

By the time I hit the 15th floor, Lord Dredmor is waiting for me. Me? I'm high as a kite, tripping puffballs, I've got spores coming out of my pores, swinging swords and lips drenched with blood. Some crazy bottle of hooch I found back on the 7th floor brought me into harmony with the stars, man, so I'm stellar. I look into Dredmor's dead eyes and stuff a handful of shrooms into my face.

Coward knows he's in over his head, and teleports away. Aw, hell.

I blast my way through the entire bottom floor, a fungal lady of death, killing everything that moves, but the jerk isn't there. What the hell, Dredmor? How rude is it to hide from your guests? I grind up some shrooms and rub the powder in my eyes and realize, damn, these walls are hollow. One Bolt of Mass Destruction flushes Dredmor out, he's not casting cause I revoked his license, he's running cause the shroom girl is screaming, he's stuck, he's got a Holy Hand Grenade on his face, boom.

And the diggles said my degree in dungeoneering means nothing here. Hah.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016593081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 20656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20579, 'last_played': 1485239748}
review:
A crazy mash-up roguelike that aims to be approachable but still have a huge sprawling dungeon to explore.

And by and large it succeeds - few debilitating badstats, abilities much more easy to understand, and the lightening effects of humor to make losing a little more fun. It doesn't quite have the quick loop times of your action roguelikes or your purpose-built Sproggiwoods, and even in No Time To Grind mode can be quite draining.

So a medium-weight roguelike, then. If you've had good experiences with other roguelikes you can beat the dungeon in an hour and want the next step up in complexity, this is a pretty good step.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038659734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3106, 'last_played': 1545707629}
review:
Let me make this clear - [i]I like rogue-likes[/i]. I do. One of my friends actually bought this game for me for Christmas two years ago, saying that it was similar to one of my favorite games - [i]Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup[/i]. At that time I played this game and wrote a negative review for it on Steam which relied heavily on comparisons between the two games.

That was unfair, I admit. I should judge the game on its own merits, not on how well it holds up to my own favorite game. I also bought both the DLC for the game – “Realm of the Diggle Gods” and “Conquest of the Wizardlands.” So, we'll see if all of this improves my experience at all.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The game works. I can say that for it. It runs competently and seems to be more or less free of bugs. It did crash on me once, and actually gave me an achievement for it - “Suddenly the Dungeon Collapses.” So that was.... cute.

Sadly, that's about the only good thing I can say here. The game is just boring to me. I'm sorry to all the people who love this game, but it is. At no point while playing did I ever find myself really looking forward to what was going to come next.

I never looked forward to the next floor, because I knew it would be exactly the same as the floor I was on, but with different wall and floor graphics.

I never looked forward to seeing a new enemy. There were occasional clever designs, but they all work basically the same and are super wimpy. At no point was I ever forced to switch up my tactics at all.

I never looked forward to finding some fancy artifact weapon because they're never interesting. In most rogue-likes finding a good artifact can make or break your entire run, but here? At most it's just going to be the same as a normal weapon of its type but maybe with +1 or +2 to some stat that I never use. Yawn.

I also never looked forward to my next skill, because the game has you choose all of your skills when you make your character and you can never deviate, so there's no room for experimentation whatsoever. To be fair, I guess that puts the game on par with most other RPGs... but it's still disappointing.

Also, the levels are just... tediously long and boring. There is a “No Time To Grind” option that shrinks levels in size while giving boosted experience, but it doesn't increase loot, and so is therefore absolutely worthless.

In all: it works, but Is just so boring. 3/5.

[b]Presentation[/b]
Well, our main character isn't an “@” symbol, so that already puts it ahead of most rogue-likes.

Okay, but seriously, I have no real complaints about graphics or sound. Because the view isn't exactly top down, enemies, items, and traps can sometimes be obscured from view by parts of the environment... however, when this happens, the game politely points them out in various ways – sparkle effect on items, a pointy arrow for enemies, and a red outline for traps. So that's nice. It doesn't point out stuff hidden behind doors or dungeon objects, though.

I would also like it if my equipped armor actually changed my character's appearance, but it's not like the game has to do that. It would just be a nice bonus if it did.

I'll give presentation a 4/5.

[b]Writing[/b]
Finally, the last part. I usually put this as “story” but... you know, it's a rogue-like.

I'll be brutally honest. I don't like [i]Dredmor[/i]'s writing style. In my original review I described the writing as “edgy” but I don't think that's really the right word for it. The writing is just immature. I can't even call it parody. It's just random jokes that mean nothing.

This game was clearly written by the type of person who thinks “irreverent” is a compliment, and who believes knowing the word “sesquipedalian” makes you smart. And if you don't know what I meant by that last bit... then you're probably the type of person I'm talking about. I don't guess that really makes it bad, though. If you like [i]Family Guy[/i] and [i]Robot Chicken[/i], you follow Cracked, and you think the Clock Crew rules the Portal... then you'll probably love this game's sense of humor.

But if you'll excuse me, I need to pop my monocle back in, and go think about how much I hate you while enjoying my Beaujolais and camembert, and partaking of more intellectual entertainments... like anime. Anime is great. 2/5.

[b]KR Rating: 3/5 MEDIOCRE[/b]

In all, I give it basically the same score I gave it before. Owning the DLC didn't really change my impression that much. There's some fairly interesting additions in them, but nothing that makes the game any less boring to me. Even [i]Conquest of the Wizardlands[/i], which adds a huge number of randomly generated "wizard tower" mini-dungeons, is just... they're all the same. Yawn. At the end of the day, even with the DLC, it's still [i]Dungeons of Dredmor[/i].

And now that that's all said and done... yeah, I just can't end this without bringing up [i]Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup[/i] again. It's an excellent game and a perfect example of a rogue-like done right. In that game, I actually did look forward to reaching new regions because they had unique properties and interesting enemies. I also looked forward to finding new artifact items because they actually meant something. Finding the right artifact weapon or armor could make or break your entire run, unlike this game where randarts just mean +1 to some stat I don't care about and I'll probably just sacrifice them to my Horadric Lutefisk Cube... speaking of immature writing.

I just can't recommend this game to anyone when I already know there's another game that's just like it only better in every way AND ALSO FREE already out there. I can't.

[url=https://knightlyreviews.blogspot.com/2018/12/video-game-review-dungeons-of-dredmor.html]Read the original on Knight's Reviews.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198061332612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 8641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7328, 'last_played': 1695772936}
review:
117hours played and still couldn't beat the boss. That's one thing I don't like about thing I don't like about the game: I made my clockwork (steampunk-like) dual-axe weilding pirat and walked easily through hordes of enemies. But the boss killed me in a blink.
Still a great game. Did I mention you can make a clockwork (steampunk-like) dual-axe weilding pirat? If you don't like pirates (but who doesn't?) perhaps you want an indiana jones mathmagician who goes full fist fighting while being heavily armored?
The many classes you can mix are the thing which lures me back into this dungeons again and again.

review:
Want something you can pick up and put down easily?  Or rather, something you can pick up and will put YOU down easily?

Fun, relaxing, creative, and memorable.  One of the most enjoyable games to play when you dont have much free time and just want to wander around a quirky lounge/dungeon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042373502', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 394, 'playtime_forever': 4428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3851, 'last_played': 1483965293}
review:
[i]…Давным-давно, в одном сказочном королевстве появилось Зло. Зло беспринципное, недалекое и очень страшное. Смотрело оно на мир сквозь густые брови и ехидно улыбалось, хотя та улыбка больше напоминала звериный оскал. У зла этого было много имен и они значили не больше, чем отзвуки эха. Но оно не было обезличенным, о нет. Те, кому посчастливилось выжить, говаривали, что лица у зла, а их у него было два, могли выглядеть даже приятно, если бы не жадный блеск в глазах да одежды, покрытые кровью ни в чем не повинных обитателей поверхности. И сейчас, когда близится год Черного ворона, это зло собираеться спустится в наши подземелья, дабы лишить жизни владыку Дредмора. И если это вдруг случится – прячьтесь дети…[/i]

В очередной раз мне пришлось пожалеть, что в Steam’е нет возможности оставить нейтральный обзор, благо обозреваемая игра подходит под определение крепкого середнячка – все в ней выглядит добротно. А временами даже забавно, но она не вызывает сильных чувств и эмоций, как это бывает с другими рогаликами. Причина? Она достаточно проста: Геймплей упирается в то, какие навыки вы взяли своему герою изначально. Попытались сделать из него вора? Ну-у-у, поначалу вас будут нещадно бить, если, конечно же, не взяли перк на дальнее оружие. Взяли мага? Да вы всё и сами знаете. По первости своей мага убить может порыв ветра, а вот если каким-то чудом удастся прокачаться, то маг станет неостановимой машиной смерти. Ну а с воином все просто. Ходит себе такой танк и выносит все что подает признаки жизни. Это все было во множестве игр жанра слешер-рпг и к подобному раскладу геймер привычен. Другое дело, перед нами все-таки рогалик, а коли так ждешь того, что игра будет удивлять и раз за разом подбрасывать что-то новое, неожиданное и увлекательное. Есть ли здесь нечто подобное? Гмм, очень хороший вопрос.

В игре присутствует система рандома, будь это разбросанные тут и там фонтаны, выпив из которых управляемый персонаж может превратиться либо в козленочка, либо в Илью Муромца. Есть кузница бога Кронка, который подобно своему тезке из «Похождений императора» может улучшить ваше оружие. А может ухудшить. Тут уж никогда не угадаешь наверняка. Ну а еще есть квесты, которые заключаются в том, что надо пойти и убить местную страхолюдину за что игрок получит какую-нибудь вещь. Замечу, я не сказал полезную вещь, так как награда за выполнение задания чаще всего бесполезна, ибо предназначена не тому классу за который вы сейчас играете. То же самое относится и к зачистке огромной комнаты, населенной монстрами до отказа и прозванной "зоопарком". Лишь в редком, очень и очень редком случае вы можете рассчитывать на полезную вещь. Разработчики это знали и по этой самой причине сделали так, чтобы все упиралось не столько в вещи, которые на вас навешаны, сколько в навыки, которые вы прокачали. Взяли тяжелую броню вкупе с ловкостью? Отлично. Враги в шести случаях из десяти по вам и не попадут. Тем самым все упирается в те самые навыки, которые вы взяли изначально, а никак не в то, что в вас бросит игра. Таким образом элемент случайности пусть и выглядит слишком выпукло, но особой роли не играет. 

Звучит так, будто я только и ругаю игру, но это не совсем так. Перед нами клон Дьяблы с той лишь разницей, что бюджет у разработчиков был более чем скромен, но при этом им удалось сбалансировать навыки таким образом, дабы не один не был лишним. Да, некоторые выглядят достаточно странно, а некоторые и вовсе вызывают недоверие, но все они работают и вносят разнообразие в геймплей. То самое разнообразие, которое должна была давать игра по мере прохождения, а никак не сразу, ну да ладно. Был также сделан упор на юмор и высмеивание всевозможных штампов жанра, а также множество отсылок на известные, а порой и не особо известные произведения. Да и монстры, одним своим видом, вызывают улыбку. Посему, как я и сказал, – игра неплохая, но она проигрывает другим рогаликам именно тем, что сваливает на игрока сразу все и в дальнейшем «Dungeons of Dredmor» не сможет предложить ничего нового, оттого и интерес к ней теряется.

6 из 10 разъяренных продавцов

author: {'steamid': '76561198057166480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 23884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14775, 'last_played': 1621032646}
review:
One of the first games I've ever bought on Steam and to this day still one of my favorites. Why? The replay value, I never get tired of playing this one. There are several options you can tweak to alter your play style, the levels are all randomly generated, plus you can choose from a long list of "professions" to change your abilities/spells with each new try you make at beating the final floor. (or at least getting farther than you got last time)
     Depending on what you pick from the profession list, you can spend your time crafting plenty of neat things to help you hack and slash your way through the dungeon. Engineering is one of my favorites to have, (making bombs, chainsaws and armor that lets me survive being struck by lightning is always a plus). But there's much more to pick from than that, which always gives you something new to try each time you play. Want to make a Thief that knows Blacksmithing and can teleport? You can do that. How about a Pirate that makes acid potions you can throw on crowds of monsters but can also summon minnions to fight for you at will. Yeah, you can do that too. There are so many combinations to choose from, it keeps the game interesting for a really long time.
     So yes, I recommend this game. Not just for the all the movie and game references you can find on a lot of the items or all the random jibberish the monsters will say to you, but for the sheer amount of fun I have had wandering around the dungeon looking for treasure..and usually finding a Monster Zoo..(that's an entire room FILLED with monsters..yeah.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198013132245', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 316, 'playtime_forever': 6254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6041, 'last_played': 1509738577}
review:
What makes this game stand out against other DnD hack and slash, is crafting.  I admit I've only played a few hours.  But the crafting provides more motivation to keep playing than just finding loot or doing quests.  The 2D map layout with hidden corners is very nice, and now and then some puzzles (so far very simple - maybe they weren't intentional and just how the map generator works).

There are quests that are given out at statues that involve "kill the baddy" or "get the item".  Also you don't have to craft - that's just how I'm playing it.  There is a HUGE amount of grinding in this game.
 
The stats are quite funny.  Wielding an enormous axe will boost your character's "caddishness" trait.  See: http://dungeonsofdredmor.wikia.com/wiki/Stats

This is turn-based RPG - the screen freezes between moves allowing time to plan what to do next, which slows the game down and makes it Uberwunderschoen - take your time, relax, figure out what you want to do.  There's no timer running.

Early game without any good equipment "run away from emenies while you heal for the next attack" is a real strategy.

The tone is humorous and light.  Acceptible voice acting and the artwork occasionally touches on the relaxation nerve just right.  Good stuff.

Mostly this is it's own flavor of all the other DnD games out there - it does a good job and it offers enough to keep coming back.  However the grinding can get tedious after so much of the same thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039629122', 'num_games_owned': 816, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1482798901}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043721080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1483136762}
review:
It was my first run of the game. I bought a horrendously overpowered sword from a salesdemon in a hideous pinstriped suit and was slaying my way through floor after floor of the dungeon. All was going well until I my curiosity got the best of me... what would happen if I put a Lutefisk horadrik cube inside another?

10/10 would die to paradox-explosion-flames (and get an achievement for it, too!) again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018598516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482878921}
review:
As someone who has played the original Rogue, as well as Moria, Angband various -Band variants like Zangband and Gumband, Pernband and Cthband, and then later games like ADOM and TOME, I have a real love for this line of gameage.  Dungeons of Dredmor is a light hearted comedic take, that is very easy to get into, and has a lot of options.  But it lacks the depth of some of those other games too.  That's fine.  It's a $5 dollar game that's more than worth the price of admission.

There's nothing in teh game that's not pushed to a humorous level.  Take the stats for example.  Gone are stats like Strength and Intelligence.  Instead we have Burliness and Caddishness.  And that's fine.  It's a fun send up of the entire RPG concept.  But I stil have to do a mental translation each time I read a name a few hours into the game.  And the jokes wear old.  There are only so many evil potatoes you can kill before the joke starts to wear a little thin.

Now I do love that you aren't locked into classes.  Choose your skills!  For my first character, who died pretty quickly, I grabbed a melee attack, missile attack, armor, shield, psionics, paranormal investigator, and perception. It's more flexible that a lot of the true roguelikes.

And make no mistake.  DoD is a true roguelike.  Many games call themselves roguelike but are't.  They might evoke one or more aspects, like permadeath, of the Rogue games, but not DoD or similar games out there.  Nope.  This is a pure Rogue descendant.   

And there is a lot of versatility under the hood.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005079603', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 5123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3658, 'last_played': 1674576331}
review:
I have a soft spot for roguelites, even though I'm (generally speaking) absolutely SHÏTE at them. But they're usually a whole lotta fun. Charging into a horde of enemies, battle-axe in hand, loincloth flapping in the wind, and then getting stomped into monster sandwich spread because what kind of a fûckin' retärd doesn't wear PROPER armour when they're out savaging monsters?!

But I digress. Dungeons of Dredmor then. I like it. I won't go so far as to say that I love it, but I will just spoil this review right now and tell you: YES, I WILL RECOMMEND THIS FÛCKING SHÏT, BECAUSE IT'S A REALLY GOOD GAME.

I feel like I basically cut myself short just now, seeing as how I don't have all THAT much to talk 'bout when it comes to ol' DoD. I mean, the humour in it is nicely silly, without being overly dumb. And I do like that it's not pitching a tent in either the Bulletstorm cesspit or the Duke Nukem Forever leper colony, but the much less unappealing Monty Python-esque silly nonsense, uhh... fish factory. I dunno. I was struggling to come up with something, so I just wrote the first thing that came to mind.

Anyway! Moving on. I like that pretty much every single skill in the game is at least somewhat unique, and that they all have some measure of usefulness, even though some are pretty damn overpowered (lookin' at you, Perception (yes, that was a pun, get over it)) while some are... well... less useful (*coughs* veganism *coughs*). But anyway. The ability to mix 'n' match skills 'til your boxers squeal (because the expression "till your hearts contents" makes no göddämn fûcking sense!), so you'll have plenty of replay value.

The gameplay itself is nicely straight-forward. You typically walk around with WASD, you see an enemy, approach them, and then either bump up against 'em or click on 'em to attack. Not exactly rocket surgery, ehh? But the fact that the game is, how should I say... "step-based", I guess? Well, whatever you'd call it, it's the only hybridization of real-time and turn-based I've ever seen that actually works really well.

Those of you who've played Fatal Labyrinth on the SEGA Genesis know what I mean. To clarify, enemies can only move, attack, and do other stuff at the same time as you do, but you don't take traditional turns attacking each other. So when you attack an enemy, they'll attack you back. This makes it so that you'll ALWAYS have time to think about what to do next, but the pacing of the game doesn't necessarily suffer for it, unlike in games like Heroes of Might & Magic or XCOM.

The graphics are fairly simple and low-key, just to change the topic com-fûcking-pletely, but they have a nicely stylistic charm to them. Most pixel games generally just go for the 8-bit style out of sheer laziness, but DoD seems to take the same road as Stardew Valley or Shovel Knight, and instead have a pixelated style with plenty of details and actually nice colour palettes. Which I obviously like.

And now I'm reaching dangerously close to the final point regarding DoD: if it's such a solid game, why do I not like it more? Well, I will warn you right now that it's insanely fûcking grindtastic, and unless you play with the Smaller Floors option on, you'll be doing a fûcking retärded amount-a walking around in the game. There's also the fact that even though almost all skills are in some way useful, there are builds that WILL inevitably break the game, even on the hardest difficulty, and basically turn you into an all-powerful mega-god.

But I have to admit, DoD does a lotta things really, really, REALLY well, and since my only complaints with it are minor nuisances at most, I really can't give it that low of a grading. It's also worth noting that Dungeons of Dredmor (unlike nearly every single roguelite out there) does actually let you play on a fairly softcore difficulty level, and while I personally wish there were more options to customize the "hardness" of the game, this does make it so that even less skilled players can play it. So that's definitely a big plus.

All in all, DoD has a lotta solid points, and while it's a bit rough around the edges, it's still got a lot of charm to it, and it's definitely worth buying, even if you're normally not a huge fan of roguelite games. 89/100

author: {'steamid': '76561198003229218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1661, 'last_played': 1694415309}
review:
This isn't a terrible game, so consider it a mixed review, but after 30 hours in and not wanting to play anymore and not very excited about it, I can't rate this positively for a rogue-like game.  I will note, though, that if you generially like the idea of "rogue-likes" but are mostly turned off by lack of feedback/graphics/music, this is a good game to get into the genre.

Quick review:
Pros:
-Varied builds
-Lots of loot
-Very good music
-Good graphics
-Standard hard rogue difficulty curve
-Cute mechanics like monster horde rooms

Cons:
-Very repetitive, imagine a single player only diablo
-Catastrophically bad inventory management
-Grindy as heck, even on the no grind game option (lol)
-Not very well balanced
-Surprisngly simple for a rogue game

Details:

Possibly the worst part of the game is the inventory management.  This sounds like a weird gripe, and I've played lots of games with terrible inventory management and just dealt with it, but this is definitely the worst inventory management in a game I've ever seen.  Basically you've got somewhere on the order of 1000 different item types in the game, and all can be used to craft stuff, but you can only hold onto 60ish items at a time.  Sure you have a dimensional stash that you can visit any time, but with that many item types, you'll be visiting it every 3 minutes.

Even choosing a no-crafting skills build, which seems to be the only option, its still surprisingly annoying to deal with given you need food and booze of which there's like 100 types.  So then it comes down to choosing builds that don't craft and use vampirism (no food), and don't use throwing or crossbows,  just to play the game without going insane.

Next up is the repetitiveness.  Most roguelikes have unique enemies with interesting abilities, enviromental hazards, and their own brew of general randomness to spice things up.  This game is mostly just stacking on various resistances and bonuses and dealing with your enemy's resistances and bonuses.  You look at the forums, and most build discussion is even just about choosing builds that let you stack certain stats.  This kind of munchkinery is super fun for about 15 hours or so, but it gets old really quick.  When you combine this with the fact that a floor takes about an hour (half an hour on "no grind" lol) and there's fifteen floors, and you're mostly just spamming the left mouse button, I think a lot of people will just get bored.  Even with the builds that implement some form of strategy, it's going to be the exact same strategy for any situation.

There's some major balance concerns as well, although since it's single player, you can just opt out of using the overpowered crap or choose random builds.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999011256', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2944, 'last_played': 1634646914}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995318320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 12477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5963, 'last_played': 1696318294}
review:
Do you like rogue likes? Do you like diving into randomly generated, themed dungeons in the search of treasure? Monsters to kill for XP? Property to break for XP? Traps to disarm for XP (or to kill you)? Strange puzzles and stranger choice of wall hangings? Do you like side quests? Main quests? Personal quests? This isn't really a quest but I'm going to ship it anyway? Do you like selling off loot for money? Do you like robbing vending machines? Do you like strange snippets of humor so obscure even the most pale of basement dwellers will have to resort to google? Do you like strange dimensions filled with yet even more strangeness? Do you like trying all sorts of weird and illogical character setups just to see how wonderfully or poorly you do? Do you like weird achievements that'll have you chuckling and scratching your head at the same time?

... no???

Then what the hell is wrong with you!? Get this game!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004368051', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 1243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1238, 'last_played': 1661265818}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a rather silly rogue-like with its odd sense of humour, but one with an extreme amount of depth to it. In many ways it is extremely simple to play, with a variety of skills to choose and customize your character with, crafting of various types of items ranging from weapons to armor to consumables, and a huge roster of different enemies to fight.

Essentially the game is played by traveling room by room. There are multiple stairways which are used to changed levels, and there are also a plethora of different interactable environmental items, and you also have your personal pocket dimension which you can use to store loot.

Primarily what is really good about this game is that it is beginner friendly. While experienced players can also find enjoyment from playing Dungeons of Dredmor, one who has never really experienced what Rogue-like games has to offer will likely be the targeted audience of this game. 

While other Traditional Rogue-likes will generally be more about attracted players who have already played Rogue-likes, it is rather unique to see a game like Dungeons of Dredmor which seeks to attract players from outside of it.

Hats off to this game for that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048015091', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 2511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2249, 'last_played': 1670300252}
review:
[h1]Я не понимаю, почему эта игра так не популярна...[/h1]

По мне, так это самый лучший рогалик на свете. Тут есть и отсылки и юмор на высоте. Уровни не надоедают разнообразностью (главное докупите ДЛС - больше монстров будет разных).  Много скилов и стилей ведения игры. Я вообще не понимаю, как ты до сих пор не установил себе игру. Хочешь увидеть женщину-пчелу с копьем? а может летающую картошку с глазами? или с ручным драконом побегать?

Да, здесь нет шапок от Габена или мида, но вот список вещей, которые тут есть:
-броня чувака из Doom
-шашлык-меч
-световой меч, который называется Mace of Windu (͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
-шапка-дорожный конус
-кинжал-невидимка
-куча слизней
-омлет из яиц дигглов
-лютефиск
-еще слизни
-скил археолога и банкира (в подземелье, да)
-можно стрелять лазерами из глаз
-атомная бомба (крафт из водки и черной дыры)
-кривые мечи
-слизни-клептоманы
-враждебная брюква
-враждебная морковь
-слиток пластмассы, из которого можно сделать пластмассовый меч, который будет наносить больше урона, чем твой из свинины
-серп и молот, скил коммуниста...
-мастерская с модами от сообщества
-много юмора [b]ПОВСЮДУ[/b]

[i]Серьезно, если ты любишь рогалики и/или хочешь хорошенько прикончить время, эта игра идеально подходит![/i]

[h1]10/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198344257980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2941, 'last_played': 1483125412}
review:
レビューとサンプル動画が面白そうなのでセール中に購入。
コストに対しての内容が非常によかったです。

各種ステータスなど多彩(無駄が多い？)なのでそこがとっつきにくいですが、何度か死に覚えしてわかってくると幅がぐっと広がります。
厳密なローグライクとは違うのですが、難易度も選べてゲームバランスも悪くないのでローグライクが好きな方はｵｽｽﾒです。

深く潜れば潜るほどレアが落ちてプレイが楽しかった。

review:
the game is fun and silly.
it gives me the best feeling I have had with the idea of "It is fun to lose" kinds of themes.
it also has the power to get me playing it when i am a bit board and don't know what I want to do with some spare time.

a nother good thing about it is that because it is turn based you can just walk away to answer the door, get distracted by your partner, or just fall asleep with your head on the desk. it does not matter the game won't suddnly kill you.

all that said it is also a game that can take quite some time to get a good build to win the game.
which is also pulling me back for "just one more run" to finally kill the boss.

review: Good for who is nostalgic of old school games, funny and really hard, nearly everything makes you die: Drink a weird potion? Die. Kick a door? Die. Enter a portal? Die. The best part of this is that the anger of loosing makes you start playing it again to beat the challenge but after a while might get boring (after you learn how to properly play), so its good for short time playing but it will not last long.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996647128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5719, 'last_played': 1511377811}
review: Roguelite RPG. Thematically funny and deceptively deep mechanically. Able to provide tens of hours of entertainment at a very low price, and Steam workshop support helps extending its lifespan. Great purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001414588', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1369, 'last_played': 1532456684}
review:
A great little rouge like game with surprising depth. Numerous skill choices result in a large amount of replayability and even when you die on a particularly successful run, you are always left looking forward to the next game.

I highly recommend playing with the Death by a Thousand Taunts mod from the workshop, it makes the game just that much more funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005718966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 8016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7943, 'last_played': 1518382882}
review:
SKÖL! Having had this game for a great while, I can never forget the stress it is to invest and effort, hell, maybe even "blood, sweat and tears" can be used, into defeating Dredmor. Your choices REALLY matter in this game. You may survive more dangers than you can remember in a journey only to find yourself helpless to finish your quest. Or misclicking and attacking the shopkeeper one level before the end and run into a monster house while running from him.

This is a game that rewards defeat because (1) you will face lots of it; (2) you will hurt and you will perish and; (3) losing can be very fun if done right. And there's no other game in which starting over is as fun.

I will be forever torn between Dungeons of Dredmor and Team Fortress 2 for the title of the game that entertained me the most in Steam. And considering I played TF2 ten times as much, you can guess how concentrated the fun is in this one. Go into the workshop, subscribe to a "even more insults" mod and enjoy DoD!

review:
Dungeons of Dredmor создана  студией Gaslamp Games, состоящей из шести человек. Своеобразная игра - бродилка по подземельям. Рогалик одним словом. Но несмотря на относительное однообразие игрового процесса, она затягивает.

Плюсы (+):

Уровень юмора на высоте

Минусы (-):

Уровни штампованные, практически не отличаются;
Оголтелый  и бессмысленный крафтинг;
Отсутствие баланса в скилах

author: {'steamid': '76561198018635302', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 16988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9177, 'last_played': 1552667169}
review:
It reminds me of a game, I've played some years ago. How was it called... hmm... hmm... aha Castle of the Winds for Win95.
I have loved it and I'm was happy that I found similar rogue-like games now on Steam like DoD. 

And what have CotW and DoD common?

Well one fact to pitiful fail ^^, if no one has a plan first how it works, but after some time it isnt not really a problem anymore.
And DoD goes one step further with its sense of humor... just to die by "kicking something" down.

If you like rogue-like rpgs/games with its own sense of humor then I can recommend DoD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026513342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11121, 'last_played': 1483863278}
review:
Negatives: 
I wish there was a “disable auto-save” button. It’s every five minutes or so and causes lag every time. Crashes the game from time to time but hey, you get that achievement very easy if that’s what you’re after. 

Positives: 
Nice not to be bound by rules of who can do what. You can define your skills any way you want.  
Side quests are offered. You decide if you want to do them or not.
The taunts are funny, making your own gear is really nice and you can have companions.
The monster zoo’s are difficult – brutal even. Often I’ve found myself out of lock picks, kicking the door down and whooa.. I was NOT prepared for this! Wyrmling? Come on boy – let’s do this! :)
 
Result:
To begin with I thought the game looked a bit “naah”, but that changed when I tried it. It’s a great game. How to play is easy to learn. The hard part – besides killing Dredmor – is to figure out what skill-combo and strategy works best for you. It’s trial and error. It’s brutal at times. But it’s fun, challenging and very addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036269456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 23919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22846, 'last_played': 1481199532}
review:
You will die. You will die in the tutorial. You will die in the main game. But you will push on, you will persist, and in the end, by dint of hard work and mental fortitude... you will die again. Yeah. Just take a gander at my playtime.

Dungeons of Dredmor is a frustrating and addictive time sink, with uproarious descriptions (like Self-Righteous Sword of White Lies: "Really, it's for their own good" and One-Armed Leather Jacket: "Evidently we DO need another hero"), intermixable skill trees (you can be a Communist Vegan Tourist Pirate with the power of Mathemagic) and deceptively cute enemies. I mean, the game's mascot is called a Diggle. It even SOUNDS cute!

review:
The first couple of times I played this, I found the humour, mechanics, and gear management to be interesting and fun. At this point, when there isn't much new stuff to discover, the game has evolved into a satisfying game to play while doing other things (watching tv, listening to a podcast, etc.). Either way, I've sunk a lot of time into it, and you probably will too.

This game is probably the oldest in my recently played list. Still a favourite.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035619813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8330, 'last_played': 1571599440}
review: I love this game. Dungeons of Dredmor is a Rogue-like game that doesn't take itself too seriously. In fact, I would call this game plain goofy, in the best of ways. You play as a hero trying to defeat Dredmor; starting with a build of 7 skills and your wits you delve into the dungeons ready to fight whatever monsters you meet and collect a wide variety of items that can be useful (or not) in your quest. The large number of skills to pick from, as well as the insane number of stats to investigate give thee player the ability to customize their character beyond what anyone could consider rational. But thats the fun of it, after all!

author: {'steamid': '76561198019158619', 'num_games_owned': 548, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 18565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18354, 'last_played': 1648518504}
review:
It's a damn fun game with a fun sense of humor. Graphics are good so your eyes aren't bleeding from looking at the screen. Music is great. Some skills are broken while others are underpowered, but that's just the nature of the game. RNG can make or break you but most of the time you're fine as long as you play cautiously. The game also doubles as a great way to introduce people to the Roguelike genre.

Main con is its instability from time to time. Could use a bit more work on the backend but Gaslamp Games has since moved on to solely working on Clockwork Empires, so don't expect it anytime in the near future (or at all, but never say never!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198001178635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3379, 'last_played': 1494179635}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051133213', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 6602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3799, 'last_played': 1670767241}
review: An absolutely fantastic game that is cheap as chips and has a ton of replay value. There are hundreds of ways to play and build your character which allows for some roleplay too. Last playthrough I was Lee Chan One Punch Man with a fully unarmed build. Other times I've been a Paranormal Undercover Werediggle. It's just a lot of fun, with well designed creatures, loads of hilarious names and comments and to top it all off it has a great soundtrack and Steam Workshop support with a whole host of mods available. It was one of the first games I must've bought on Steam years ago, and I still find myself playing it today. I only wish it was available on mobile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010545742', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 31671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12611, 'last_played': 1688055216}

Its replayable becouse of the above.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999168975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 15153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10588, 'last_played': 1685647967}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016568458', 'num_games_owned': 1432, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 5839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4254, 'last_played': 1707685760}
review:
Настоящий Рогалик с большой буквы Р. Полный комплект: куча полезных но непонятных (и не менее любопытных) веток скиллов, куча полезных и не очень бафов, режим пермасмерти (по желанию), возможность зайдя "не туда" мгновенно получить люлей, и конечно же рандомная генерация, вполне достойная. Можно упомянуть систему крафта, хотя это специфично для жанра.
И конечно же Графон, нет, не эти ваши 4к текстуры с размыливанием в виде DOF и блюра, а вполне приятные глазу спрайты.
... Святые яйца диглей, тут есть воркшоп!
И да пребудет с вами благосклонность рандома.
Все еще читаешь этот обзор?! Однозначно надо брать!

review:
It ticks all the right rogue boxes for me:

- Difficult enough that I've never beaten it on easy after 100 hours
- Too many damn builds to master
- A bunch of arcane nonsense I can't come close to comprehending (stats, crafting)
- Enough rope to hang yourself with if you start thinking you're getting the hang of it

Game of the forever.

.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012442546', 'num_games_owned': 2657, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 3422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2974, 'last_played': 1612379349}
review:
This is probably about the best roguelike money can buy.
You could pay for others... but this one will do the trick, it's pretty enjoyable and has a nice amount of content.
Keep in mind this is a Roguelike, not Roguelite. 
If you're looking to give this kind of thing a try this is probably what you ought to go with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046275524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 16273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3588, 'last_played': 1695205553}
review:
If you're looking for a Rogue-Like game that is full of mentions of other games, series, movies and nerdy stuff, (for example Doom, Doctor Who, 300, Warhammer Fantasy) then this is your game. 

Game is tough and proves enough of a challenge at first, but once you get a good skill combo and get the hunch of the skills and abilities, you can get pretty far. I've done 20+ runs and only once managed to kill Lord Dredmor.

Also the steam workshop offers some nice user-made mods that bring in more content to the game (I enjoy the new rooms especially, since the old ones get kinda boring after a while)

Also, this game is dirt cheap. Geddit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975160678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2036, 'last_played': 1493587540}
review: This is a great roguelike that combines some very silly Piers Anthony-esque humor and a skillset system that makes it possible to make wildly different characters.  It is way too easy to get stuck in the "one more room" loop and wind up playing the game hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053509084', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 66852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48521, 'last_played': 1701126621}
review: A silly little dungeon crawler that teaches you important lessons about Communism, fungal farming, wading through crap you'll never need, accepingt criticism, micromanaging binge drinking, and the futility of accomplishing anything.  It is recommended you embrace random skill generation and find the pleasure in struggling to salvage the build.
