author: {'steamid': '76561197987043371', 'num_games_owned': 789, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 7512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6821, 'last_played': 1607294690}
review:
So, it's occurred to me that I've had this game for a long time (and played it for more hours than it even shows here) and yet I've never done a review of it as I usually do for favorite games.  'Bout bloody time I did.

So, Dungeons of Dredmor... where to begin?  It's hard to really talk about all of the aspects of the game because there are SO MANY of them.  This is likely to be one of the first things you notice about Dredmor:  The sheer ridiculous amount of content, particularly once you have the expansions installed (and I highly recommend all three).  Character creation for example... even just the base game has 35 "skills" to pick from, with the number being just under 50 with the expansions installed.  And these skills are really skill SETS.  You choose 7 of them when you create your character (any combination is fine), and once you're in the game, each of these will start at their base skill.  When you level-up, in addition to getting a boost to your prime stats (more on that later) you also go into the big skill list, and you choose one of the seven to rank up.  Each rank in each set offers you something new... some fun new active ability, some wonky passive, some stats... in my experience, there really arent any "duds" among the skillsets here, and levelling up is always very satisfying.

And the skills are VARIED.  There's some crazy stuff here.  Some of them are fairly basic... for example, sword skills, or crafting.  But then you get to Dredmor's general comedic weirdness.  For example, one of my favorites is the Bankster set.  Right from the start, this one gives you an ability called "High Interest Loan".  Use it, and a big pile of money drops at your feet.  Sounds good, right?  Well, it has a fair chance of then also hitting you with a "Bankster debuff", of which there are about 7 types.  ALL of them drain money from you in some fashion, with one of them lasting indefinitely until you either run out or the effect is removed.  Now it doesnt seem so good, yeah?  Well, that's where the rank 2 ability, "Dump Toxic Assets", comes in.  You can take any Bankster debuffs you have at the moment, turn them into poison-based damage, and fling them at your enemy.  As with any skills in the game, these have cooldowns, so using this set PROPERLY (as most of the abilities in the set can debuff you) requires that you time your skill usage correctly, and that you understand what they do.   Skills and spells in the game are like that:  Some of them get complicated in an interesting way, and they often tend to be fairly creative in how they behave.  I mean, really, when was the last time a game let you kill a giant angry carrot by having a bad credit score at it?   Things get even more interesting when these skill sets combine, and with so many, there's TONS of ways to synergize.

Items are pretty similar:  Very creative, very diverse, very useful.  And this game LOVES it's items.  You'll get a ton of them.  WAY too many.  You have a large inventory, but you'll run out of space fast.  From things like food/drink (heal HP/MP) to potions or mushrooms to crafting equipment or much crazier stuff, the game has about a kersquillion items.  The best part is, most of them are actually USEFUL to you.  

And that's good, because the game REALLY expects you to be using them.  While the combat, at it's core, may be simple (walk towards a monster to strike them, and of course you have your spells and such) the game likes to throw alot of monsters at you.  Sometimes a HUGE amount, in what are known as "Monster Zoos"... big rooms where every single freaking tile has a monster on it.  You could get anywhere from 50 to 150 monsters in one zoo; zoos are effectively the "boss fights" of the game (complete with unique music) and there's one on each floor (but you dont know where!) except the first.  Beyond that, sometimes you get elite monsters, the occaisional monster from a couple floors up, and of course monsters have various stats and abilities, some getting rather unpleasant indeed.

Which relates to one issue that some players may run into is that, yes, while the game may be accessible in some ways, it can get pretty darn tough.  I've seen plenty of players hit their first zoo and just get utterly splattered (and then try it a few more times, getting splattered even worse); traditional roguelikes dont exactly teach you to deal with 120 enemies (many of them with ranged spells or goofy abilities) all at the same time!  Yet the game expects you to do this on EVERY floor.  This is where all of those items and skills come in though... beating really tough encounters in this game, zoos or otherwise, is almost like solving a puzzle, carefully figuring out how to use all the stuff available to you to defeat it; you cant just beat everything over the head and do nothing else.  The good thing is that the game pretty much ALWAYS gives you the tools (there are a sqillion items lying around for a reason...) you just need to figure out how they can be used to get past a given situation.  It can get complicated.  Not to mention the way your stats work.  You have 6 primary stats, and 19 secondary ones.  Primary stats can affect secondary ones, but more than that, this means that there's LOTS of possible stats that can appear on equipment (or on buffs/debuffs).  Building your character well means understanding what all of these do.  In addition, there's ALSO like 16 damage types.  For players such as myself that love min-maxing and dealing with stats in these games, well, this game does it VERY well.  But for others this may be a major turnoff.

However, this IS a roguelike... one way or another, there are so very, very many ways to die, yet one issue is that this is a LONG game.  Each floor is huuuuuuuuuuuge, and in the base game, there are 10 of them (with expansions, there are 15, as well as special side areas).  And there's about a gazillion things to do.  A full run-through of the game takes quite a long time.  This isnt exactly new for this genre, but it's very worth mentioning.   You have the ability to save & quit at absolutely any time though.  But it can be very frustrating to do something like get aaaaaaallllllll the way to Lord Dredmor (who is NOT a pushover) and then die to him.  All that time it took to get there... lost in one moment of SPLAT.   The game will never kill you in ways that are genuinely unfair, but that of course never stops frustration in a case like that.   Accessible though the game may be, it really is best suited to roguelike fans that are more than used to things like that happening.

If you can get past that bit though.... this is an absolutely fantastic game.  I've played so many roguelikes, but this one is by far my favorite. It has it's small issues... but there's so very much going for it that it's way more than worth those minor quibbles.  Also it's got a really good sense of humor.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005741042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 3171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2988, 'last_played': 1628488752}
review:
Pour quelques euros, Dungeons of Dredmor et ses DLC proposent un «donjon» solo riche et complet, qui me ferait presque passer pour un commercial devant mon enthousiasme sans limites. Il est évident qu’il ne fera pas fumer pas votre carte graphique et ne triturera pas vos méninges avec son scénario en carton. Mais ce rogue-like à la jouabilité simple et efficace, sa rejouabilité énorme et sa modularité en font un must have à posséder absolument. Ou, du moins, à tester pour les plus sceptiques, mais à déconseiller aux gens hermétiques au tour par tour qui trouveront l'action trop lente. On regrettera qu’il ne soit pas en français pour profiter de son humour décalé. Du coup, si on accroche à la patte graphique, les heures défileront et c’est la preuve que l’on est face à un grand jeu. Tout petit, mais grand !

Le détail de ce test : http://rpgjeuxvideo.eklablog.fr/dungeons-of-dredmor-dlc-a127286238

author: {'steamid': '76561197977575504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1577, 'last_played': 1479508038}
review: Great rouguelike game, fun and addicting.  The amount of different builds you can create is massive, the RNG element make this game very replayable.  One of my favorite rogue like games out there next to Risk of Rain.

review: This was the first dungeon crawler i've ever played. And yet i'm more then satisfied by what this game has on offer. The tutorials help you get grounded and the difficulty begins with simple enemies that help you ease into the game. despite being/looking simple this game has a lot of depth to it. I highly recommend it to everyone to at least give a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032402434', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3992, 'last_played': 1572933177}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970898685', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1561467747}
review:
The game will give you several hours of enjoyment before the fun wears off. It's repetitive, fairly easy and YOUR INVENTORY IS FULL. At it's current price, it's really not a bad deal but could use a little bit of love in the UI department.

Edit: A couple of years later and I decided to revisit the game. I was unable to beat the final boss and I can live with that, however it is such a missed opportunity that they did create an endless level mode or at least add more. Based on what I've read, there's 15 under certain circumstances, however I only saw 10 before getting wiped out.

The game became a breeze, so it was a little odd for the final boss to be nearly impossible to beat. You have to run specific builds and honestly, that ruins of the fun of having so many oddball skills at your disposal if only a handful of them will get you the win in the end.

Still, a fun game that I ended up really enjoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052611814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1429791968}

author: {'steamid': '76561198037960504', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5210, 'last_played': 1649298972}
review:
Not a perfect game, but one of my favorites nonetheless.

First off, the graphics are an old-timey pixel style and it relies heavily on humor, both of which are subjective. I happen to like them but you might not. Because it's so much a matter of opinion I won't be considering these things in my review. Also, some people have complained of bugs and save corruption, but honestly I haven't experienced any of that. It's probably dependent on your hardware, but I can't say for certain.

What I can say is, get the DLC. It's only a couple extra dollars for a [i]lot[/i] more content. Some of the most interesting and creative skill trees are in the expansions and they will vastly increase the longevity of the game. One of them adds a "pocket dimension" which you can usually unlock in the first level, which is essentially a safe room you can warp to at any time. I use it to store items far beyond what the regular inventory allows and I can't imagine playing without it.

First the good news:
[list]
[*]The game seems simple on the surface but there is a surprising amount of variety in the abilities you can employ and the enemies you will face. There's a lot to keep track of so it won't be for everyone, but for me it is incredibly satisfying to find a clever solution to a seemingly inescapable problem.
[*]All playstyles are viable. Obviously some classes synchronize well with certain others, but there's no single combination that dominates all the rest. As I said in the previous point, it's all about using what you have creatively to beat the odds.
[*]The developers have given a huge attention to detail. Whether or not you're a fan of the game's sense of humor, they have gone to great lengths to allude to a much greater universe in the descriptions of the items and enemies, as well as making their narrative themes line up with their in-game abilities.
[*]There's always time to think. This is more a matter of opinion, but as someone who can never get his head around fast-paced real-time action games, this one plays out almost like a weird sort of chess. You can take as much time as you need between moves to plan your actions. Because the AI is fairly predictable, tricky situations become more puzzle than battle, and if you want to succeed I recommend thinking of them as such.
[/list]

Now the bad news:
[list]
[*]There is a lot of RNG in this game, which makes things inherently unfair. It WILL screw you over, especially if you play with permadeath. You can't get too attached to your games because of this.
[*]The UI is pretty clunky, which seems to be one of the major complaints looking at other reviews. Because the game is turn based it doesn't [i]usually[/i] screw you over, but it is annoying.
[*]In trying to be witty, the descriptions of skills and items don't always give you a clear idea of what they do. I figured it out gradually just by playing the game, and I'm sure there's some sort of wiki you can use as well. Still, the developers could have made it a little clearer.
[*]Some of the settings can't be changed in-game. This can be annoying, but once it's set up the way you want it, it shouldn't be a problem very often.
[/list]

So, as I said at the beginning: not a perfect game, but still a very good one. It's not be the kind of game you play for hours on end every day, but I return to it every so often for a few hours of fun and very rarely do I leave disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083045493', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1477800894}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is overrated. I'm not sure why it is, but one thing's for sure: It's sure offset as hell.

The gameplay itself is average compared to other dungeon crawlers, except for the fact that the game is almost impossible to play without taking the tutorial first. RPGs are usually easy to learn to play on your own, but DoD just flat-out crosses the line. To give you an idea, it takes you about 8 seconds to simply place a goddamn item in your inventory. There's an option for a quick place, but it barely makes a difference.

The camera is offset to the point where it's risky to just move down. The GUI is in the way of almost the entire bottom screen, and there are no options to move it somewhere else or even just lower the size.

Don't even get me started on the graphics. The graphics are as if Doom and Oregon Trail II had a baby and then proceeded to puke all over it. Maybe that's an exaggeration, but the screen is blurry, it's hard to make out what the monsters even are, and the main character. Ugh! Why did the developers make his eyebrows the size of the Titanic?

Overall, I rate Dungeons of Dredmor a 4/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071421958', 'num_games_owned': 855, 'num_reviews': 340, 'playtime_forever': 1812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1337, 'last_played': 1670817479}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028096483', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 1020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1501163941}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038688690', 'num_games_owned': 844, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 13967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13841, 'last_played': 1477463062}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmore is funny, it has a lot of wit to it and deciding what skills you want to bring into the game is always a blast.

But the buck stops there.

- The game is poorly optimized often lagging on machines no matter their power level.
- you cant change many options once the game has loaded
- important options like being able to scroll through the battle log are not in the game (hope you didn't need to know if your attack did any damage, or who out of the 8 monsters on you hit you the hardest) Change the ui on the screen? Nope, you get to fear walking down in this game because you ui blocks anything below you so you will never know what's there until you walk headlong into it.
- game has little annoyances that slow it down into a slog, like constantly having to pick things up manually (yes there is an auto option for pickups but its lackluster) or having to watch your screen like a hawk for traps because even though your character  can see them, he will happily walk into them like an idiot if you are not paying close attention.

and finally the most damning problem of them all

- THERE is a RIGHT way to build your character, and if you built them any other way you cannot win! At least not fairly.
The final boss has only one real weakness so I hope you chose one of the skills at the start that let you capitalize on that, else your dead. Restart and try again from the beginning chump.

This game has great potential but it lacks common sense and a large amount of polish that it needed it ever be worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987101362', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1586029424}
review: The gameplay seemed too slow for me, even for a roguelike, and the interface was clunky. For example: clicking on a found item does not add it to inventory, but picks it up with the cursor so you have to click on the player character to add it to inventory, but if you don't click on the square your standing on the item will drop on the square behind you. Also, you have to open two separate windows (character and inventory) to equip items.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009093193', 'num_games_owned': 2404, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 12313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4540, 'last_played': 1708889194}
review:
One of the most fun rogue-like games I've ever played, the one that got me into rogue-likes too if I'm being honest, there's so much great about it too.  The crafting, the skill lists, the ability to basically build your own character, the expansions.

And it's only $5 now?!  If you don't have this yet you have no excuses aside from "I didn't know it was a thing!"

Seriously, this game is great.  Only real flaw is if you have a low resolution monitor, your vision-range will be capped to your monitor size. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198056701760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 5306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5167, 'last_played': 1648943818}
review:
Without mods, this is one of the best dungeon crawlers I've ever played. And with mods, this is my favorite dungeon crawlers of all time. Extraordinary customizability, cool monster designs, and a terrific sense of humor make this a terrific game. Only major complaint is that the portal to leave level 0 of the dungeon sometimes doesn't spawn in an accesible area, trapping you there forever.
Also, shield bash is best skill. Enemy giving you trouble? Shield bash it into a pile of mush. Item spawned under a vending machine? Shield bash that vending machine into the next dimension. Don't feel like solving a puzzle? Shield bash the puzzle until it gives in and gives you its rewards. Shield bash is all you need.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012942245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2507, 'last_played': 1478024525}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028827870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1670286350}
review: I must say that I have been eyeing this game for a while, seeing it and its low price and thinking "wow, that game doesn't look that bad and it's only five dollars.", but let me tell you, its worth way more. This game is so captivating and fun to play that I can just get lost in it, even though I have only been playing for roughly 4 hours. Today, my aunt told me if I watch her dogs until she comes home, she will pay me $10 an hour that I am here and I get to bring my computer. This game was a LIFESAVER because I have been here since 3:00 and its almost 11:00. One of the dogs is blind, so nothing to worry about there, and the other is a cripple, so nothing to worry about there either. Neither of them move and I would have been so bored but this game was so interesting with its skills that let you do a wide variety of spells and other such abilitys. If you like turn based RPGs, then this is the one if you want to know what an original classic is like. By the way, the Diggles are the best enemy ever they are so CUTE!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067601581', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 33311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26501, 'last_played': 1706466469}
review:
Well... what can I say? I have over 400 hours put into this game and I still love it. If that's not enough proof, look at my achievements, certainly I wouldn't be playing this game to just get the achievements to prove a point.

Instead of the usual from what is said from many other reviews, I would like to point out what I liked about the game.

1. Skill Diversity: You can pick any 7 skills out of the ones presented before you. Truthfully based on my 400+ hour experience, any build is viable but killing Dredmor himself is entirely something else. Not all skills will/may be used and even a skill at their first level may be good enough throughout the whole game.
2. Loot/item diversity: There is a lot, and I mean A LOT, of items in this game. Most for crafting and some really good equipment. If you're the kind of guy that likes to hoard up on items for use later, this is your game.
3. Simple, yet addictive: When you start the game it's probably one of the hardest things to go forward from. You're weak, you're level 1, you might not have a weapon or enough food. But whatever the case once you get the hang of it you just can't stop playing, especially when you find a new and better weapon to use or a skill that's so freaking awesome.
4. Music/sound/animation: To complement with the game it has music. It's got sounds including voices. And they even had the time to animate pretty much all the attacks in the game. This ain't no ASCII nethack ( no offense to them really). Enjoy it while you can.
5. You can mod it: You may need an expertise to help you on this but nevertheless you can mod this game and make your own skills, skill portraits, attacks, and what not. There are literally thousands of mods out there, find one you like, load it up and play it.

Now this game isn't all perfect. There have been a number of glitches, annoyances, and bugs, can be game breaking, beneficial, and unfair, included in this game and have never been fixed. Some of them include game crashes, walking through enemies, mulitple turns, steam cloud issues (i only had this happen once and found out the problem), infrequent slowdowns on animations, and game loading issues. The bad bugs don't happen as often as you think and the good bugs are game breaking so I don't want to talk about how to do them.

Overall I really highly recommend this game. Don't be put off by the graphics, or let alone the innumerable number of stats you have to read. Once you play the game you'll find it to be quite appeasing, especially the countless number of jokes and references it makes to real life and fictional media. It's one of the running gags in the game. A very prime example would be the portrait you see on the bottom of the screen so go take a minute to look at the images for this game. It pays homage to the Wolfenstein games and your character gets more bloody the lower his/her hp, just like in Wolfenstein. Are you a Star Wars fan? The character Mace Windu has a sword named after him in this game called Mace of Windu. Not a Star Wars fan huh... what about Star Trek? Weld a Lirpa and destroy your enemies with its fantastically high attack power.
There's so much reference it makes to the outside, try to spot them all. That alone should be enough to keep you intrigued about the game.

10/10 EXTREMELY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for roguelike lovers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013180364', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1499266111}
review:
As far as I played so far it's a neat game. There are a few flaws: some skills are just plain OP'd while others are unbalanced (compare golemancy to pyro), and it's far too easy to walk into traps if you're using the arrow keys or WASD (there might be an option to stop the player from walking into detected traps, idk). There's not that much variety in rooms- you're going to die so much that you'll be able to memorize all the rooms that appear on at least floor 1. Dungeon floors are way too big but there is an option for smaller dungeon floors which imo should be the default, but at least it's there.

When permadeath is enabled, the game's extremely challenging- but at the same time, there's just not enough variety to make going through the first few floors tens/hundreds of times exciting, even with a different build. One of those games you should play for maybe 40 minutes a day when you're not busy, but it's still a good game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198016810426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 22379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8117, 'last_played': 1707728992}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040711515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 20370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14078, 'last_played': 1477816348}
review:
This game is a TRUE rougelike. As in follows the same gameplay format as the original Rouge. Compared to Rouge however, Dredmor is a lot more accessible and takes itself less seriously.

Dredmor is good. It's a GREAT place to start if you're looking to get into true Rouge games, or even before all the Rouge-like variations as it is very much more forgiving (there's a non-perma death setting ;) ).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035566899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1665076425}
review:
I genuinely was not expecting to enjoy this game so much. The style of graphics are really, really bad, and that put me off of the game initially. It looked amateurish to me.

However, after reading recommendation upon recommendation, I decided to pick it up. This game is so damn complex and well-crafted, I feel almost foolish at having discarded it at first. Although I still dislike the graphics, the UI itself is close to perfect, the replability value is enormous, and the combat and interface is finely tuned.

Excellent stuff, and I highly advise any rougelike fans to pick this up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987270895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 8636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8586, 'last_played': 1530392054}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a fantastic game if you haven't played any "real" roguelike games like Nethack, ADOM or Crawl and would like to make the entrance as smoothly as possible. Dredmor is hard, has permadeath (as an option!) and is procedural. Artwork is whimsical, silly and everything is covered in humor. There are jokes in item, skill and creature descriptions, in the lore and... everywhere! Tongue in cheek you seek the lord of the dungeon and try to slay him using skilltrees like Mathemagic and Communism with all sorts of weird DIY-gear from plastic arrows to tin hats. 

All this might fall a bit short for those that know the genre by heart and seek both complexity and difficulty. Both exist here too but not in a sense where you want to spend hours thinking "what should I wear" and how can I survive this situation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214592032', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1636976332}
review:
Note: my play time doesn't reflect my countless playthroughs. I can't even fathom the hours I've poured into this on rainy days.

PROS:
* As roguelike as roguelike can get. Sometimes RNG will bite you in the butt, but sometimes the dice are nice. For the most part though, it's pretty forgiving, at least early on. Most of the time it's just a matter of picking a couple skills that can reliably get you through the first few floors, and by that time you'll have enough levels (and lucky loot) to keep on climbing.
* Maintains an upbeat, quirky, and tastefully humorous tone in the music, dialog and flavor text, all of which belie the treacheries of the Dungeons.
* Mods galore! More rooms in floors, more classes with unique effects that are (usually) balanced, check out the Steam Workshop and see if anything tickles your fancy, there's plenty to choose from. 

CONS:
* Very bulky crafting system, with an equally bulky UI to go with it. More often than not, you're better off praying to RNGesus than trying to amass the skill levels and materials for some recipe you found. Ironically, the game itself makes fun of how bulky its crafting system is, one joke I did not smile at.

Overall, if you like roguelikes even in the slightest, this is a must-have in your library. Get it, play it on hard with perma-death, get really far, die, get frustrated, shut it off, then come back because you *know* you want some more of that sweet Dredmor punishment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084019881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 480, 'playtime_forever': 4978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4978, 'last_played': 1403323356}
review:
Рогалик — цель которого было стать эталоном в мире рогаликостроения, то есть история отсутствует как класс,  используется не сильно отвлекающая от игры графика, море вражьего мяса (в буквальном смысле, вы офигеете [i]sic![/i], когда первый раз вскроете  Monster Zoo) и принципиально разные способы его переработки.

При создании героя нужно выбрать семь умений из весьма обширного списка ёмкостью в несколько десятков. Следует понимать, что эти умения вам будут нужны не только чтобы выжить на начальных этапах, но и убить босса, так что рекомендуется посмотреть что выбирают другие, так как ошибиться легко.

[h1]Пример билда[/h1]
Лично я сторонник магического развития, так как это позволяет не входить в физический контакт с озверевшим мясом, а поджигать его издалека. Ключевыми для меня умениями являются Golemancy (Unliving Wall — стенка из камня, блокирующая проход) и Promethean Magic (Gog's Tactical Pyre — стенка огня). Даже босс игры легко блокируется каменной стенкой и сжигается огненной. Для мага важно ещё уметь элегантно сбежать с поля боя, поэтому знание Mathemagic крайне желательно, а именно Xeuclid's Translation. Так же полезно The Recursive Curse, чтобы напустить его на врагов иммунных к огню. Маг без маны — дохлый маг, поэтому удобно взять Blood Magic, Magic Training и Ley Walker. Вы поймёте почему первое архиважно, когда наткнётесь на свой первый зоопарк. Также полезным умением внезапно является Archaeology, точнее It Belongs In A Museum, так как экспы мало не бывает. 

Собственно всё. Да, есть ещё некоторое количество секретов, но с ними вы разберётесь в процессе прохождения.

[h1]GNU/Linux[/h1]
К порту GNU/Linux претензий нет.

[h1]Обзор входит в список [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1103944566]Игры, Linux, Steam, обзоры[/url].[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993344223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1045, 'last_played': 1471153923}
review:
Have you ever wondered what it would be like to have a Rogue-like developed by a team of roughly 10 people who grew up in the mid 90s and were raised entirely by Doom and The Secret of Monkey Island? Of course you don't, that's pretty weird.
Fortunately it exists and it is probably one of the best "true" rogue-like games made in the past 10 years.

[h1]What is it?[/h1]
Dungeons of Dredmor is a Roguelike Fantasy RPG with several pop culture references from the 90s up to the 2010s.
If you are unsure of what a [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roguelike]Rogue-like is[/url], it's a gameplay style based on the 1980 release "Rogue". In a nutshell, you are given [i]one[/i] life to complete the entire game, any death results in a save wipe or a sentence back to the start of the game. As such the game itself is relatively shorter than other RPGs, maybe 2-3 hours with experienced players.

In the more traditional rogue-likes, like this game, you move in a square based grid and take turns with the enemies to either pick up one of the 20 or so types of cheeses, find new gear to equip, or die horribly to one of the many monsters in your way.
Controls to this game are rather simple, move in a grid based map with WASD and use the mouse to interact with objects next to the player. However, [b]I very much recommend turning off mouse movement[/b]. It sounds nice at first, but as far as I know you cannot cancel any mouse movement queues. So if you are suddenly ambushed, you have to take a good 3 turns just to move to the spot you clicked. Which is very bad.

Long story short, this is a [b][i]very[/i][/b] difficult game for newcomers to rogue-likes or even intermediate players who understand most of the things. 
If you really like the concept of this game and must play it first rather than others, thankfully you can lower the difficulty and disable permanent deaths. And it doesn't even make fun of you for it!
I highly recommend the tutorial even if you know what you're doing, it's humorous and gives you a good idea of how to play (character numbers good, hp good, damage bad). 
Further help can be found in this guide that i totally didn't pick because it is only the top rated one: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=148533918
If you want a more casual rogue-like experience to ease into the realm of insanity, I’d recommend trying the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series of games from Spike Chunsoft for Nintendo DS/3DS
If you want a harder, more confusing, and actively update rogue-like; try [url=http://www.bay12games.com/dwarves/]Dwarf Fortress Adventure Mode[/url] (good luck)

[h1]My Experience[/h1]
I've "started" playing this game maybe 4 years ago when I received it in a Humble Bundle. I played it, died, got angry, died again, and wrote it off as a bad game. Since then I have learned that there can be fun found in losing as well as winning. So, About a few weeks ago I picked it back up and tried to beat it again.
As I am writing this (August 14th, 2016), I have yet to complete the game in its entirety, let alone the DLC which extends the game even further. I have met my inevitable demise about 20 times over the years i played this off steam and even now. I plan to make it to the end on my own accord on Normal with Permadeath on, even if it takes me another 4 years.

[h1]Price Point?[/h1]
5 years ago this game released for an almost unheard-of price point of $5, it is still $5 because you can't really lower it anymore than this. They eventually added 3 DLCs. 2 for $3 and 1 for [b]absolutely free![/b] (under the caveat that you have to give it a name). Since then the made a complete edition bundle for $7, which is obviously the best choice in this scenario.
Sales of this game are somewhat common, roughly once every 2-3 months for 50%, with it having a deep discount of 75% at one point.

[h1]Game Updates?[/h1]
On [b]April 1st[/b], 2012, the devs [url=https://www.gaslampgames.com/2012/04/01/dungeons-of-dredmor-ii-3d/]"announced"[/url] that they would be making a sequel to this game. In 3D with the inclusion of Microtransactions and Social Media postings.
As of August 2012, after the release of the third dlc, the devs have no longer added content to this game and moved onto other projects.
Thankfully the game has native steam workshop mod support, so you can add a set of items, skills, or re-sprites to add more to the game. Of course there won't be many mod developers for such a small game as this, but there are quite a few at least.

[h1]Is it worth buying?[/h1]
[b]Yes[/b]. If you like the humor from Monkey Island, the gameplay styles of any "true" rogue-like, or even want to try one for the first time. Definitely pick this title up, even if it's not on sale.
(You're spending maybe $3.50 extra, that's like half the price of a fast food meal for 2)


[url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DoomRL](Also, hilariously enough, there actually is a Doom roguelike)[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198045796166', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 1591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1529, 'last_played': 1393066822}
review:
Rogue-like for non-masochists

It's a beautiful, funny and easy to play rogue-like (turn-based dungeon survival), full of jokes and terrible ways to die. It has options to be played on easier modes than the classic rogue-likes, and has a lot of interesting skills to try, but it is somehow limited on the number of monsters and itens. Playing on "easy" (non-hardcore mode) you will probably hoard a lot of powerful itens that you will never use, because you won't need it. Playing on "hard" is the same thing, because you will die before you get the chance. Reading the itens description will provide some laughs. Other than that, it's an addictive light-rogue, where you can select the amount of punishment you want to have, so if you are into comical graphical rogue-likes, you may like it.

Conclusion:
Addictive and satisfying, a rogue-like that makes you laugh and lets you get to the end within less than a lifetime.

Positive points:
* Beautiful graphics
* Very funny item ans skills descriptions
* Can be played on "easy"

Negative points:
* Not much variation
* Lots of useless and repetivive stuff
* The final boss is boring

author: {'steamid': '76561198079020543', 'num_games_owned': 275, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1642, 'last_played': 1697384501}
review:
[i] Dungeons of Dredmor is an awesome game to play for half an hour at a time, or even hours if you're like me. Although I enjoyed myself playing it, hence why I have more Pros, and do recommend you pick it up if you like what you read, there still are some cons as like with every other game. [/i]

[h1] Pros and Cons [/h1]

[u] Pros [/u]
[list]
[*] Fun skillsystem
[*] Nice graphics
[*] Variation of monsters
[*] Quick run start
[*] Complex statsystem
[*] Nice floorgeneration
[*] Quick to get into
[*] Awesome crafting system
[*] Loads of fun mods
[*] Good difficulty scaling between floors
[/list]

[u] Cons [/u]
[list]
[*] Rare random crashes
[*] Some mosters are weirdly balanced
[*] Loot is weirdly balanced
[*] Repetitive lootgrind
[*] Possible spoiler: [spoiler] Lord Dredmor keeps messing me up [/spoiler]
[/list]

Thanks for reading, hope it helped :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054596844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2770, 'last_played': 1472601046}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026956315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5007, 'last_played': 1469592683}
review:
The thing about Dredmor is that, on the surface, it's really just an average roguelike, intended to ease people into the genre by featuring colorful graphics and easy controls (with mouse support!).

But Dredmor actually does have a few things going for it:

- Workshop support.
- Witty Dialogue.
- Skill Trees (most roguelikes only have a class system, with each only having one specific ability that you're allowed to build on).
- Actually being a roguelike, in spite of its goal of easing people into the system.

Dredmor's Skills are on a build-as-you-want-it basis, so you can take a magic skill tree and pair it with a warrior skill tree with some (possibly disastrous) degree of efficiency. And with every update adding a few more skills, you can technically play a lot of classes without having to play the same combo ever again.

It's also actually a roguelike, compared to "roguelikes" like Binding of Isaac (don't get me wrong, that's a fun game, but it's not a roguelike as some people claim it to be), Enter the Gungeon, and so on and so forth.

Of course, it wins on Gaslamp's sharp wit department. You might end up chuckling at least once at all the referential humor the game boasts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064268501', 'num_games_owned': 1413, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 5023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2347, 'last_played': 1708717279}
review:
Today, Dungeons of Dredmor (DoD) completes five years, and it still remains a great introduction to the roguelike genre, whilst it offers a great deal of challenge for veterans. 

DoD features character building, with a wide range of skills to choose; easy to understand mechanics; great dose of humor, with a lot of references to movies and games; a fantastic soundtrack (the best of this kind of game, IMHO); Steam Workshop for mods and  Steam Cloud support. The gameplay is slow paced, ideal for a strategic approach instead of an action-oriented one, and demands patience from the player. 

The biggest bless and curse of this game, at the same time, it's the [i]loot fest[/i] at every level. When you start playing, you'll certainly spend a decent part of your playthrough managing your loot in your tiny inventory (remember to use Shift+left click to pick up and drop items with more ease). Thankfully, the "Conquest of the Wizardlands" DLC adds the Pocket Dimension - a place where you can store unlimited amounts of loot. By the way, this game is so cheap that you should buy the complete package for a better experience. 

Last but not least, I strongly recommend you to enable OpenGL on the launch options to achieve a smoother experience, avoiding crashes caused by memory leak, and making possible to use the Steam Overlay. To do this, simply right click Dungeons of Dredmor in your Steam library -> Properties -> Set launch options -> type in -opengl -> press ok. 

Funny fact: [spoiler] Everyone that claims this game it's "too easy" never managed to beat it. Funny, huh? Despite the cartoonish graphics and light-hearted aesthetics, DoD can be brutal. [/spoiler]

But if you do try harder then i do then this game has a lot of  replayability and a good sence of humor to it as well as a ton of character builds and a lot of content, and with expansions you wont get bored soon. conclution is that it is very worth the money

author: {'steamid': '76561197963518212', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 17320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1952, 'last_played': 1700178011}
review:
This is by far one of, if not the, best roguelikes for beginners. It's got all the staples; permadeath (optional), difficulty levels, dungeon crawling, randomised level layouts, and different skills that let you customise your build. The skills aren't just the typical RPG '+1' stat boosts, they're actually interesting and unique, and they combine with skills from other trees to make a huge variety of ways to approach the game. And you have just one objective; get to floor 10 (or 15 with the DLC enabled) and kill Lord Dredmor. It's hard, but not copy-proven-builds-from-the-forum hard, and you don't have to be constantly searching a wiki either.

It's challenging, but not essentially impossible like so many roguelikes. Because it's turn-based and offers plenty of different skills, there's plenty of ways to tackle this one. I love that the weapons, trinkets and armour (of which there are many) are static and not procedurally generated. This means you can go hunting for a particular item you need for your build or to deal with a given type of enemy. And when you come across that super rare, super powerful weapon...

A solid choice for those looking for a toe-in-the-water for rougelikes. On top of it all, the game has a great sense of humour. Sure, it's a little rough around the edges. I'd love a bit more variety in the level randomisation. But as they're an indie developer I'm happy to cut them some slack. And it's so cheap; just give it a shot!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039066437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 3882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2906, 'last_played': 1623145221}
review: Yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982863242', 'num_games_owned': 1312, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 11559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8503, 'last_played': 1656196578}
review:
I have played 6 or more new characters over the last couple days. Many of them I played for upwards of five hours. Every last one of them has had their save lost or corrupted after the game crashed. Every one. I tried playing without mods, I tried flushing steam cloud, I tried disabling steam cloud entirely, both from steam and the xml file. I want to rant about this and give them a big thumbs down, and yet-

How many other games could keep me coming back to make a new character after these bullshit crashes?

author: {'steamid': '76561197993862905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 3025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3022, 'last_played': 1480605648}
review:
One of my favorite rouge-likes. This game has a very goofy tone and sticks to it with a very unique sense of humor. Replayability is extremely high, with a wide variety of build options.

Great turn based combat. Easy to play hard to master.

Great bang for your buck. You will definitely be satsified with how much time you get out of such a cheap game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046961562', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1472766132}
review: There is nothing I DRED MOR than Dungeons of Dredmor™

author: {'steamid': '76561197994763127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3189, 'last_played': 1486436292}
review:
I didn't expect to be into this game as much as I have been. FTL has been the only rogue-like I've enjoyed until now. I've played just over 40 hours, have had maybe 30 games and have only gotten as far as level 6. Losing is half the fun. The monster taunts keep me chuckling, and I really enjoy the witty writing for skills and weapon flavor text. There's a lot that I haven't done yet, you learn more about how to play each time you play.

If you enjoy a challenge, dungeon crawling, RPGs and/or mushrooms, then this game is for you!

Downside? The Diggles will haunt you in your sleep...

author: {'steamid': '76561198004197501', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1476332009}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor is just one of those games that takes a well-known genre and does it well. Beyond the very nice gameplay, you get a nice level of humor that just makes it a fun title to mess around with regularly. It's also a friendly game to mess with under the hood, and I recommend it for modders and such.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965771164', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 7202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7202, 'last_played': 1466478064}
review:
One of the better roguelikes on Steam. With all of the DLCs loaded, there are literally dozens of different skill trees that you can pick for a new character. Not to say that all of them are equally useful (because they're not), and it's entirely possible to cherry-pick an overpowered build - which, if you ask me, is perfectly alright: let people play how they want to. It makes hitting the 'random' button during character creation more exciting.

The game's sense of humor will either totally pull you in or will totally put you off. Every skill, enemy, and item you find in the dungeon will have a description that's punny, a meta-reference to something else, and/or just silly. Personally, I love it, but I could see some people taking the game's lack of seriousness as a point against it.

Levelling up almost always provides new skills and abilities that significantly improve your hero, so you really feel like you're getting more powerful - it's not just 'your mana bolt is now 1% stronger.'

There are negatives/things that bother me:

- There are only about a dozen different monster types. Going deeper in the dungeon will just unlock the same monsters with new color schemes.

- By default, everything moves wayyyy too slowly. Hit the '+' key at least once when starting out so you don't have to spend hours watching your character amble along through the dungeon.

- Inventory management is a total pain in the ass. Even with the Wizardland DLC (which I highly recommend), which gives you your very own dimension to store all the crafting junk you come across, you'll still find yourself constantly running out of room because you've picked up a dozen types of cheese, a bar's worth of different types of booze, masses of mushrooms, crossbow bolts made out of six different materials of four different qualities (not even including one-off bolt types!), potions, throwing weapons, wands, etc., etc., etc. Get used to hearing "Your inventory is full!"

- The game's too long, and yet there are options to make it even longer! By default, there are 10 levels of the dungeon. At around dungeon level 5 or 6, your character will probably be strong enough that anything outside of massive monster zoos or a crazy mini-boss monster won't pose much (if any) threat. However, to be able to keep up with the power curve, you're going to have to grind through the levels anyway. With the DLCs, you have the option of expanding the dungeon to 15 levels, as well as having a virtually unlimited amount of wizarding worlds to explore - I would highly recommend NOT doing so.

- While there's an option 'no time to grind', which makes the dungeon smaller (yet having a roughly equal XP curve), which I totally recommend playing with, do note that by choosing this option, you significantly alter the balance of loot - specifically, any crafting class will find it more difficult, since you'll run into significantly less materials.

- Dredmor himself has been balanced against the twink builds. This means that it's possible to have a character that can clear out the entire dungeon but still be unable to actually win the game. Especially classes that are forced to go toe-to-toe with the big man himself - bring massive amounts of dodge and counter or you may as well just go home.

All those things are real problems with the game. However, I've sunk 120 hours into this game and have won it at all difficulties (with permadeath), so I obviously think that the game is well worth playing, despite its warts.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997554291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2442, 'last_played': 1491751635}
review:
Nearly every single piece of flavor text in the entire game reads like a joke written by a Redditor and 99.9% of the jokes are "this game has generic fantasy elements but it's self-aware about them O_o"

But, it's such a fun roguelike that you can actually overlook that

author: {'steamid': '76561198021350576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1674, 'last_played': 1695262153}
review: The comic relief in this game is pure gold.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098457791', 'num_games_owned': 1756, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1542940837}
review: Great roguelike. A little repetitive and a little unbalanced, but fun. Excellent sense of humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059188118', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1787, 'last_played': 1385326705}
review: Simple, fun, easy-to-learn roguelike perfect for people looking to get their feet wet in the genre but who are looking for a simpler experience. The persistent sense of humor is what really sets it apart, with everything from mobs to skills to item descriptions having some ridiculous pun or reference thrown in that keeps things light-hearted throughout. While I will say that there are certainly some issues regarding balance of skills and easy abuse of AI mechanics, the game is for the most part well balanced and definitely polished, and definitely worth the asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067139860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2255, 'last_played': 1703970986}
review:
The forgettable adventures of whatever

Yes I know rogue-like games are light in the story department, but this game is so severely and conspicuously lacking a story that I have to mention my disappointment somehow. It would have been so much better if it was accompanied by a whacky story to fit the mood but, as good as the mechanics of the game are, the soul is not there.

Diablo had a consistent mythos that sucked you in the atmosphere of dread and more (yeah just wrote that). Compare it to this game which breaks the fourth wall so much that it is like it’s calling the player an idiot to his face and expect you to like it.

I tried several builds to find some redeeming factor to my wasted time on this game and FORCED MYSELF to finish it after wasting many hours in it and I must say that I did not get any satisfaction from it.

If you are looking for the fleeting thrill of leveling up a character and looting some treasures, then this game is for you, just be aware that there is not a world to immerse yourself in, just a forgettable experience. IMHO this game is not worth the time invested on it, the aftertaste is bitter and disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060913279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 6167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3450, 'last_played': 1578990715}

review: A little ridiculous, a lot of fun. I like playing it in little chunks of time, 20-30 minutes, going deeper into the dungeons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027331916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 12191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5088, 'last_played': 1557252920}
review: This game is in the classic rogue-like style.  By this I mean you move a square/attack/ect, and enemies perform their move at the same time.  However this is one of the freshest of these styles out there.  The humor in it is top notch, and tons of exciting styles of class play.  It also isn't too difficult to learn like so many of these are but can still be plenty difficult to master.  I highly recommend this game over about every one of these styles of turn based rogue likes for new players and experienced players alike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037690813', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1356595200}
review: Sag mir leide nicht zu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051570604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1265, 'last_played': 1495728779}
review:
Roguelikes are not my thing and never have been. Who wants to work hard on their avatar only to see it die with no save or restore?
I saw this game on a friends game list and thought I would give it a try.
I mean what harm could it do, right? 
Oh my, what big eyebrows you have, big angry eyebrows. 
All the humor, some of it even a little shocking. (No I did not really do that to the sheep despite popular belief among the dungeon monsters.)
All the beautiful loot, and my own safe place to store it in big piles where I can gaze upon it like a Scrooge McDuck.
And finally, you can play with permadeath or without!
I Love This Game!
10/10 would roguelike again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969887501', 'num_games_owned': 3031, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1479073866}
review: I love love LOVE Dungeons of Dredmor. It looks wonky, seems basic but under the skin is one of the best roguelikes on the market.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097548949', 'num_games_owned': 708, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2650, 'last_played': 1449037630}
review: I found Dungeons of Dredmor somewhat compelling, but every time I would play, I would get sucked in for several hours as I traipsed through level after level systematically destroying everything, only to get wiped out by one stupid play. I eventually decided I was wasting too much time with it and not enjoying it any more, so I uninstalled it. I found it frustrating that I couldn't min-max *everything* because some crafting recipes are pretty much always not available to you. I liked the skill system and that you can choose several rather than just rolling up one of seven different classes or whatever, and some of the descriptions were entertaining, but ultimately my problem with roguelikes is that they often end up as the video game equivalent of road hypnosis -- you spend hours and hours playing them and then you slip up once and you're toast. Or maybe I'm just playing them wrong?

author: {'steamid': '76561198078588729', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1668139531}
review: Ok, honestly, I wasn't sure if I would enjoy this game. Usually when I buy games like this, this being an independant game, I tend to request a refund because the game just doesn't feel right and fun to play for me. I WILL NOT be doing that for this game though. This is quickly becoming a favorite game of mine. It combines the very deep gameplay mechanics of roguelike's with a very funny and sometimes absurd asthetic that absolutely works. The animations and graphics add a great deal to the immersion and adventure. The sense of discovery permiates every black, unexplored corner of the dungeon and you can't help but to continue trecking around for hours. All together, I highly reccommend picking this game up. It is definitely a must own in anyones steam library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005675183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7338, 'last_played': 1709675152}
review: A funny, well designed, deep and entertaining game with near infinite replayability. I honestly cannot reccommend this game enough, especially with the expansion packs as the sheer amount of content in terms of items, skill trees, enemies and floor layouts means that there will always be a new way to play. Be a melee tank, dodge focused rogue, wizardly spellcaster, engineering tinkerer building bombs and weird weapons, or be a Vampire Communist Sword dual weilding tourist who uses blood magic. Dredmor, the RPG that doesn't give a f**k.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044923847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1663482046}
review: OMG fun! I can see getting into this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067153098', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1649478015}
review: Best casual roguelike game on steam. The humor is nice, lots of weird off the wall classes making for a lot of unique ability, an easy to read and use UI and still a good amount of roguelike depth. Dungeons are interesting, enemies are entertaining, and there are a lot of interesting mechanics to explore. You will likely get bored after a while as the runs can be rather slow paced at first but for $5 plus a couple more for both expansions. It is still a very good roguelike to get into the genre, or just for a more casual rl.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030365684', 'num_games_owned': 102, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 27412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4199, 'last_played': 1705172996}
review: Best rogue-like with interface there is. Hard, replayable, with mods and lots of things to learn, use and kill.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041738500', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6430, 'last_played': 1637882852}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a roguelike. For those of us who are not elite(ist) gamers, just think of it as a hard hack-and-slash game with procedurally generated content and very real risk of permanent death which forces you to start over (a little wiser each time)

My initial impression of this game was a very positive one. It's very easy to get into, has a lot of skills to choose from for character creation (implying lots of replayability, but I was wrong) and it covers everything with a layer of clever tongue-in-cheek humor (like witty pop culture references? this game has lots!)

However after playing this game on a netbook for over 80 hours, properly experiencing it in all its glory, I stand corrected enough to say that I would not recommend this game to someone else looking to derive some fun out of their play sessions, unless their entertainment consists in dying over and over unfairly...case in which I probably still wouldn't recommend this game because it simply isn't that good all things considered.

First off, a major technical issue. This game is built poorly, seemingly by dwarven plasticsmiths (those bastards) It's a little 2D game with sprites that have 2 animations each. Still it actively takes 600MB of RAM, reserving even more than that. On my 2GB RAM netbook I can forget running this and a browser at the same time. 

Shame, because it looks like exactly the type of game to be played on a netbook/tablet, and not on a proper desktop configuration like the game demands. It also personally annoys me as this seems to be a problem with more and more lazy pixel-style indie games: games that look like they were made 20 years ago demand 4GB RAM and 1GB VRAM. What the hell?

Onto the gameplay itself. It's balls hard. Not in a good way as it seemed on first glance. It's unfairly and frustratingly hard. It's unfair because while you have an ample amount of skills to choose from, only a few are actually effective (give you a high likelyhood of winning the game) while others are downright useless. The same goes for weapons (don't use crossbows unless you like taking 4x longer than a character with his bare hands to win the game). This wouldn't be so bad, as every such game has some strategies that work better than others, but this game in particular is very stingy with its descriptions of mechanics. Without reading a guide, you will frequently encounter weapons and abilities whose actual effects are very underwhelming compared to what their descriptions would have you believe. You pretty much have to read a guide before diving into the game, or you'll frequently wonder "what does THAT mean" when finding, say, an artifact or another with a typical description like "The honorable poodles - it is studded with cheese crust and decorated with high quality tin"

Once that's out of the way, and you finally have a good understanding of the game mechanics that let you create an effective character with a fair chance of winning...you will run into another problem. Basically, once you figure out how to not die, everything all the way up until the final boss becomes one relatively simple, mindless, long-winded repetitive grind. And the final boss? FUBAR, because even many good builds won't scratch that guy (hints: [spoiler]Magical Law, Burglary, Crossbow, crafting/encrusting in general[/spoiler]). A situation in which 99% of the game play is mindless faceroll, and that 1% (final boss) has the shot of taking it all away because of RNG is not fun (again, unless you're a difficulty fetishist). I also have to ask myself why they even made the game with 51 skills to choose from when less than 15 of those are actually going to let you win the game. 

Could it be that in spite of first impressions, this is not that good of a game?

author: {'steamid': '76561198009511609', 'num_games_owned': 881, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1312, 'last_played': 1456600860}
review:
Enter the dungeon, collect loot, slay the monsters, and die ridiculous deaths.  Dungeons of Dredmor is one of the most accessible rougelikes on the market, but don’t take it for granted.  This is a punishing, difficult game.

You start the game by selecting the skills your well-eyebrowed hero will use.  There are your normal RPG expectations, like Swords, Armor expertise, etc.  But then you get down to skills like Battle Geology, Necronomicomics, or Egyptian Magic.  Pick Vampirism, and you’ll sparkle like a bad actor in Twilight.  All these ridiculous and funny skills are useful in their own way, but its up to you to combine them in useful ways to ensure you can survive the depths of this dungeon.

Each randomly-generated floor of the dungeon is chock-full of monsters, traps, food to eat (which replenishes your health), alcohol to drink (which replenishes your magic), and most importantly, loot.  You’ll come across a sword that does existential damage (it may or may not damage enemies if, in fact, they do not exist) or a set of rubber pants that prevents conflaguatory and aetheric damage.  There are so many different stats to keep track of, points to weigh against one another, but it is not overwhelming.  Everything is clearly presented, and the random seeding will rarely give you useless stuff as you go deeper and deeper.

You can play this game entirely with the mouse, though keyboard shortcus and movement make it a lot easier.  You can either play with Permadeath (one life, no mistakes) or turn that off and play a little more casually.  I started with permadeath, but after losing a couple characters 3-4 hours in, I turned it off so I’d be able to rewind only 5 minutes instead of multiple hours.  This game is punishing, and sometimes can feel a little unfair as you run into things you had no idea would be coming, which you had no chance to prepare for.

The humor in this game is top notch.  From pop culture references to simple gags and dad-joke level puns, there is hardly anything in this game that takes itself seriously.

I did manage to reach Dreadmor, and I stabbed him a few times, but the power of his attacks are so far beyond anything else in the dungeon, he killed me in a few hits, even with every buff I could give myself.  I think I might never actually beat him.  Some things are meant to stay unfinished.

Dungeons of Dredmor has two paid expansion packs and one free one, if more ridiculous skills and bad puns are your cup of tea.  This was a fun game, with just enough depth to keep me interested but not enough to drown me.  This is a kiddie pool Rougelike.  Guess that makes me a gaming toddler.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989031571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 7001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6974, 'last_played': 1416841354}
review:
One of the most fun and addictive games I have ever found. Endless dungeon-crawling goodness with an enormous array of skills, tools, and combinations, a great sense of fun, and the ability to progress at your own speed. You can always roll up a new character and find something you hadn't seen before, or learn a new trick. 

The game is a series of dungeons descending to an ultimate evil, with pocket dimensions, shops, and altars to various gods along the way. You create a character with a wide selection of skills in different trees (Archeology, Paranormal Investigation, Barbarian, to name only a few) which you can then level up as you progress. Along the way you fight strange and often hilarious monsters and collect materials to craft or sell. Strange combinations of these produce interesting results, mixing in teleportation, tunneling, invisibility, mind control, and many more!

The game is charming, the art is lovely, the creators are helpful and responsive, and the music is pleasant. Try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060697186', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4036, 'last_played': 1698721692}
review:
This game is irony

Edit: I think I have enough hours to actually make a review now, so lets go.

This is the video game equivalent to Monty Python and the Holy Grail.

To start with, this game is probably the best roguelike experience on the market. It beats Issac, it beats Gungeon, it beats Nuclear Throne. You name it, it's probably not as good as this masterpiece.

Now with all this praise, you would probably think to yourself, "Now what makes this game special?" And the answer is simple. EVERYTHING. Have you ever wanted a game that isn't afraid to make fun of itself but also takes itself very seriously? No? Well, I didn't either, until I saw this treasure.

The way this game presents itself is as a generic dungeon crawler. But, it becomes far more quirky as you venture deeper into the dungeon. Just about every tooltip in the game is a joke, reference, or pun. All three of these things is very much appreciated. Thank you, DoD.

Now let's talk about the way a run starts. You pick 7 amazing and totally useful skills (almost always included in this set is Burglary, because of lockpicks.) and go into an amazing, proceduraly generated dungeon filled with monsters that taunt you with witty remarks and items that taunt you with witty tooltips. What this game has in cutting wit, it also doubles with deep gameplay mechanics. 

There are over 15 elements to attack with, and, like, a lot of other stats. But who cares about those? (Don't answer that.) You're here to have fun, and numbers are boring, lets talk art. The game has charmingly outdated graphics. From what you see of the screenshots, that's the game. You've seen it already. Why are you still reading this paragraph, it's useless in the whole scheme of things.

Oh yeah... A rating... uhhhhh....

Mechanics: Super Deep, and has lots of ways to play. 10/10
Music: Absolute Banger, jazzy and makes you tap your foot. 10/10
Writing: The funniest jokes and the best puns. 10/10
Overall: Buy this right now or else you don't get to experience the greatest Roguelike of our generation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995894805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 5474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4230, 'last_played': 1699679591}

review:
I picked this game up in a humble bundle a few years ago, and it has ended up being one of my favorite games that I always seem to come back to. Perfect blend of brutal permadeath and comedy, just enough to offset the frustration that comes with loosing a character.

Nothing like making a new character, hitting "random" for your skill choices, and trying to make it work! Not only does this lead to entertaining combinations, but also keeps the gameplay fresh.

review: A fun silly game that makes fun of itself, and other dungeon crawlers. The skills you can pick are entertaining, such as emomancy, killer vegan, and if course communist, because political affiliations are skills too. Go on pointless side quests to appease Inconsequencia the goddess if pointless side quests, and use the lutafiisk cube to turn inediable objects into equally inedible lutafiisk. It's a great time waster and it's fun to try different skill combos to see how far down into dreadmor's dungeon you can get before you die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020788783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 3311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1466, 'last_played': 1619687944}
review:
Feels like an old PC game that you can play for hours straight and have a headache at the end, in a good way. It has turn-based combat on a grid. You can make your own talent tree when you create your character. Loot is randomized, and you can become so overpowered to the point where you can negate cursed items completely. There is an odd sense of humor present (think Monty Python) which I thoroughly enjoy. It's also brutally difficult on the later floors, which it expects you to have a decent amount of gear. 

If you see this game on sale, and you like rogue-likes, dungeon crawlers, and RPGs, this is definitely worth your time. You cannot go wrong for $2.50. (The expansions are also great, and at this point I'd say that they're almost essential at only $1 more during a sale.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198041996767', 'num_games_owned': 1363, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1695, 'last_played': 1456236970}
review:
장점
특성 선택으로 인한 자유로운 스킬 조합
쉬운 조작과 그래픽

단점
낮은 긴장감과 지루함
항상 똑같은 모습인 캐릭터
난잡한 아이템 조합
대각선 이동 불가

이 게임은 로그라이크 입문용으로 손쉽게 추천을 할 수 있다.
입력이 먹통 되는 버그는 있지만 게임 자체 완성도도 나쁘지 않다.

하지만 반대로 로그라이크로서의 장점이 별로 없다.
맵과 적이 반복적이고 배고픔이 없기 때문에 쉬운 난이도로 지루함이 쌓인다.
크래프팅이 있지만 조합식을 얻어야하며 그만큼 장비외에 재료아이템수집으로 인벤토리가 지저분해진다.

로그라이크가 처음이라면 한 번쯤 해보는 것도 좋지만
조금이라도 경험이 있다면 그리 재미를 느끼지 못할 것이다.
로그라이크의 장점을 살리지 못하고 단점만 보이는 느낌이다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078027694', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1675711759}
review:
If you are anything like me, you'll watch the trailer, see the screenshots and think to yourself.. 
Well, it looks pretty terrible so how comes it has all the positive reviews? 

Originally I wasn't going to buy this game, due to the graphics and interface. 

Then the first time I played it I didn't like it, whatsoever. 

Then I completed the tutorial, watched a YouTube video about it, went back in and played again... Drowned, got electrocuted, died from acid burning my throat, attacked by various strange looking creatures and throughly enjoyed my time playing. 

This is the start of my epic journey to complete this game, buy the game. It's great. Trust me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063952373', 'num_games_owned': 798, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1406, 'last_played': 1496406132}
review:
I love this game, I really do, I haven't played a roguelike so entertaining in a long time. It has good ambientation, really good OST, very lively graphics, gorgeous overall presentation and infinite replayability. Yet, I've seen some people complaining about the lack of tutorials about how the abilities work and what the potions do. Well I gotta say, those people don't know how roguelike games are, because the very nature of a roguelike is getting thrown in the game with no explanations at all, and being you the one who finds out how the game works. Games nowadays treat players like childs, telling you how to do everything from the beggining, and that results on the players being uncapable of solving a problem by themselves in an unknown situation where the game didn't teach them what to do. That's what make Dungeons of Dredmor so different, and so lovable. Having said that, there are a couple of cons about this game, not enough to make say "fuck this piece of trash", but enough to nag me. First of all, the well known "runtime error" that hasn't been solved in the last 3 years by the developers who, by the way, are aware of this issue. Luckily in my experience, I haven't got my save game corrupted, but I get a mini heart attack everytime the game crashes (which is a lot by the way). Then, we have the load times. Now, I don't know if this is just me, but the game takes A REALLY LONG TIME to start considering the requirements, and after that, it takes another full minute to load a save game.
         Summing up, even though I recommend this game, I'd like to see the developers caring about the issues I mentioned and fixing them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086984404', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1559820674}
review:
[h1]Что там у нас? Dungeons of Dredmor?[/h1] Ну ладно...

Эта игра, скорее всего, одна из лучших в своем жанре. Сейчас объясню почему:

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]

+ Хорошая стратегия. Нужно продумывать свои ходы, а не бездумно бросаться в бой.
+ Система перков и скиллов порадовала.
+ Тяжелая, но не делающая игру хуже, прокачка.
+ Привлекательный 8-Bit дизайн.
+ Немного юморка никогда не мешало.
+ Поддержка Steam Workshop
+ Низкая цена

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]

- Отсутствие сюжета
- Несбалансированные уровни (принцип: "Я первого уровня, зашел в первую комнату - здравствуйте, 20 боссов. Как приятно вас видеть")

В итоге оценка такова - [h1]8/10[/h1]

Хорошо убьет и время, и нервы.
