author: {'steamid': '76561198240862168', 'num_games_owned': 3725, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1634857809}
review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title: Dungeons of Dredmor
Genre: Casual, Indie, RPG
Developer: Gaslamp Games, Inc.
Publisher: Gaslamp Games, Inc.	
Release Date: 13 Jul, 2011[/b]

[h1]Basic Overview[/h1]
Dungeons of Dredmor is a very intresting and very different from other Rogue-like RPGs I have played in the past. This game has randomly generated levels, along with loads of skills that you can mix and match to your liking. This adds very high replay value to the game, which is what you would expect from a (optional) perma-death game. It's sometimes frustrating to be killed by an enemy when you've spent to long on a play through, but that's to be expected from a perma-death run of this game.

[h1]Game play[/h1]
This game has a lot of variation, whether it's randomly generated floors or a huge amount of skills to choose from. Each run is very different from the last. I found myself dying a lot when I first started playing it, but the I kept coming back for just 'one more run.' Then that one more run turned into two or maybe three. The game really pulls you in, it has a great atmosphere when playing it on Perma-death. You never know what's going to happen which makes you more alert for what can happen, maybe you will find a monster zoo and then you have to be careful. There is a wide variety of different enemies for each floor, and each floor has a different theme to it with specific enemies that you will encounter along the way. As for the weapons and classes there is a nice variety for them as well which gives you a better attack damage for a specific weapon type and will depend with what happen you start off with. But what makes this game even more unique is that you can substitute a weapon class for another skill that may or may not be better. You can make the game even more difficult on yourself if the hardest difficulty is too easy for you by having skills that aren't very helpful to you. There are so many traps, and levers that you have no idea what it will activate. Maybe it will open a door, or maybe it'll teleport you to somewhere else. That's the beauty of this game. The attack system is turn-based, so you move once then the enemies move. It can be a simple point and click or you can use WSAD for moving your character, then attacking is just simple being close to the enemy (if you use a melee weapon) and clicking on them to take it in turns to attack.
[b]Score (Out of 10): 10 - Very high replay value and variation![/b]

[h1]Sound & Music[/h1]
The music for this game is perfectly fitting for the atmosphere and the game play for this game. Although it can get a little bit repetitive it's still nice to listen to when you are fighting a bunch of enemies at once. The sounds of each thing that you use, such as swinging your sword or axe is all very unique. It is quite obvious that the developers put a lot of time and effort into creating the sounds for each things. I would like to see some more music in this game that matches the atmosphere of the game.
[b]Score (Out of 10): 9 - Would like to see some more music that fits the atmosphere[/b]

[h1]Graphics/Art Style[/h1]
For me the art style of this game is just perfect. It really fits in with the with the whole atmosphere and dungeons kind of feel. It's not a too series style of art, but then again it doesn't look innocent. It just fits perfectly with the whole gaming experience. Some people might not like it because of the cartoon kind of style to it, but I am just saying it from what I think.
[b]Score (Out of 10): 10 - My own personal opinion, you might not like the art style[/b]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
So there is my whole review for this game, it's a very unique type of rogue-lite RPG game. It has [b]very high repay value[/b] which always makes you come back to the game. It has great atmospheric music, I would only want to see a few more soundtracks on this game, and the art style, well take it or leave it. You'll either love it or you'll hate it.

Also, feel free to check out my [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZnoW6jbcKfQttUSJ-R2ReA]youtube channel[/url] if you have the time to. Whether you do or don't, thanks for reading my review.[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198066475173', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1676612631}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a very enjoyable experience -- easy to learn, but very difficult to master (at least for me). However, I must warn you, that if you are looking to buy this game and/or its DLC, know that it can be extremely difficult. Don't expect to win on your first try (if you are playing Permadeath mode). I'll list some of its pros and cons for those thinking to buy this game.

Pros
[list]
[*] At least 30 different skill trees to pick, all catering to different playstyles. You can pick 6 each time you start a game.
[*] Compared to other roguelikes (Angband, Nethack, etc) its pretty easy to learn, but still retains a lot of complexity. DoD also has a tutorial.
[*] Also unlike traditional roguelikes, it has mouse support. You can play the entire game with your mouse, but you can always use your keyboard if you want to.
[*] Lighthearted roguelike with a lot of humor and references,
[*] Creative monsters and mechanics.
[/list]
Neutral (depends on your opinion)
[list]
[*] Everything is unlocked by the get go, unlike the modern permadeath games you see today (Binding of Issac, FTL, Necrodancer, etc).
[*] Turnbased and gridbased, similar to the traditional roguelike.
[*] Long game, will most likely take hours to complete a single run.
[/list]
Cons
[list]
[*] Can get very grindy at times, levels are too big in my opinion (there is an option to shorten the levels however, but I haven't tried it yet).
[*] Crafting system is iffy. Not incredibly useful (at least in my experience), and you usually don't get enough crafting materials to build anything substantial. If you find yourself wanting for a certain crafting material, there doesn't appear to be a definite way to get that exact material. You have to leave it up to the hands of the RNG.
[/list]

TL;DR rating 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198067646777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1667930290}
review:
Of all the rage-inducing, rogue dungeon crawlers I've thrown tantrums at, this is my favorite.

As early as character creation, the creativity that went into this game is apparant. Not only are there a rather decent amount of skill trees to pick from, there's quite a few "out of the box" skills, like... Mathmagician. Or Fungal Arts. Perhaps you want to be a fleshsmithing viking vampire? You got it. Pyro berserking archeologist? You got that too.

The gameplay itself has kept me entertained well enough that I don't mind kicking the bucket as frequently as I do. The mobs (diggles, blobbies, thrusters and the like) yell obscenities at you as they die (Your mother is a radish!), which really does nothing but make me dish out my own sass to my monitor. There's sidequests and minibosses and lots of lutefisk. There's tons of items and crafting and omlette making.

The best part about this game though, hands down, is the Omnipotent Pork Sword. If you ain't pork swordin, you ain't living.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042138344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6934, 'last_played': 1693210052}
review:
There are very few Steam games that I would recommend more than this game. Actually... *looks through Steam library* nevermind, there is no other game. If you haven't played this game yet, you are doing YOURSELF a disservice. This game is probably the most accessible roguelike you will find on the Internet, PERIOD (yes, I'm accounting for Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup).

This game is funny as hell, and has plenty of skill trees to keep you occupied for a LONG time. Hell, I've been playing since 2011 when this game came out, and I still find it immensely fun to play. I have yet to find another game that offers this kind of humor, complexity, and great balance of RPG elements. Please, do yourself and Gaslamp Games a favor, and BUY THIS GAME.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963154938', 'num_games_owned': 975, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1602963687}
review:
[b]Technische Schwierigkeiten überwinden[/b]

Der Beginn mit Dungeons of Dredmore ist durchwachsen. Ich kann keine Screenshots machen und das gesamte Steam-Overlay funktioniert nicht. Nach kurzer Recherche stoße ich auf den Tipp für Dungeons of Dredmore in Steam die Startoption “-opengl” einzutragen. Damit funktioniert zum Glück sowohl Fraps für Screenshots als auch das Steam-Overlay reibungslos. Als erstes wird versucht mir die Aspekte des Spiels in vielen kurzen Tutorials zu erklären: Mit Tatstaur oder Maus gehen, anklicken um anzugreifen, rechtsklicken um Fernkampfangriffe zu benutzen, Hebel ziehen etc. Als mir aufgetragen wird eine Armbrust zu suchen finde ich eine in meinem Inventar, rüste sie aus und erschieße den Gegner… doch nichts passiert. Im Nebenraum finde ich eine Armbrust auf dem Boden liegen und rüste diese aus. Der Auftrag lautet nun “töte den Diggle”… hmm der ist aber schon tot. Nur mit einem Verlassen und Neustart des Tutorials geht es weiter – unschön. Das hätte man anders lösen müssen, aber sei es drum, die anderen Tutorials erledige ich auch schnell noch und dann geht es ab ins erste echte Abenteuer.

[b]Munchkin - The Roguelike?[/b]

Als erstes wird unser Held (oder unsere Heldin) erstellt. Dafür picken wir uns aus 47 Skillbäumen 8 raus, die unsere Startwerte und -fähigkeiten festlegen. Neben relativ konservativen Rollenspielfähigkeiten wie Swords, Smithing oder Golemancy finden sich in unserer zufällig zusammengewürfelten Startausstattung auch sehr kuriose Fähigkeiten: Viking Wizardry und Paranormal Investigator. Auch Emomancy und Communist habe ich gesehen, das kann ja heiter werden.
Wir betreten das Dungeon weil… der dunkle Lord Dredmore vor langer Zeit tief unter der Erde eingesperrt wurde, nun aber seine magischen Fesseln gesprengt hat und deshalb gestoppt werden muss – schon wieder. Ein guter Grund. Von oben schauen wir unserem Helden zu, wie er die ersten Schritte in den unbekannten, zufallsgenerierten Dungeon macht. In typischer Roguelikemanier gilt es Truhen und Türen zu öffnen, fiese Monster zu besiegen, Dinge in den Mund zu nehmen, von deren Wirkung man keine Ahnung hat und möglichst lange zu überleben. Das alles läuft rundenweise abwechselnd. Erst führen wir eine Aktion aus, dann der Rest des Dungeons. Man sollte sich also gut überlegen was man als nächstes tut um idealerweise den ersten Schlag zu landen oder noch unbeschadet flüchten zu können. Das Töten von Monstern und andere erfolgreiche Aktionen geben uns Erfahrungspunkte und ggf. Geld und Loot. Besonders freuen wir uns natürlich über neues Equipment, dass uns direkt stärker macht. Jedes Item und jede Fähigkeit hat einen humorigen Text als Beschreibung und ich fühle mich an die Texte von den Munchkin Karten erinnert. Das ganze Spiel ist voll von lustigen Texten und Anspielungen auf andere Spiele. Recht früh im Spiel finde ich z.B. einen Threepwood Helmet – einen gusseisernen Topf. Großartig ist auch der Schrein von “Inconsequentia, Goddess of sidequests”, die uns auf Wunsch Nebenaufgaben aufträgt. Das Geld können wir in Shops und Automaten verprassen. Genug Erfahrungspunkte bescheren uns natürlich ein Level-Up und wir müssen uns entschieden, welchen der acht zu Beginn ausgewählten Skills wir eine Stufe verbessern wollen, was uns wiederum eine neue Fertigkeit oder einfach bessere  passive Boni gibt.

[b]Von Vielfalt erschlagen[/b]

Was anfangs recht übersichtlich ausschaut überfordert den Einstieger schon bald. Überall finden wir uns unbekannte Gegenstände, was tun die bloß alle und brauchen wir die später noch? Das Handwerkssystem haben wir im Tutorial gar nicht beigebracht bekommen, doch gibt es mindestens 7 Handwerksberufe. Zum Glück ist das Craftingfenster halbwegs übersichtlich und nach bekannten Rezepten und vorhandenen Zutaten filterbar. So schaffen wir es bald zwei Eisenbarren und daraus eine erste fesche eiserne Beinrüstung zu schmieden. Doch der Überblick über die Zahlreichen Fallen, Bolzen, Nahrungsmittel und Tränke geht bald verloren. Die einzelnen Dungeonetagen sind sehr weitläufig, so dass ich bereue nicht die Einstellung “no time to grind” gewählt zu haben. Mit dieser sind die Etagen kleiner – ob sich das auf den Schwierigkeitsgrad auswirkt werde ich in dieser einen Stunde nicht überprüfen können. ich komme an Regalen mit neuen Rezepten vorbei, treffe und erlege viele verschiedene Gegner, betrete Teleporter, lege Hebel um, sortiere immer mal wieder etwas aus meinem begrenzten Inventarplatz aus und betrete schließlich mit Hilfe von gefundenen Wizard Keys die Hölle der Diggles, eben jener Viecher, die wir im Tutorial und den oberen Etagen massenhaft erschlagen haben. Und nun schlagen sie zurück. “Congratulations! You have died!” Danke, danke, die Stunde ist ohnehin um.

[b]Fazit[/b]

Dungeons of Dredmore ist ein technisch limitierter Roguelike der durch Humor zu überzeugen weiß und ansonsten durch Vielfalt und ein funktionierendes Gesamtkonzept glänzt. Ich bin mir sicher es gibt noch jede Menge zu entdecken und ich werde mit den unterschiedlichen Spieloptionen rumprobieren müssen, denn in der Standardeinstellung kann so ein Durchgang vermutlich einige Stunden gehen. Sehr schade ist, dass sich die Ausrüstung in keiner Weise auf das Aussehen unseres Helden auswirkt. So muss man sich mit den Texten und der eigenen Vorstellungskraft zufrieden geben. Bei mir reicht das sicher noch für einige weitere Durchgänge, es gibt noch viele Skills, die ich ausprobieren muss. Und ich bin erst bis in Level 3 gewesen, soweit ich weiß geht es bis Level 15 runter… es gibt viel zu tun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018436333', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 4737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3448, 'last_played': 1688138851}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049097610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1477282339}
review:
This game has many good things going on for it. It has the potential to be an amzing roguelike. 
Yet it falls short for four reasons 
1) Lack of depth. A major part of roguelikes is exploration, synergies and "huh thats cool" moments. ToMe, ADOM, NetHack, Caves of Qud and many others excellent roguelikes do this well.
2) Graphics; although this purely a personal compalint, but i can look at an @ sign for hours but the terrible walk animation I can not.
3) Difficulty, the difficulty jumps incridably steeply, without giving players a good indicator of why, a chance to adapt or means of survival.
4) The games length is artificially extended by grinding out enemies and clearing floors to deal with the difficulty cruve.

That being said this game simplicity makes it an excellent roguelike introduction to players new to the genre as they wont be swamp with complicated numbers and stats.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009654132', 'num_games_owned': 2910, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1562, 'last_played': 1474328776}
review:
One of the best roguelikes in the market. Dont miss this one out if you like the genre.

Pros:
+ Everything a roguelike needs; character variation, skill variation, map variation, crafting variation, skill variation.
+ Crafting is fun
+ Workshop material is great
+ Amazing replayability

Cons:
- Can be too repetitive depending on the randomly generated material. (Cross your fingers)
- A bit complex for the newcomers to the genre.

Final verdict:
9/10 After 4 years, this game still keeps me busy from time to time and it delivers great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167613087', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 12030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7183, 'last_played': 1623626037}
review: Excellent roguelike for those new to the genre. It doesn't overwhelm newbies with information as would more in-depth roguelikes such as Tales of Maj'Eyal and NetHack, but has more than enough substance to warrant it's price tag (and is an *actual* roguelike to boot!). The game has a slightly cartoony art style and general sticks with a humorous theme. Sometimes the game tries too hard to be funny, but I personally didn't find it intrusive. This game features a bunch of different "professions" which fit some kind of archetype. These can range from more traditional and generic archetype like "fire magic" to more unique archetypes such as a tourist, a dirty businessman, a communist, and a math wizard. Your character can choost 7 of these if I recall. Everything else more-or-less fits the bill of "roguelike but somewhat simplified". Have fun, well worth the money IMO.

Shoot absurd wands, craft traps, be a vampire, take legal action against monsters, get wasted, eat shrooms, vandalize private property and so much, much more.
Few games rekindled my sense of amazement and adventure like Dredmor. It is quite possibly the definitive Rogue-like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044038432', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 23956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19511, 'last_played': 1617967005}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a game that focuses on making fun of RPGs, Rogue-likes, and other similar games. but it does it so well, that it is, itself a really good Rogue-Like RPG. As such, it can be ridiculously challenging to survive through it's randomly generated death-traps. If you've never played a roguelike before, this is a good introductory game. If you HAVE ever played one, this is a good game to play (with harder settings) and laugh at many of the common tropes used in such games.

The 16-bit art-style fits the feel of the game perfectly. Each floor has it's own distinct feel, but some of the designs can be a bit hard on your eyes (stupid fungus level). If you've ever played an RPG for any amount of time, but have an interest in roguelike games, you should like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042940812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6242, 'last_played': 1501462957}
review: Beat it after 104 hours on easy and non-permadeath

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 1869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1869, 'last_played': 1484591849}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor ended up being the gateway roguelike for a lot of people on Steam. The ASCII tiles of NetHack and ADOM aren't the best place to start for everyone, but the goofy classes and antics of Dredmor's bushy-eyebrowed heroes are an easy sell. It straddles an important line between more mainstream adaptations of the concept and the originators, where neophytes can find easy access and veterans can find a new take on old ideas. And while it may not be perfect in a lot of ways, it passes the main test of being something you can play for way, way too long.

Dredmor is really a traditional, grid-based, turn-based, everything-random roguelike dressed up in some handsome(ish) graphics and modern(ish) sensibilities. The only story you get is that you're a hero, and you're descending into the titular dungeons to whack the equally-titular Lord Dredmor. There's a thick layer of nerd humor over the whole package that runs more than skin-deep, as it even informs the class and stat systems with entries like Mathemagic and Caddishness. Luckily it's not the aggravating metahumor of something like Retro City Rampage, and is actually quite snappy and clever for the most part.

The aforementioned class system is probably the big draw of DoD, for newbies and veterans alike. Each character you roll gets seven skill sets to choose from a list of dozens, including everything from sword and shield skills to veganism and communism. Every time you level up, you can unlock another skill from one of your sets, allowing you to knock out one tree with half a dozen levels or diversify as you see fit. Sets tend to be eclectic mixes of active skills and passive bonuses, with some being demonstratively better than others but all of them interesting and worth a try.

Outside of the skill system, there's admittedly not a lot of innovation to be found here. You wander the dungeon, grab loot, kill monsters, and so on. There are shrines to pray to, gods to appease, vending machines to shake, traps to disarm, levers to pull, and plenty of things to die to. Unlike the roguelikes of yore, however, death tends not to come all that swiftly in Dredmor. It's pretty easy to keep your stats and gear up with the challenge presented by enemies if you're cleaning out the floors, to the point that by floor three or so, nothing's going to kill you outside of a room completely packed with monsters. Your demise is more likely to come via attrition, by small mistakes adding up to run you out of healing items and eventually health.

This ties into the main problem with Dredmor, the fact that individual runs can get pretty boring after a point. Unlike most roguelikes, the early game is when you need to pay attention to your skills and your loot. Once you get your rhythm locked in, levels start to blend together. The slow default move speed and animations drag things out a bit longer than they should, and your inventory and crafting windows really could have used another pass on usability. For as many steps forward that Dredmor takes as a modern roguelike, it has a couple feet planted firmly in the past.

All that said, I was able to sink 30 hours into the game before I grew well and truly tired of it. And those were an enjoyable 30 hours of looting, smashing, and giggling at the goofy jokes. The odds aren't good that you'll face down Lord Dredmor before boredom claims your character but on the way there, you'll get to charm diggles and make omelettes and wear a magic traffic cone on your head. Dredmor will go a lot farther with those new to the roguelike genre, but there is undeniably something for everyone, at least while it stays fresh.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005140137', 'num_games_owned': 493, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 21301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18105, 'last_played': 1589715570}
review:
Be warned. This game is hard. 
If you are a namby pamby elf, this game is not for you.
Give it a finger and it won't take your arm, it will take your entire family tree. 

However, it is also fair.
Get used to the phrase "YASD" which stands for "Yet Another Stupid Death". 
When you die, it is your fault. Maybe you didn't pay attention to where you were going and stepped on a trap. Maybe you underestimated your opponent and didn't realise you had to run before it was too late. Keep your escape routes open and weigh up risk/reward before doing anything.
You are one step away from death at any and every point in the game.

The challenge is overcoming the dungeon, but also yourself. Those rash impulses that overtake body and mind as victory looms every closer. When you finally see your prey, the Lord Dredmor and bloodlust over runs your mind, hunger for the suffering of the one who put you through so much to get here, fight it! Your hatred and thirst are his greatest weapons, though his array of spells aren't to be sniffed at.
Becoming complacent is akin to suicide in this game.

All of that aside though, if you're looking for a challenge, it's a good intro to the rogue like genre and I got 300 hours out of it, for my £3, so it's a great value proposition. Be careful and you should be fine, once you learn the tricks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964195220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 17432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25220, 'last_played': 1669993002}

author: {'steamid': '76561198050048102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1597701173}
review: An amazing rougelike, with enough humor and difficulty to keep you playing for hours on end. And while the base game can be a tad bit bland, there is a [i]plentiful[/i] amount of community content and some DLC. Also, it's cheap as fυck (even with the DLC). There really isn't a reason to not buy it unless it's not your type of game, obviously. But for anyone interested in the dungeon-crawling genre, it's a great addition to have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039104428', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2812, 'last_played': 1663006201}
review:
I purchased this game when it was on sale back yonder thinking it was just another generic rogue-like, Boy was I wrong.

This game is fantastic, there are so many references in this game, references to things like: Warhammer, Star Wars, Metal Music and many many more. The character customization is amazing, choosing skills before you set into the dungeon then leveling each one as you level your characters health up and gain new abilites. 

I highly recommend you play this even if you aren't a fan of the genre, 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198075500887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1731, 'last_played': 1540370067}
review:
Хороший рогалик, в котором не нужно выбирать между файтером, рогой и магом - нужно комбинировать эти классы, чтобы вам не дали пососать. Система крафта, без скиллов которого придётся очень туго. Вырезать monster zoo на третий раз становится очень скучно, особенно, если шмот приличный. А ещё в воркшопе полно модов.
Минус всего один - скудное музыкальное сопровождение, через пару часов гринда уже порядком надоедает. 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001003065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1323, 'last_played': 1691110909}
review: Honestly, there aren't many meaningful challenges in the game. Most enemies are incredibly easy. Most gameplay is wandering around identical rooms in the dungeon trying to find better equipment or crafting ingredients. Most combat is standing on the same tile, waiting for the next monster to walk up to you so you can defeat it in 1 or 2 swings. Crafting would be fun if inventory management were easier. The skills are funny, but they don't add a whole lot to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031811354', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1709500586}
review:
Exploring the dungeon casually with my moustache-golem until found a pocket dimension device.
Inside the dimension was a portal device, where one could input custom text.
I wrote Dredmor, and a red, hellish portal activated. It didn't look safe at all, so I went in.
Ended up in Diggle hell and got surrounded by smaller Diggles in all the colours of the rainbow.
There was also one bodybuilder Diggle. And the walls looked like they were made from ribcages.

Will play again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026422405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4144, 'last_played': 1447344122}
review:
First roguelite game I bought on a recommendation from a friend. I've been playing this on and off for quite a while now, and have enjoyed every death immensely. Still haven't tried out most of the different skill trees, mostly because I tend to die quite often.
The devs really do help out with some of the problems the negative reviews mention, like bugs and crashes, and the mod content can really flesh out any aspect of the game.
A really great game you can waste time on anytime and anywhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998264878', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 8344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3429, 'last_played': 1515714507}
review:
The funny thing about this game is this:
The major cons that I would cite are not the fault of the developers. It's things along the lines of the fact that there is no readily accessible wiki that is up to date. It takes some major diggling around to find the one that actually includes proper enemy stats or all of the encrusting recipes. And yes, I understand that a lot of people want to discover things for themselves, but you'll be kicking yourself the first time you discover that yes, you DID need to keep all of those steaks for Gaga's Glaze, or that bronze is very useful for the Offensive Shielding encrust.

The other thing that I would note is that you can hit endgame gear  pretty quickly (about dungeon level 5-7 out of 15), so there can be a very odd difficulty curve where you no longer have any significant changes to your stats, but things will get pretty tough. If I were to change anything, it would be to make that curve a bit more linear.

Otherwise this game is fantastic. For a price tag of $5, I have played this far more than many other titles in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031824146', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 13059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7092, 'last_played': 1535890874}
review:
The most crazy, random, and interesting dungeon crawler / rogue-like around. If you don't like one of those styles of games, and the pixel-style is not your thing, then stay away from this game.

However, if you do and enjoy weird and over the top humor, then you'll find this game to hit the right buttons. Add to it a great number of skills, items and general things to discover, and you'll find a rich, interesting, game. It can hook you really bad though, so be warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974388614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2453, 'last_played': 1449852889}
review:
Fantastic little game. If you can get passed the non-existant graphics and animations you will discover a suprisingly deep character creation and crafting system. Tons of items and each level is randomly generated. Definitely a steal if found on sale.

Recommended for people who are looking for a light-hearted, casual and engrossing RPG experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043385216', 'num_games_owned': 1687, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 1771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1769, 'last_played': 1590180605}

author: {'steamid': '76561198129587123', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1572697365}
review:
技能组合很多，画面风格很喜欢！总体上是很不错的roguelike游戏。
美中不足的是，属性的用词很复杂，对于汉语玩家来说挺不友好的，一开始的时候我就各种查词典才能明白...
游戏的崩溃确实有点多，有时候save&continue就直接跳回菜单了。
一开始可能会很沉迷，但是慢慢玩确实稍有无聊，有了各种mod好了不少。
不过总的来说是款不错的游戏:-D

author: {'steamid': '76561198075427229', 'num_games_owned': 911, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 3799, 'last_played': 1710001530}
review:
Подземелье Дремора на удивление хорошая в своём роде {Рогалик+фтл+Дремор} игрушка.
Но, так как щас надо пояснять за мысль..:
[list]

    [*]@ Ты заходишь в подземелье, и понимаешь что набрал абсолютно неиграбельные перки.

    [*]@ Умираешь пару раз в скором времени, выбрасываешь игрулю на Луну.

    [*]@ Поступаешь в Инст, понимаешь что игра стоит внимания, пытаешься выучить Английский.

    [*]@ Фанатеешь какая игра со смыслом, сидишь вечерами с Гугл-переводчиком, играешь, умираешь.

    [*]@ Решаешь что тебе нужно написать обзор; сказать людям что в игру надо втянуться, тогда будет вкусно.

    [*]@ Заканчиваешь лист из "Собак", садишься шастать дальше. т.к. боги требуют... Наверное?

    [*]@ Думаешь. Дремор по себе идеален если не рассказывать этим неандертальцам с CS:GO и Дотками [spoiler] (Димас и пару челиков исключение) [/spoiler] о нём.

    [*]@..

    [*]@...

    [*]@Джиз я люблю его подземелья ;ъ

[/list]
Геймплэй всё решает, вы и так это понимаете... Тут нет стоящей стори, или графики, но вреяпровождение с процессом и рисовочка... [b] Они делают конфетку из Дремора..!  [/b] 
И, да, как обычно в конце самое острое: 
Тут много ачив, все вам захочется иметь... Даже ачива с 'мутным пойлом' чего стоит. 
Много отсылок, они тоже хорошо играют.

Лама был с вами в обзоре, мир индюшкам Kippa

author: {'steamid': '76561198022459092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1339484400}
review:
Not as fun as it could be with better sounds, art and skill system.

Might be a bit comical in some humor and charming the way it is, but it's definitely not something everyone would like.
And as you go deeper in the dungeon, it doesn't feel like much changes, which would be required for the game to feel exciting.

I can't recommend it, sorry.
If it looks like something you'd enjoy after watching a few episodes of a let's play, go for it. 
But it may get a bit dull and boring sooner or later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065320958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1399, 'last_played': 1670457166}
review: This game is quirky and enjoyable, I do wish equipping different armors would change the look of your character, but that's not important. The game itself is solid but not very exciting, going through the dungeon is sort of a math problem all on it's own. You need to pick the right skills and get the right equipment, its actually a real challenge to reach the end of the dungeon. Heck, I haven't even done that yet. But what really makes the game worth the time you'll put in is the flavor text. Flavor text for the items, for the food, for the monsters, for the armor, even the little background decor. The humor is what makes this all enjoyable, and manages to take the incredibly drudging experience and make it full of, well, bemusement!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991263358', 'num_games_owned': 2882, 'num_reviews': 222, 'playtime_forever': 2196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2196, 'last_played': 1426975821}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993304005', 'num_games_owned': 5464, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 2118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2118, 'last_played': 1434745722}
review:
When I started playing this game, I liked it, but the more I played the more I realized how boring and uninteresting it is. First of all, there are many technical problems with the engine. Crashes (with an achievement), bugs and input lag are always part of the experience. I never bothered with the non-permadeath mode but If you play this mode, the game is completely broken due to crashes corrupting the save file.

The humor in Dungeons of Dredmor is something most people seem to be in love with but I found it to be uninspired, unoriginal and not funny in any way. The more hours I spent playing, the less patience I had with the game's poor performance and input lag. These two issues are simply awful and unbearable after a while. Worst of all is the crafting and lack of a decent enough inventory system. If you make a character build focused on crafting, you will be in for the most frustrating, annoying, cumbersome experience in any crafting related game. It's so poorly implemented and backwards that once you go through the troubles of attempting to keep ingredients/items, organize them and finally begin crafting, you will never want to craft another item in this game again. The negative combination of the awful inventory system and the hideous crafting system is enough to quit playing and never go back to Dungeons of Dredmor again. Sure, the game could certainly be played using other builds and you don't have to craft anything to beat it, but the horrendous inventory system is still there and there is no way of making it less painful to organize, keep and use items. Dungeons of Dredmor could have been so much better if the developers spent more time polishing and tweaking many of the major issues the game has.

Dungeons of Dredmor is mediocre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976128981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 8403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7778, 'last_played': 1666738246}
review: The goofy, messy presentation of Dredmor hides a very competent roguelike that will punish you every bit as much as any of the older short(er)form ASCII classics out there. While it tends to wallow in it's own crapulence after a while, the core mechanics are solid and the sheer amount of variety on offer means there's an easy 30 hours of discovery here before you even begin to take the top off the system and really poke around in the guts of it. Definitely recommended to anyone with the deadly, turn-based explorathon bug. Don't let appearances fool you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994122900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 18806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17444, 'last_played': 1560802256}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025724769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 4728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3981, 'last_played': 1600992849}
review: The only turn-based roguelike I will ever need. I could play this game endlessly, and for any amount of time. Sometimes for just a few minutes, wandering into one or two more rooms, sometimes for hours at a stretch. The skills are numerous and varied and the crafting system is excellent. There are a lot of character stats, but you don't need to know all of them to start playing. Most things have tooltips, so you'll learn as you go. Personally, I think the game should be played with permadeath on. That way you can try different builds, searching for the one that will net you the least embarrassing death when you ultimately fail.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085229239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1438887119}
review:
Non ho giocato tanti Roguelike ma so che la semplicità in un gioco lo rende piacevole da giocare e da apprezzare, con Dungeons of Dredmor la semplicità si va a far benedire.
E' un gioco completo di tutto, ma il troppo stroppia e mi dispiace dirlo ma in questo gioco c'è troppo.

Chiariamo la cosa, giocandolo per 1 oretta ho capito che devi stare a perdere tempo leggendo qualsiasi descrizione di ogni oggetto che trovi avanzando nel dungeon, non è possibile che per 2 passi che fai trovi un oggetto! Troppe descrizioni, troppi oggetti.. il tutto in inglese. Se una persona fa fatica con l'inglese non deve assolutamente comprare questo gioco, perderebbe minuti e ore della propria vita a leggere la descrizione di ogni cosa.

Ho cercato di continuare facendomelo andare a genio, ma l'unica cosa che ho fatto in 1 ora è stato andare in giro per i dungeon uccidendo 2-3 mostri e leggendo le descrizioni di un sacco di oggetti.

Lo consiglierei? Si, se a qualcuno piace leggere e ha una buona padronanza dell'inglese.
                           No, se non si ha una buona conoscenza dell'inglese e la voglia di leggere la descrizione di ogni
                           singolo oggetto.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113340827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3371, 'last_played': 1685077079}

Nice graphics. Check.

Difficulty. Million dollar check.

review:
A roguelike that doesn't take itself seriously. AT ALL. It's incredibly funny with various references and easter eggs to other games all over the place. It has a huge selection of different character classes to pick from and they actually really play differently so you can play the game numerous times and still have fun.

Great value for money!

I do not want to work with a game where I constantly have to keep working around and muddle with save games in windows folders and backup copies. This is not the MS-DOS era. Although I did enjoy the first hours, this bug simply kills all enjoyment because it means you will have to start a fresh new game from the start.

Simply not recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998851375', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 39284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 995, 'playtime_at_review': 25518, 'last_played': 1710468721}
review:
Roguelike games tend to be either too basic and simple, like Chocobo's Dungeon, or too complex and impenetrable for newcomers, like Nethack. Dredmor is..... well, it's not perfect, but it's a better middleground then any I've ever seen. Starting off is still a little tricky, but at least you have graphics and whatnot to lend a hand for once. Nonetheless, I'd recommend playing on Elvishly Easy mode and perhaps looking up some guides to get a handle on how the stats work. Melee damage is based on "Burliness," which is based on how many "Warrior" skills you have. (as opposed to Rogue and Wizard skills) This is how most stats in the game are calculated, and it does take a little getting used to.

Once you get over the initial "What the crap is going on?" stage, the tactical turn-based gameplay really takes off. I've played this game dozens if not hundreds of times, and I'm still trying out new characters and new strategies all the time. I will say, the game got a lot deeper with the expansions, which means in retrospect, the base game felt a little shallow, but like I said, there's a steep enough learning curve that the pool won't run out for a little while, at the very least.

If you like turn-based games - old-school RPGs or certain board games or card games - Dredmor might just be the thing for you. If you like roguelikes like Nethack, Dredmor might seem a little basic. I highly reccomend Dredmor, and the expansions, and I reccomend you check out the mods as well. There's quite a lot in the modding community adding all manner of fun things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073684745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1451480462}

Its really hard. Like I have beaten tons of hard games and this one kicks my butt every time, Enemies are cheap.

Yet, the game is still fun. Some classes are poorly balanced, Ignore the guides that say it belongs in the muesuem is awesome. Its trash along with the rest of the arch skill tree.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013156635', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 6137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5487, 'last_played': 1511707410}
review: Hilarious and extremely well done roguelike. Set in a universe of Moustache golems and malevolent vegetables, lead your eyebrowed hero on the quest to defeat the evil overlord Dredmor. Do you want to be a communist astrologist banker dual weilding axes? Now is your chance. Summon your minions, don your flip flops and grab all the booze you can carry. Dungeons of Dredmor will keep you entertained for a long long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077624633', 'num_games_owned': 7602, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 9132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2141, 'last_played': 1607473804}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor's voluminous depths are littered with an abundance of wacky treasure to horde and enticing weaponry to cleaving all sorts of evil beasties in twain with. The fact you'll die incessantly in pursuit of such delights doesn't dull the fun, since a glut of intriguing character skills to tinker with makes re-tooling your hero over and over again a blast. Several options designed to lessen the brutal difficulty for casual players are welcome additions, but this indie roguelike is best enjoyed the way the dark gods intended: sadistic and old-school.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026461830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 5727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1919, 'last_played': 1674216333}
review:

review:
뭔가... 뭔가... 뭔가... 부족하다.

내가 이 게임을 하기 전에 아이작이나 뭐 다른 로그라이크게임을 즐겨서 그런지 속도감도 떨어지고 복잡한 느낌이 강하게 든다.

맵이 넓고 한 판당 플레이시간이 오래걸려서 썩 내취향은 아니었다.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198052463354', 'num_games_owned': 941, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1490626788}
review:
1st delve.
-Killed first by a diglet of Diggles (plural(or it should be in my opinion))
-Rage Quit for being killed in the first room.

2nd delve
-Created the ultimate warrior wielding sword, axe and viking magic.
-Killed by a Blob who claimed no one loved him, I can't imagine why cause he attack me on sight.
-Rage quit because a blob got too excited and hugged me too roughly, snapping my spine.

Loved every second of the rage and fell in love with this game.

In all seriousness, despite my relatively short play time (Just over an hour). I can definetly see the appeal of this game, although somewhat "lack luster" in it's hand drawn art style (which i personally find very endearing but some may not). the game is a turn based, tile by tile "rogue like", rpg, dungeon crawler. With a few refrences to boot - I have a trait called "Witcher" and i quote "Going by the name "White eyebrows" you travel the world killing monsters for good, and making witty and sarcastic comments about various social endeavors -, the game unlike most rogue liek rpgs does not by any means take itself seriously, humour riddles the sprawling floors of the dungeons, with the various enemies insulting you and making genric comments about various aspects of you, the dungeons facilities (Quote - "The vodka is good, but the steak is stale" ).
But like most games in the rogue liek genre, it turns into a loot rush as you scurry to gather gear all the while avoiding what would be considered tier 1 mobs and very easy fights due to the sheer squishiness that you character can suffer if the right traits aren't picked.

All in all... "The vodka's good, but the steak is stale". The game is characterful, but the genres it's in is bloated and stale dragging this gem down with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000824354', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1438120603}
review:
A very accessible rogue-like with enough depth, strategy and personality to stand above most of the rest. The simple graphics and combat of Dungeons of Dredmor obscure its incredible depth of design, functional mechanics and polishing, and it really is a fully fleshed out title. My fun in Dungeons of Dredmor comes from battling through hoards of monsters while interacting with the world, using traps, spells, crafting and more, all while exploring ever deeper.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

There are plenty of little things that help this stand out and help to make it something more than most rogue-likes, but the central design philosophy of accessability and the respect it has for the classic elements that make rogue-like games so fun that make it very much worth my time and keep me coming back.

A plethora of additions and extra gameplay elements like crafting and landmines which would easily become an annoying chore or distraction in other games has been made completely optional and ignorable here, yet still adds lots of practicality to the game when you spend the time.

* The attention to enabling and supporting Steam Workshop content definitely deserves comment. It's been woven into the game perfectly and means sharing rooms, items, monsters and even things like insults and decorations is rewarding.
* The humour deserves mention. There are references to movies, old video games and culture not just spread throughout the world, but even in the U.I. and elsewhere.

[h1]Mistakes and Annoyances[/h1]

It has been genuinely quite hard to find something to dislike about this game and the only things that are worth pointing out haven't really affected the fun I've had with this title, but they're here in the interest of a complete 

review. The main drawback or limitation of the game is in the simple and, some would argue, boring combat. Fighting thousands of monsters in the same way, typically using the same specific skills and abilities can wear thin and unless you're willing to make some form of goal and targets, or story for yourself, reasons for playing can easily feel empty and flat.

* The tutorial is quick and simple, but also very lacking. There are a ton of gameplay elements and user interface mechanics that aren't covered anywhere and usually have to be searched for to learn about, or will simply be discovered by chance.
* Dredmor, the end-game boss can feel out of place and the ending can feel abrupt for some.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Presently available on Steam for £3.49/4.99€/$4.99 and with no real limit in replay value, Dungeons of Dredmor will take around 20 to 30 hours to complete a successful run, but reaching that run may take you 100 hours or more. As a 

result, it's very fairly priced and good value for money even when not on sale, yet routinely goes on sale for -50% and -75% and is a must buy for anyone looking for an approachable rogue like.

The Complete version costs just 30% more, is available for £4.99/5.99€/$6.99. It is almost exclusively the better choice over the stand alone because it adds Conquest of the Wizardlands and the Realm of the Diggle Gods DLCs which add a total of 12 new Skill Trees, hundreds of new items, dungeon levels, monsters and mini-bosses and plenty more. Unless you don't expect to play more than a few hours or you're on a strict budget then there's no obvious reason not to grab the Complete pack.

* Don't forget to install and name [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/98821/]the Expansion Pack[/url] which is available for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010742666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1573576978}

author: {'steamid': '76561198119926007', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1532537061}
review:
Определенно один из лучших рогаликов в которые мне доводилось играть. Порадовали простота освоения (в отличии от, например, Cataclysm или упаси господь, Dwarf Fortress), простое управление и приятная графика. Но с управлением не все так хоршо - оно мне кажется слишком не отзывчивым, "заторможенным", что ли.

В любом случае, это 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994506042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 2419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2419, 'last_played': 1437613675}
review:
It's fantastic. If you ever wanted to try out a rougelike, but were too intimidated; this is the game for you. It's accessable and simple to learn. If you're a veteran of rouglikes, then this game will appeal to you as well; by offering a wealth of quirky and colorful content. It's on target with all of its points. 

I only have a couple of minor gripes with this game. After a while, room patterns start standing out more and more; leading to you memorizing all of the tricks the game can throw at you. The game isn't completely randomized; so this is more or less to be expected. Next, skills in general range from decent to just plain underwelming. I feel like a little buff here or there would do wonders. In my playthroughs, I ended up feeling like I slogged through a bunch of minor stat boosts to get to a decent spell or passive. Maybe this was the intention... if so, well done. But, as a side effect, leveling up doesn't feel like that big of a deal until you've pounded through a couple skill trees.

All of this aside, this game is a wonderfull investment for those looking for a rougelike experience with a little bit of flair and a lot of cheese and booze. Like a lot. Like a lot a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025034639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6848, 'last_played': 1436911035}
review:
As others have mentioned, the game has a very serious bug that rolls back your game just about every time. Every time I play it I will eventually get a crash that leaves me with a save file from the day before, generally costing me about 8 hours and leaving me with a save that took 25 minutes to produce. It's intolerable.

The game is fine, otherwise. But just fine. Not great. Not amazing. Not worth the aggravation or the money, cheap though it may be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050282163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 35410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14262, 'last_played': 1706471961}
review:
This is a roguelike game, but it doesn't have the bizarre interface, hard-to-learn game mechanics, or ascii-graphics normally associated with the genre, making it very accessible and an excellent introduction to roguelikes.  Some of the jokes appear to be aimed at veterans, though.  There are a lot of jokes and a very strange sense of humour.  This doesn't mean it's a silly game - the game itself is not a joke, but a lot of the flavour text is. 

Instead of choosing a class, you choose 7 skills, ranging from weapon skills, armour skills, numerous magic skills, dodging, veganism, geology, archaeology...  so although there's no "warrior" class, you can just make a warrior by choosing all weapon and armor skills.  Or make a mage, or a rogue, or just about anything in between.  Because of the way heavy armor and spellcasting work together (they don't), warrior-wizard hybrids have some problems, but any other hybrid can work well.

There are also crafting skills, and a lot of craftable items and discoverable recipies.  Thanks to some very powerful craftables introduced in the expansion packs, crafting is a bit overpowered.

Modding support is very good - indeed, the free expansion pack is mostly made up of of the best player-made mods.

I have very few complaints.  One is that the final boss is *MUCH* more dangerous than anything that comes before it.  The problem is not the toughness of the boss by itself, it's just that the rest of the game doesn't do a good job of teaching the player how to deal with him.

Also, this is an indie game, made with an indie budget.  Occasionally that shows, like with late-game monsters that look like palette-swapped versions of earlier monsters.  It also comes with an indie price tag, and that makes it excellent value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014985201', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 2229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1756, 'last_played': 1564178863}
review:
男=まゆげ。そして、DLC も女=まゆげ。つまり、まゆげ祭り。

2015/07/04
ゆるい感じのローグライクRPG。
気まぐれで再開したが、比較的平易な英語でなんとか私の知識でもプレイ可能だった。全く忘れていたが、かなり面白いゲームだと思えた。少し取っつきが悪いのでそれが難点だが、小一時間ほどのプレイで慣れると思う。
初期のスキルセットの自由度が相当高いので様々なスタイルでプレイできるのが大きい。これほどレベルが上がるのが楽しみなゲームも珍しい。BGMも格好いい。

難易度も適切で拡張DLC3つ入りをお勧め。

author: {'steamid': '76561198019545783', 'num_games_owned': 530, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1949, 'last_played': 1415665803}

author: {'steamid': '76561198076919950', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 12237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11539, 'last_played': 1590143827}
review:
带我入STEAM坑的游戏。ROGUELIKE和地牢的元素都有了。几十种职业任意组合，各式各样的武器，道具，怪物，复杂的制造系统，随机的地图和任务。简直有无限的时间可以游玩。更不要说还有创意工坊提供的各种MOD，上面说的这些元素都可通过MOD再次拓展。
你可以扮演正统的战士，法师或者武术家，盗贼之类，也可以扮演一些歪门邪道的职业，一切奇葩的组合任你想象了。
难度方面也很开放，最简单的可读档让你轻松通关，最高难度的死亡消档让你做抖M。你可以轻松捏死最终BOSS，也可以被第一层小怪捏死。
总之喜欢ROGUELIKE地牢冒险游戏的，买这个不后悔！请一定要买完整版！

author: {'steamid': '76561198066781509', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 20236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18518, 'last_played': 1523325563}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065169321', 'num_games_owned': 742, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1640736584}
review: Many a time I have guaged a game's quality based on how much I think the game should be worth, and how much the devs are chargin for it. For example, the game 1000000. It is a cheap game, sold at a cheap price. And then take BL Pre-sequal, a game that arguably charges more than the content it provides is worth. However, Dungeons of Dredmor has presented me with the rare privalege of saying that this game is worth more than the asking price. Since purchasing and playing many a game, over many an hour, I am happily willing to say that, if it were demanded of me, I would have payed 15$ for this game. Maybe even 20$. That is how much it is worth to me. Any many of my friends agreed with me. Many of their first words of reaction were "You got this for HOW MUCH?!". And so I present to you Dungeons of Dredmor, a game that, for some reason, feels the need to make you pay but a fraction of the game's true value. Buy it, and buy it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046982282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3147, 'last_played': 1532704577}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor не прячет звериного оскала за овечьей маской. В самом начале игры вам честно говорят: вся суть мероприятия в том, чтобы испытать себя. Придется умереть, и не раз, но если будете достаточно настырны, то в конце концов одержите верх. А чтобы не было повода сомневаться в серьезности намерений, в меню выбора сложности по умолчанию включают опцию Permadeath, которая стирает персонажа после смерти. Ее можно и выключить, но, сделав это, постоянно помнишь о том, что играешь неправильно. Не так, как было задумано.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078722730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 7564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3681, 'last_played': 1610173491}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041127532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2906, 'last_played': 1522186782}
review: Very solid rogue-like, if you love really cheesy humour you'll love this. Can be unforgiving, but the game doesn't force the player to stick with a single sort of build to be successful. Art style can be a bit odd or unappealing at times, but is not a major issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042009132', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2497, 'last_played': 1677901539}
review:
I really like games that have a good mix of lightheartedness and difficulty, and this game brings just that. The randomness aspect of pretty much everything makes every run almost entirely different (unless you decide to use the same skill set every time which I don't recommend unless its the only one you are good at and oyu are going for a win). The ability to make a run short with the 'No Time to Grind' option is really nice, since   you can have quick runs in a game that usually takes a few hours for a near complete run(with DLC). I didn't play very much of the game before I got the DLC, but I can say that the DLC gave it what it might have needed: more stuff. 

The only problem (and it isn't a real problem) is that in the later floors there are mainly reskinned enemies. Many of them do different things than the original though, and there are still new enemies occasionaly, so this isn't something that takes away interest in the later floors.

Essentially, this game has enough variety to allow most players to enjoy it and gives a lot of replay value like good roug-likes should do, but has plenty of comedy and difficulty to make it fun to play each time instead of just being different.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020678205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 66759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47000, 'last_played': 1705035004}
review:
Yup, I've played this a lot so high marks for re-playability.

I like the challenge of the game.  My efforts through most of the time spent plodding through the dungeons are mostly in an attempt to finish the game on the hardest level with a character using random skills.

The skills are one of the best parts.  The number of them makes for some great synergisistic strategy development.  The humour is nice too, where else can you play a comunist banker vampire vegan with an ax?

One problem is length.  In the full size mode it takes ages to clear each level but in the 'no time to grind' mode there is only a very limited amount of loot which can make some builds tough to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057473202', 'num_games_owned': 809, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 5386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3843, 'last_played': 1532394723}
review:
A hardcore roguelike in the traditional fashion that somehow manages to be brutally hard and accessible simutaneously. What really sets this game apart is its humor. There are enough hilarious tidbits written in the descriptions of the classes, abilities, and items to keep you entertained for many, many playthroughs. It's a good thing, too, because you will have to do many playthroughs. This game is hard. There is an acheivement for dying to one of the easiest enemies in the game for that very reason. Thankfully, for the weak of heart, there are a number of difficulty settings.

I'm now going to list off reasons that everyone should buy this game.
- It's vegan friendly
- You can be a boy OR a girl
- You can spread your communist agenda
- You can live out your Twilight vampire romance fantasies
- You can pass your Math exams
- You can relive the glory days when My Chemical Romance were still together

If you aren't convinced to buy this yet, you might as well sacrifice your mushy, lutefisk-looking brains to the Lutefisk God. Shame on you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198087425643', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1427747637}
review: 作为一款小游戏！非常非常的赞！里面元素非常齐全，料理啦天赋啦魔法啦锻造啦什么的，唯一遗憾是没有汉化玩起来心累。。

author: {'steamid': '76561197993818789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 1797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1477, 'last_played': 1592689613}
review:
Incredibly challenging turn based roguelike with tongue-in-cheek humor. There's a complicated crafting system, randomly generated dungeons, a customizable skill tree, and... well that's about it. It's very good to entertain you when you're bored, but don't expect to really get anywhere.

Storyline: 1/10 - As far as I can tell, there isn't one.
Graphics: 3/10 - Not much effort was put in to them, but not much effort was needed.
Sound: 2/10 - Splat and squish effects recorded in someone's bathroom.
Gameplay: 7/10 - You don't play for anything else here. This game is ALL about the gameplay, and it's fantastic at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040908291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1429729825}
review:
What a great roguelike! DUNGEONS OD DREDMOR was the first commercial traditional roguelike that got popular, before-hand roguelikes were mostly free and way too complex for a broad audience. Dredmor came and changed that. Don't give me wrong; DoD still is a traditional roguelike but alot of the mechanics were dumbed down so that most of the people would understand them. DoD simplified a lot of stuff but kept the standard mechanics of a turn-based roguelike. This game still has the most important things:
<> randomization  
<> Perma Death (there also is an option to turn that off, again trying to appeal to a broad audience)
<> Crafting
<> Skill Trees
<> Quests
DoD had all that but as I said simplified! And that's what makes this roguelike so great! It's simple yet so challenging and complex. It always keeps this fine balance between "dumb-easy" and "complex-easy". But this game is not easy to beat; not at all! 

DUNGEONS OF DREDMOR is pure roguelike-awesomeness, and it also is the perfect game to start for newcomers to the traditional roguelike genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987549843', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 13071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7479, 'last_played': 1708063403}
review: This game is an incredibly charming roguelike with enjoyable gameplay, great art design, a greater soundtrack, and seriously humorous flavor text. It's clear to me that actual care was put into this game and it's rare for that to seem so for all of your run-of-the-mill cookie-cutter indie games that contain so little substance under the pretense of being "art". Dungeons of Dredmor can very well be seen as a beautiful oil painting that has [b] actual [/b] inherent meaning to its artists as opposed to a wooden plank with nails hammered through that [i] should [/i].

author: {'steamid': '76561198000887954', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 125, 'playtime_at_review': 12735, 'last_played': 1710724152}
review:
I love this game so much that I have a habit of buying it for all my closest friends. Even if they don't like this type of game. 

I've sunk many hours into DOD and no doubt I'll sink many more. It may have it's bugs and flaws, but it's character easily overrides that. 

It's witty; Creatures will call you names as they gather around you, whittling you down into various piles of giblets. 
It has charm and personality, but it isn't a pushover. If you manage to even get to Lord Dredmor, you can bet your ass you're not prepared enough to beat him. 
The skills are ridiculous, some may even harm you in the long run. If you dare to roll random, you'll always be in for a challenge. 
You can kill yourself by kicking down doors. There's even an achievement for it. 
It has squeaky noises. 

It's silly, re-playable and hard to win. That's all I really want in a game, personally.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023141293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1432023488}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057815250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 6023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4701, 'last_played': 1654650049}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996760968', 'num_games_owned': 1341, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 6061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5629, 'last_played': 1607850425}
review:
I feel like this game is the mother of the -modern- "roguelike", in that I only remember seeing the extreme popularity of the genre rise after this game was released.  Likely a coincidence, who knows for sure.  In essence, this is THE roguelike dungeon crawler to get if you're looking for this kind of game, complete with its steal of a price tag.

This is about as archetypal as they come:  a(n optionally) perma-death dungeon crawler that is turn-based, randomized floors, a lot of randomized loot, a LOT of surprises, borderline unfair difficulty (which is what makes it so fun) combined with fine balancing, a boatload of skills to make a unique character in a large number of ways, strong overtone of well-executed humor, and then some.  Charming visuals and old-school, catchy music seal the deal.

I once died trying to kick a locked door down.  No, I wasn't actively going for the achievement.  Yes, there's an achievement for dying while kicking a door down.  There is also an achievement for crashing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996843201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1490, 'last_played': 1493255668}
review:
If you're a fan of traditional roguelikes, you're a bit like a fan of hitting yourself in the knee repeatedly with the pointy end of a claw hammer. Dredmor puts a fun, inviting spin on what is essentially a vicious cycle of internal self-abuse. Losing a game repeatedly due primarily to random chance, but being tricked into thinking it's due to your poor optimization or lack of skill has never been so pleasant! Dungeons of Dredmor, the game that puts a lovable, cheeky attitude to your enternal torment!

If you love roguelikes, you have my condolences. Maybe one day I'll start a support group.

Hello, my name is Kaypar, and I am a roguelike player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087517943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3286, 'last_played': 1658435411}
review:
An excellent game, providing replay value as well as challenge. If you like rogue-like games, this is a good one to invest in. 

The character choices are many, allowing for any number of gameplay styles and also allowing for an even greater amount of variety, which is fantastic. The skill tree system is straight-forward and nicely balanced, which is lovely as well. 

It's comedic in many parts, from the absolutely absurd names it randomly generates, to the moderately silly introduction, to the many, many references to a whole bunch of different things - like Morrowind and Bioshock, to name a few. 

If I had to complain about anything, I'd say that I'd like to see more permanent unlockables, kind of like in The Binding of Isaac, where you can unlock items to find in later runs by achieving certain landmarks.

Even at that, however, the game is more than satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988066623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1569, 'last_played': 1532445889}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966419253', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1464, 'last_played': 1622940713}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044283666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1431060809}

author: {'steamid': '76561198098041403', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9116, 'last_played': 1590131041}
review:
Ye gods, the pop culture references...so many pop culture references.

Dungeons of Dredmore is your typical roguelike; maintaining the tradition of esoteric skill trees, randomly generated dungeon levels, and optional permadeath (ouch).  The actual gameplay is fun and incredibly engrossing in and of itself, the game could stand on that alone even though that is not what makes DoD truly shine.

The thing that really makes DoD the first among roguelikes, the reason that you should play THIS roguelike is the irreverent, unrepentant sense of humor.  It keeps you laughing through every.last.permadeath.  Nothing is sacred...least of all the protagonist.  The descriptions of the "normal" loot, equipment, skills, etc. are hilarious; and the standard content is just the tip of this iceberg of absurdity.  Then there is the humor inherent in the things that you would never expect from this kind of setting.  Really, though, who wouldn't love a game with skill trees for such things as Veganism, Archeology, Magical Law and Tourism?

Finally, this game will really reach out to you with more cultural references than you can shake a standard-issue 10' pole at.  Really, recognizing all of them would borderline on a superhuman ability.  Not only is the sheer number impressive, but the game creators chose to cast this particular net over a large area of pop-culture and sub-cultures rather than limiting themselves to areas of interest most common to gamers.  It would take a vastly longer review than this to list off all of the fandoms, but rest assured that something near and dear to your heart will be mocked.  It's a tough call, but in the end I think that the cultural references are the funniest part of the game.

There are only two criticisms that I have to offer.  First of all, the mad libs-style random generator for the names of places and artifacts is rather inelegant.  The intent is funny, as are some of the results, but frequently the grammatical issues with the names and titles just gets in the way of the humor.  Secondly, there seem to be specific room layouts that are frequently re-used in the random level generation, making the rooms occasionally repetitive.  I don't know anything about coding, so I have no idea if that is something that is even possible to change.  However, neither of these two issues drastically impact my enjoyment of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024659144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1532914141}
review:
This game was recommended to me by one of my friends. He absolutely rants and raves about how much fun he has with it... I'm not sure that we should be friends anymore. This game is extremely boring. The enemies are simple recolorings, the combat is not challenging other than trying to stay awake, and the levels are bland.

The humor in the game is slightly funny at first... But this is not enough to keep anyone interested on this alone. The battle mechanics are repetitive and the only real strategy is to funnel the enemies into a hallway where they can't attack more than 1 or 2 at a time and hack away. The graphics are HORRIBLE. A few floors in the background/floor/wall/everything looks like a gravel driveway with vomit mixed in.

At some point, I stopped playing the game, and just started seeing how many characters I could create with some form of "eyebrow" in their name... 

And then I shelved it....  Overall, I'd say if you've never played a top down turn based roguelike, or if you want a reason to never play  another top down turn based roguelike, maybe pick this up when it's on sale. If you want a game that will keep you interested for more than half an hour without feeling like repeatedly clicking on an icon in windows 3.0, pass this up completely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041391297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1369506988}
review: too much for me

author: {'steamid': '76561198005378126', 'num_games_owned': 700, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 4006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3269, 'last_played': 1637536658}
review:
This game is addicting! You choose what abilities you start with, some of which are normal fantasy tropes, but then quickly move into silliness (e.g. vegan powers?!). Part of the charm of this game is that you have to figure out what combination of abilities/powers work. Then you head out armed with an orange plastic street cone on your head and a cardboard sword. The game mocks you when you die, which can happen pretty frequently. You do have the ability to turn off perma-death if that's your thing. The DLC just makes the game more fun. The mods also add all sorts of fun new things. There is a lot of crafting, if you take the abilities to advance in it, and you can make some pretty zanny stuff, which tends to be more powerful than the standard gear you come across.

This is an extremely addicting turn-based game, and I can't recommend it enough. A++

author: {'steamid': '76561198009616027', 'num_games_owned': 506, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1848, 'last_played': 1430669675}
review:
Before you get this game, I strongly advise that you do some research.
Not because the game sucks, it's actually one of the best roguelikes I've played recently, but because of a problem I'll describe.

The game has an auto-save feature that sometimes crashes the game (Runtime Error).
You can NOT remove this auto-save feature, which wouldn't be a problem if it didn't corrupt savefiles, but unfortunately it does.
The developers of this game even acknowledged the issue, but did nothing after 2 years of knowing about it.

The only workaround is to:
1) Turn off Steam Cloud
2) "Save and Continue" in the menu (unavailable if you play Permadeath mode)
3) Manually backup your savefiles from Windows folders every now and then,  so when it happens you can replace the corrupted save


I lost a 28 hours savefile due to not knowing of this issue, and I'm not gonna recommend the game despite it being rather good. I might give this another try someday, but right now I'm stunned.
Do yourself a favor and do some research before you get this game, and you won't be caught offguard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035997350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1017, 'last_played': 1430654672}

author: {'steamid': '76561198178638229', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1680646745}
