author: {'steamid': '76561198037878832', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2745, 'last_played': 1510584488}
review: A very good tongue-in-cheek roguelike. Very funny and a good game to kill time. Can usually finish the game or at least get to the final floor in about 5 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965333589', 'num_games_owned': 2800, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4647, 'last_played': 1589374882}
review:
Para los primerizos, ¿qué es un roguelike? Según [url=http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roguelike]Wikipedia[/url] podemos encontrar una lista de características y Dredmor las cumple todas.

Ahora empiezo con mis palabras: Dungeons of Dredmor es un roguelike nacido en la ápoca en la que este tipo de juegos han "resurgido de sus cenizas" y la gente se ha hecho eco de este tipo y hay un gran número de ellos en el mercado. Puede que no sea gran cosa gráficamente, puede que la música no sea de vuestro agrado, pero intentad darle una oportunidad y observareis que el juego os va a borrar del mapa en cuanto os descuideis.

Este juego tiene una gran libertad tanto en "perks" del personaje cómo en acciones: ¿Quieres ser un hombre-diggle emo comunista vampiro? Adelante. ¿Prefieres ser un herrero con artes mágicas egipcias y turista? Ningún problema. ¿Quieres beberte ese alcohol puro 100% que has encontrado en el suelo y que probablemente consiga envenenarte? Trae p'acá ese alcohol.
Hay que tener en cuenta que estamos en una mazmorra totalmente hostil, aquí no hay nadie que te pueda ayudar, salvo Brax que es nuestro "querido" vendedor, un demonio que no durará en mandarte al nivel 1 de vuelta si quieres robar algo de su tienda. Bueno, también hay máquinas expendedoras... en una mazmorra. Sí, yo tampoco sé con qué están encendidas, pero bueno.

Llegar al nivel 10 y encontrarnos con Dredmor será todo un reto, pero el propio Dredmor no será ningún hueso fácil de roer, luchará hasta el final con una dureza extrema hasta que sólo quede en pie uno de los dos.

A pesar que antes hemos comentado las características de un roguelike, Dungeons of Dredmor proporciona una opción para la gente que no le gusta morir y perder el personaje, por lo tanto podemos encontrarnos con 3 niveles de dificultad ("Los elfos quieren divertirse" o fácil, "Moderación enana" o normal y por último "Yendo Rogue" o difícil) y una opción para elegir si queremos jugar con permadeath o no.

En la página de Steam junto al juego encontraremos 3 DLCs para el juego, comento por encima lo que lleva cada uno:
[list][*]Realm of the Diggle Gods: Aquí encontraremos 5 niveles más para el juego (es decir, ahora Dredmor nos esperará en el nivel 15), seis nuevos perks que podremos elegir entre saqueo, emomancia, persona-diggle... y nuevos objetos, aparte de más cosas.
[*]Conquest of the Wizardlands: Aquí podremos encontrar Wizardlands, unos nuevos niveles a partir de códigos que podremos conseguir por "graffitis mágicos" que encontraremos por la mazmorra, Diggle Hell, seis nuevos perks entre los que encontraremos poder ser un banquero, un turista, un comunista... y por supuesto más objetos y enemigos.
[*]You Have To Name The Expansion Pack: Este DLC nos da cuatro nuevos perks, enemigos, objetos... no es tan extenso cómo el resto pero es gratis.
[/list]
Dungeons of Dredmor también tiene una gran cantidad de mods para el juego por la Steam Workshop, así que si estais hartos de ser un hombre-diggle vegano quizás podais encontraros a gusto siendo una gallina robótica del futuro (nota: si este mod no existe lo siento, es lo primero que se me vino a la cabeza)

Mientras avanzais por la mazmorra no os será raro encontraros con monstruos que os gritan frases extrañas mientras intentan hacerse un vestido con vuestra piel, y es debido a la gran cantidad de referencias que tiene el juego, ya sea por frases, objetos o cualquier cosa que podais encontrar mientras descendeis a por Dredmor.

Para la gente que no se sienta a gusto con el lenguaje de Cervantes, lo siento pero el juego sólo está disponible en inglés, aunque también es cierto que Dredmor no requiere un gran nivel de inglés.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961312181', 'num_games_owned': 820, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 15535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10757, 'last_played': 1625424670}
review:
UPDATE:  Running the game with -opengl launch open seems to drastically reduce this stated problem, but in a 16 hour long clear, I think I had 5 crashes.  Corruption is known to happen still, but it was rare enough with often enough auto saves that it didn't cost more than a miute or two.

ORIGINAL:

I want to recommend this game, as it's a really nice roguelike for people that don't want to deal with the more nuanced classical roguelikes, but it requires constant saving due to crashes.

And it can crash while saving.

Further, the game seems to corrupt through play, so things you use will arbitrarily stop working.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049305971', 'num_games_owned': 1347, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 12339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3290, 'last_played': 1701864440}
review:
[h1][b]Dungeons of Dredmor[/b][/h1]
Es un roguelike que sigue el modelo de los dungeon crawler tradicionales de un heroe que adentra en una mazmorra para luchar contra el mal.

El juego no intenta profundizar mas alla de eso, no hay npc con los que relaciones mas alla del demonio de la tienda. Algunas estatuas de la diosa te pueden dar alguna mision y poco mas. El juego no intenta presentar un mundo o un guion solido. Tampoco hay puzzles o desafios.

Dungon of Dredmor es jugabilidad, ni mas ni menos. Los diversos modos y opciones para diferentes tipos de partida junto con el basto repertorio de arboles de habilidades donde elegir solo tienen como objetivo asegurar partidas variadas y una alta rejugabilidad.
Sumale un sistema de crafteo y encantamientos complejo, numerosos objetos y consumibles, niveles generados de forma aleatoria y una dificultad que castiga los errores y tendras una formula arcade que llega a ser bastante adictiva. El combate y el movimiento/acciones es por turnos.

El personaje dispondra de un inventario y las ranuras de equipo junto con una hoja de estadisticas. Si queremos craftear habra que elegir la habilidad  correspondiente y rezar para tropezar con el equipo (yunque, etc).

Cabe resaltar que todo el juego respira humor, desde las frases de los muros o las exclamaciones de los monstruos hasta las propias habilidades o equipo, todo esta repleto de detalles graciosos. En algunas ocasiones puede resultar hilirante.

El apartado grafico no luce bien ni lo intenta, lo primordial es la fluidez. Tampoco hay tantos modelos/animaciones de los enemigos como uno se esperaria. Los niveles si que estan claramente diferenciados. La BSO es igual de simple que el diseño visual, cumple y poco mas.

[b]Pros:[/b][list] 
    [*]Mucho humor
    [*]Gran variedad de: efectos de daño, objectos y consumibles, habilidades y estadisticas.
    [*]Gran rejugabilidad
    [*]Muchas hora de juego
    [*]Buen precio
    [*]Workshop
[/list] 
[b]Contras:[/b][list]
    [*]La BSO y los graficos son simples
    [*]No esta en castellano (tampoco hacen falta grandes conocimientos de ingles para entender las referencias y los chistes)[/list] 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Juego muy divertido y adictivo. Se puede ajustar el nivel de dificultad y el tamaño de la mazmorra a gusto personal. Si te gustan los rogue like ten por seguro que lo disfrutaras. Ademas tiene un buen precio (aunque tiene DLC) 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197992293366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1410004650}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968545033', 'num_games_owned': 874, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1436, 'last_played': 1480264555}
review:
A wonderful rogue-like, with a lot of the traditional "we're not necessarily going to tell you what everything does" vibe, starting with character creation. Can make it a bit less "jump in and go" like something like Desktop Dungeons or Binding of Issac, but that doesn't mean it's a bad thing, just different. As if to make up for the complexity, you can save your progress in the game, as well as toggle on and off "permadeath", where, if you die, you can't re-load from saves you may hae made, which definitely raises the tension.

With lots of difficulty, lots of replay value, and a different random dungeon every time, you will be playing this for a long time to come. Highly recommended for rogue-like fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055801628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1744, 'last_played': 1529400746}
review:
Ce jeu est un très excellent (peut être le meilleur) dungeon-crawler / roguelike. Il a tout pour plaire : 
- Un gameplay extrêmement poussé et complet entre le système de skills et de crafts qui fera la joie de tout bon minimaxeur.
- Visuellement très plaisant, la plupart des items ont une apparence personalisée unique et le jeu s'offre le luxe d'animer les monstres et le héros.
- Une énorme durée de vie et une difficulté bien dosée, voire corcée (je l'ai pas encore fini en facile).
Enfin un humour omniprésent qui ne vole pas au ras des pâquerettes.

Amis joueurs anglophiles, ne boudez pas votre plaisir si vous recherchez une épique aventure au coeur d'un univers déjanté.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996666428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5618, 'last_played': 1560639689}
review: Interested in classic-style roguelikes, but intimidated by the harsh learning curve? Worry not! Dungeons of Deadmor is very accessible, with tutorials and helpful tooltips to keep you informed and make sure you know that it really is your own fault every time you die, because for all of the steps Dredmore makes to keep the game accessible, it retains the kind of punishing difficulty that roguelikes are famous for. A wonderful sense of humor and one of the more interesting skill and leveling systems I've seen in an RPG make this one a keeper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047517645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2092, 'last_played': 1391426735}
review: It’s a really entertaining rogue-like with a lot of fourth wall breaking humour. The flavour text pokes fun at itself while the game options offer various degrees of difficulty and decent gameplay. Per usual, turn-based style when the enemies act when you act. The UI can be a bit confusing, mainly when it comes to icons on the character sheet – by the end of the game items can have almost a dozen of effects and the icons are small and look similar. Also choosing the “paths” at the beginning is obfuscated by the fact that you’ll see the progression they offer only in game, not at the character creation page. Other than that, a lot fun to play. Score 80%.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998340377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1413215716}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor, where do I begin? One of the original indie rogue-like darlings in my memory. A truly fantastic rogue-like with a great sense of humor, exploration and music to boot. This game is all about exploring randomly generated dungeons floor by floor until you reach the deepest level and defeat the big bad guy. That being said, it is no small feat doing so and will take quite a long time.

The game starts out by allowing you to choose a number of skills trees to associate with your newly created character from Mastery of Fungi to Viking Magic and everything in between. The first skill from each tree is automatically granted to you at the start of the game. Each time you level up you gain one skill point which can be placed in any skill tree you desire. This system of mixing and matching what skill trees are available to your character allows for a great deal of customization and replay value.

Each floor in the Dungeon of Dredmor is increasingly difficult and will require you to raise your level as well as seek out better equipment for your character. There are an incredible amount of items, weapons and armors for you to discover and that number is made even larger by secret recipes you discover along the way. Crafting is another large part of the game as many of the items you pick up are only useful for crafting other items. For example you come across many different type of ingots which are used to smelt armor and weapons both mundane and special. Without crafting these items simply take up space in your inventory so it is important to learn the usage of many items in recipes.  

There are monster galore in the dungeon and simply clicking on an adjacent creature will attack it. Enemies can dodge, block and even counter your attacks and the same goes for you. It's all in the stats and this game has many, possibly too many? Many more stats than I can go into here, but with such a wealth of useful ones there are plenty of ways to build a functional character.

The humor is spot on and I have found myself laughing at a number of things in the game from achievements to items and beyond. Enemies also like to give witty quips as you attack them and subsequently as they die. 

Musically Dungeons of Dredmor nails the MIDI sound and I can't say that's an easy thing to do. Usually I find MIDI sound to be quite limiting but not in this game. Almost all of the songs are very catchy and fit the mood one way or another. The soundtrack alone is worth checking out.

Dungeons of Dredmor gets 9 Lutefisk out of 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198049186119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1388327104}
review: The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078173390', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1401632318}
review:
Juego RPG al estilo de dragones y mazmorras, mas concretamente roguelike, que nos pondra en la piel de un heroe en su viaje dentro de la catacumbas con el fin de derrotar a Lord Dremor.

A pesar de tener unas buenas bases, la tosca jugabilidad que presenta el videojuego y los excesivos detalles de decoracion que sobrecargan la pantalla del titulo, lo hacen un juego muy mejorable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015936327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4403, 'last_played': 1440621526}
review:
This game definitely has all the characteristics of a roguelike but is modernized in a way that let's us mere mortals enjoy it as well, has a great artstyle and enjoyable humor, and of course, extreme difficulty.

Your goal is to get through all ten floors and defeat the dreaded Lord Dredmor, but DLC adds an additional 5 floors as well as bonus floors. I would definitely recommend getting all dlc and the base game at the same time, especially considering the price for the amount of content.

If you're not daring enough to get through the entire game on its intended settings you can disable permadeath and/or lower the difficulty.

This game is also highly moddable, which should further extend the large amount of replayability that already exists in the base game, just look at the steam workshop for some fantastic user created mods.

And remember, dying is fun! Sometimes!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063136509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1458960143}
review:
My initial look at the video and screenshots did not give me high expectations for this game.  Fortunately, I still decided to try it out, and I am very glad I did.  This is an excellent and charming rogue-like, very true to the spirit of the original rogue, or later, nethack.  The graphics and sound effects are not mindblowing, but they work very well.

If I were to criticize at all, it would be just to wish for some more UI options, such as moving/adjusting the log scroller, and perhaps adding more detail to it, as well as some way to look at tiles that are behind walls.  But these are minor annoyances, and don't really detract from the fun I've had playing so far.  I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys rogue-likes in a heartbeat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034747621', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1467126316}
review:
A delightfully engaging roguelike,where the replayability comes not only from the myraid choices you make for your character's class,but also the thrill of finding hilarious new enemies,weapons,and other miscellaneous jokes.

Fun,time consuming,and possesing a significant amount of depth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052377216', 'num_games_owned': 5706, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1590124757}
review:
This game serves as an excellent example of how something can be "dinky" and still good. There are all sorts of "rogue-like" and "rogue-lite" games on Steam nowadays, and this is certainly among the best.

You're basically a person with some customized build of your choosing going through a dungeon with the goal of becoming more powerful and slaying some guy. The story is comical and background noise at best, and the real strength of the game is in exploration and advancement.

The one flaw in this game is the art style. Obviously, the graphics are very low tech, but there is a difference between "good" low tech (Shovel knight, Braid, etc) and "bad" low tech, and this, albeit barely, falls into the bad. Everything around you kinda looks vomit-colored and some of the monsters blend in with the scenery so well that they look like furniture. If it weren't for the fact that items "sparkled" when on the ground, you'd really have no way of knowing the difference between a new pair of boots and a corpse. Dob't get me wrong; it's not the worst looking game in the world by any means, but it could easily be made better.

In short, this game is cheap and goes on sale a fair bit. It's perfectly for when you've got some spare time at work and things are slow, so you should look to add it to your library when you get the chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998079940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1410115184}
review:
This is a damn good roguelike, that is a nice entry point to the genre as there aren't really any dumb random game ending mechanics and it has multiple difficulties so beginners can get eased in.

The graphics are really good for a roguelike and have a nice charm. 

The humor is REALLY GOOD in this game. You should read every single tool tip you can because most of them are hilarious.

There's a decent amount of character building options too.

The music is pretty good.

All of the DLC is good and recommendable.

Steam Workshop has some awesome mods to add more character class options or game content.

That said, it is a beginner's roguelike, there isn't enough depth here to play the game for hundreds and hundreds of hours like some of the heavy hitters.

Verdict: SALE.
DLC Verdict: SALE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014987184', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1590329262}

review: Ho preso questo gioco nell'humble bundle che comprendeva anche audiosurf, world of goo e un altro gioco drm free, io ho preso il bundle perchè mi interessava soprattutto audiosurf gli altri giochi li ho presi un po' alla cieca, anzi questo gioco nemmeno mi ispirava molto, ma ho deciso di provarlo. devo dire che avevo dei pregiudizi negativi al riguardo, ma appena ho iniziato a giocarci mi ha appassionato non posso dire sia il migliore dei giochi però lo consiglio se si vuole un gioco leggero e non troppo ''impegnativo''. Il gioco ha una difficoltà media e ha molta longevità visto che gli achievement sono parecchi, e io adooro i giochi con parecchi achievement ;) Nel complesso questo gioco mi piace molto perchè fa passare velocemente il tempo è simpatico e mi fa tenere attaccata al computer perchè voglio esplorare al 100 % tutta la mappa,  scendere al piano successivo, e ovviamente per completare gli achievement ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197981147776', 'num_games_owned': 1231, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 10954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8345, 'last_played': 1551632278}
review:
I'm going to be frank here, Dungeons of Dredmor is one of the best roguelikes to come out period. Definitely pick it up, if not for the normal price then at the steam sale or the humble bundle!
Here a few bulletpoints about the game:

+ The game features a HUGE amount of content with 1 free expansion and 2 paid DLC
+ The game as well as it's DLC is often featured in the steam sale, so it can become very cheap
+ The amount of skilltrees featured in the game as well as the random level generation guarantees a unique experience each   playthrough
+ The variety is yet increased by the addition of mods via steam workshop
+ This game has great humor seen in the enemy taunts, item descriptions, skill descriptions or random stuff you find in your quest to slay dredmor

+- It's hard as balls! Be prepared to die over and over again. First you'll die at the first few floors, but as you get better you start dying in the last few floors because you're overconfident^^. 

+- I'ts not made for short play-sessions. Even on the "No time to grind" setting which let's you have smaller floors worth the same experience points it will take you 15+ hours to beat to game (or lose those 15+ hours dying from a mistake on the last floors)

To be honest the game doesn't really have glaring flaws, however combine the difficulty with the fact that you might spend a lot of time on one character only to see him die can be quite infuriating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009315672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2720, 'last_played': 1567543061}
review: This is hands-down my favorite rogue-like (an actual rogue-like) that I've ever played. The base game itself contains so many ridiculous skill trees and items that its hard not to derive even a little fun from it even for those not into turn based RPG's. On top of that the DLC's add even more content that adds to the absurdity and wonder of this game and one of them is free. Also, this game is cheap as hell. It is easily worth triple what they are charging for it and I honestly feel kinda bad that I can't hand them more money. In addition, just in case you manage to somehow-inconceivabley-run out of things to do in the base game and DLC, the mod support for this game is fantastic, with hundreds of new skills, items, and enemies to be easily downloaded from the workshop. This game easily falls onto my list of must own games on Steam and for this price ($5) there is no reason not to own this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029405632', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1471869644}
review:
10 / 10 Roguelike fanoknak kötelező !!!

Sziasztok ! Gaaraati vagyok. 
Szerintem ez a játék egy tökéletesen kidolgozott roguelike játék. Én egyébként is nagy Indie és Roguelike fan vagyok úgyhogy nekem ez egy "nobrainer" volt. 
Ez egy olyan játék, ahol konkrétan beledobnak a közepébe és nesze b+ tanulj. Egy kis játék után hozzálehet szokni a félig-meddig rts, de mégis körökre osztott játék furcsaságához. A crafting rendszer végtelenül egyszerű csak a megfelelő anyagokat kell begyűjtenünk és mehet is a crafting.
A grafikájáról annyit szeretnék mondani, hogy nem egy BF3 és nem is kell annak lennie. A pixel-art egy tökéletes módja, hogy kifejezzük, amit szeretnénk és ez sok játékban vissza is jön. 
Nagyon megéri az árát !!! MINDENKINEK CSAk AJÁNLANI TUDOM !!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001342466', 'num_games_owned': 1778, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1431297344}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972395003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1692, 'last_played': 1471990419}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor seems to lack a lot of the features I like in a pure roguelike game, such as item identification, and 8-directional movement. But it also has a fairly interesting crafting system, and enough item and skill variety to be fun. The interface is functional and easy to use and can be totally controlled with the mouse, which is always nice.

Design wise it has lots of personality to say the least, with many of the items being jokes or references to other games, and most of the monsters are strange and unique creations that at the very least will stay in your mind. One highlight is the use of randomly generated names for just about everything, from artifacts, to unique monsters, to even rooms. I will not even attempt to gauge how successful all this manages to be in the area of actual humor, but it sure is trying hard.

Also I was very surprised to find out that a good chunk of the soundtrack I recognized,  since a good bit of it was composed for another game that got canceled, and I was familiar with the composer. It's really good stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016318816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1410191282}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040860015', 'num_games_owned': 1306, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 17679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13582, 'last_played': 1695252221}
review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]	[i](longer version below)[/i]
One of my most favorite games that I've been able to play for countless hours, filled with humor, great music and funky graphics.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Achievements:[/th]
        [th]Cloud Saving:[/th]
        [th]Trading Cards:[/th]
        [th]Workshop:[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]YES[/td]
        [td]YES[/td]
        [td]YES[/td]
        [td]YES[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Click [u][url=steamcommunity.com/id/neon_cacti/recommended/] here[/url][/u] to see my other Reviews or follow my [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33254425/]Curator Page[/url][/u] for more recommendations.


[h1]In-Depth:[/h1]
Usually I am not a fan of turn-based games, but I love RPG's, which is why I decided to try Dungeons of Dredmor and it was totally worth it. You won't actually notice the turn-based part of it too much and you can even increase or lower the speed of the animations.

With a very quirky and enjoyable soundtrack comes along a great sense of humor as well. From item descriptions to enemy taunts, the game is filled with jokes and references. There is a lot of masteries and items to choose from, although the end game can feel slightly barren.

Crafting allows the player to both create new equipment but also enhance it. Several game modes add challenge to the game if it felt too easy. I've played it several hundred hours off Steam, but I keep coming back to it. Definitely a game that every RPG enthusiast should play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997549374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1467658373}
review: I love rogue-likes and I love the SNES feel to this game. It also will run on lower end systems very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025021719', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1419468023}
review:
Everyone who likes [i]real[/i] roguelike games (as in games that are similar to the original 'rogue' game, not all these platform games and stuff that people keep calling "roguelike") must buy this game! This is the best modern adaptation of rogue/nethack/moria/etc that I've seen so far. (Also see Sword of the Stars for a good sci-fi themed game of this sort.) Crafting makes a good addition to the game, as does the excellent skill system. You're also given difficulty level settings and permadeath can be enabled or disabled.

Overall this game just kicks ass and it's hard to find anything wrong with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003554686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 10566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7215, 'last_played': 1605417906}

author: {'steamid': '76561198153107069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 4808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1660257813}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041786271', 'num_games_owned': 1167, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 2159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2159, 'last_played': 1373547474}
review:
Jeden z lepszych rougelike'ów w jakie grałem z masą smaczków i nietypowego humoru nawiązujących do innych gier i ogólnie popkultury - różnorakie okrzyki potworków, opisy umiejętności a nawet same umiejętności. Całkiem spora ilość umiejętności oraz dobrowolny ich wybór sprawiają, że można zrobić postać praktycznie pod cokolwiek i jakkolwiek działającą, czy to typowego ciężkozbrojnego woja, czy też typowego maga... albo postać która równie wdzięcznie włada toporem co i magią. 
Warto zaznaczyć że wszystko dzieje się w turach a każda przeprowadzona akcja (ruch, otwarcie drzwi, użycie umiejętności, atak itd.) to jedna tura, podczas której każdy przeciwnik może przeprowadzić czynności co trzeba brać pod uwagę podczas zarówno walki jak i ucieczki. Grafika może trochę odstraszać, jednakże dzięki temu gra działa znakomicie na słabszym sprzęcie.
Modowanie gry jest proste dzięki zintegrowanemu workshopowi a same mody nie sprawiają większego problemu oraz można uruchamiać wiele równocześnie. Poziom trudności gry nie jest zbyt wymagający, ale mimo to na tyle trudny że da się dosyć szybko zginąć przy braku ostrożności (lub, jak w każdym roguelike'u - przy odrobinie pecha). Polecam dla każdego, kto lubi się trochę odprężyć przy tego typu grach.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000526549', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 3244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2658, 'last_played': 1704494018}

author: {'steamid': '76561198060536702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3518, 'last_played': 1437625200}
review: One of the best rougelikes I've ever played. If you are new to rougelikes, you will have a real easy time playing this game since it has a mouse interface. The game even has a sense of humor, which is rare for rougelikes. There are a lot of references in the game also, but these things don't make the game any easier if you think it does. I still can't beat the game even though my experience with the rougelike genre. So, the bottom line is, expect to die. A lot. It's a fun and humoruos game and a hard one at that. I recommend it highly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066058506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2305, 'last_played': 1652957249}
review:
A comical challenge for all ages.

Dungeons of Dredmor has been my most favourite purchase on Steam.

First off is the choices when making your character, some sound normal and make sense such as Dual Weilding and Blacksmithing, and then you find the lower end which are just as useful if you know how to use them, Tourist where your camera flash stuns surrounding enemies and the fungal arts, unleashing the power of mushrooms within the dungeon.

Then we finally get into the dungeons, equipped with the various skills of choice and setting forth on our adventure, vending machines placed around the levels to give you the quick buy of food, drink and various items.

Food gives you health regen and alcaholic drinks give you mana regen, it's very realistic like that.

Now exploring the dungeon you will come across monsters, and of course you need weapons and armour, but don't worry you're spoilt for choice with swords, knives, axes, maces, polearms, tomes, wands, crossbows, traps and throwing weapons not to mention you can just fight unarmed if you choose too, and various armours  for preference can be found littered across the floors protecting all your squishly fleshy parts from harm

So with the choices of weapons, skills, armours and items, they must have been boring with the monsters right? Wrong! You will run across a large variation of bats, demons, slimes and diggles and many more things that must be killed before facing Dredmor.

Right now I suggest spending a measley $9.99 or so have a bit of fun, oh and see how many references you might notice within the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989792816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1374, 'last_played': 1409499529}
review: A great entry level roguelike with a good sense of humour. Just as most of the games of this genre, it's fun as long as you're striving for survival. Once you find a self-sustaining skill build, get lucky with items AND don't do any mistakes, it becomes easy and kinda repetitive, but those are circumstances some players might never experience and therefore they could enjoy the game even more. I only wish monster zoos were either implemented differently or removed from the game. Other than that and some skill explanations being cryptic at times, it's a really good, polished game that I highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044132893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2336, 'last_played': 1689649096}
review: Son las 3 de la madrugada y siento que algo me llama, es Dredmor, un juuego realmente entretenido, con adorables Diggles los cuales los aplastaras con lo primero que te encuentres, habilidades absurdamente útilies(absurdo en los dos sentidos) Es un juego perfecto para cuando la vida da asco, ya que gracias a sus expansiones puedes recurrir a la emomancia y hacer que los demás enemigos sientan la necesidad de autoinmolarse. Cuando no tienes nada que hacer y no se te ocurre nada, éste es el juego perfecto.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046951873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 6199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 2757, 'last_played': 1709936371}
review: Dungeons of Dredmore is a great rogue-like RPG, playing both as an homage and parody to the hack 'n' slash and roleplaying games of old.  What makes this game stand out most is the artistic style and the humor of the game itself, being sure to take itself just seriously enough to remain a very solid game.  Also worth mention is the music within the game, composed by Matthew Steele.  If you are a lover of the rogue-like genre, this game is a great deal at less than $5 (U.S.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198013697865', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1409937658}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is an RPG set in a fantasy world. Play as a noble hero who must stop the demonic Lord Dredmora. The once very powerful, was finally defeated, stripped of his power, and then thrown into the underworld. Centuries later, after regenerating his powers, Lord Dredmor decides once again to destroy the human world. 

Before the start of the game create your avatar. Producer gave up from the traditional choice of character classes. Instead, we assign our hero seven skills that come along with the progress in the game, we can develop. 

Moving around randomly generated locations (mostly dungeons) kill hundreds of enemies, collect treasures and avoid traps. A variety of weapons includes swords, axes, and magic. During the game we are able to combine items and create them, such as healing potions or better weapons.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198023387800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4333, 'last_played': 1544855141}
review:
This is a great game. There's a lot of flexibility in making your character, and it's fun to try new builds.
Heads-up: The game takes forever to finish for a roguelike (something like six hours, even with the No Time to Grind option enabled).

author: {'steamid': '76561197966885982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 7468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6602, 'last_played': 1428169821}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a graphical roguelike that parodies popular culture and roguelikes in general. It was released in 2011 by Gaslamp Games. Like most roguelikes it has procedurally-generated dungeons as well as a lot of monsters and items for the player to discover. Your task is to venture down into the unknown and vanquish the Dark Lord Dredmor.

There are three expansion packs available for Dredmor: Realm of the Diggle Gods, You Have To Name The Expansion Pack and Conquest of the Wizardlands. These bring more starting skills, monsters, levels and items into the base game and are all recommendable.

+Very replayable.
+Lots of humorous references.
+Challenging, especially on hardest difficulties.
+A huge selection of starting skills.
+An easy-to-use interface.

-Some builds are very overpowered and some can be practically impossible to win with.
-Tends to slow down when there are many enemies and items on the screen at once.
-One Steam achievement is bugged and one is practically impossible to get.

And remember:

LUTEFISK FOR THE LUTEFISK GOD!

author: {'steamid': '76561198116682978', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 23399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10263, 'last_played': 1688150415}
review:
A silly, beginner-friendly yet potentially tough roguelike.
To me, its greatest strength is the customization - you can pick seven skill paths for each character, which heavily influence gameplay and can result in interesting combinations. Additionally, there's user-created skills and other content, some of which is as clever and balanced as the original game.
Compared to NetHack and most similar roguelikes,  there's a lot more focus on clarity, but there's still some things you have to learn through experimentation. There's also a lot more focus on spellcasting and character creation and the (optional) crafting system.
Combat is fairly hack-and-slay, which can feel pretty tedious, but there's a "no time to grind" option for smaller floors, and synergetic abilities can finish battles a lot faster.
The game features three difficulty modes and the option to turn off permadeath, so beginners (and anyone else) can reduce its frustration potential if they want to. On the other hand, the hardest difficulty delivers a great challenge akin to traditional roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025885324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 11826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4348, 'last_played': 1636692082}
review: I want to tell you the story of one of the most fantastic adventurers I ever created, his name is Gershwin. He began as a strange idea for the most stupid type of character I could have made. He would punch everything, get the crap kicked out of him, and drink every philter of booze he found. I crafted him and then set him loose on the first level and was amazed when he did not die immediately. I followed his adventures as he raided kitchens, punched robots to death, and drunkenly stumbled through level after level. He made it farther than any other character I had made, I formed a massive backstory for him as he went that bordered on actual fanfiction. It was the most beautiful thing that has ever happened. Gershwin swaggered onto yeat another level and began tearing through the obstacles in the best hat zorkmids could buy.  Gershwin ran into a room filled with fountains and saw a single lutefisk warrior on an outcropping. He rushed over to give him what for like the gentleman adventuer he is, but the warrior must have known him by reputation as he started to hide behind the nearest fountain. Gershwin rushed over and gave him the, "Dance of One Thousand Boots." Then Gershwin realized, he had kicked the fountain in his haste as well. The fountain had landed in an immovable position and was wedged there forever. My heart broke in that moment because I knew, Gershwin would forever be bobbing his eyebrows on that stone islet. Never to adventure again. He is now the only save file that will forever remain, and Gershwin will forever be punished for my hubris. Buy Dungeons of Dredmor, have adventures, inadvertently enact a tragedy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038398955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3912, 'last_played': 1681604772}
review: It's difficult to put my reaction to this game in little words. This game has a great amount of peculiar humor that put a smile on my face when I read the names of items or weapons and even the descriptions to skills. This rogue-like game is a big luck test. In fact, I'd have to agree that the game revolves around how lucky or unlucky you get upon moving through each dungeon run. You have tons of skills to pick from at the start of each character run, may you select them on your own or just hit random to go with the flow. I'd have to say that playing with random skills each time is the real kick of it. Although, this quirky game isn't meant for all gamers alike. But, if you're interested in rogue-like games and you're alright with dying several times over; I'd think this game would fit you perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962721376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 5682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3916, 'last_played': 1705928261}
review:
Bottom line up front?  I love this game and would recommend it to 99% of my friends.  The other 1% I recently had a falling out with, so they deserve what they get.

+A polished rouge-like, with a large ammount of variety and possibility, wrapped in an attractive shell that is accessible and rewarding.
+Great humour throughout, with references to Monty Python, Skyrim, and many others!  Nerds rejoice!
+Simple, but effective UI, with clear graphics that have a lot of charm and thought behind them.
+A robust set of traits and skills to improve, with a large set of craftable items to make or find through levels filled with devious traps and deceptively-cute enemies.
+Optional settings, allowing you to choose permadeath, difficulty, and size of levels to meet your desired scenario and play style.
+Randomly generated levels ensure endless hours of engaging gameplay, with extended Steam workshop mods providing even greater customization and variety.
+Amazing value and one of the best of it's kind.  It is an almost-peerless rendition of the rouge-like genre for modern gamers and old alike.

If you enjoy games like (duh) Rouge, Sword of the Stars: The Pit, NetHack, ADoM, or love zany humor, give it try.  You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029099955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1500, 'last_played': 1407715540}
review:
I don't recommend this game. For a roguelike, it drags on too long, like, WAY WAY TOO LONG. When every floor and every encounter feels so samey, and all the encounters just blend together eventually, your eventual death at the end of slogging it down for hours and hours will come from making a dumb mistake just because you're SO BORED that it's hard to pay attention.

Nothing else in this game even needs consideration, it's all overshadowed by that one point. I just want to see the ending, but the incredible patience required to slog your way there is the true test, and it's one you DON'T WANT TO PAY FOR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998027156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1652, 'last_played': 1406977024}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ve0yS6C9qGI
Tile based procedurally generated dungeon crawler.

From that alone most people will already know whether this is the type of game they want to play. If that's the kind of game that appeals to you, then you'll be happy to know that Dungeons of Dredmor offers a pretty polished experience in that vein.

However, the game is sadly a victim of the typical problems of procedurally generated games. Just as the items that litter the dungeon floor and the level layout are random, so are the enemy placements and sheer volumes of them, the knock on effect is you can wander floor after floor with few health recovering items being spawned while being expected to clear out swaths of enemies. The difficulty of enemies and power of the weapons found does increase as you progress through the dungeon; the usual difficulty curve that you'd expect, but because of the random nature, whether its actually possible to progress more than a couple of floors leaves you entirely at the whims of the game's random number generator.

The game features the concept of a "Monster Zoo", which is basically behind a door you'll find a room filled to the brim with enemies. Clear the room out and you'll be rewarded, though if you use stairs to escape to the safety of another floor, you'll forfeit the reward. These are cool the first couple of items you encounter them, but on later floors they're just a nuisance. I've had the first door I've opened on a floor be a Monster Zoo and been completely annihilated in mere turns.

The lone shopkeeper in the game also seems to be randomly generated rather than guaranteed every 'x' floors, which can lead to some frustration, especially when you're flush with gold and nowhere to spend it or simply tired of lugging a hundred items in your inventory intended for resale. The items he has on offer also vary each time, so you can be at Dredmor's doorstep only to find him trying to flog the types of items you didn't even bother picking up on the first floor.

As such whether you'll enjoy the dungeon crawling on offer here is purely down to your luck with what the game spawns for you. On the one hand, this is par for the course with these types of games, but that doesn't really make up for the fact that the game basically decides randomly whether it will be fun to play or not.

Destroying monsters, disarming traps, unlocking doors or smashing statues (for some reason) will provide experience, however level ups themselves aren't really of that much use. Instead of the traditional major boost to your stats (you get your health and mana raised by a painfully small amount), they basically just provide you a way of unlocking a skill in one of the skill trees you selected at the beginning of the game (so make sure you actually choose something worth levelling up, as appealing as it is to just let the game randomise it).

The game offers a lot of different ways to spec your character, but almost to the point of overkill. The game doesn't take itself too seriously and that extends to the options available here, but they only serve to muddy the waters as a lot aren't worth using. The steam workshop does feature a number of additional ones you can add to your game to extend it a little, some of which I found to be more useful than the default ones available.

The game provides a whole host of different weapon classes to choose from, but generally swords and arrows seem to be the most commonly found type in the dungeon. The game also boasts a magic system, but I was never able to work out how to make it work. In addition there are also wands you can use to cast spells regardless of your innate talent for the mystical, which are used in the same way as class based skills.

The item limit does feel a little restricting, but it does prevent you from trying to be a jack of all trades, since you simply don't have the space to fit all your alchemy ingredients alongside the ingots of metal you want to stockpile since they might prove useful at some point. I rarely ended up using them, but never failed up pick them up, something feels wrong about leaving loot lying around on the floor.

The game isn't the most aesthetically pleasing, but does at least feature a fair number of different enemies and the level tile sets fit together to make levels that fit together well. Each floor also makes use of a different tileset but for the most part that's all that sets floors apart so it can start to feel very "samey" by the time you've made it to later floors, though some do have some gimmicks like specific tiles that will erupt into flames when you walk over them.

As mentioned, the game is a light hearted affair (though that can go out the window when you're fuming over your most recent death), so the item descriptions feature of a lot of "references" or a simply "funny" designs themselves, such as the traffic cone helmet. Of course the enemies are all fairly whimsical too, for the most part you'll be finding some kind of penguin hybrid called diggles or black balls with arms, legs, a face... and a huge moustache. The most common health restoring item found in the game are various forms of cheese, though if that's a reference it was completely lost on me.

The game does feature a rather hefty, though initially confusing, crafting system. With the correct ingredients and a high enough ability in the corresponding skill you can craft everything from potions to armour to cheese on toast, the list of options gets rather long, and there's "hidden" recipes in the game that are uncovered by investigating bookshelves. However the limitations on inventory space led me to ignore the crafting aspect entirely for the most part.

Despite its shortcomings, the game can be enjoyable to play (if you can get a decent dungeon to play in), and scratches the itch of looting dungeons for progressively better items pretty well. Each floor can take a substantial amount of time to fully investigate as well, usually around 20-30 minutes I found. While the random nature of the dungeons does make the game infuriating at times and feel unbalanced, it plays well and the dungeon generation does at least feel different enough each time to offer up a reason to replay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993191436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5591, 'last_played': 1408755899}
review:
Game is fantastic roguelike with many options for both character capabilities and equipment!  I have played many games, a few to to the end, and have loved so much of it the whole time. As the expansions have come out they have added more character options, more equipment, new game features (new crafting system, new locations, better storage management with a pocket dimension, and more!

If you like strategic roguelike's then this game is for you!

review: 로그라이크라는 장르와 전혀 친숙하지 않음에도 불구하고 재밌게 플레이 할 수 있었다. 던전 크롤 같은 것도 찾아서 해봤는데 역시 좀 다가가기 힘들었는데 이 게임은 그런 게 없다. 평범한 캐주얼 RPG 게임처럼 쉽게 즐길 수 있는 게임이고 이런 저런 독특한 요소들이 매력있게 다가온다. 무작위로 생성되는 던젼을 탐험하며 성장하는 재미도 쏠쏠하다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024977470', 'num_games_owned': 1398, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 25199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22155, 'last_played': 1664058716}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a great roguelike game in the spirit of the original games. Turn based, dungeon crawl with challenges of inventory management (though a bit easier now).

The challenge starts at the very beginning with the selection of a skill set that has the proper synergy (ghads, I actually wrote that? No, I'm not a middle manager, why do you ask) - though do give random a try (there's a badge for it). Tossed into this mix is crafting (and encrusting), spell and ammunition management, and choices about which skills to level up when.

The theme game is to be taken light heartedly, but the challenge of the game is right up there with Nethack and its brethren (and yet, it is still much more approachable than the roguelikes of old). You will find new and interesting ways to die (there's a badge for that too). The game is a worth it at twice its standard price

author: {'steamid': '76561197983546384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1307, 'last_played': 1406391252}
review:
Il primo livello è frustrante, il secondo livello è divertente, il terzo livello comincia ad essere un po troppo sbilanciato sulla semplicità e il quarto livello è di una noia assassina, i nemici muoiono solo a guardarti.
L'altro problema sono le ricompense delle missioni e il loot in generale. Sono un ladro, quindi vorrei usare i pugnali, ma mica se ne trovano di pugnali in giro! Neanche come ricompensa delle quest...E allora? Semplice, ho il ladro che usa mazze, asce e spade....Cioè, allora cosa personalizzo a fare?

author: {'steamid': '76561198008369673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2155, 'last_played': 1661022297}
review:
I re-write this review on the grounds that I have now purchased the DLCs that are available for it.

And all I have to say is, get the game and get the DLCs.  You will not regret it.  

Yo absolutely do not need the DLCs to enjoy Dredmor, the game is really good on its own.  However the DLCs add so so much more to it and in a good way.  Much more creativity for making your character and many more enemy types to go through and it extends the game by 50%, so you get a bigger game as well.  

Seriously this is a great game made better and for little outlay.  You will regret nothing upon buying this addictive piece of gaming art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032590325', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3419, 'last_played': 1514312743}
review:
I got an achievment for the game crashing. 10/10

In all seriousness, though, this game is fantastic. It has incredibly fluid gameplay, which is both challenging and addictive. The combat is a little like Skyrim, in that you can get out of it exactly what you want. I'm generally kind of cheap, but there is no question about this game being worth its asking price. My suggestion is that you get the DLCs as well. They're cheap and they add a ton of content to an already fantastic game. Plus, you get the full range of mods from this game's wonderful community.

If I had to pick a gripe, however, it would be an aesthetic one. I don't love the way the game looks, though it is serviceable. The main character's eyebrows are almost distractingly large. Aside from that, none of the equipment that you pick up or craft shows up your character. This is a little irritating, as it doesn't necessarily give you the sense of progression that one might want out of a game like this. Regardless, however, this game is fantastic. If you're into dungeon crawlers or rogulelikes, don't even hesitate to pick this one up. It's a real gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095010628', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2668, 'last_played': 1603268318}
review: Bought this during the Steam Summer Sale and this title alone was worth the bucks I spent in total - it's hilarious, it's full of wonderful references and at its core an awesome rogue-like crawler. For those in the know: It's like Munchkin-turned-videogame. Bashing through the next door, bleeding (from an agressive carrot) you kick in the door, sacrifice lutefisk to the lutefisk god, hoping for something good to whack those creatures only to find yourself at the receiving end of a nasty trap. You're dead. Did I mention it has Emo as a school of magic? And that you can become Totally Not Drizzt? Yeah. Now go, spend these few bucks and have a blast, best turn on some cheesy fantasy music (DND Soundtracks anyone? *chuckle*).. and whack them all!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034306697', 'num_games_owned': 1401, 'num_reviews': 614, 'playtime_forever': 3992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2102, 'last_played': 1632414931}
review:
Though a pretty cool game I did NOT have a great personal experience with it.

A LOT of skills, crafting options, and equipment within the dungeon to choose from.
All skills are chosen from the very beginning and are upgradeable as you level up in the game. They range from highly practical to just downright shits and giggles (though still useful).
A lot of the fancy crafting has to be done with specific crafting skills that you have to choose when you start the game. They can range from armor, weapons, crossbow bolts, more crafting materials, potions, etc. Every type of item category in the game has a lot of items under them. The fancier stuff either have to be crafted or, if you're lucky, just found randomly as you explore.
Loot can be far too plentiful and since I usually like to hoarde loot I was easily overwhelmed by how much I had to let go and sell off to make room. If you're a bit lucky you can get a storage-like item in the form of a big room where you can put a load of crap in and access it whenever & wherever you want.
The whole game can be rather difficult if you just rush through it so you're sort of forced to keep killing enemies and exploring to find and/or make better equipment.

Along with the cool stuff here I've also got a few personal problems with this game and one of them is how lenghty these dungeons can be. I like to explore every nook and cranny of a dungeon usually and these maps can be huge. There are 10 levels in this dungeon (15 if you have that DLC). Exploring can be delayed by way of a huge mob of enemies coming at me, kicking my arse, and forcing me to reload to my last save thus having me think of better ways to get through said obstacles.
Another problem I have is that I crash every now and again when, I presume, it attemps to auto-save which I can't toggle on or off. Luckily there's a manual save but there's no real way to load a file while you're in the dungeon. If you want to quit the game you're either forced to save & quit, crash, or end the process via task manager. You can only make ONE file per playthrough too meaning you can't choose another slot for another save in one run; you only have your manual save file and your auto-save file.

This probably won't happen to everyone but the one thing that ticked me off the most is that after 30+ hours of playing this game I get to the final Level, run into the boss of this whole game (Lord Dredmor) and suddenly have him disappear thus leaving me with no way to finish the game. While fighting him he teleports every now and again just to mess with you and throw magic at you but for MY case he teleports and just vanishes. I've explored the whole dungeon multiple times to see if he's just messing with me again but he was nowhere to be found thus labeling my over-two-dozen-hour playthrough to be a waste. It was guaranteed a waste because my only saves took place after he bugged out since I thought he was just somewhere in the current level waiting for me.

[b]Overall, it's still a great game (and at a cheap price, too) with a lot of exploring & crafting, equipment, and skill options to choose from. Also don't let the not-so-stellar artwork be a downer. [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198048176584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 10262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4646, 'last_played': 1439257593}
review:
Un jeu honnête, joli, avec pas mal d'humour. Un peu répétitif mais la rejouabilité est bonne grâce aux skills plus ou moins loufoques que l'on peut choisir (de "maitre de l'épée" a "Vegan" en passant par "Emo" ou "Communiste")

Avec ce jeu, vous ne regarderez plus une carotte ou un rutabaga de la même facon. Vous faire tuer par des légumes qui vous traitent de n'wah en hurlant FUS ROH DAH, ya que ca de vrai ..

author: {'steamid': '76561198062085036', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1514724279}
review:
別被粗眉毛嚇到了，這款遊戲絕對比你想像的有趣許多

和一般rogue-like不同，在遊戲開始前你可以選擇要帶上的技能
各種技能的組合讓每次的冒險更顯有趣而不容易感到乏味(rogue-like比較容易膩)

配合不同的技能，在迷宮中你也會被迫去使用不同的戰術
例如使用短刀配合法杖，或是使用肉搏配合投擲武器，當然也可能出現肉搏加刀劍這類矛盾的組合

就算沒有技能加成，也還是可以使用該武器
遊戲的靈活度非常高

其他還有像是合成系統等豐富的要素
推薦給喜歡嘗試各種組合，以及rogue-like的玩家

author: {'steamid': '76561198013723081', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 365, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1429655266}
review:
Hello friends,

I decided to review this game called Dungeons of Dredmor. This dungeon game is a tongue in cheek game that is quite a random dungeon romp, although it looks very silly and acts that way, it is quite a hard game..i have played it with lots and lots of difficulty. There are also references to lutafisk in it too. Not sure what that is about, it could be a reference to the developer of the game. I have yet to finish this game due to it's difficulty.

The game also contains several DLCS for it. One of the most unique ones is the one you can name yourself the DLC. There is even a achievement associated with it, which i found very interesting to do.

The game is well designed and quite fun, but i still found out it is very dififcult. I will recommend because of how good the game is designed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979697267', 'num_games_owned': 2788, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3186, 'last_played': 1377137005}
review: Depending on your settings this is a much longer Rogue-like experience then most, which can make those losses much harder to take. I definitely enjoyed the ability to play with different character builds and all of the humor in the game. This is one of the first traditional rogue-like games that I have ever beaten and I still boot it up every once in awhile. The DLC have all added a lot to the game. I like the way this studio approaches the community and development in general and will probably buy their next game right away. I suggest giving this a try if you like traditional rogue-like games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992567771', 'num_games_owned': 2159, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1373627185}
review:
Dungeon of Dredmor ist ein Dungeon Rouge-Like RPG. Man erkundet mit seinem Avatar ein gefährliches Dungeon und hat das Ziel den bösen Herrscher Dredmor zu besiegen. Dabei startet man am Anfang mit einem ziemlich geringen Repertoire an Fähigkeiten und Gegenständen und muss sich erst mühsam hoch arbeiten.

Am Anfang wählt man den weiblichen oder männlichen Charakter, gibt ihm einen Namen und wählt zum Start ein paar grundlegende Fähigkeiten aus. Dabei kann man sich schon hier entscheiden ob man lieber als Magier spielt oder ob man doch lieber Schwert oder Axt schwingt oder irgendwas dazwischen. Im Spiel kann man dann gänzliche frei seinen Charakter formen. Man kann am Anfang einen gebrechlichen Magier haben und am Ende einen blutrünstigen Berserker der trotzdem noch mächtige Magie wirken kann. Es ist alles möglich. Danach wird man auch schon mit einer kleinen Erklärung zur Mission ins Dungeon geschmissen und kann es frei erkunden. 

Schnell wird man dann Bekanntschaft mit den ersten Monstern machen die man auch schnell besiegt hat. In den oberen Etagen sind die Monster noch relativ einfach zu besiegen, desto tiefer man in das Dungeon steigt desto stärker werden aber auch die Monster. Ab hier ist eigentlich alles wie in einem normalen RPG, man kloppt Monster weich, sammelt fallen gelassene Items, erreicht höhere Level, vergibt Skillpunkte, nimmt Quests an mystischen Statuen an. Und nicht vergessen Lutefisk zu sammeln!

Dabei darf man aber nicht vergessen das in Dungeon of Dredmor der Permadeath gilt! Stirbt man einmal ist alles vorbei und man darf wieder komplett von vorne beginnen. Deswegen wird man vor allem am Anfang sehr vorsichtig zu Werke gehen. Für Weicheier gibt es auch noch einen „Noob“ Modus bei dem nach einem Tod einfach der letzte gespeicherte Spielstand geladen wird. Im normalen Modus werden beim Tod die Spielstände gelöscht. Dazu gibt es noch einen Hardcore Modus der nochmal extra schwierig ist.

Die Grafik ist klassisch gehalten und einfach. Man merkt das die Grafik überwiegend handgezeichnet ist und es gibt viele kleine Details. Die Monster sind teilweise etwas eigenwillig gestaltet, nachdem man sich daran gewöhnt hat werden einem die Monster inklusive der putzigen Diggles schnell ans Herz wachsen. Die Animationen sind durchschnittlich, es gibt für fast alle Waffen unterschiedliche Schlaganimationen das war es aber auch schon. Die Präsentation passt zum Spiel, es gibt viele unterschiedlich gestalte Räume die alle Abwechslung ins Spiel bringen. Mit dem Steam Workshop kann man sich dazu noch sehr viele zusätzliche Räume, Waffen oder Fähigkeiten holen. Das einzigste was mir nicht gefällt ist, dass man Ausrüstung und Waffen nicht optisch am Helden sieht. Es ist schade wenn man eine richtig krasse Rüstung hat und der Held immer noch mit dem einfachen Wams herumläuft.

Dungeon of Dredmor ist ein Spiel mit Ecken und Kanten, aber es macht viel Spaß sobald man sich an den eigenwilligen Stil gewöhnt hat. Die Grafik ist einfach erfüllt aber gut ihren Zweck und hat trotzdem einige Details die einen schmunzeln lassen. Das ganze Spiel ist eher auf Humor ausgelegt, man möchte sich einfach einmal die Skillbeschreibungen durchlesen. Für alle die auf Rouge-like RPGs wie FTL stehen werden auch mit Dungeon of Dredmor viel Spaß haben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055914756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5973, 'last_played': 1404982379}
review:
Well worth the price.  One of the better rogue-likes on steam.  

Pros:
- Loads of character and item stats and skills that govern almost all aspects of play and almost all of which can be important at some stage or another.  For example, the visibility range stat seems less than usefull until you get a great item that limits visibility and you are looking and just adjacent squares when moving.  Then you start looking for any other item with some more visibility stats!
- Power creep and level difficulty seem to balance quite well with just the right amount of toughness to keep you trying again and again.  
- Ability to combine a range of the many available skills make for near limitless variety in character buils. 
- Every character level you get to add a new power from one of the skills - so every level-up is actually worthwhile.
- Has that old rogue-like tension to it. Nothing like wandering around a monster filled level all beat-up  with no more food to heal and hoping the next door you open actually has food instead of monsters!
- Artifact system is cool as it makes true unique items out of any of the tons of standard items.  You can literally get any combination of extra stat bonuses to a fixed item.  The anvils that have a chance to upgrade items by adding random stats are cool as well.

Cons:
 - A bit too silly and cartoonish for my tastes - prefer my classic orcs, goblins and ogres - samurai robots, leprechauns and Diggles not so much.  Unique Item names are also nonsensical   - A sword called "Sapfurpor the Potent Aardvark"!!  Really?
 - Not as much variety on monsters as I would like - lots of reskinning and just power creeping of a few core models.
- Crafting skills while implimented well are not as usefull as they could have been,  You can basically find any item you can craft (fairly easily) and with crafting you end up filling up spending way too much time collecting and organzing crafting componets. When i do take them it's more for that stat bonuses then the crafting itself. 
- A little unstable for me in the late game with lots of crashes but auto-save mitigates this rather well.
- Lack of decent documentation.  Had to resort to the wiki to actually understand what the heck many of these stats and skills actually did! 

Bottom line -  100 hours in and I am still enjoying the game.  How can you argue with five cents an hour for entertainment!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067511511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1408859992}
review:
For $5 this game is a snag. It's a pretty basic turn-based dungeon crawler but its easy to lose your time in the many character combinations, weapons, items, and levels. The only thing to complain about is that I RUN OUT OF GOD DAMNED INVENTORY SPACE! This really isn't a problem I just wanted to address the fact that with so many items it's hard to make room for what you want to keep. One thing I would want added to the game is that equipped armour is visible on the character when you're playing. Also what's up with their eyebrows...? The crafting aspect is a nice touch, doubling with secret recipes you can find around the dungeon bookshelves. The community is good and there are a bunch of mods you can play around with, adding more items, weapons, dungeon rooms, character traits and perks, and enemies. After a few play-throughs I got hooked and started really enjoying the depth of the game. 
I would recommend this to anyone who is a fan of the dungeon crawler, turn based, or rogue like genres, or anyone curious about the game. BUY IT NOW (or wait for it to go cheap on sale)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990968670', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 10332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6618, 'last_played': 1574661345}
review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]

To get the basics of the game out of the way, Dungeons of Dredmor is a hilarious turn-based dungeon crawler RPG with permanent death and brutal difficulty (which are both technically optional but we all know how the game is meant to be played). I love this game and I've decided to present my thoughts in a pros-and-cons list:

[H1]Pros:[/H1]

-Consistently silly visual style throughout the artwork and sprites, which is retro-ish and visually appealing at when it wants to be. Sometimes it's just goofy and you have to wrap your head around the fact that they decided to draw a [i]mustache golem[/i].

-Charming audio design. The music is a bit repetive, but the sound effects of the enemies and spells are sometimes as silly as their descriptions. The real beauty of the "sounds of Dredmor", is the announcer. He is very HAM and his gruff voice is always there reminding you to DRINK MORE BOOZE.

-A fair number of skills to choose from and combine to make new characters, with many unique playstyles able to be experienced. I've heard that past roguelikes have had more deep character building and stats, but DoD still has excellent replayability and there are no class archetypes restricting your skill combinations.

-A very large amount of equipment and consumables available to collect, with an enchantment system that revolves around randomly added statistics and the possibility of cursing your equipment because you're a greedy SOB and we all know you'll ruin your best weapon with spontaneous combustion.

-Absurd enemy types (again [i]mustache golems[/i]) that randomly spout out movie references while rending you eye from brow.

-Absolutely every item/skill/enemy/random dungeon furniture description is worth reading.

-It has 3 difficulty options and [strike]optional permadeath[/strike] absolutely required permadeath for real gamers. Generally the game is pretty difficult, but you have options and that's a plus no matter what.

-Very cheap, the whole game and all DLC can be bought for less than $5 and that is incredible value in my opinion.

-Functional UI that adequately accommodates the many complex systems of the games. It's not perfect but it gets the job done.

[H1]Cons:[/H1]

-Some skills and skill combinations are just too reliant on finding good items or are outright too weak. While this trend is not uncommon in roguelikes, in a game that presents itself as a silly RPG, sometimes you just want to do something silly and make it work.

-There is a lot of RNG, ei random chance, involved in the combat and the acquisition of new and powerful equipment which you [b]must have[/b] in order to progress. This can be mitigated by choosing skills which lower your build's gear-reliance but that's still impinging on your build freedom.

-The capabilities of the enemies and their AI are fairly limited throughout almost every level of the dungeons; 90% of them either avoid you and throw out random spells from afar or try to brawl with you at melee range no matter the circumstance (every enemy has a melee attack of some sort, fyi). The last 10% consists of the very few enemies that casts spells while also slowly advancing towards you. I have yet to encounter a boss monster with unique mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026089393', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1321, 'last_played': 1602738339}
review: Was killed by activating rocket jump. 10/10 would rocket jump again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003435423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2030, 'last_played': 1393289275}
review:
If you're looking for a difficult roguelike, this isn't it. If you're looking for a fun roguelike that allows you to "break" the game by finding unique combinations and laughing at the in-game humor, you've foudn the perfect game!

This is a fun game to play but the majority of the game will be you killing enemies that can't hurt you if you play your cards right. If you take the opposite approach and give yourself random skill rolls (or force yourself to use bad ones) then this one can be a fantastic game to play with a god edge of difficulty.

Unfortunately, the only "real difficult" aspect of the game is the final boss; I took no more than 5 damage at a time until I got to the very end and suddenly the end boss is doing 8 times that! He could still be defeated thanks to the near infinite amount of items found as the game went on, but this jarring spike in difficulty from the boss can definitely be a downside to someone who doesn't want to min/max everything and only use the best perks.

Other than that, play the game and have fun. Find a friend with the game and compete to see who can get the farthest with the same skills.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038276360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7265, 'last_played': 1484153313}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065874448', 'num_games_owned': 936, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1637086879}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a roguelike game that is considered really hard by indie game critics. I think this game is amazing and is actually one of the best games I have ever played. This game is also really funny (everyone who has played will agree on that.) It also has an amazing soundtrack, which the tracks come on at the right times to give you a sense of emersion in the world. I highly recommend this game to people who like the Binding of Isaac. Think of another roguelike (Brogue) and mix it with a funny game (Super Meat Boy.) I give this game a 10/10.

If you want a satirical review:

I got humped to death 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198027324612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3552, 'last_played': 1481057544}
review: This game is very funny, but I found myself enjoying the mechanics as much as the humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023828387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1767, 'last_played': 1544700865}
review:
Игра позволяет окунуться в те самые времена, когда проходить игры было по-настоящему трудно, здесь нет фастранов на пять минут, здесь нет халявного дропа, здесь нужно думать, еще до запуска первого уровня...
Ведь то, какие таланты выбрал игрок - более чем повлияет на игровой процесс, а может даже интерес к игре.
Может вы  хотите мага-пироманта, что будет восстанавливать ману каждый шаг и аннигилировать врага огненными шарами, вот только до тех пор, пока не появятся фаер-резист мобы, но это уже совсем другая история.
А может  мелкого воришку-невридимку, что будет избегать ловушек и подлых ударов врага, при этом раздавая пендали направо и налево, а может даже стреляя из арбалета..
А может вы пират, что саблей несет добро в темные подземелья дредмора?!
