author: {'steamid': '76561198028926884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1678412189}
review:
Several years ago, I was introduced to a little game named "Nethack." Odd little game, where there is an intricate system of loot, monsters, and YANDs. I enjoyed it, and I enjoyed the addition content in Slash'em, but I never got very far, and the skills I needed to do everything from kicking a door down to throwing a potion are lost to the rust of unuse. Then here comes this game, recommended by a friend, and I'm right back to the confusing first steps of my first Rogue-like. However, unlike the times where I could not get anywhere without a wiki check for the shortcuts and commands, I can keep trying out the zany possibilities and unique skills without feeling completely lost.

I won't say everybody will enjoy this game, but if you've got an itch for the classic gameplay of Rogue and can't remember how to even use the 'e' word, give this a shot!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987279127', 'num_games_owned': 5630, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 4495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3687, 'last_played': 1435532501}
review:
This is a fun roguelike that gives you some very nice customization options on how you want to play.  You can turn permadeath on/off, and you can turn on "no time to grind" mode, which makes the levels physically smaller (so there's less loot), but the monsters give more xp per monster kill, so there's still the same amount of xp per dungeon level.

I'd recommend playing a few times on permadeath mode, because your first couple characters are going to be terrible because you don't know what skills work well together.  Permadeath mode is also VERY intense.  Although I had fun playing with permadeath off in later characters, there's nothing like the thrill of getting out of a situation where you thought you were totally screwed in permadeath mode.

Once you've been killed by the final boss in permadeath mode (he WILL kill you the first time you fight him), by then you know what you're doing, and can turn permadeath off and build a good character to beat the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011427124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1391723338}
review: This game is a total riot. A hilarious roguelike game with funny gear and creatures. Fantastic music tracks. The graphics are pixely retro in a good way. You can play as a Killer Vegan, a tourist with a camera, a werediggle, and other ludicrous classes. There are all kinds of cheese laying around to eat. Gruyere? Gouda? Stats include burliness and caddishness. There are vending machines all over to buy raw steaks or sewer brew. You can throw baseballs at enemies. And when you die, and you will many times, the game salutes you by saying "Congratulations! You have died!" What can be better than that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198047212696', 'num_games_owned': 987, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1655798083}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is an intelligently designed Rogue-Like, it's very hard and extremely satisfying. You choose between a variety of perks when you start off your character, and it's crucial to pick a good build, because that's what you're stuck with for the entire run. The game has a moderatly strong sense of humour that come up in incredibly surprising places, the soundtrack is enjoyable, there's lots of enemy, item and level variety, but most importantly, there's no spiders (as far as I've been).

Overall, I think that Dungeons of Dredmor is a very good game if you enjoy rogue-likes  and that you should pick it up with the DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997252853', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1393515588}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043430970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3791, 'last_played': 1635809999}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor has amazing music, about a billion different items, and floors galore. It's a really fun game that has a different outcome every time you play. With a bunch of different classes to choose from and combine with other classes, this game gives a different experience every single time. I have to personally say that Dungeons of Dredmor is up there in my top 10 list of games I love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978273424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6869, 'last_played': 1461079965}
review:
Brilliant roguelike - and a genuine roguelike, not a platformer-with-permadeath or other rubbishness. 

Quirky 80s-british humour, good gameplay, really interesting skill progression. Hard enough to constantly challenge, but not frustratingly impossible. Not as insanely complex as nethack or DCSS, but still with a vast amount of depth to explore. 

If email addresses bring you out in a cold sweat, you will love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984223758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2593, 'last_played': 1392268081}
review:
Few games personify the attempt to make Rogue friendly and approachable like Dredmor. There are lots of games out there now that rock a similar angle— many of them good, some of them great— but very few retain the structure of Rogue like Dredmor. Here you will find bare-bones inventory management(so many times you'll drop things, rearrange them, et cetera), permadeath(though it can be turned off), procedurally-generated labyrinths and stupid monsters. The crafting system, the skill trees, all of it is designed to let you fall through the cracks. All of it is designed around letting you die.

And it is gloriously addictive, if you like that sort of thing.

The first forty hours of Dredmor I didn't even get to see the namesake Lich at the bottom of the dungeon. I was playing on the hardest difficulty, with permadeath, and I just kept dying before the fifth floor. Then, suddenly, playing a character named Pyra Mancy, everything lined up perfectly and victory was assured. It was delicious.

Triple A games have abandoned this concept, that insane difficulty makes ultimate success that much more rewarding. But of all the games I've beaten on my gameslist, it's no wonder that I'm proudest of Isaac and Dredmor. The art is amateurish, the music repetitive, the story nonexistant.

But it nails the sense of accomplishment that comes with patience and dedication, and for that, it's well worth the asking price.

review: One of the best rogue-likes i've played with quite good community support. And it's also easy to get into for those not used to that genre. Hours of fun and way worth the money, one of the best investments i made on steam.  Was already a complete game, then added hours upon hours of fun content by releasing affordable dlcs. author: {'steamid': '76561198049472865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2319, 'last_played': 1637971149}
review: Think dungeon crawler + Skyrim. What do you get? Dungeons of Dredmor! The game itself is very well made, hard but still do-able. The DLC only adds even more to the game. The mods even more so. Probably the best thing is that dying feels like it's YOUR FAULT. It's not that the game is too hard, it's that you messed up. Be forewarned: you will get frustrated and quit. But, you'll always manage to find yourself crawling back. It's apparent that Gaslamp put everything into this game, and they hit all the right notes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057320995', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1508684200}

review:

Just one tip. DO not go into any mysterious portals.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999300526', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1416700336}

author: {'steamid': '76561198074687164', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 4622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3414, 'last_played': 1637678652}
review:
Parody. That's the right word to describe this game. This is one really big parody on almost everything - games, movies, books, characters, quotes etc.

I haven't played roguelike before, this is my first. Although I haven't still finished DoD, I really love playing it. Why? Let me explain on some in-game items:

Mace of Windu (any Star Wars fan out there? thi is one purple glowing stick-shaped mace)
Chainsaw axe (I think you guessed it right)
Axetar (have you seen guitar of Gene Simmons from KISS?)
Axekeytar (what a nice purple guitar shaped keys? errr... I mean axe)
The Sword in the Stone (ever heard about one of this kind? Little help - it starts with "E" letter...)
Bolt of mass destruction (imagine atomic bomb on the end of the crossbow bolt - nice!)
Razor sword for her (this one is really good for... killing enemies)
FUS RO DAH!!!! (mighty Thuum used by creatures - unfortunately for them, it does nothing)
N'wah (not everyone will remember this...)
Horadric Lutefisk cuve - I hope many players know what Horadric cube is. Well this one converts everything to... lutefisk

Next, look on skill images and achievements:

Archaelogy skill - man with fedora, everyone knows one of Harisson Ford's best roles
Bloody mess achievement - Have you ever heard of flying limbs and lots of gore in any of Fallout games?
Realms of the Id achievement - Id Software, enough said. When you see what you must do for the achievement, it brings smile to your face
Suddenly the dungeon collapse - At last! Thank you developers for making this behavior good for something - this time to get achievement

This game is one big laughter. I definitely recommend this. You won't probably ever regret it!

review: This is an excellent RPG game if your in for turn based games. even for players who are not particularly into turn based RPG can derive many hours of fun from this humor filled, challenging RPG. even though it may seem like a short game from the review it can actually take a decent amount of time just to get a few floors in not to mention permadeath makes it so that when you die (which will happen alot) you have start from square 1. all in all a humourus game with just about infinite ways to die (especially if you add mods).

author: {'steamid': '76561197964702183', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1703531538}
review:
This is a game I recommend as a primer for Roguelikes.  If you've never played Rogue or Nethack before, play this first.  If you have played Rogue or Nethack...then play this too!

It's chock full of adventure, loot, style, humor and most importantly fun.  Permadeath is of course the only true way to play. 

The complete game with all the DLC is well worth the regular price but you can get this in numerous game bundles for cheap as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980010740', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1501611083}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is by far my favorite modern day rogue-like. I've played quite a few that piqued my interest, and many that delivered on the promise of an exciting and truly random experience. However, DoD takes the cake hands down. It is a legacy that others should attempt to live up to in the future no matter how they may fail, and they will. 

Read my full review at my blog here: http://bigdadgamer.blogspot.com/2014/02/3-days-ofdungeons-of-dredmor.html

review:
Pretty much the worst game I've ever owned... and I've owned a LOT of games.

Not even the above-average attempts at humour can save the game from horrifically tedious gameplay. I love roguelikes but this one felt too random - as though my actual gaming ability was inconsequential. I suspect the whole thing might have been a lot more enjoyable with regular, pre-designed levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021986083', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1584161035}
review:
Ye gods! What do the lutefisk gods want? Ten slabs of lutefisk burned upon their altars and nothing!

Seventh character and third floor down into the dungeons, I was armed with the Murderous Shiv of Crowbars, and Interdimensional Axe, and a Crossbow Bolt of Mass Destruction. I was feeling good. So good, in fact, that I tried stealing the world's most amazing three-bladed sword from Brax, the salesdemon. Then I proceeded to flay his cheap suited form with it. Ecstatic, I frolicked through the loot - Bolts of Squids, a Cyber Construction Cone helmet, and a Steam Powered Mechanical Arm of Crushing that belonged to some guy whose name I couldn't pronounce.

Then the Dread Collectors came.

Pink, blubberous monsters with pot-bellies and devious Spanish goatees. I unleashed my Bolt of Mass Destruction from Cranky (TM), by automatic crossbow. It bounced off... The walls of the dungeon were rent apart by the force of the nuclear blast, and a handful of the Collectors lost a tenth of their health. I scurried down an aisle of shelves to form a choke point, and smeared poison on my new weapons. I chucked Flasks of Brimstone and Softballs. I turned on my Swashbuckling Auto-Counter ability. I ingested at least six different mushrooms, endowing me with lobstery skin, flannel, a beard, and the might of Chuck Norris. Then the first Collector reached me. I counter attacked him into a fine pink mist.

With chants of "Slay the eyebrowed one!", the second Collector counter-criticalled me into next Tuesday with a vengeance as I tried to escape into my pocket dimension. I slumped down, blood pouring out onto the floor.

BUY THIS GAME, BUT DO NOT, FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THE WONDERFUL LOOT IN THE DUNGEON, DO. NOT. EVER. SHOPLIFT.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025658024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 5046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3593, 'last_played': 1671674912}
review: Seriously fun Rogue-like, good sense of humor in everything. Two points of advice: be prepared to die, a LOT, and always use Burglary.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024992846', 'num_games_owned': 556, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1586226864}
review: From the endless combinations of unique skil trees, to the bizarre and often downright hilarious randomly generated names, this is everything I want in a Roguelike. The world is srange, the music perfect. The combat is simple to understand, and offers endless possibilities for character builds. I got this game as part of a Humble Bundle, and would gladly have paid full price for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079539312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2263, 'last_played': 1391683532}
review:
This is a game that I recieved in my recent Humble Weekly Roguelike sale.  Now I don't have a background in roguelike games, but I've been known to play an RPG or two, and the video game commentator Northernlion who I watch previewed a fair number of the games and I found I liked what I saw.  Though I'd worried that the turn-based gameplay would make it too slow, that the daunting skill and attribute assortment might be too much, but all that worrying was for naught.  After a brief run through the tutorials it's made clear that the basics aren't hard to master at all.  As well, the skill set, though hilarious and seemingly random, actually has purpose.  It is without a doubt an awesome game for anyone who is found of the RPG genre.  

Since buying it a few days ago I have put an embarassing amount of hours into this game and am here to say that it is more than worth it's exceedinly reasonable price.  If you can still pick it up in the Roguelike bundle, I totally suggest doing so, because there are some other brilliant games in there as well.  

If you're tentative watch some gameplay on YouTube, get a better look than what the honestly vague trailer video is telling you, realize the game is awesome and buy it.  It's funny, and a lot better than the old school graphics and cheesy name would make it seem.  Don't get me wrong, it's still cheesy, but in a good way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055098442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2463, 'last_played': 1671092653}

review: Seems like it has a lot of depth, though I haven't even scratched the surface yet. I think I would love this if I were a bigger fan of roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056260433', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1127, 'last_played': 1517801814}
review: This game is really good, but it's also quite difficult. It may not exactly be Super Meat Boy, but it's not for the people who rage a lot. There's tons of customization, from choosing different skill sets at character creation (sword mastery, fire magic, and even battle geology [that's only in the You Have to Name the Expansion Pack I think, but I think it's free]), to the ability to power-up your weapons and armor through some anvil and encrusting (enchanting basically), and there's a decent amount of weapon types. The game is also fully modable, which allows for even more changes (I recommend at least the Hero of Time mod, but whatever). Just remember, the Diggles are out to kill you. EDIT: I forgot to mention: HEROIC VANDALISM

author: {'steamid': '76561197986103157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1525772683}
review:
This is a game that tells you nothing and is all about weighing your odds in order to survive. Pulling a lever could mean the difference between life and death in this game; it could spawn an awesome item, or it could spawn nasty monsters- the same idea applies to opening doors, drinking potions, and drinking from fountains. The first time you play, you know next to nothing and may think that the game is unfair when you die, but, in time, you will learn that every situation in the game can be overcome with a little bit of creativity.

This is a game that forces you to learn everything about it through trial and error. A game that will throw monsters at you that you just can't fight. A game that will make you think really hard about pulling levers.

I've never experienced anything like it, and on top of all that it's really funny.

I couldn't recommend it more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006216609', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2086, 'last_played': 1652990901}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004663985', 'num_games_owned': 2730, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1390993102}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a roguelike. So you have random level generation, tile-based graphics, turn-based gameplay and permanent death. I'm not a fan of the turn based gameplay most of these games have. Although Dungeons of Dredmor can be played fastpaced, but you missclick a lot. Unless I missed a option you always need to play with a mouse beside the keyboard.

The atmosphere the game creates also doesn't really click with me. It tries to hard to be funny. Which end up in lame enemies with an art style I don't like. The dungeons look fine and with better characters the game would look a lot more appealing. The music also doesn't help. It's annoying and repetitive. Dungeons of Dredmor isn't bad game, but it doesn't click with me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980294402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1391368150}
review:
Horribly addictive "one more run" kind of game! There is a HUGE variety of skills and loot available and the dungeon crawling aspect is a huge deal of fun. This game doesn't take itself seriously in the least and has a great sense of humor (full of references to other games, horror movies, etc.)

You owe it to yourself to play this game if you like RPGs, dungeon crawlers, dark comedy, anything by Doublefine, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046701721', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1391663797}
review:
tl;dr  good game with minor flaws

Fantastic game! Picked up recently during the humble bundle and (like many games) I didn't think I'd get around to playing it. I love games with RPG elements but i'm not a huge fan of turn based games. I was pleasently surprised with Dungeons of Dredmor. It has a simple, but appealing, art style (reminiscent of a flash game). The gameplay is fun and easy to pick up, plenty of pop culture refrences and throwbacks to games. Before I wrote a review I wanted to put a couple more hours in and i'm glad I did. 

My few gripes with the game:
-The control customization is lacking some but easily remedied with a simple AHK script
-The fast travel system is a little annoying, would have prefered an in-game memory system
-The crafting/profession system (although helpful) just remained unused in most my playthroughs and it didn't make a difference

author: {'steamid': '76561198114331792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1679782406}
review: This game is awesome. For fans of old school roguelikes this is probably the best Steam game to fulfill your needs. Also, the modding community is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060632696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1556, 'last_played': 1708230776}
review: One of my favorite games of all time. It has a charming sense of humor, its addicting, endlessly replayable, very easy to pick up and play with a steep difficulty curve, and most of all its fun. This is a streamlined (for the better) return to PC RPG classics. You explore dungeons, killing monsters, getting better weapons, getting stronger, and looting. You can be a wizard, a warrior, a scientist, a blacksmith, a duel wielding brute, or any combination you can think of. I absolutely enjoyed the hell out of this game and I cant fathom how its only $5. The screenshots of the game are kinda unimpressive and I was iffy on the art style at first too. But this is the best $5 I have ever spent in my lifetime. Its an absolute steal, an underappreciated steal, not to mention classic and timeless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024923179', 'num_games_owned': 663, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1577362403}
review: The FIRST roguelike game (at least for me), in which you can easily switch off permadeath (I know, it should be the heart of the genre, but it's a big NO-NO in my dictionary), which is a great deal for me. For this alone it deserves thumbsup, but it has more value than that. It has tons of easter eggs and funny references, it's interesting, and has a great combat/move system. Definitely worth the buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033431815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1479, 'last_played': 1416774150}
review: Very well-written dungeon crawler. The dev obviously has a good sense of humor and put together a pretty interesting game. No fancy graphics or elaborate quests/puzzles, but entertaining nonetheless. If you like the type of game that makes fun of itself, then this is for you. Some of the skills/classes are a bit...overpowered...while others are practically useless, but they still offer a ton of replayability and I'm sure that there are lots of build combinations I haven't even come across yet. I'd pick it up on sale for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000423747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1324454400}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995928059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1427858638}
review:
Robust yet simple, deep yet entirely lighthearted, Dungeons of Dredmor is a shining example of a roguelike done in exactly the right way-- Hilariously.

This is how it's meant to be. You build a unique character from skill pools ranging from simple swordsmanship and spellcraft to things like math, legal, and veganism-based combat, and proceed through a randomized, turn-based dungeon in the traditional roguelike style- which is to say, slowly, with an emphasis on choosing what you'll do next and contending with the consequences. Commands are never overwhelmingly complicated, with the game dishing out new active skills conservatively, and yet there never seems to be a shortage of ways to handle any given situation. As frequently as death comes (it's the nearest thing to an inevitability), there's always the sense that maybe, just maybe it would have been better to hurl something at that last monster and run away than to have tried to sneak up on it. 

While there's inevitably some frustration in trekking through a dungeon for a full hour before being reduced to a bloody, lifeless high score, Dredmor eases the pain with variable difficulties and and the option of turning off the permadeath, so impatient adventurers might throw themselves into something brutish and horrible just to get the full experience before rounding out their experience with a swift death, while more anxious players might tone down the experience to something more casual and preserve their precious adventurer until the game's proper end. The sheer extent to which your uniquely-tailored character can actually be developed keeps the latter approach from getting stale too quickly, while the extent to which your handpicked skill trees actually matter from the beginning keeps the quick and dirty approach fresh from restart to restart.

In the end, if there's a single thing working against Dredmor's lovingly-crafted delves, it's the entire genre's problem: Every move is its own intimate life-or-death decision, with all the time in the world to choose between as many actions as your character is capable of, and as such it can only have ever been a single-player experience. As tempting as it is to tell your friends about that incredible time you narrowly escaped a desperate one-sided fight by electing to abandon your sword and instead physically throw the monster into a brutal trap, it's an experience you'll have invariably shared with yourself alone. It simply can't be helped- Dungeons of Dredmor is a very single-player game, and yet it still does its best to keep you company. Each learned skill rarely comes without a joke to accompany it, monsters sling petty insults your way, and even in your most dramatic victories, the game's narration will do everything in its power to take the piss out of you- but what more can you expect when you're a law-school educated burglar, communist viking, or Regent of Throwing Stuff At People? Dredmor's a lonely experience, but makes every effort not to feel like one.

Overall, if you've ever been a fan of roguelikes, Dungeons of Dredmor is a refreshingly unique presentation of everything you're already certain you like, and if you've never touched one before, Dredmor is still a perfectly complete example of everything the genre ought to be, with success dependent on what you do, rather than how fast you can do it. As hard as you make it, as deep as you feel like going, and dripping with wit and charm (and other fluids), this game isn't content to simply kill you repeatedly. It wants to be your friend while it does so.

My advice? Let it. Unless you've specifically got a problem with turn-based or single-player gaming, Dungeons of Dredmor is a humble yet delightful dungeon-crawl worth far more than its modest price tag in delicious suspense, strategy, humor, and gratuitous fantasy violence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008770828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 994, 'last_played': 1708491142}

author: {'steamid': '76561198067244916', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1419469508}
review:
If you have a thing for classic dungeon crawlers, and consider yourself a fan of the Rogue-likes genre, then DoD is worth the money hands down. It makes up for what it lacks in graphics with an abundance of classes, skills, items, and genuinely clever content written about all the above. The ability to play with perma-death keeps me going, and for those that would rather a more casual game, you can simply turn it off.  Throw in randomly generated dungeons, and now you have a great game worth holding onto.

The first few plays through you may well end up dying horribly from the unsuspecting trap or challenging enemy, but once you get a feel for which classes work well together it really just comes down to patience, skill and a just the right amount of luck as any good rogue-like does. If you're having trouble progressing far in the dungeon, its probably due to a bad build or unwillingness to try something new. 

Overall its a great RPG with a unique class system, interesting crafting, tons of DLC and player made content, and a good sense of humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001858688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1390607126}
review: There's something endearing and addictive about this mix of RPG Roguelike with Comedy. The branching skilltrees, beautifully constructed art-direction and sense of humour keeps this budget-game both on my computer monitor and on my list of recommended games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081016925', 'num_games_owned': 1576, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1375679950}
review:
This is one roguelike with a clear personality from unconventional skill trees (emomancy, anyone?), to Diggles (the game's mascot monster), you'd likely find yourself amused. And with multiple difficulty levels (including a permadeath option for roguelike purists), anyone could try their hand at it.

The gameplay is pretty nice with sometimes comical crafting combinations that are useful even if you didn't specialize in the line, various little quirks in the dungeon, and statues to heroically vandalized for exp.

In short there may be many rogue likes, but none quite like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998643921', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1390543542}

review: This is a very addictive rouguelike game. It's a lot of fun, but maybe not as accessible to a nongamer as a more ubiquitous roguelike/lite like the Binding of Isaac. I think it could be very easy to spend hundreds of hours in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011471620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 2734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1685, 'last_played': 1593644570}
review:
actually a decent mini roguelike, some issues but mods fix most things. 

pros:
-easy to pick up
-can play multiple times
-lots of "class" tropes you can play as, or mix up skills to play a custom "class"
-mod support = really useful

cons:
-feels like warrior tropes (heavy armor + weapons) is the best way to play the game, other classes get pooped on, especially casters
-really limited item pool, heavily favors warrior type characters
-no super-epic phat loot like you might expect from a dungeon crawling roguelike
-can be kinda grindy at times

still a good roguelike to play when you're bored or while you're watching twitch or something idk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064156757', 'num_games_owned': 3338, 'num_reviews': 380, 'playtime_forever': 14174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8434, 'last_played': 1662602866}
review:
Long ago, the Dark Lord Dredmor was bound in the darkest dungeons beneath the earth by great and mighty heroes. Centuries later, the magical bonds that hold him in place are loosening and his power grows ever stronger. The land cries out for a new hero, a powerful warrior or a mystic wizard like those spoken of in the prophecies of yore. 

What they have, unfortunately, is you... 

Step into the Dungeons of Dredmor! Embrace your destiny! Face evil of the likes the world has never known - the terrifying Swarmies, the undulating Thrusties, and the adoreable nest-building Diggles. Worship Inconsequentia, the Goddess of Pointless Sidequests, or try your luck as a devotee of the nameless Lutefisk God. Cast powerful magic learned from the dark business warlocks of the school of Necronomiconomics, or summon the Viking Runes of your ancestors to blast your foes with thunder and lightning! Discover the power that can be had by wielding a bizarre armament of devastating weaponry such as the Interdimensional Axe, the Plastic Ring, and the Invisible Shield (if you can remember where you left it). Wield shoes decorated by the Dwarven Glittersmiths, all of whom have now committed suicide because of their shame, and embrace the joys of destroying giant moustache-wielding brick demons with a mace decorated with tawdry, delicious bacon. 

While you’re at it, be prepared to die. A lot. In hideous, screaming pain that makes you throw your keyboard out the window. 

The Dungeons of Dredmor await. Are you ready for them?

author: {'steamid': '76561197978214792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2591, 'last_played': 1403588306}
review: Buy this shit...

author: {'steamid': '76561198084417215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1674093349}
review:
Cuanto más juego más me gusta... Tiene algo que lo hace muy especial. Absolutamente rejugable, un sentido del humor inteligente y brillante... Dentro de los juegos casuales que abundan este es una magnífica opción, sin olvidar las posibilidades infinitas que aporta el Workshop. Lo recomiendo 100% a todo aquel que quiera enfrentarse a un reto, es realmente complejo y exigente. Plagado de sorpresas y secretos que vas descubriendo con cada run y cada mazmorra.
Más como este por favor!!!

...y varios meses después... sigo pensando lo mismo...

...y en 2017... vuelvo a opinar igual...

author: {'steamid': '76561198025416700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1389720210}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor is not a bad game; instead, it's an amusing, well-intentioned game that lacks the polish and ease of play which we have come to expect from games.  The play style harkens back to the earliest dungeon crawlers, featuring randomly generated dungeons, punishing combat, and a wealth of customization.  It's charm lies in the witty, inane humor sprinked in everything; my personal favorite joke were the shrines littering the dungeon, where you could pray to the goddess of side-quests, and receive a random task.  I swear, it's much funnier than my lame description implies.  Nonetheless, it's difficult to reccomend for you to buy the game, as the gameplay is extremely clunky, especially item and spell management.  For items, you must click and drag every single thing in the game.  That means that when you come across a trove of 9 pieces of Lutefisk, you either have to click and drag 8 times, or get lazy and leave them sitting there.  It's simply frustrating.  Additionally, stats and related systems are poorly, if at all, explained.  It becomes a burdon to try to compare one piece of armor against another.  All-in-all, Dungeons of Dredmor is an entertaining series of jokes, that lacks the polishing necessary for today's game market.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004670505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6140, 'last_played': 1448178900}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030433510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 12122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8980, 'last_played': 1667241142}
review:
If you're a fan of dungeon-crawling RPGs or tabletop games like D&D, then it's hard to imagine you wouldn't like Dungeons of Dredmor.

It's witty, nerdy, challenging, and deep.

It can be a little glitchy sometimes (but not in a game-breaking way) and the visuals and sounds harken back to older games, but I've never encountered anything that's turned me off from this game.

I think of it like a turn-based Diablo 2 if Blizzard's writing had a great sense of humor instead of a soul-crushing sense of tragic despair.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997137272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 4230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1649577496}
review:
Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup lite edition.

Its pretty good, and the permadeath harder modes make it a lot more challenging to beat the entire game. A lot of the stuff in the game is plain retarded though, as if they put no thought into the quality of the artwork or the art style at all. 

The limited monster variety is pretty shit too, you end up fighting recolored generic grunts a lot.
Even the harder modes are pretty easy, most character builds will plough through generic enemies and the only times I have died is when i have encountered a monster zoo (its a room packed with hundreds of similar grunts) as i was surrounded and unable to move my dudesman.


The devs were good enough to include a development kit so there are a large amount of mods to fix the multitude of problems with the game and to add additional modes which is really good.
The mods really add many more hours to the game, but the game as is, is averaging a 7/10

review: A damn good roguelike that is a parody of other roguelikes and contemporary pop and fantasy culture as well.  Chock full of numerous film, fantasy and video game references, it also has incredibly deep gameplay; with many playstyles to choose from and a incredibly complex crafting mechanic.  The modding community is also busy with this game; and there are lots of great and hilarious mods that are fun to play.  A great game at a great value with lots of replayability.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080432789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1699837699}
review: I've never been much one to favor indie-style games, but this one is one of my favorites. Each playthrough is endlessly  customizable and completely different from the last. For a game with a small-ish fanbase, it has an excellent modding community, with enough extra content to keep the game fresh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028800053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1629, 'last_played': 1450150841}
review: Although it's a-lot simpler than Angband, NETHACK, ADOM, and other reknown, much older rogue-likes. Dungeons of Dredmor is a very humorous, fun, and simple rogue-like on it's own. It has a very interesting class system, and should be played on GRPD (Hardest Difficulty, and Perma-death) if you want the full rogue-like experience. The only problems with the game are the crashes, and the corrupted saves. I had no problem with these problems after I nuked Steam-cloud though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017223587', 'num_games_owned': 1849, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 18665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14669, 'last_played': 1589685799}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a rather by the book implementation of the concepts presented by the nethacks, rogues, and past games of the genre known affectionately as, "rogue-like," you take the genre and pump it full of Internet Memes, Canada and Scandanavia jokes, and then add Diggles...  Like a packing plant pumping their meat full of water and a hint of salt.

The game plays well, and is rather thoroughly randomized, the difficulty stems more from your skill choices than from the game's settings, death can be permanent if you wish, and after playing a game or two you may like that extra bit of pressure on you.

The hand drawn animated deaths are nice and the game has a sense of humour about the entire affair, you'd be surprised the variety of ways one can die.

The DLC for the game do flesh it out a bit, and when on sale it's well worth picking up.  And though the mods that are available are rather hit and miss, they can add a good deal to a game if you're willing to slog through them to find the gems.

This is a solid rogue-like game - one you should give a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960457558', 'num_games_owned': 1781, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 5908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5812, 'last_played': 1559023234}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a flexible rogue-like with a sense of humor.

If you want a difficult, classic rogue-like run of a dungeon, complete with perma-death and RNG elements, Dredmor has it. If you want a casual, chip-away-at-a-dungeon-as-you-will experience, Dredmor has that as well.

Gameplay is walk and click. RPG elements keep each playthrough challenging in different ways, and a huge number of skills make the game replayable for a long time. The modding community, although small, is fervent and helpful to newcomers.

An excellent example of the modern rogue-like.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977909889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1396754962}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051514195', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 12793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7865, 'last_played': 1708329703}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045033623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1447045577}
review: Addicting dungeon crawling game. I had to run the tutorial to learn how to use items.  I really wish they would make this game controller supported and make simpler controls.  I love how there is an option to play until you die and not respawn.  The extra challenge makes the game more rewarding, however it does get annoying going through the easy floors over and over again.  I also really like how one can customize the character's skills/abilities before starting the game and how the dungeons are always organized differently each game. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024954311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1525840112}
review:
A fun, dungeon crawler that requires you to play the tutorial before playing throwing your hat into the ring. Very clicky, very fun, the crafting system tends consist of "What, I need experience to craft all this? What do you mean I can't make these? Where do I get this anvil thing? I don't have enough inventory space for all this!" but it feels optional so far.

I especially like how much the game feels like a Lucas Arts adventure game. Give it a try if you like dungeoning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028798458', 'num_games_owned': 1017, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1388510952}
review:
Yesterday i've played a couple of indie games and today i've decided to continue my way through indie-games-jungle lol. 
This time my choice fall on Dungeons of Dredmor. I can say that this game is quite interesting in explore way. It looks like the Binding of Isaac exactly same. author: {'steamid': '76561198037649336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5124, 'last_played': 1703425383}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor - 7/10

Dungeons of Dredmor is a dungeon crawler for Dungeons and Dragons enthusiasts and overall geeks and nerds, using those terms endearingly. Exploring multiple floors (10 to get to Lord Dredmor, 15 if you're using the Realm of the Diggle Gods expansion), your character must grow in strength and loot to take on the challenge of battling Lord Dredmor himself, an evil lich that you have to kill because the game tells you to. That's pretty much all there is to the plot. The formula for a dungeon crawler has been boiled down to it's basic components:  large dungeon full of traps and monsters, the occasional store to sell your stuff (you can even attack the storekeeper and attempt a five-finger discount, though I wouldn't advise this as crime usually ends in death in the Dungeons), and a variety of equipment and items scattered on the floor as if a kleptomaniac had a hole in his bag. 

The core of the game lays in the character creation and the random dungeon layout. Notice how I said earlier "your character"? There isn't a named hero or heroine to Dungeons of Dredmor. It's an avatar with massive eyebrows and whatever skill set you want that avatar to have. The game starts immediately by picking out 7 skills from a bank of 35 (+6 if you get the Realm of the Diggle Gods DLC, +4 if you get the You Have to Name The Expansion Pack DLC, and +6 if you get the Conquest of the Wizardlands DLC) either by choice or by random. Then you pick a name and either the massively-eyebrowed male avatar or the massively-eyebrowed female avatar. The process is kept simple, allowing players to spend as little time as possible on rerolling characters once they die. There's even a "Last Choice" option, allowing players to repick the same skills the previous life had. My complaints with this are that (as far as I'm aware), you can't see what the skill trees will look like before or as you choose the skills, which means you can't pre-plan skill progression beyond guesswork from what the name of the skill implies. Also, some skills are rather pointless or even completely weak in my opinion. The loading time between games can also be considered choppy as you have to get past an arbitrary scoreboard before you can get to the new game screen. 

The random dungeon layout also adds some uniqueness to Dungeons of Dredmor. No two dungeons are going to be the same. Now, when I started writing that sentence, I was about to type "no two adventures", but then I realized every game of Dungeons goes the same way, which can make the game stale quickly to those not interested in the mandatory grinding it takes to get strong enough to get to Dredmor. The random dungeon layout and room layout can also make some rooms inaccessible because of object placement, such as an impassible candelabra or iron bars. Store placement can make or break a run, as the inventory is cripplingly small. Doing so makes have to prioritize items you want in your inventory for the upcoming battles even though you're only on the first or second floor. Shop items are randomized too, which means you can find expensive, yet powerful, weapons on the first floor or junk for crafting. 

The crafting system is meh. In order to craft items, you must a) have the appropriate skill level, b) the appropriate items to craft with, and c) a crafting tool. There are also secret crafting recipes that can be found in bookshelves or dropped from monsters if you have the right skill. However, in order to have a high crafting level, you must have a crafting skill in one of your 7 selected skills. This makes crafting nearly moot, as the more powerful (and more  useful) items require high levels of crafting in order to make. At least the item-upgrade system is easy. Just find an enchanting anvil, pick your item, and bam! It's enchanted! Of course there is a risk of making the item worse, which is always a gamble in any RPG when it comes to item enchanting. The game is secretly turn-based. I say secretly because you don't really notice it until you have a screen full of monsters who are acting at the same time as you. What you may think of as lag is actually the monsters taking their turns in response to your actions, making moving one square at a time feel like a chore, especially if you're attempting to run away.

The game can be, and most of the time is, really frustrating. A lot of grinding is necessary to get past the monsters that lurk in the Dungeons, and traps can be difficult to spot quickly if you're using the WASD controls to move. A really good run can end in moments by stepping on a mine you didn't notice in time or by not paying attention to your health when battling your way through a room. As of writing this review, I still haven't faced Lord Dredmor, even on easy. But even with all this difficulty, I wouldn't quite call it Nintendo-hard. A lot of the deaths I've had have been my own fault, either not paying attention to my health or where I'm going, or just getting so burned out on the run I'm on that I get reckless. 

The humor of the game is based entirely on nerdy references. Almost everything has flavor text, and most items and skills make references to nerd culture such as Doctor Who or Supernatural to name a couple. It's cute at first, but grows stale after a while because there really isn't much more in the ways of humor for this game. It's funny the first time you see a little Diggle shouting FUS RO DAH at you as it charges into your sword, but the screen can get littered with corpses, items, monsters, and flavor text quickly. The same can also be said of the soundtrack, which I stopped listening to after about a week of gameplay. The smooth jazz doesn't quite scream adventure or exploration to me, and feels out of place.

Despite of all the complaints I have, I'm still playing. I'm still grinding out achievements and levels, still climbing that mountain of corpses to get to Lord Dredmor. Every time I go in, I say to myself, "Yes, THIS is the run!" only to die ten or twenty minutes later to an Unfriendly AI. It's a game that definitely bites back, and for that I find it somewhat enjoyable. My score for Dungeons of Dredmor is 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008258575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2441, 'last_played': 1641857019}
review:
This is a fun rogue-like with a lot of silly humor mixed in.  There are many skill trees to choose from and you can mix and match them however you'd like.  (You pick any 7 at the beginning of the game.)  Add to that the content in the Steam Workshop and you have a nearly infinite variety of options to keep you occupied for hours.  

Despite the cartoony presentation the gameplay requires a decent amount of thinking.  If you're looking for a great strategy rogue-like RPG with light-hearted elements buy it.  If you're looking for a casual game you can play on auto-pilot this probably isn't it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023855970', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 915, 'last_played': 1427683669}
review:
This game is a great spoof of most RPG dungeon crawlers, but is a great RPG dungeon crawler at the same time. This game takes nothing seriously, but has great mechanics, and will make you laugh as you explore the levels, abilities, and items.

Fun, humorous and very replayable, one of my favorite games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978558001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1735, 'last_played': 1506138878}
review: A fairly solid and less hardcore roguelike than most. I would recommend this game to people looking to get into the genre but are looking for a more gradual learning curve (also the ability to disable perma-death). The game has a good bit of depth to it for those looking to dig, but a fairly casual player should be able to triumph on the lower difficulties if their character is properly focused. Those looking for a more intense experience are also rewarded here, the game's higher difficulty levels can be punishing and will quickly crush those who aren't playing to peak efficiency.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003732038', 'num_games_owned': 1051, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1449565317}
review:
Довольно-таки трудно выносить вердикт Dungeons of Dredmor. Поскольку он является практически единственным полпредом целого жанра, оценка неизбежно заденет всю родословную игры. По-крайней мере, утверждать можно об одном: это чертовски старомодная услада, вкус которой для многих игроков, воспитанных феерической лёгкостью и скрытой за поносом из спецэффектов примитивностью баснословно дорогих боевиков, покажется прогорклым и гадким. Ведь нынешний массовый потребитель не очень-то уважает запредельную сложность и острую необходимость думать, шевелить извилинами, а не развешивать хедшоты-аиршоты. Им же хуже: они упустят одну из самых интересных игр современности.

 [u]Оценка - 7/10 [/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198018929360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1392810890}
review: Modern rogue-like. This means better controls and ui, great inventory system, steady combat, and difficulty options. You can choose an easier mode and also choose a mode that lets you keep a save file to reload after death. Or you just play it the old fashion way, with permadeath and on highest difficulty. The options make it quite nice. There are plenty of skills to play around with. Tons of items. Each floor of the dungeon is unique. The graphics and writing are very playful. The little descritptions of everything are written with great care. Great game, kudos to Gaslamp(the developers) you guys knew what you were doing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993712446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 5379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5107, 'last_played': 1597673918}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor. I've found it something that I've gone back to time and time again. Each time I'll get further, although it's usually about the 5th level dungeon it mostly kicks my behind.

The multitude of ways in which you can create various builds in the attempt to succeed and triumph within it, has always been a concept I admire. Although I admit I rather enjoy bows and crossbows within.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006575550', 'num_games_owned': 1631, 'num_reviews': 624, 'playtime_forever': 9952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7170, 'last_played': 1476675950}
review:
This game is awesome, it's a great way to get into a rogue like game that has good graphics and so much depth. I always had a slightly passing interest in rogue but this is on a whole other level. I've probably spent just as much tims playing the game as thinking about which build I should go that would get me far into the dungeon. Get bored of the game and there is a ton of community created content. 

It's not an action game, you have to think about your moves but it is still really intense. Get this game but becareful because you could really lose yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994897453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4407, 'last_played': 1579027761}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a roguelike in the traditional sense of the word: a turn-based dungeon crawler with permadeath that is challenging and makes you stop and think tactically and strategically if you want to win. While it certainly doesn't stand up to the big name traditional roguelikes like Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup or Tales of Maj'eyal, it's an excellent choice for someone new to the roguelike genre, and can be a good step up for those who want to give true roguelikes a chance.

One of the biggest drawbacks of the game is the animation speed, so it's worth noting that it can be sped up with the + key. The other big problem is inventory management; even with the free DLC, if you take a crafting skill you'll be playing inventory shuffle a lot. That said, the absurd number of skills you can choose from do give you some interesting choices and keep the game interesting for quite a while. For those who are used to the older roguelikes such as DCSS or Nethack this game will come off as a bit easy, but for anyone new to the genre it will give a solid challenge, and is worth at least a few playthroughs trying different builds.

If you're a roguelike fan looking to try something a bit different, or if you're interested in the (real) roguelike genre and you're looking for a good introductory game, I would recommend this highly. On the other hand, if you're already a skilled player of deeper roguelike games such as DCSS or ToME, this game may feel like too much of a step back for you. In any case, it is a well-crafted game, and for its target audience would be a solid buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004517600', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1935, 'last_played': 1682374842}
review:
This game manages to be the perfect gateway into real roguelike games and also as hardcore as any other out there. Its tutorial makes beginners feel very welcome and prepares them for their journey(s) ahead. The charactercreation is more simplified than you would probably expect from a roguelike like DCSS, but the system of picking 7 different skills, thus having hundreds of different combinations makes your choices more than meaningful.

What sets it apart from other genre competitors is its presentation handsdown. Where other roguelikes kind of lack in that department and are just pure gameplay, Dungeons of Dredmor has a lot of charm in its visuals and writing. This is one of those rare games thats overgrown with little jokes and references but still stays funny and unique.

If you have never played a real roguelike and want to get into them, this is probably the best game for you. If you're a seasoned veteran, it is also a good pickup because of its unique skillsystem and refreshing presentation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025050147', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 895, 'last_played': 1574144030}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a very fresh take on the roguelike game.  The additions of mouse controls and real graphics vastly increase the accessibility of the game, while at the same time not compromising on the difficulty one expects from a roguelike.

One thing I think could still be improved is the targeting of flying enemies.  Flying enemies can't be clicked like regular enemies when you attack them.  You have to actually click the square the flying enemy is in, rather than their graphics.  If you're playing a melee character this probably won't be too bad, but if you're focusing on ranged combat or magic, you may find yourself having misclicks a fair amount of the time.

The game used to have a glaring inventory space problem, but that's not so much of an issue anymore.  An update a while back added the "Pocket Dimension".  Once you find the keys to it, which should be in the first level somewhere, you have access to it and can store an unlimited amount of stuff there.  So go ahead and be a packrat, because you can just hop into the pocket dimension to grab what you wanted to sell off when you get to a merchant.  Although, there are better uses for certain items than offloading them to a merchant...

Overall the good far outweighs the bad in Dungeons of Dredmor, and it's worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026074229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1532381686}
review: I love games where the players get to pick their own poison on how they plan to take the game on and that's an area this game really shines on. There's a lot of different combinations you can slap together to make a class. Want to be a mace dual wielding vampire who summons golems? Sure. Or a crafty rogue who can steal items from vending machines and uses egyptian magic? Why not. There's a lot in here that's fun. The gameplay isn't difficult but the game is, if that makes sense. There's an in-depth tutorial that explains everything you need to know to play the game, that's optional, then you're off and playing. Taking on monsters and disabling or avoiding traps gets pretty hectic at times and as of yet, I've not felt cheated in the game. Intestingly enough, as of this writing, my first game has been my highest scoring and best game! Wassupwitdat?!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981353644', 'num_games_owned': 1406, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 2045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1691, 'last_played': 1622513974}
review:
One of the best games for it's money on steam.  Even the DLC's are packed with content for only $3!

If you are a huge fan of roguelikes or prefer more casual roguelikes(thank god for options), you can play it either way.  Full mod support and plenty of monsters, skills, floors, and content to keep you playing for hours on end.  The game is packed with giant eyebrows as well...something a lot of games lack these days. 


Seriously, buy this game.  Between a five dollar footlong and Dungeons of Dredmor, this honestly wins.  It's humorous, creative, rather fun to play, has rather nice graphics and music.  

There are some problems, as I have found multiple bugs.  These bugs could be getting stuck in an object due to a teleport fucking me over, or a portal teleporting me into a wall.

These bugs rarely happen, but it's still a pain in the arse.  I hate cheating as much as the next guy, but the easiest way to fix this involved using the developer console.  That's no fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053041128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2383, 'last_played': 1693773122}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990381411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1382857155}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a pretty good rogue-like. It's a pretty solid game with a lot of depth, a lot of replay value, and a lot of appeal. And it has a great sense of humor.It nails everything down and doesn't make it complicated. The only thing I can find with Dungeons of Dredmor is that it doesn't do anything different. That's not necessarily a bad thing. Why change what isn't broken? 

Overall, Dungeons of Dredmor is still a good game. You'll have a lot of fun min-maxing your character and trying to find the best loot. But sometimes, during the grind, you might ask, "Is there more to this?"

If you're looking for a good rogue-like and you have a lot of time to burn, get Dungeons of Dredmor. 
If you're looking to find something new in the world of Rogue-likes, this isn't it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041799286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2286, 'last_played': 1553892890}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971926028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 13695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8636, 'last_played': 1562430649}

author: {'steamid': '76561198078139239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 13342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2453, 'last_played': 1661619621}
review:
To start off, I really enjoy this game. For just a measly five dollars (or whatever regional equivalent), this game offers HOURS of content and nigh-endless replayability. 

Pros: 
Despite the price tag, the dungeon crawling aspects of this game are fairly in depth. There are many different kinds of items, different ways to play, and each playthrough is a bit different every time. The loot is MASSIVE. I kept finding new types of items well past the twenty hour mark. The game doesn't take itself seriously, and it's a light-hearted romp throughout. With Steam worksop integration, mods are plentiful and practical to install. The number of different skills and equipment types make it difficult to play the same character twice. 

Cons: 
While this game is quite nice, I found a few nagging problems. For one, I found the experience repetitive after a while. This is natural for every game, but only when I notice it does it become problematic. The combat is mostly fine, but it quickly becomes a clickfest which may bore some. The music ranges from decent to just plain grating; the same couple tracks play over and over and OVER. I was tempted several times to just mute the music. Without playing with perma-death and/or a higher difficulty, I found this game boring over time. 

However, any gripes I can find are fairly minor and don't detract from the game overly. 

At such a low price with so much content, it almost feels criminal to buy this game. There's so much in such a tiny package that I can't recommend it more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992856964', 'num_games_owned': 1025, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 12806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5439, 'last_played': 1617595620}
review:
Roguelikes are good for mindlessly clicking, exploring, and looting; and proudly inherit all of the ups and downs of tabletop dungeon-crawling.  Simplified a bit, of course.  Dungeons of Dredmor sure does exactly that.  Good mechanics, about a paragraph worth of story, and a sense of humor best exemplified by the expansion pack "You have to name the expansion pack." (which, if you click on the title screen for it, you can rename).

You can toss about as many hours into it as you have to waste, and it'll soak them up admirably.  More replay value than Solitaire or Minesweeper; and a must-have on my computers for that reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060041542', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1664280261}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025201418', 'num_games_owned': 978, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 3451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3451, 'last_played': 1386759203}
review:
Where's the "I'm not sure" for recommending this game?

The game leaves a fantastic first impression - it's easily one of the most intuitive, easy to learn Roguelikes, without sacrificing customization and a level of the strategy.  It's colourful, full of personality, and clearly made with love.  Amazing for introducing someone to the genre.

It also, however, begins to drag after a while; a complete game with Realm of the Diggle Gods and full-sized floors takes an absurd amount of time for what quickly starts devolving into incredibly repetitive content.  Monsters have little variety, stellar equipment slowly starts fading into a pile of ultimately unremarkable items, there's extremely little secrets or rare content to discover... it lacks the meat, depth, and sense of discovery to actually sustain itself over long periods of time.

So to be most specific on whether I'd recommend this game or not: If you don't know what the word "Roguelike" means yet, this is a great way to start the genre and enjoy yourself.  But if you're already into Roguelikes, as charming as Dungeons of Dredmor is, you'll find that once you get a game that survives the first ~4 floors, the game is ultimately just reptetitive and boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021922182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1384659376}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is hilarious. It's a fresh take on the reemerging "rogue-like" genre. 
The game is a balanced mixture of old and new. Although turn-based, the gameplay moves quickly and is challenging. What's more, the humor is spot-on.
The only possible downside is a small, but steep learning curve. You're left to learn from your failures, of which there will be many. This may or may not be a negative, depending on personal preference.
Overall, a great game well worth its price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966713462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2523, 'last_played': 1628236426}
review:
42 hours in and no signs of stopping. Great humor, tons of classes, skills, items, and enemies combined with wicked hard difficulty makes Dungeons of Dredmor a must-play for fans of the Roguelike genre. The GUI makes the game approchable and the art style and lighthearted attitude will soften even the most unfortunate deaths.

Dungeons of Dredmor gets five stars in my book.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993624207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 22489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16808, 'last_played': 1635667535}
review:
This game is amazing. 280 hours on record, and counting. There are lots of skills and so much variation it's unreal. And then there's user-created content. A lot of which is balanced and well thought out, showing how much people enjoy the game.

This is one of the best $5 games ever made. The variety is great, the humour is great, and the DLCs are nice add-ons to an already great game.

If you're after the latest 3D graphics, this game isn't for you. But if you can put that aside and appreciate the graphics for what they are, you are in for a treat.

A large part of the game's greatness is due to the character customization. You choose seven skills , which may be related to fighting, magic, roguey stuff, or general skills that are slotted into one of those three categories. Each of those options is actually a skill tree, with multiple skills that you unlock as you level up. You can also do a ton of crafting, or none, as you wish.

This game is all about giving us players the choice to try to win the game however we like, which is why I will keep going back to it again and again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055617036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 11060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3902, 'last_played': 1643206783}
review: Классный рогалик адаптированный под современную аудиторию. Если надоело постоянно умирать, то выключи опцию "рогалик" и играй с сохранениями!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963760307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1347, 'last_played': 1585111953}
review: Great game if you love Dungeon crawlers. This game has good but simple combat and you can choose how you want to play your character. Great game and definitely worth getting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999317368', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1406313036}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor combines the fun of a classic dungeon crawler, with zanny and hilarious monsters and abilities. Be an egyption vampire sword smashing alchemist, or maybe being an emo reporter who enjoys traveling to show of your fire magic. Be whatever you want to be, and experience a new way to play every time. For more fun, try to utilze the random abilities feature, ensuring that every time you play with be completely new. Want to compete with a friend? Choose the same abilities and see who can survive the longest in the dungeon. A never ending source of fun and merriment for all who play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027282102', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1388241250}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045238921', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1386755027}
review: I'm pretty obsessed with this game. It's so much fun and being randomly generated guarantees a totally different experience each game. Definitely check out the DLC and mods in the workshop, they make it even better. Because who doesn't want Bowiemancy? Even if you get killed by a Diggle on the first floor, at least you'll get an achievement! DoD is a great game for when you have twenty minutes to spare, or ten hours. I've done super casual playthroughs and serious hours crafting and scheming. It's really cheap and totally worth it, so why not pick it up (and actually play for a bit)!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048790189', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1190, 'last_played': 1582625506}
review:
Pretty neat tile-based RPG with so many unnessary things. It have really deep complex about in-game inventory and etc.

If you like to see what happen if you drink this drink or put something or use one of 200 skill in this game (which in the description somewhat not helpful for me)

And you like to read things, this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046354763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1206, 'last_played': 1682731494}
review:
If you're looking for a classic-feeling dungeon crawler with  a nice twist, this game's the one that you NEED! Not only is it hard, but it's just something else when you run into the monster zoos, evil boxis or even the Uberchests that force you to scour the whole floor just to open them. It makes it possible to be different than the standard sword-and-shield, but you can wield staves, spears, daggers, orbs, books, a stick of meat and much more.

Nice to see a game go with the classic dungeon crawler mechanic while still making it random, and rewardign to go through the whole area.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971245404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 2881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2827, 'last_played': 1535278993}
review:
Конечно графика примитивная, но очень глубокая механика и отменное чувство юмора. А ещё игра рандомная и очень трудная. Для тех, кто любит РПГ не за красивый сюжет и графон, а за хитрую механику и сложность.

И да, знание английского необходимо. Обычные параметры, типа "сила, мудрость и воля" тут заменены синонимами типа "бычность, заумность и упёртость", так что привычных str, dxt и т.п. тут не найти.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096294934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 1320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1003, 'last_played': 1388466184}
