author: {'steamid': '76561198035248547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1173, 'playtime_at_review': 5254, 'last_played': 1710283970}
review:
A wonderful Rougelike and a great introduction to the genre for those who haven’t played a rougelike before. Be sure to play with permadeath on, since that’s actually one of the selling points of rougelikes and makes everything much tenser when dying actually deletes your character.

Overall, this is a really hard and really funny game. However, it’s hard in an enjoyable way and whenever you die, you feel as if it’s because of something you did, not the game being cheap (although remember, the game IS trying to kill you). With the large amount of skills to choose from to make your character, the size of the randomized floors and the dungeon as a whole, there is plenty to do in this game. A single character can feel like an epic journey as they get deeper into the dungeon, and the game is really designed so you can try out many different builds, and play many many times (while eventually dying horribly for most of them).

author: {'steamid': '76561198008151793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1340089200}
review:
Fuckin' HATE you Dredmor.

Because of you, I now see Digglers in every shadow; magically ingestible meat products in every rectangular storage object; crafting ingredients in every dumpster I happen to be pass by on the way to the liqour shop, which is also a newly-adopted habit that you are solely responsible for. YOU DID THIS TO ME.

You told me that you weren't other roguelikes - a claim made with no small amount of brag that, in spite of myself, I cannot dispute. You promised me endless hours of entertainment, quirky humor, addictive crafting and that, you did deliver on... but the beatings...

And now, not a day goes by where a shadow, a box or any random dumpster doesn't draw my eye in immediate, fearful response. For once you become friends with Dredmor, there's no promise that you won't come out of the experience broken, bewildered and wondering helplessly why you're bent over a bus stop bench dressed like Gordon Gekko with the distinct stench of semen on your person.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043627942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 1909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1089, 'last_played': 1561228471}
review:
Excellent game, yea so it looks like it was a bout 20 years ago, and maybe the basis was, but that worked, and this game is fun and addictive!  It gives you a good challenge as well, generally if your not careful, your gonna die.  

Half of the reason why this game is so great, not only because it is incredibly good at what it is meant to do, but because of the style to it, the stupid Big eye brow thing, the taunts the enemies throw at you before you (or they) get beaten into the ground and the weird random names brought up for rooms and weapon/equipment! Classic!
 It's skill system is also vast enough( even then mods (numerous) expand on that further) to keep you busy.

Yes this game is Diablo I , but it is so much more!  To suggest it is very little more than that is admittance of your own mindless, blind state.   - especially for £1.50 ! It is WELL worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198054521718', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4131, 'last_played': 1450873923}
review:
Roguelikes in the 21st century should be like this. Graphical, yet simplistic. Deep, yet won't take ages to learn. Mind you, Dungeons of Dredmor is by no means easy.

You are a Hero, chosen to vanquish the evil lord Dredmor. In order to reach him, you must use your wits and skills (chosen in sets of seven during character creation, out of several dozens of skill sets) and reach the tenth level of the dungeon before meeting with the dread lord. (for your reference, I have not ventured deeper than level six, and this was with a character with some 10+ hours of playtime.)

And then there are the achievements for you to accomplish. Some are ridiciously easy (like killing some Diggles, oh you will meet them, lots of them in your journeys) and some are rather difficult (especially some skill trees are quite difficult to master, not to mention completing the game with the hardest difficulty setting and permadeath... *shiver*)

A very good game that ought to keep you occupied for quite a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970819940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2195, 'last_played': 1344582000}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019826070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 6206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2226, 'last_played': 1430082114}
review: Everyone knows I'm a sucker for a good Roguelike game. This one has the timeless gameplay of the genre coupled with amusing graphics and a great sense of humour. If I say I could play this game for hours, I mean that I HAVE played it for hours on end, only to look at my clock and realize it's been like 6 hours since I said "I'll just play a little more". Hopelessly addictive and ludicrously fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024193156', 'num_games_owned': 1817, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 492, 'last_played': 1373510692}
review: This is a roguelike for people who normally don't care for them. It's very fair and tactical, so rather than being screwed by the random number generator, deaths are usually well and truly your own damn fault. It also has longevity: the variety of skills and steam workshop integration ensure you'll always have a new way to play the game. Lastly, the writers have a very silly and enjoyable sense of humor, which helps give the game a quirky flavor quite unlike anything else out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981373573', 'num_games_owned': 1791, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5088, 'last_played': 1346742000}
review:
This game is like digital crack. It is a Rogue-like dungeon crawl, but with nice tile-based graphics, a 2D Diablo or Torchlight. The levels are procedurally generated, so every game with a new character is different.
 
Each new game you choose a difficulty level, you can turn off Permadeath (if your character dies, you have to start a new game), and you can select to generate more compact levels for faster play-throughs. Then you select your 7 skills. There are only basic descriptions (half the fun is figuring the game out), but there are several Wikis devoted to detailing the inner workings.
 
"Just one more room and then I'll save and quit!" Hah, 16 hours later the birds are chirping and I have to go to work in an hour. The humor & treasure are what keep me coming back. There are many nods & winks to other games peppered through out. And they added user mods available thru Workshop. The game just morped into digital meth. Skol!
 
"Lutefisk for the Lutefisk God!!!"

review: It's a relatively mindless click dungeon crawler, but incredibly addictive. Every run through is generated proceduraly, so each playthrough (and death) is unique. You should probably get it, but if you're waffling, it goes on sale regularly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020931284', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1963, 'last_played': 1527188806}
review:
Now, for those that grew up on rogue games, this one is much more timid. However, it has graphics :).  The sense of humor makes me chuckle, and the game play, other than crafting, is very tight.

I really like all the many combinations of unique builds you can make based around a list of characteristics rather than just one class.  It keeps the game interesting even after a few deaths. And you will die.  Permadeath is really the only way to play this, as it adds that extra tension that makes the thing so exciting in the first play.  

Not much for story, but as a turned based dungeon craller, you won't find much better than Dredmor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008564686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5448, 'last_played': 1567951613}
review:
Its fun, cheap, and suprisingly deep while also simple. If you want a simple hack'n'slash, or if you want to do some numbercrunching, this game should be able to keep you happy, although I think the sense of humour is the best thing about this game. Killer Vegan? Necronoeconomics? VIKING MAGIC?! The latest expansion pack adds a lot of fun stuff, and is free on top of that. I think the last thing I could say is that a friend of mine called his expansion pack ("you must name the expansion pack" is literal, btw) *ROCKET EDITION*. This has, amusingly, proven to be a fairly accurate description.

Play this game, it deserves it.

review: When I first saw this game, I wasn't so sure about it. Then someone bought it for me, and i sat down and started playing. And the hours ticked by. It's funny, it's entertaining, and it understands something that few games do: Losing is Fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962556029', 'num_games_owned': 853, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 4175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4175, 'last_played': 1402263755}
review: The combination of simplicity with complexity in this game meld into a strange carnal pleasure. It has your gear finding, monster killing, leveling, but all with a ridiculously outlandish coat of paint over it. Setting it to the highest difficulty with permadeath will not only create frustration and anger, but when you finally beat it a real sense of accomplishment. If only for five minutes before you start up another character.

review: Its a very challanging yet "fun" rougelike. Lots of levels and skills and even more quirky humor. I have yet to beat it but i have spent a ton of time playing it. 5 golden diggle beaks for this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015177528', 'num_games_owned': 919, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 15220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14599, 'last_played': 1611439092}
review:
So you wake up, battered and bruised in the back of some alley somewhere, the rain pattering down on what little clothing your muggers left with you with, "Gosh." You'd say, "I may have quite possibly lost the use of my left hand, but at least Dungeons of Dredmor can be played using just a mouse, as well as keyboard controls, setting it apart from quite a few roguelikes!"  Then you'd probably spit out some blood and teeth, continuing on, "Sure, it won't be a bed of roses, but it's a fun quirky game that doesn't take itself too seriously, and it's something you can save, quit or start and pick up at any point! I can't wait to play it when I get back from the hospital!"

Sure, its a great game. Challenging enough so that you can't beat your head against a wall repeatedly to win, but the way the randomized dungeon's layout works is a bit annoying, in my opinion. Branches from one route never connect to another.

And what kind of jerk doesn't use Maces?

author: {'steamid': '76561197965965295', 'num_games_owned': 531, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1444, 'last_played': 1453243762}
review:
If you've ever played and enjoyed the following games, you will probably enjoy this game: Doom 1 and 2 and expansions, any roguelike (angband, nethack, adom, whatever), any secret of monkey island. 
At its heart, DoD is a simple roguelike with is own unique and very flexible system and a solid random dungeon generator that is sure never to get too stale. Ontop of that, the game has fancy graphics and sounds and a clean and useful interface (for a rougelike), and is constantly self and other-satyrical of the genre and related. 
...I think its pretty neat anyways, and the '1000 taunts' mod for it on the workshop adds that extra bit of humor that completes the deal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972828729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3812, 'last_played': 1377654912}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970714568', 'num_games_owned': 1899, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1590357946}
review: Do you miss skulking around dungeons and old ruins in those old rogue RPGs? Look no further than Dungeons Of Dredmor! The game fills your nostalgic little head with every rogue-like cliche in the book. It also has a TON of video game pop-culture references everywhere. It's fast and perfect to play inbetween games. Though, like all  rogue-like dungeon crawlers, it is terribly hard so be prepared for the odd bullshit situation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996559457', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1437489709}
review:
Тупа шикарный индюк, это классический мать его данжен краулер (можете рогаликом назвать если вы из "этих"). 
Отлично зайдет тем кому интересно шариться по подземельям этих ваших скайримов и подвалам Каэд'Нуа. 
Да, выглядит немного отталкивающе на первый взгляд, но это пожилая иллюзия и на деле все удобно и весело. 
Тупа лойс, игра крутая.

Алсо там есть бог лютефиска которому можно поднести лютефиск и он даёт за это ништяки, есть и другие храмы но лютефисковый бог ван лав. 

Алсо она иногда крашится.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004698379', 'num_games_owned': 492, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1511533156}
review: If you like rogue like game,s you will love this. Has a deep sense of humor hiding a surprisingly complex game. However, please keep in mind that this game is very HARD. You will die. Constantly. Super fun though if you like the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993267600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2302, 'last_played': 1373578126}
review: I'm normally not one for Rogue-likes (pansy), but I found myself enamored with Dungeons of Dredmor. The humor might not appeal to everyone, but the underlying game mechanics are solid and the customization allows for many unique and interesting character builds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025438561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1612329491}
review:
What's this? A roguelike? In this day and age?
(plays for a bit)
And it's hilarious? THE WORLD MUST KNOW!!

Sorry about that. In any case, Dungeons of Dredmor, has a completely bonkers sense of humor that covers (read: makes enjoyable) a surprisingly deep roguelike with complex stat progression, crafting, and alchemy.

tl;dr Fun game, funny game, complex game.

NB: Even after many patches, the game has a reputation for the occasional crash (even going so far as to have an achievement for experiencing one), The game is still fun and the crashes almost never happen after all of the patches the developers have made. That being said, the game is definitely not perfect, but is enjoyably and funny enough to deserve your dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034614210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 1027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1027, 'last_played': 1388935611}
review:
다소 떨어지는 퀄리티의 그래픽이 부담되는 건 사실이지만
상당히 잘만든 로그라이크 게임

게임을 시작할 때 총 7개의 스킬을 선택할 수 있는데
거의 무수한에 가까운 조합이 가능해서
어떠한 스킬을 선택하고 육성하느냐에 따라
다양한 방법으로 던전에 도전할 수 있습니다.

로그라이크 좋아하시는 분들이라면
걱정마시고 도전하세요!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993732288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1249, 'last_played': 1430639108}
review: Dungeon crawler roguelike with charming aesthetics. The feeling you get when you barely clear a floor after opening a Monster Zoo can't be beat, since you know you overcame the odds. And it'll also prepare you for the rage when your lvl 60 Hardcore Inferno character, decked out with hundreds of dollars of gear, dies to a lagspike in Diablow 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999337717', 'num_games_owned': 548, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 2942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1447, 'last_played': 1527536394}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is something you get when you take an appropriately brutal Rouge-like game and mix it with not only the offbeat comedy of an RPG a la Earthbound but with geeky shout-outs strewn into a pile on the murky floor. It'll take you roughly 20 hours to finish the game since you'll need a LOT of experience in order to take on the final boss whom is mixed amongst his followers on the final floor of the dungeon (so you can either find him right away or be forced to search every room, in either case it doesn't end well). You'll need to grind to survive, especially on later floors. Thankfully there's an option for those who don't live on level grinding like myself so I can recommend this game to just about anyone who likes a good RPG. In other words, expect to die a lot but not enough to make the game unfun.

If I were to sum up Dungeons of Dredmor to an emotion, it would be that of finding a Monster Zoo in this game: complete surprise followed by fearing for your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025053130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1586065239}
review:
After finishing the first floor of the mysterious Dungeon of Dredmor, I was hooked.

Excellent underrated adventure game right here. Fun 'turn-based' Diablo feel with Workshop support and tens of hours of contents. With the Steam Summer Sale going on right now, you can get this gem for only $2- along with its expansion, Realm of the Diggle Gods, for only a dollar more :0 I haven't beaten it yet, but I can tell you the experience is timeless, with much more to add with mods.

Oh, and the game is completely unforgiving, and will insult you time and time again with witty remarks from the enemies and smart, well-written descriptions of everything in-game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968869240', 'num_games_owned': 3714, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1342767600}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038436722', 'num_games_owned': 1880, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 7093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7017, 'last_played': 1417225413}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor could be viewed as a casual, beginner's first roguelike. It has a great sense of humor and numerous references that will put a smile on your face. It's quite a long game, and it can get a little repetitive after a while, especially considering that most of its charm lies in jokes that can only really be experienced once. However, the game is cheap and certainly worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009553904', 'num_games_owned': 631, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2304, 'last_played': 1328169600}
review:
It's an ok game after its said and done.  If you're looking for decent rogue-like for its price, this is it.  If you seek something more hardcore, look elsewhere.

Edit:  To the dislikers, there's Nethack, Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup, and Tales of Maj'Eyal just to name a few examples of games better than this.  They're also free, have more content, ard are more challenging in general.  At best, this game is for those who don't want to learn how to play any of the aforementioned games.  This isn't a bad game, but IMO its lacking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017297532', 'num_games_owned': 1551, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 4667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2255, 'last_played': 1658329465}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000400848', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5282, 'last_played': 1653686351}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor, es un roguelike bastante "accesible" con un estilo y sentido del humor muy peculiar, que recuerda al Munchkin. Con habilidades como Emomancy, Necronomics, y un monton de bromas en las descripciones de objetos y skills, es un juego muy desenfadado donde te puedes echar unas risas.

No por ello deja de ser dificil, ya que en dificultad maxima y muerte permanente, se convierte en todo un reto incluso en el primer nivel.

Los desarrolladores siguen dando soporte al juego, con expansiones y alguna DLC gratuita, que añaden habilidades, mas niveles y en general, mas rejugabilidad.

Bastante recomendable si os gusta el genero o quereis empezar.

review: As of this writing, I'm 120 hours in. I have not only not beaten Dredmor, I haven't even seen the damn Lich. I'm still playing, and still having a lot of fun. It's hard, but it's a worthwhile hard. This game is by turns frustrating and incredibly rewarding, but I have fun, even when I'm raging at a lucky hit from a Diggle Commando.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999112883', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4096, 'last_played': 1652149337}
review:
Do you like randomly generated dungeons full of randomly generated loot?
Do you like the ability to pick your skills and make any combination of Fighter, Mage and/or Rogue?
Do you like humourous references and silliness mixed with permadeath making every game a mix of levity and tense combat?

Buy this already!
Best character so far: an enchanted kilt-wearing women dual-wielding staffs who was (RIP) a master Battle Geologist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025693569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 15962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1600568010}
review: Are you fond of Roguelikes? I always have been, and this one takes that delightful roguelike feel and puts it into a game with enjoyable graphics and animations. The world itself is quirky and crazy, with that difficulty curve that we of the roguelike world love so very much. With skills like 'Killer Vegan', 'Pastamancer', and 'Necronomics', the game begs you not to take it seriously... and then *destroys* you when you don't! I wouldn't have it any other way. An all-around A+ game. And the expansions just add more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997029967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1471, 'last_played': 1610262847}
review: This roguelike game is fantastic. The game is chock full of humor and has a wide variety of awesome skills. Crafting, lutefisk transmuting, and discovering new areas, items, and enemies are all very fun. It's easy enough for almost anyone to pick up, yet difficult enough for you to go through several characters in a few hours. I highly recommend it, especially for fans of dungeon crawlers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996337129', 'num_games_owned': 1063, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3167, 'last_played': 1626044880}
review:
In rogue-like games like the artfully crafted Dungeons Of Dredmor you are placed into a procedurally generated series of dungeons with randomized adversaries and monsters along with lootable items and environmental attributes (traps, levers, readable artifacts, etc). The biggest defining feature of a roguelike is that your character has only one life which means that when you die in the game all your progress, loot and experience vanish. This adds a sense of danger and excitement (as well as terror) as your environment tries to kill you.
Dungeons Of Dredmor does a good job of creating a quirky world that wants you dead. When I first started I got killed the first door I opened. As I learned how to protect myself better and properly use loot (and read the descriptions) I began to really enjoy myself. I still die but I like how the next game is never the same.

review:
You can purchase this game in complete form for like $2.40 as of today, for how long I've no clue. However, you should definetly take advantage of this. Hours of entertainment for such a low cost. It's fantastic! Don't let the graphics fool you, this game is exeptional. Very good beginner dungeon crawler/rogue game. The game itself with the dlc's is pretty deep, but the community content through the workshop adds even more.

Update 10 years later. Why is this still the best dungeon crawler out there? Shame the studio is gone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025596448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2311, 'last_played': 1561886488}
review:
I love this game.  Absolutely love it.   It's just a simple Roguelike, and clearly made by a very small, amateur team, but made with a lot of love.   The artwork feels like it was entirely done by "that guy in high school that was pretty good at drawing", and it's incredibly endearing.  The comedy is subtle yet very funny, the gameplay is an actual challenge (in that frustrating Roguelike way), and there's a genuine feeling of reward as you get more powerful and find better items.  

I think my only complaint is that the crafting system is way too elaborate and extensive to be so useless.   You can become a master crafter, brewer, tinkerer, etc. and fill your precious inventory space with plenty of materials to make weapons that aren't *quite* as good as the ones you could just buy in a shop if you sold all those materials.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993489980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2815, 'last_played': 1461026535}
review:
A whimsical rogue-like with loads of self-aware humor.  The game description mentions the skill path of Necronomiconomics, the economy of the undead - but fails to mention Flesh-smithing (Other men work with wood, stone, or metal.  We call them squeamish), Emo-mancy (with the Sigil of Whatever, which overwhelms your foes with apathy), and other tongue-in-cheek (or perhaps tongue-on-floor?) touches that make it well worth the five-dollar price point.

Although, I have to say, as an avid drinker - this game drives me to sobriety.  Drunk decisions tend to get me killed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027265213', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 7852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7738, 'last_played': 1621472950}
review: Okay, I give this two thumbs up. In fact, let me borrow a thumb, this deserves three. Addictive game. Simple interface, random dungeons, wide variety of character building skills, and an ongoing sense of goofy humor about itself that made me happily read all the little flavor texts in the game. At nearing 100+ hours of play, for me, at least, this game was more than worth the asking price.  A really really good game for when you're doing other things at the same time, since it's turn based. You move, enemies move. lather, rince, repeat. Slaughter the monsters. Get the loot. Slay  Lrd Dredmore himself.  Yeah, best of luck on that one, I've accomplished it ONCE so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044771141', 'num_games_owned': 934, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 6166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1754, 'last_played': 1702256773}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999823834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 1018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1518119973}
review:
It's slow-paced, brutally difficult, and not very pretty.

And I love it.

This is a throw-back to Castle of the Winds, NetHack, and any other rogue-like you can think of. This will not be a game that you're on the edge of your seat playing. It requires much more methodical planning and strategy. With the combinations of skills you can use, it is incredibly deep. Some combinations of skills make the game borderline impossible, but once you get your feet wet, you'll have a good idea of which skills work with which other skills. 

Don't forget that permadeath is the default, so if you don't want your save files to be deleted when you die, make sure to turn that feature off.

I love this style of game, so this gets a 9/10 from me. If you like this genre, you can easily sink 200 hours into this game and still not see everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053281403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1336719600}
review:
An excellent, simple to play, impossible to master, Rougelike game. Indie Game of the Year 2011? Yeah. I'll agree with that. 
I don't know how much time I've sunk into this man....

review: It's not a particularly difficult roguelike, at least not compared to a few of the more popular classics, but that doesn't make Dungeons of Dredmor any less fun. The game has a quirky and not-so-serious feeling to it, which both adds to the experience and can make you underestimate enemies rather easily... A few recent patches fixed the more overpowered skill trees, making this game more than worth its low price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036116771', 'num_games_owned': 1338, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1528830914}
review: Now, as much as I hate the fact that every indie game not called Minecraft coming out and getting praise is a rouge-like, this rouge-like I like(see what I did there). Dungeons of Dredmor is a rouge-like that parodizes the genre in a good fashion. Think Grotesque Tactics style humour on a 16-bit plane. The items are hilariously named, and the enemies are ridiculous. My only grip with the game is the crappy inventory system. It's very akward to use. I do enjoy the wicked amount of class customization anf crafting abilities. Grab it if you need a good grid based rouge-like.

review:
Przeurocze zwiedzanie komfortowych lochów, być jednocześnie roguelike i przystępną grą, to już samo w sobie jest niezłym wyczynem, ale Dungeons of Dredmor oferuje do tego tonę humoru, humoru który naprawdę bawi. A także lutefisk. No powiedzcie sami, ile gier oferuje lutefisk? Zdecydowanie warto w to zagrać. I niech bogini pobocznych questów będzie z Wami!

PS: Będziecie ginąć. Często. I na przeróżne możliwe sposoby. Ale ukończyć grę też się da. Podobno.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025006821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1429878745}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197972535127', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 4468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2209, 'last_played': 1678552488}
review:
While I enjoyed this game quite a lot when it was originally released, time has not been kind to it. If you have a 4K display, there is basically no way to play since everything will be absolutely minuscule and impossible to read. The company that made this game is long gone and there are no community updates forthcoming, and that includes numerous crashing and save file corruption bugs.

Save your money. Original review below for posterity

Nethack/10.

Losing is fun! And you'll be doing a lot of it. This is a pure roguelike, meaning you'll be crawling around dungeons, killing monsters, casting spells, and never being 100% sure if the next door you open will reveal a room full of hundreds of hungry monsters.

DoD really does feel like a more graphical Nethack, with its own charm and sense of humor.

You absolutely can't go wrong for the price, and it'll run on almost anything. The graphics and audio, while low res (the music sounds very midi), are catchy and memorable.

A great game, and highly recommended at almost any price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010169537', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1626650045}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042118407', 'num_games_owned': 6189, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 23170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6582, 'last_played': 1593412927}
review: A simple rougue-like. For those who don't know, that basically means randomized dungeons and loot, a somewhat punishing difficulty, and when you die you die. Those who are deep fans of the genre may tell you about all the options that are better on gameplay, and that Dredmor is coasting on the pretty visuals (well, pretty for a roguelike). They're right, but it doesn't matter. Dredmor is still a great fun game in its own right, and a good introduction to the genre if you find yourself enjoying the style of gameplay. 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197992032392', 'num_games_owned': 2823, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1184, 'last_played': 1375128271}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997515522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 28466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15623, 'last_played': 1584294615}
review:
This game will have you hooked for hours, and that's honestly no lie. The game doesn't take itself seriously, and it knows that, and plays off that the entire time which definitely makes for an enjoyable experience; the humor doesn't get old as it has so many jokes and references. 
The gameplay itself might not be what you expect from a Roguelike-- it's not as complicated. However that doesn't make a bad rogue-like by any means, as the core mechanics are certainly there: you're gonna die and die and DIE until the game feels bored with you... and then will kill you at the final boss anyways, because well hey, it's a Roguelike and that's just what they do. 
You'll be playing this game for hours, trying to figure out what is the best combination of skills for your liking, how the enemies work, and what items do what and how they even do that. It's jolly good fun, the expansion is entirely worth it... and this, on complete, is less than eight dollars. It's literally a steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043857791', 'num_games_owned': 615, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2254, 'last_played': 1616505572}
review:
Indie hra Dungeons of Dredmor spadá do netradiční škatulky Roguelike RPG žánru. Tato odrůda klasického hraní na heroje se vyznačuje randomizací, tahovým systémem, většinou ASCII grafikou (pokud nevíte co to je, tak vězte, že ☺ je hráč a D je zuřivej drak, na ty bacha!) a v neposlední řadě permanentní smrtí, kdy vám po špatně propočítaném tahu umře namakaná postava, smažou se savy a vaš úspěch za několik hodin hraní je minulostí stejně jako vaše pevné nervy. Ptáte se kdo by tohle vůbec chtěl hrát? No přece hardcore hráči, kteří se nebojí stále nových a těžších výzev a všichni ostatní, kteří se nebojí zkoušet něco nového.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Zbytek recenze na  http://gamenation.cz/?p=788

author: {'steamid': '76561197993027837', 'num_games_owned': 606, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 4400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4227, 'last_played': 1527189164}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997619576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 3345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3345, 'last_played': 1590097097}
review:
A game that is both a roguelike and hilarious. There are not many games like this. Packed with nerdy references galor and infinite replayability, it's hard to not adore this game. Tons of skills to choose from (even more if you get the $3 expansion), including skills such as Necronomiconomics, Psionics, Mathemagic, Golemancy, and Fungal Arts. There are tons of skills to choose from to make your ideal "hero". There are also a variety of difficulties/modes to play on, and since every floor of the dungeon is randomly generated, you'll always be surprised. This is one of the funnest indie games I have ever played, and I think it deserves more attention.

The expansion, Realm of the Diggle Gods, introduced the skills Big Game Hunter, Emomancy, Werediggle, Killer Vegan, Piracy, and Demonologist, along with100 new items, 5 new dungeon levels, and many other little things. It also doubles the amount of genders you can choose for your character.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969417125', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 2917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2917, 'last_played': 1373707482}
review: DoD is a really fun "roguelike" RPG. While the story has no depth, and the presentation of the graphics and sound are extremely basic, the character creation system is varied, and the turn based combat is very tactical. Each character selects 7 skills from a pool of 30+, which cover melee and ranged combat, offensive magic, summons, buffs, crafting, thieving, and more. Each skill can be improved at level up to unlock new spells or abilities. The strategy of combat revolves around knowing where to position yourself, and choosing the right time to use an ability, item or spell. The many different combinations of skills provides lots of varied playing styles. Replayability is further extended by each of the 10+ dungeon floors having a random layout for every new game. The ultimate challenge is to play through in permadeath mode, where your character and any saves are deleted upon death. The low purchase price is ridiculously good value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042128307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2604, 'last_played': 1477251682}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976237743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 1457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1490375944}
review: It's basicly a Rogue-like with actual graphics. It's great for when you're bored at work, but don't get too attachted to a character as they are prone to die / lose progress because the game didn't save when you asked it to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043660467', 'num_games_owned': 807, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1509426831}
review:
This game is a Rougelike Dungeon Crawler. You have multitudes of skills to choose from that can make each playthrough feel unigue. At first i thought i wouldn't like it, but once I got into the groove of things, I'm really starting to enjoy this game.

Even if you don't like the genre, you should at least check it out for its humour and shoutouts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018283079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3522, 'last_played': 1373768488}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor might as well be its own psychoactive drug. Once you pick it up, you'll soon find that the witty, reference-overdosed guide text, the complex stat system, and the swanky soundtrack all make it immensely difficult to put down. It lacks much of the finesse and depth of other definitive roguelikes like Nethack, but it still puts up quite a package for a five dollar game. Definitely give it a try, especially if you're an avid roguelike fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981329854', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 17807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6612, 'last_played': 1707541082}
review:
As roguelikes go, this one's definitely very approachable. It's got a great sense of humor, and a nice amount of depth to it that doesn't overwhelm you. When I'm in the mood for something that doesn't require twitch reflexes and allows me to plan things out at a casual pace, I load this up. 

There IS a slight learning curve to it though, so the first death or two (because yes, you will frequently die since this IS a roguelike) will leave you scratching your head... and while the tutorial will give you an idea on how the controls work it doesn't really give you any ideas on exactly HOW you should be playing.

If you're even vaguely curious about the roguelike RPG genre, give this one a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975831270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1329638400}
review: This game crashed IN THE TUTORIAL.  Looking online, there are a lot of issues with this game.  It seems as though the scripting system does not handle script problems well.  It's sad too since I like roguelikes.  I recommend that nobody spend money on this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010102758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 4560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3913, 'last_played': 1555847569}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002148461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 5470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4859, 'last_played': 1489907336}
review:
Well this is a roguelike, isn't it.

Everything is very well-animated, the humour is great and omnipresent, there are tons of items, skills, and stats, and the UI is not half-bad. I have two nitpicks: the crafting system might be overwhelmingly difficult, and for some reason hotkey presses don't always register every time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972261741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1335, 'last_played': 1660786709}
review: In dungeons and dragons you're a cool bro with a cool shirt. You walk around trying to tell people about how boss Jesus is, but they all get mad and you have to send them to hell. You tell the kids to get off your lawn, and then you go downstairs to do it again. You get all sorts of weapons; long names and lots of icons means they're good. CoD is over in 8 hours, this game lasts forever, so it's time to rethink your life. If you don't play this game, Yugi will banish you to the friend zone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042073255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3471, 'last_played': 1658033769}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970597310', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 48758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2786, 'last_played': 1679197039}
review:
Excellent 2d graphical translation of Nethack [& other Rogue-like games].
Great music, humor/puns/references, etc.
Like Nethack without inventory weight (space limit instead), food is needed to heal yourself instead of eat, and the need to identify items is removed...
more/different initial character build/customization options (quite well done),
but otherwise very similar to Nethack-like games (it is HARD).
Great replayability!

Summary:
One of the best cost:value ratios of any game I've ever played.
Buy it now if you like turn-based, tile-based dungeon crawlers
(build character, explore, loot, kill, chuckle, loot, level up, explore, loot, quest, kill, loot, level up, chuckle etc).

author: {'steamid': '76561197960270050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1012, 'last_played': 1495333513}
review:

It's fun and cheap, you can't really go wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025616678', 'num_games_owned': 1573, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2673, 'last_played': 1468159645}
review:
Had first thought this as a cheapo indie game that gotten rave reviews (including one from a good gamer friend of mine) mainly because it is some typical pretty graphical RPG game or something like that.

Boy, I was so fantastically wrong. Had spent 2 days nonstop gaming from the moment I put in some effort to pick up the game. My 2012 CNY? Whisking through as fast as my poor hero(es) death rate. Definitely some thanks to those Dingles (penguins that look like Prinnies from the Disgaea series) for my early deaths. Looked down on them far too often but no worries, plenty more heroes from where it came from!

Anyway, long story short. It is cheap. It is fun. It is an old-stylo-roguelike-RPG that totally deserves all the reviews and time spent. Adding perma-death and random maps as well? Good grace, save me the nonsense and play the damned game already! =D

author: {'steamid': '76561198024953074', 'num_games_owned': 8928, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 36841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15107, 'last_played': 1640192295}
review: Originally given to me as a gift, I didn't expect anything mindblowing this game as I had seen what it was like. However, the game did hook me and I ended up playing far longer than I ever expected to. Great roguelike for people who either want a challenge or just like to loot things. The choice to have a permadeath character is a nice touch, perhaps this will attract you if you don't like losing all your progress if you happen to die.

review:

It is probably as user friendly as a roguelike game can get. You will enjoy this game if you like oldschool RPGs, wacky sense of humor and crossing your fingers in hopes of getting a nice sword out of a smashed open chest.

Очень няшный рогалик с кучей лута, скиллов, циферок, буковок и безумства. Великолепная поглощалка времени и неплохая временная замена той большой игре которая выйдет где-нибудь через сколько-нибудь времени.

review: Don't own Dredmor? Smite yourself with one of the many varieties of weapons you'll never get to use otherwise. You'd probably die at the hands of a Diggle anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994967722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1609653462}
review:
This game brings the grand total up to like, six games that I'm recommending in part because of its great soundtrack.

Other reasons I'm recommending it, is that it does the skinner box routine pretty well, lots of different ways to build your character, and make them exactly the way you want.

If there was one problem I have with this game, it's that its humour sometimes obscures exactly what it's trying to say. For instance, one of the skills (think of them as kinda career paths) is arithmatician... What exactly does that mean? What kind of abilities does one get from that? It's funny to think of someone going into a dangerous dungeon, and doing math to (assumedly) kill monsters, but how exactly?

But still, the game is very fun, and has sucked me in for quite a few hours, worth the buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977428523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 4140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1566, 'last_played': 1452520134}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049619936', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 14155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13627, 'last_played': 1664375528}
review:
Just the right amount of randomness.

This is my first rogue-like game. If you don't think you can take the frustration of defeat at the hands of Lord Dredmor and have to start all over again from the first floor, you can always disable the permadeath feature and play this like a casual.

Pros:
- Sick sense of humor, congratulating you on your death and many more funny stuff that you'll encounter in the dungeon.
- Vast amount of skill selection with countless combination plus steamworkshop = great replayability
- Diggles

Cons:
- My dungeoneering skill does not help me in playing this game.

The Dredmor School of Dungeoneering was my crash course in Dungeoneering, and I endured long and painful hours of trial at the hands of Lord Dredmor's enforcers and the loathsome paladins of the Lutefisk God, not to mention the Voluntary Quality Assurance Programme. But you know what? I could never have become a Master Dungeoneer or Adventurer or even Hero without this struggle. Dungeoneering on Going Rogue with Permadeath CHANGES a man. Fighting Brax and cleansing floor after floor of legions of Dread Collectors was mere practise for my eternal struggle with the Shopkeeper. The Dungeons of Dredmor were my undergraduate programme, just as Spelunking under Master Israel Blargh was my postgraduate programme. I cannot overstate the cultural impact that these have had even upon my writing. Few works of any kind operate on my cerebral wavelength, but this is one of them. A unique curriculum for unique students.

Actually, it isn't that hard if you're cunning and attentive, for where is the rogueliting without any roguery?

author: {'steamid': '76561197960432563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1611720099}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012150876', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1407140137}
review:
Cada vez que você jogar será diferente. Você se preocupará com seu personagem, mesmo ele sendo um sprite 2D e que não fala. As possibilidades de criação de personagens são imensas, e vão desde mago-vampiro-alquimista até espadachim-ferreiro-cogumelista. Milhões de armas, escudos, armaduras, comidas, bebidas alcoólicas e metais. E plástico.

Werediggles gonna weredig.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995651679', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5180, 'last_played': 1700271742}
review: Oh, so you think your a bad ass??? Think you know how to pwn video games in your sleep??? THINK AGAIN! This game originaly came with a humble bundle I purchased and I will never regret it. This game is HARD! The last time i was challenged like this was Ninja Gaiden BLACK... and even then only the boss battles were brutal. This game puts it to shame. With satire humor and refrences to other works of art/gaming, it will make you laugh, cry, and possibaly throw your keyboard into the monitor. But for some reason I can't stop playing it. Turn-Based RPG with some serious cahones!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967304461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1575828408}
review:
In one word, ridiculous. Now to complete the sentence, ridiculous...ly awesome. This game is not only fun but its challenging, and NEVER takes it's self too seriously, or seriously at all. The game is funny and makes a point of it being one big joke, but besides all that it is a solid low commitment RPG. Jump in and play for 5min, it saves your progress exactly where you are.
Side note:
Only way to play is perma-death!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026782701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1445216908}
review:
It's an amusing mouse driven Rogue-like. Its one of the better Roguelikes out there, although not as good as ZAngband(the version of ZAngband *before* they started trying to make a random overworld and screwed everything up, then AFAIK stopped working on the project.), although the point and click interface is much nicer than trying to remember stuff like Q is your quest list but q quaffs(Quaff? Who the %&@# says quaff?) a potion. The musics kinda annoying but it can be turned off. Its def worth the 5$.

Also: Horadric Lutefisk Cube! How can you go wrong with that?

author: {'steamid': '76561197986636237', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1575, 'last_played': 1339052400}
review:
Actually quite good. Each level has a different flavor to them in art and munsties. Combat is pretty satisfying. Could use some more skills, maybe races, and otherwise moar mods and DLC. If it's ever on sale, or you don't mind paying 5 dollars, go for it.

Great, humorous RPG and rogue game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972271187', 'num_games_owned': 890, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 12433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7333, 'last_played': 1674935666}
review:
Love playing this game. Its old school dungeon crawling-rpg goodness. Crafting,lots of skills to choose for your own custom player class,items,weapons,enemies to keep you busy as you venture further and further down the depths of the dungeons.Lots of different status effect stuff to enjoy and hate.The most confusing part when you first play will be what skills to pick for your very first character,but its also part of the fun.

Game got a lot of  love from both the Dev's and the players. If  you want something that can soak up over 100 hours of ur gameplay time (depend on how much you like playing with different class builds) I say get this. Has 2 pay for dlc that are actually more like full on expansion packs, and 1 community dlc that is free for everyone.Lots and I mean lots of mods,I play vanilla for the most part but I put in a few craft mods and a skill mod here and there.The game has different difficulty modes for different flavors of players from casual players to hardcore types.

For the ol school player out there I HIGHLY Recommend this game.Get the complete version and you will not go wrong goes on sale for a wooping $1.75 for a single and is worth the purchase.Or get a 4pack and share with yor friends.

This game falls in my archieve of games to play before you die. Yes I love it that much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041224930', 'num_games_owned': 1677, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1577186256}
review:
I really didn't know what to expect from Dungeons of Dredmor, but what I found certainly didn't diappoint. There are a lot of 'crafting' type indie RPG's out there, most notably, Minecraft and Terraria but also lesser knowns such as the under development Lords of Uberdark and Project Zomboid. The result from these systems is a sometimes nearly unfathomable abundance of items to create and use within the world.

What sets Dungeons of Dredmor apart is it's rogue-like insistence, calling you a little tiny baby manz for not having the 'permadeath' feature on. Like Terraria, this game gives you the chance to set how masochistic you want to be. The geeky wit finishes the game off, with many absurdities lending a WTF moment to every session you play. Bring on this new retro generation of games, let us forget about Modern Warfares and Battlefields.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014735735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1329, 'last_played': 1343890800}

review:
Bit of an odd 'un this - is a roguelike, but with a much more approachable front-end, and less punishing mechanics than most.  

The complexity is all there, much of it hidden behind humorous sounding stuff, but it can be largely ignored if you don't want to bother with it...

Is actually genuinely funny at times, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023558710', 'num_games_owned': 1209, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1935, 'last_played': 1375994252}
review:
Восхитительная бесконечная roguelike со стильной ретро-графикой и триллиардами отсылок к разнообразнейшей игроклассике, современной и не очень. Шизофреничный набор способностей и элементов экипировки вызывает только истерический хохот, а то что при всём при этом она ещё и является довольно строгой классической данженоползалкой лишь усиливает общий кайф.

Настоятельно рекомендуется всем, кому хочется рогалик с винтажным геймплеем, но не со схематичной графикой =)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997237088', 'num_games_owned': 1543, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1895, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
Some people consider this game to be like a gateway drug to the roguelike genre.
I enjoy it because of the ever-present humour, always having time to think about my next move, and always knowing what killed me, often followed by a good laugh or facepalm. Or both.
Permadeath is the best way to play, but whether you get random skills or not is more of a personal choice depending on how challenging you want it to be and how serious you want to be about trying to get to the end.

All in all, this is a very fun game that I have enjoyed spending a lot of time on.

review: Wow! Much better than I expected. If you like ARPGs, you will love this. Do not be fooled by looks of this game; Gameplay is greater than graphics. It is very similiar to the "The Binding of Issac" because of it's randomly generated rooms and item drops. It is a very hard game and I doubt I will be completing it anytime soon. Even the tutorial says beating it is a task you may never accomplish. This is a game that is very challengeing and very fun for a very small price.

review:
Back when this game was just starting to be developed, I was skeptic that "the masses" would like to play a roguelike, even if it was made as accessible as possible.

I'm glad I was wrong. This is a great introduction to the roguelike genre and it deserves the popularity it's got.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999729274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1324454400}
review: A fantastic take on the "rogue-like" genre.  Tons of pop-culture references, fun gameplay, and mountains of loot.  Don't forget your grilled cheese!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005313952', 'num_games_owned': 736, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2441, 'last_played': 1459764045}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a very complex and addicitive "roguelike" game that gives you a huge amount of options in terms of skills and items to choose from. You can battle your way as a fire-throwing wand-bearing mathemagical communist or as a fully-armored baseball-throwing vegetarian werediggle. Add to that about 30 character stats that can be enhanced both by skills and items and you have a ridiculously complex system that is as unbalanced as it is fun to play.

Just have in mind that this game can be sometimes very unforgiving. One wrong move and you could step into in your own wall of fire or a hidden trap and be killed instantly. Only invest in this game if you think that losing is half the fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044715229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 13123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10820, 'last_played': 1589320163}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024945377', 'num_games_owned': 1031, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 15303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11968, 'last_played': 1703475179}
review:
I watched the trailer and I was like, "Meh." I played the tutorial and I was like, "Meh." Then I tried actually playing through some games, and it turns out this game is surprisingly addictive.

In particular, the skill trees are actually a lot of fun. You pick a set of skills when you start out, and you get to gradually advance them, which is very satisfying. And depending on the skills you choose, the game plays significantly differently, which is some serious replay value. Seriously. So much replay value. It's insane.

There's a lot of visceral pleasure in exploring the dungeons, uncovering new rooms, beating the monsters senseless, and stealing all the treasure. It's much more fun than I thought it would be.

review: This game is like an indie, genre-savvy, snarky, pixley love-child of Diablo II and Skyrim, though more the former than the latter. From randomly generated dungeons, monsters, and loot tables, to a built-in process for modding, this game makes it pretty clear that you're never going to crawl the same dungeon twice. I've wasted hours of my life to this and have no regrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024976479', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 10178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10162, 'last_played': 1502269661}
review:
In Memoriam of Gaslamp Games

Dungeons of Dredmor is the first of two games Gaslamp Games made before they went under- and it's really quite a sad story. I'll spare the details, but essentially they went on to make a Dwarf Fortress-like, and then disappeared off the face of the planet with no further contact. It's a shame, because they come from where I was born and raised and I think dredmor is a fantastic (if not a bit flawed) roguelike.

What makes Dredmor so special in my opinion, is that it's casual enough to not be soulcrushing but allows you to get in deep if you want. There are many stats to consider and things to juggle, many skill tree combinations and factors to... factor into each encounter, but honestly if you really want you can just whack stuff mercilessly and not think much at any point while continuing on your crusade. It's a "You can't really go wrong" type of game, where even if you have the most terrible build you'll at least be able to survive to the midfloors if you know what you're doing. This plus the fact that there are a lot of items and drops that allow you to escape or mass murder things on a moments notice removes a lot of the stress that roguelikes usually carry with them.

Of course, you can still get instakilled by stepping on a trap. Or getting hit by a crit (spells can crit too!). Actually, I think the main problem with Dredmor is the lack of player information. Skills grant you passives and other things but the game doesn't tell you what half of them are, some items do mysterious things where the side-effects aren't clearly displayed, lots of ideas are obtuse and confusing and need a look-up on a wiki to be clarified, honestly it's all a mess and not really in the positive way. Cryptic things are fine when needing to know what they do isn't essential to your survival. Also, some skills or items are woefully unbalanced one way or the other, and it kind of punishes you for screwing around later on in the game as from floor 6 onwards it gets pretty strict with strategy. I think there are a few mods that rebalance things available including some that fix tooltips, but a lot of them are on the now defunct forums, so you might have to go searching around for it.

The humour is really funny and often not laid on too hard, it's something that comes of more endearing than anything. I can see people hating the humour just because they think roguelikes shouldn't have humour or something, that is fine and it's just personal preference. Just know that it's got quite a lot through and through, it's very much a comedy game in the same silly vein as something like Monty Python (maybe a lot less humourous, but a similar style). I like the art style and music as well. It comes off as lovingly made, if not a little cheesy.


Bottom line, I recommend Dredmor and all it's expansions wholeheartedly. They're so cheap (especially on sale) that you can't really go wrong. It's more casual and chaotic than other roguelikes, but in my opinion that's what set it apart. I feel like some of the issues with accessibility and bad balancing could have been fixed by the company surviving and patching it or releasing a sequel, but unfortunately they promptly died about a year ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038639022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1488, 'last_played': 1404738885}
review: Just doing this for Steam chieves, but i thought what the hey, might as well get into it just a little. When it comes to sheer joy when you compare it to price, this title comes up on top most times for me. The replayability of this game is astounding and the numerous deaths that you will encounter will not leave you frustrated, even though you must start again from the beginning (that is, if you play it on permadeath, but who doesn't?). The randomly generated dungeons and vast amount of perks and skills to choose leave you wanting to play over and over again and enjoying every minute of it. The humour and variety of enemies, rooms, items and ways to approach an encounter leave this game in my top 5 for 2011, and, with the developers caring about their game, adding new content to it all the time (usually free - there is one priced dlc) I keep coming back to play it, and dying, again and again. A definite yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051311104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1376806999}
review:
This is... interesting... to say the least, the learning curve, to me, seems incredibly steep. You know, you have to click, sometimes you have to even click twice! 
This is very fun, but also, I'm finding it pretty difficult. But some of the things that pop up in the combat feed are just hilarious. ElectroBlobby collapsed into a fetid puddle of love. Stuff like that. It's well worth getting this if you enjoy dungeon trawling for hours. There is a save button so you can leave and come back later,  which is good, because I see this taking maybe 10 or more hours to finish...

author: {'steamid': '76561198025466460', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4964, 'last_played': 1681644721}
review:
This one is an awesome game for the dungeon crawler fans out there. It's a large turn-based dungeon crawler-ish game, a so-called roguelike, with a LOT of stuff to do in it. Well over 30 unique skill trees into which you can invest, tons of unique items, a whole bunch of magic spells and many other things make this a great game for the gamer who likes to have lots of things to tweak and mess around with. 

Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016788984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1735, 'last_played': 1467386736}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor was certainly a nice surprise for me. I was expecting an "easy" Rougelike with a pretty interface, and while this is true to some extent, this game has got some charm of its own. The difficulty is lowish if you're used to NetHack, Angband and the like, but if you aren't, it can be a devilishly hard game, so expect to die- often. And masochistically ask for more. There are lots of gags and pop culture references thrown around in the game, just check the names of the achievements and the lines creatures utter before attempting to kill you. The game is rough around the edges, and there are a few control issues here and there, but for the most part, nothing that would seriously affect your gameplay. All in all, I recommend it.

review: Dredmor was very fun to play. I won't lie, at times it can be very unforgiving, but that is all part of the fun. Mix up your skills and go as far as you can in a random dungeon. With addition of the expansions (one of which is free!) and mods, you can extend your replay by a few hours.

review:
One of the best roguelike games I've played. Sure, its not as hard as traitional roguelikes, but its still relatively hard. 

For those who don't know what a roguelike is, check this game out. This is a good game to introduce you to roguelike (the other game is 100 rogues for the iOS). Just don't treat it as an RPG - treat it as a survival game.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004393100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 24637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14917, 'last_played': 1650415924}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027428638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 29468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29356, 'last_played': 1447985703}
review:
On a personal level, Dredmor hit a sweet spot of nostalgia, complexity, and charm that really resonated with me. The game's lighthearted nature helps keep it casual, but the depth of options and decisions to be made make it challenging and rewarding. It's a classic-style roguelike: tile+turn based, combat heavy, randomly generated dungeons, and a good variety of weapons, armor, and skills to equip yourself with.

From the art-style to the item descriptions, to the tool tips for environmental curiosities, I was consistently (and pleasantly) surprised by the attention to detail. Even the modding community does an excellent job of keeping with the spirit of the game's charm, and many of the mods out there are so seamlessly integrated artistically that it feels like the game could have shipped with them. 

When I picked this title up on a steam sale years ago, I was not expecting to get so much value for such a small investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976139683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8850, 'last_played': 1699749021}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is one of my favorite games.  It is just so much fun to play, so many small little thing have been refined to just make it a really fun and good game. It has a lot of skills you can choose from, the crafting is pretty large and it really gives you a lot of options on how to play it. If you think the game is a bit of a grind you can turn on "no time to grind." It speeds up the game quite a bit.  If you think it is too hard you can try easy. If you think the game isn't forgiving enough you can turn off permadeath. The humor is great, and the interface is really well done, making the game feel very fun to play. nowadays I usually play on no time to grind, 15 floors normal difficulty with random skills, there are still skills I haven't played a full game with, plus there is a lot of community stuff as well so it almost feels like it is endless fun. 

Though if you are one of those people looking for a cheap thrill through graphics, or If you must have completely laid out for you, this game might not be your cup of tea.  You have to put a fair amount of effort into it to beat it on permadeath.

review: I grabbed this during the sale. I was doubtful at first, even after watching a preview, but bought it anyway (partly due to the gift achievement, partly due to the price). I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. I've never really been one for roguelikes, but I've really enjoyed this game. I understand it's pretty entry-level for this genre, but it's still difficult nonetheless, and has some nice humor thrown in as well. I still haven't beaten it, and I actually had one run where I died in the very first room, but that's all part of the fun. Give it a look if you're interested in roguelikes or rpgs in general and don't mind losing every now and then.

review: A surprisingly entertaining dungeon crawler (I guess they're called "Roguelikes" these days?), that has an equally surprising sense of humor.  A must-have for any RPG fan who likes a good joke.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970834381', 'num_games_owned': 766, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1435487298}
review:
Keine Sorge! Es ist völlig normal in dem Spiel das zeitliche zu segnen, sei es durch den Konsum von Säure aus einem Schreinbrunnen und oder einer der hochgradig giftigen Alchemiezutat – das regelmäßige Ableben durch Monster-Zoos und andere massive Gegneransammlungen nicht einmal mitgerechnet.

Dennoch entfaltet "Dungeons of Dredmore" seinen Reiz bereits nach wenigen Spielminuten. Ich bin mir sicher Fans der traditionellen "Dungeons Crawler" Spass an "Dungeons of Dredmore" haben werden – die kann auch 2D Grafik nicht abschrecken – aber auch allen Anderen die Spass an schrägen Humor und ungewöhnlichen Titeln haben, kann ich diesen Spiel wärmstens empfehlen.

review: When I first saw the trailer video for this game, I thought it looked horrible. But, hey, it's a rogue-like, and they don't need to be sexy. After trying it once I was hooked; each new game is unique and you just have to try once more to see if you can get a little further down. It's going to take me a while to finish with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023933693', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 13386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7032, 'last_played': 1629164857}
review:
First time I played Dungeons of Dredmor the usually intruding Achievements started popping up at an alarming rate. But instead of being annoying they were the first hint on what makes DoD really amusing: a grim sense of humor. It started with Heroic Failure: “Die during the tutorial.”; right after that Normandy cracked me up: “Die on Floor 1; play a new character with the same skills... and die on Floor 1.”.

Such mood permeates the entire game, from the anti-hero ‘Eye-browed one’ to the monsters—and their names, lines, sprite animations—to the absurd items you can find/equip/craft.

Truth to be told managing those very items is the main hindrance to hold the game back: they pile up high above the limits of your inventory—or your crafting abilities, or some practical around-the-corner selling—to the point an inelegant fix had to be thrown in as the easy-to-stumble-upon Wizard Keys, which provides the player a portal to a… storeroom.

Still, some skills can take advantage of that baggage overweight in a more interesting fashion, be them a late bandage or not. In DoD skills are the practical tip of the developers’ poisonous tongue, making form overflow into content. Experimenting with different skills combinations (and their respective trees) lends the game a much meatier replay value and helps a lot on letting the player work around failure and the genre’s typical lack of clear intel.

The original build had 10 floors available for exploring—which could be even smaller/quicker with the handy tool called No Time To Grind, used for cramping the same amount of XP into smaller maps—but I was only able to beat it after the hundredth hour of play. Anyways that’s not necessarily a testimony of some brutal difficulty level or over-punishing permadeath—even if some stupid demises were ensued in that front; it’s more like an awkward environment being a catalyst to a more playful approach where failing can be as fulfilling as winning.

review: If you like old shit , then this is stupid new shit with old shit mechanics in it,I mean really this games story is ridiculous as hell, and the naming system is ridiculous as hell and the cartoon style is ridiculous as hell, but the rogue system is still amazing and addicting i could play any rogue-like game if the graphics where 1 bit letters and the story was about 1 bit characters, just like in the 80s, the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045373464', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 9283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6326, 'last_played': 1682033849}
review: Dungeons of Dredmor is an amazing fallback to the golden era of Dungeon explorers. If you liked Diablo or Diablo 2 you'll love this game. The story is simple, but the character customization is amazing. The stat system might be a little confusing at first, but all of it is explained relatively well. The game has a huge amount of comedy on itself too. Great roguelike!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968596506', 'num_games_owned': 3581, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3354, 'last_played': 1515020920}
review:
I have been playing this during the Holidays on my crappy laptop, which gave it even more retro Pixel Feeling. I must say I didn't expect much but what I got left me hilarious: Dredmor is sort of a Parody yes but it still is consistent in the sense that it feels like all that's in there comes from the same pool. All the endless references (saw some really cool ones like Neuromancer) feel like a Geek-culture shake... and it's sweet. 

The Game by itself has a cozy retro feeling and I feel warmly reminded of my early dungeonning with Ultima, Might and Magic etc. Possibilities seem really endless and that's just so much more as u would get from most of the modern RPGs. Permadeth is an excellent feature and gives it all more sense and immersion (Run Forest Run!). Still w/o so much of a story it is and will be more of the casual choice for RPG amateurs.
My end note: needs no beast, great fun, lots of Details, big replay value
would be 8/10 i guess

author: {'steamid': '76561198044116446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7592, 'last_played': 1420619422}
review:
With its cheesy humour and monsters, you'll enjoy this game even if you dont play rpg games very much.
Skills are the most interesting part of this game for me. You can't find emomancy, viking wizardry, vegan, mathemagic and these kinda funny also creative skills in any another game.
Luck and experience is needed. You can survive for a long time with random skills. You can die at first level with most wise skill choices. You should try and try again, but don't be afraid even losing is fun in this game. It has huge replayability value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965585057', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 14897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4797, 'last_played': 1616528452}
review:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a cute parody Nethack while being a fairly faithful recreation of it's core gameplay loop. It's true that Dredmor is missing a few Nethack staples such as Bones Files, randomized potions and scrolls, the in depth world simulation, and a few other minor mechanics. Dredmor makes up for some of these missing pieces with by adding expansive skill and crafting systems. These are robust enough that they will often be fairly overwhelming at first. But, if you can get past the complexity and difficulty wall of DoD's opening hours, you'll get a lot of value out of the humor and opportunities for mastery within.

Not for the faint of heart, Dredmor is as roguelike as the roguest of them. Gorgonzola out of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996551261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1619602369}
